379 <div class="dialog-off-canvas-main-canvas" data-off-canvas-main-canvas>

If you have questions or need additional information, we invite you to contact NCI's LiveHelp instant messaging service at https://livehelp.cancer.gov, or call the NCI's Contact Center 1-800-4-CANCER (1-800-422-6237) (toll-free from the United States).">

818<article>

819

820 <div class="resize-content">

821

822 <h1>

823Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

824

825 <div id="cgvBody">

826

827 <div class="summary-sections">

828

829 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

830

831 <h6>

832On This Page</h6>

833

834 <ul>

835

836 <li>

838General Information About Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)</a>

839</li>

840

841 <li>

842<a href="#_359">

843Cellular and Molecular Classification of NSCLC</a>

844</li>

845

846 <li>

847<a href="#_470">

848Stage Information for NSCLC</a>

849</li>

850

852<a href="#_514">

854</li>

855

856 <li>

859</li>

864</li>

869</li>

889</li>

907

908</nav>

909

910

911 <div class="accordion">

912

913

914

915 <section id="_4">

916

917 <h2>

918General Information About Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)</h2>

919

920 <div id="_section_4" class="pdq-sections">

921<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

922<h6>

923In This Section</h6>

924<ul>

925<li>

926<a href="#_12_toc">

927Incidence and Mortality</a>

928</li>

929<li>

930<a href="#_14_toc">

931Anatomy</a>

932</li>

933<li>

934<a href="#_48565_toc">

935Pathogenesis</a>

936</li>

937<li>

938<a href="#_37_toc">

939Risk Factors</a>

940</li>

941<li>

942<a href="#_44_toc">

943Screening</a>

944</li>

945<li>

946<a href="#_48567_toc">

947Clinical Presentation</a>

948</li>

949<li>

950<a href="#_47_toc">

951Diagnosis</a>

952</li>

953<li>

954<a href="#_48499_toc">

955Prognostic Factors</a>

956</li>

957</ul>

958</nav>

959<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

960<a href="/types/lung/patient/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq">

961Go to Patient Version</a>

962</div>

963<p id="_484192" tabindex="-1">

964NSCLC is any type of epithelial lung cancer other than small cell lung cancer (SCLC). The most common types of NSCLC are squamous cell carcinoma, large cell carcinoma, and adenocarcinoma, but there are several other types that occur less frequently, and all types can occur in unusual histological variants. Although NSCLCs are associated with cigarette smoke, adenocarcinomas may be found in patients who never smoked. </p>

965<p id="_485740" tabindex="-1">

966As a class, NSCLC is usually less sensitive to chemotherapy and radiation therapy than SCLC. Patients with resectable disease may be cured by surgery or surgery followed by chemotherapy. Local control can be achieved with radiation therapy in many patients with unresectable disease, but cure is seen in relatively few patients. Patients with locally advanced unresectable disease may achieve long-term survival with radiation therapy combined with chemotherapy. Patients with advanced metastatic disease may achieve improved survival and palliation of symptoms with chemotherapy, targeted agents, and other supportive measures.</p>

967<section id="_12">

968<h3 id="_12_toc">

969Incidence and Mortality</h3>

970<p id="_27" tabindex="-1">

971Estimated new cases and deaths from lung cancer (NSCLC and SCLC combined) in the United States in 2023:[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9721</a>

973]</p>

974<div class="pdq-content-list">

975<ul id="_28">

976<li>

977New cases: 238,340.</li>

978<li>

979Deaths: 127,070.</li>

980</ul>

981</div>

982<p id="_29" tabindex="-1">

983Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the United States. The 5-year relative survival rate from 2012 to 2018 for patients with lung cancer was 23%. The 5-year relative survival rate varies markedly for patients diagnosed at local stage (61%), regional stage (34%), or distant stage (7%).[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9841</a>

985]</p>

986</section>

987<section id="_14">

988<h3 id="_14_toc">

989Anatomy</h3>

990<p id="_484193" tabindex="-1">

991NSCLC arises from the epithelial cells of the lung of the central bronchi to terminal alveoli. The histological type of NSCLC correlates with site of origin, reflecting the variation in respiratory tract epithelium of the bronchi to alveoli. Squamous cell carcinoma usually starts near a central bronchus. Adenocarcinoma and bronchioloalveolar carcinoma usually originate in peripheral lung tissue.</p>

992<figure id="figure_48502" class="image-center-medium">

993<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/466533.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

994Enlarge</a>

995<img id="_48502" alt="Respiratory system anatomy; drawing shows the right lung with the upper, middle, and lower lobes, the left lung with the upper and lower lobes, and the trachea, bronchi, lymph nodes, and diaphragm. An inset shows the bronchioles, alveoli, artery, and vein." title="Respiratory system anatomy; drawing shows the right lung with the upper, middle, and lower lobes, the left lung with the upper and lower lobes, and the trachea, bronchi, lymph nodes, and diaphragm. An inset shows the bronchioles, alveoli, artery, and vein." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/466533-750.jpg">

996<figcaption class="caption-container">

997Anatomy of the respiratory system.</figcaption>

998</figure>

999</section>

1000<section id="_48565">

1001<h3 id="_48565_toc">

1002Pathogenesis</h3>

1003<p id="_48566" tabindex="-1">

1004Smoking-related lung carcinogenesis is a multistep process. Squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma have defined premalignant precursor lesions. Before becoming invasive, lung epithelium may undergo morphological changes that include the following:</p>

1005<div class="pdq-content-list">

1006<ul id="_23">

1007<li>

1008Hyperplasia.</li>

1009<li>

1010Metaplasia.</li>

1011<li>

1012Dysplasia.</li>

1013<li>

1014Carcinoma <em>

1015in situ</em>

1016.</li>

1017</ul>

1018</div>

1019<p id="_24" tabindex="-1">

1020Dysplasia and carcinoma <em>

1021in situ</em>

1022 are considered the principal premalignant lesions because they are more likely to progress to invasive cancer and less likely to spontaneously regress.</p>

1023</section>

1024<section id="_37">

1025<h3 id="_37_toc">

1026Risk Factors</h3>

1027<section id="_sm_CDR0000752176_1">

1028<p id="_sm_CDR0000752176_4" tabindex="-1">

1029Increasing age is the most important risk factor for most cancers. Other risk factors for lung cancer include the following:</p>

1030<div class="pdq-content-list">

1031<ul id="_sm_CDR0000752176_2">

1032<li>

1033History of or current tobacco use: cigarettes, pipes, and cigars.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

10342</a>

1035]</li>

1036<li>

1037Exposure to cancer-causing substances in secondhand smoke.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

10383</a>

1039,<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

10404</a>

1041]</li>

1042<li>

1043Occupational exposure to asbestos, arsenic, chromium, beryllium, nickel, and other agents.[<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

10445</a>

1045]</li>

1046<li>

1047Radiation exposure from any of the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1048<ul id="_sm_CDR0000752176_5" class="list-dash">

1049<li>

1050Radiation therapy to the breast or chest.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

10516</a>

1052]</li>

1053<li>

1054Radon exposure in the home or workplace.[<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

10557</a>

1056]</li>

1057<li>

1058Medical imaging tests, such as computed tomography (CT) scans.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

10598</a>

1060]</li>

1061<li>

1062Atomic bomb radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

10639</a>

1064]</li>

1065</ul>

1066</div>

1067</li>

1068<li>

1069Living in an area with air pollution.[<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

107010</a>

1071-<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

107212</a>

1073]</li>

1074<li>

1075Family history of lung cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

107613</a>

1077]</li>

1078<li>

1079Human immunodeficiency virus infection.[<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

108014</a>

1081]</li>

1082<li>

1083Beta carotene supplements in heavy smokers.[<a href="#cit/section_1.15">

108415</a>

1085,<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

108616</a>

1087]</li>

1088</ul>

1089</div>

1090</section>

1091<p id="_40" tabindex="-1">

1092The single most important risk factor for the development of lung cancer is smoking. For smokers, the risk of lung cancer is on average tenfold higher than in lifetime nonsmokers (defined as a person who has smoked &lt;100 cigarettes in his or her lifetime). The risk increases with the quantity of cigarettes, duration of smoking, and starting age. </p>

1093<p id="_41" tabindex="-1">

1094Smoking cessation results in a decrease in precancerous lesions and a reduction in lung cancer risk. Former smokers continue to have an elevated risk of lung cancer for years after quitting. Asbestos exposure may exert a synergistic effect of cigarette smoking on lung cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_1.17">

109517</a>

1096]</p>

1097<p id="_485741" tabindex="-1">

1098In addition, after resection of a lung cancer, there is a 1% to 2% risk per patient per year that a second lung cancer will occur.[<a href="#cit/section_1.18">

109918</a>

1100]</p>

1101<p id="_485742" tabindex="-1">

1102A significant number of patients cured of their smoking-related lung cancer may develop a second malignancy. In the Lung Cancer Study Group trial of 907 patients with stage T1, N0 resected tumors, the

1103rate was 1.8% per year for nonpulmonary second cancers and 1.6% per year for new

1104lung cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_1.19">

110519</a>

1106] Other studies have reported even higher risks of second tumors in

1107long-term survivors, including rates of 10% for second lung cancers and 20% for

1108all second cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

110920</a>

1110]</p>

1111<p id="_485743" tabindex="-1">

1112Because of the persistent risk of developing second lung cancers in former smokers, various chemoprevention strategies have been evaluated in randomized control trials. None of the phase III trials using the agents beta carotene, retinol, 13-<em>

1113cis</em>

1114-retinoic acid, [alpha]-tocopherol, N-acetylcysteine, or acetylsalicylic acid has demonstrated beneficial, reproducible results.[<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

111516</a>

1116,<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

111721</a>

1118-<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

111924</a>

1120][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1121Level of evidence A1</a>

1122] Chemoprevention of second primary cancers of the upper aerodigestive tract is undergoing clinical evaluation in patients with early-stage lung cancer. </p>

1123<p id="_485744" tabindex="-1">

1124For more information, see <a href="/types/lung/hp/lung-prevention-pdq">

1125Lung Cancer Prevention</a>

1126.</p>

1127</section>

1128<section id="_44">

1129<h3 id="_44_toc">

1130Screening</h3>

1131<p id="_45" tabindex="-1">

1132In patients considered at high risk of developing lung cancer, the only screening modality for early detection that has been shown to alter mortality is low-dose helical CT scanning.[<a href="#cit/section_1.25">

113325</a>

1134] Studies have failed to demonstrate that screening with chest radiography and sputum cytology lowers lung cancer mortality rates. </p>

1135<p id="_484332" tabindex="-1">

1136 For more information, see the <a href="/types/lung/hp/lung-screening-pdq#_70">

1137Screening by low-dose computed tomography: benefit</a>

1138 section in Lung Cancer Screening.</p>

1139</section>

1140<section id="_48567">

1141<h3 id="_48567_toc">

1142Clinical Presentation</h3>

1143<p id="_484194" tabindex="-1">

1144Lung cancer may present with symptoms or be found incidentally on chest imaging. The most common symptoms at presentation include the following: </p>

1145<div class="pdq-content-list">

1146<ul id="_484195">

1147<li>

1148Worsening cough.</li>

1149<li>

1150Chest pain.</li>

1151<li>

1152Hemoptysis.</li>

1153<li>

1154Malaise.</li>

1155<li>

1156Weight loss.</li>

1157<li>

1158Dyspnea.</li>

1159<li>

1160Hoarseness.</li>

1161</ul>

1162</div>

1163<p id="_484196" tabindex="-1">

1164Symptoms may result from local invasion or compression of adjacent thoracic structures such as compression involving the esophagus causing dysphagia, compression involving the laryngeal nerves causing hoarseness, or compression involving the superior vena cava causing facial edema and distension of the superficial veins of the head and neck.</p>

1165<p id="_485635" tabindex="-1">

1166Symptoms from distant metastases may also be present and include neurological defect or personality change from brain metastases or pain from bone metastases. Infrequently, patients may present with symptoms and signs of paraneoplastic diseases such as hypertrophic osteoarthropathy with digital clubbing or hypercalcemia from parathyroid hormone-related protein. </p>

1167<p id="_485636" tabindex="-1">

1168Physical examination may identify enlarged supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion or lobar collapse, unresolved pneumonia, or signs of associated disease such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or pulmonary fibrosis.</p>

1169</section>

1170<section id="_47">

1171<h3 id="_47_toc">

1172Diagnosis</h3>

1173<p id="_484197" tabindex="-1">

1174Investigations of patients with suspected NSCLC focus on confirming the diagnosis and determining the extent of the disease. Treatment options are determined by histology, stage, and general health and comorbidities of the patient. </p>

1175<p id="_53" tabindex="-1">

1176The procedures used to determine the presence of cancer include the following:</p>

1177<div class="pdq-content-list">

1178<ul id="_54">

1179<li>

1180History.</li>

1181<li>

1182Physical examination.</li>

1183<li>

1184Routine laboratory evaluations.</li>

1185<li>

1186Chest x-ray.</li>

1187<li>

1188Chest CT scan with infusion of contrast material.</li>

1189<li>

1190Biopsy.</li>

1191</ul>

1192</div>

1193<p id="_55" tabindex="-1">

1194Before a patient begins lung cancer treatment, an experienced lung cancer pathologist must review the pathological material. This is critical because SCLC, which responds well to chemotherapy and is generally not treated surgically, can be confused on microscopic examination with NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

119526</a>

1196] Immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy are invaluable techniques for diagnosis and subclassification, but most lung tumors can be classified by light microscopic criteria.</p>

1197<p id="_48597" tabindex="-1">

1198For more information on tests and procedures used for staging, see the <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_471">

1199General Staging Evaluation</a>

1200 section.</p>

1201</section>

1202<section id="_48499">

1203<h3 id="_48499_toc">

1204Prognostic Factors</h3>

1205<p id="_32" tabindex="-1">

1206Multiple studies have attempted to identify the prognostic importance of a variety of clinicopathological factors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

120720</a>

1208,<a href="#cit/section_1.27">

120927</a>

1210-<a href="#cit/section_1.30">

121130</a>

1212] Factors that have correlated with adverse prognosis include the following:</p>

1213<div class="pdq-content-list">

1214<ul id="_33">

1215<li>

1216Increasing stage.</li>

1217<li>

1218Presence of pulmonary or constitutional symptoms.</li>

1219<li>

1220Large tumor size (&gt;3 cm).</li>

1221<li>

1222Metastases to multiple lymph nodes within a TNM-defined nodal station.[<a href="#cit/section_1.31">

122331</a>

1224-<a href="#cit/section_1.41">

122541</a>

1226] For more information, see the <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_479">

1227Evaluation of mediastinal lymph node metastasis</a>

1228 section.</li>

1229<li>

1230Vascular invasion.[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

123128</a>

1232,<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

123342</a>

1234-<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

123544</a>

1236]</li>

1237</ul>

1238</div>

1239<p id="_34" tabindex="-1">

1240For patients with inoperable disease, prognosis is adversely affected by poor performance status and weight loss of more than 10%. These patients have been excluded from clinical trials evaluating aggressive multimodality interventions.</p>

1241<p id="_35" tabindex="-1">

1242In multiple retrospective analyses of clinical trial data, advanced age alone has not been shown to influence response or survival with therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.45">

124345</a>

1244]</p>

1245<p id="_36" tabindex="-1">

1246Because treatment is not satisfactory for almost all patients with NSCLC, eligible patients should be considered for clinical trials. Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

1247NCI website</a>

1248. </p>

1249</section>

1365[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1366</li>

1367<li id="section_1.30">

1368Fontanini G, Bigini D, Vignati S, et al.: Microvessel count predicts metastatic disease and survival in non-small cell lung cancer. J Pathol 177 (1): 57-63, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7472781&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7472781&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1369[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1370</li>

1371<li id="section_1.31">

1372Sayar A, Turna A, Kili&#231;g&#252;n A, et al.: Prognostic significance of surgical-pathologic multiple-station N1 disease in non-small cell carcinoma of the lung. Eur J Cardiothorac Surg 25 (3): 434-8, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15019674&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15019674&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1373[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1374</li>

1375<li id="section_1.32">

1376Osaki T, Nagashima A, Yoshimatsu T, et al.: Survival and characteristics of lymph node involvement in patients with N1 non-small cell lung cancer. Lung Cancer 43 (2): 151-7, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14739035&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14739035&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1377[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1378</li>

1379<li id="section_1.33">

1380Ichinose Y, Kato H, Koike T, et al.: Overall survival and local recurrence of 406 completely resected stage IIIa-N2 non-small cell lung cancer patients: questionnaire survey of the Japan Clinical Oncology Group to plan for clinical trials. Lung Cancer 34 (1): 29-36, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11557110&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11557110&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1381[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1382</li>

1383<li id="section_1.34">

1384Tanaka F, Yanagihara K, Otake Y, et al.: Prognostic factors in patients with resected pathologic (p-) T1-2N1M0 non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Eur J Cardiothorac Surg 19 (5): 555-61, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11343930&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11343930&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1385[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1386</li>

1387<li id="section_1.35">

1388Asamura H, Suzuki K, Kondo H, et al.: Where is the boundary between N1 and N2 stations in lung cancer? Ann Thorac Surg 70 (6): 1839-45; discussion 1845-6, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11156081&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11156081&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1389[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1390</li>

1391<li id="section_1.36">

1392Riquet M, Manac'h D, Le Pimpec-Barthes F, et al.: Prognostic significance of surgical-pathologic N1 disease in non-small cell carcinoma of the lung. Ann Thorac Surg 67 (6): 1572-6, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10391257&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10391257&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1393[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1394</li>

1395<li id="section_1.37">

1396van Velzen E, Snijder RJ, Brutel de la Rivi&#232;re A, et al.: Lymph node type as a prognostic factor for survival in T2 N1 M0 non-small cell lung carcinoma. Ann Thorac Surg 63 (5): 1436-40, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9146339&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9146339&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1397[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1398</li>

1399<li id="section_1.38">

1400Vansteenkiste JF, De Leyn PR, Deneffe GJ, et al.: Survival and prognostic factors in resected N2 non-small cell lung cancer: a study of 140 cases. Leuven Lung Cancer Group. Ann Thorac Surg 63 (5): 1441-50, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9146340&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9146340&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1401[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1402</li>

1403<li id="section_1.39">

1404Izbicki JR, Passlick B, Karg O, et al.: Impact of radical systematic mediastinal lymphadenectomy on tumor staging in lung cancer. Ann Thorac Surg 59 (1): 209-14, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7818326&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7818326&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1405[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1406</li>

1410</li>

1411<li id="section_1.41">

1412Naruke T, Goya T, Tsuchiya R, et al.: Prognosis and survival in resected lung carcinoma based on the new international staging system. J Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 96 (3): 440-7, 1988.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2842549&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2842549&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1414</li>

Lancet 340 (8812): 145-6, 1992.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1378165&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1378165&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1425[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1426</li>

1427<li id="section_1.45">

1428Earle CC, Tsai JS, Gelber RD, et al.: Effectiveness of chemotherapy for advanced lung cancer in the elderly: instrumental variable and propensity analysis. J Clin Oncol 19 (4): 1064-70, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11181670&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11181670&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1429[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1430</li>

1431</ol>

1432</div>

1433

1434 </section>

1435

1436

1437

1438 <section id="_359">

1439

1440 <h2>

1441Cellular and Molecular Classification of NSCLC</h2>

1442

1443 <div id="_section_359" class="pdq-sections">

1444<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1445<h6>

1446In This Section</h6>

1447<ul>

1448<li>

1449<a href="#_361_toc">

1450Tumor Types<ul>

1451<li>

1452<a href="#_48569_toc">

1453Squamous cell carcinoma</a>

1454</li>

1455<li>

1456<a href="#_454_toc">

1457Adenocarcinoma</a>

1458</li>

1459<li>

1460<a href="#_459_toc">

1461Large cell carcinoma</a>

1462</li>

1463<li>

1464<a href="#_468_toc">

1465Neuroendocrine tumors</a>

1466</li>

1467<li>

1468<a href="#_466_toc">

1469Carcinomas with pleomorphic, sarcomatoid, or sarcomatous elements</a>

1470</li>

1471</ul>

1472</a>

1473</li>

1474<li>

1475<a href="#_484301_toc">

1476Molecular Features</a>

1477</li>

1478</ul>

1479</nav>

1480<p id="_484198" tabindex="-1">

1481Malignant non-small cell epithelial tumors of the lung are classified by the World Health Organization (WHO)/International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer (IASLC). The three main subtypes of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) include the following: </p>

1482<div class="pdq-content-list">

1483<ul id="_484199">

1484<li>

1485Squamous cell carcinoma (25% of lung cancers).</li>

1486<li>

1487Adenocarcinoma (40% of lung cancers).</li>

1488<li>

1489Large cell carcinoma (10% of lung cancers).</li>

1490</ul>

1491</div>

1492<p id="_485761" tabindex="-1">

1493Additional types include adenosquamous carcinoma, sarcomatoid carcinomas, salivary gland type tumors, carcinoid tumors, and other unclassified carcinomas. There are many subtypes in these categories.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

14941</a>

1495]

1496</p>

1497<section id="_361">

1498<h3 id="_361_toc">

1499Tumor Types</h3>

1500<section id="_48569">

1501<h4 id="_48569_toc">

1502Squamous cell carcinoma</h4>

1503<p id="_484201" tabindex="-1">

1504Most squamous cell carcinomas of the lung are located centrally, in the larger bronchi of the lung. Squamous cell carcinomas are linked more strongly with smoking than other forms of NSCLC. The incidence of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung has been decreasing in recent years.</p>

1505</section>

1506<section id="_454">

1507<h4 id="_454_toc">

1508Adenocarcinoma</h4>

1509<p id="_455" tabindex="-1">

1510Adenocarcinoma is now the most common histological subtype in many countries, and subclassification of adenocarcinoma is important. One of the biggest problems with lung adenocarcinomas is the frequent histological heterogeneity. Mixtures of adenocarcinoma histological subtypes are more common than tumors consisting purely of a single pattern of acinar, papillary, bronchioloalveolar, and solid adenocarcinoma with mucin formation. </p>

1511<p id="_456" tabindex="-1">

1512Criteria for the diagnosis of bronchioloalveolar carcinoma have varied widely in the past. The current WHO/IASLC definition is much more restrictive than that previously used by many pathologists because it is limited to only noninvasive tumors.</p>

1513<p id="_457" tabindex="-1">

1514If stromal, vascular, or pleural invasion are identified in an adenocarcinoma that has an extensive bronchioloalveolar carcinoma component, the classification would be an adenocarcinoma of mixed subtype with predominant bronchioloalveolar pattern and a focal acinar, solid, or papillary pattern, depending on which pattern is seen in the invasive component. However, the future of bronchioloalveolar carcinoma as a distinct clinical entity is unclear; a multidisciplinary expert panel representing the IASLC, the American Thoracic Society, and the European Respiratory Society proposed a major revision of the classification of adenocarcinomas in 2011 that entails a reclassification of what was called bronchioloalveolar carcinoma into newly defined histological subgroups.</p>

1515<p id="_458" tabindex="-1">

1516The following variants of adenocarcinoma are recognized in the WHO/IASLC classification: </p>

1517<div class="pdq-content-list">

1518<ul id="_453">

1519<li>

1520Well-differentiated fetal adenocarcinoma.</li>

1521<li>

1522Mucinous (colloid) adenocarcinoma.</li>

1523<li>

1524Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma.</li>

1525<li>

1526Signet ring adenocarcinoma.</li>

1527<li>

1528Clear cell adenocarcinoma.</li>

1529</ul>

1530</div>

1531</section>

1532<section id="_459">

1533<h4 id="_459_toc">

1534Large cell carcinoma</h4>

1535<p id="_460" tabindex="-1">

1536In addition to the general category of large cell carcinoma, several uncommon variants are recognized in the WHO/IASLC classification, including the following:</p>

1537<div class="pdq-content-list">

1538<ul id="_461">

1539<li>

1540Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma (LCNEC).</li>

1541<li>

1542Basaloid carcinoma.</li>

1543<li>

1544Lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma.</li>

1545<li>

1546Clear cell carcinoma.</li>

1547<li>

1548Large cell carcinoma with rhabdoid phenotype.</li>

1549</ul>

1550</div>

1551<p id="_462" tabindex="-1">

1552Basaloid carcinoma is also recognized as a variant of squamous cell carcinoma, and rarely, adenocarcinomas may have a basaloid pattern; however, in tumors without either of these features, they are regarded as a variant of large cell carcinoma. </p>

1553</section>

1554<section id="_468">

1555<h4 id="_468_toc">

1556Neuroendocrine tumors</h4>

1557<p id="_469" tabindex="-1">

1558LCNEC is recognized as a histologically high-grade non-small cell carcinoma. It has a very poor prognosis similar to that of small cell lung cancer (SCLC). Atypical carcinoid is recognized as an intermediate-grade neuroendocrine tumor with a prognosis that falls between typical carcinoid and high-grade SCLC and LCNEC.</p>

1559<p id="_465" tabindex="-1">

1560Neuroendocrine differentiation can be demonstrated by immunohistochemistry or electron microscopy in 10% to 20% of common NSCLCs that do not have any neuroendocrine morphology. These tumors are not formally recognized within the WHO/IASLC classification scheme because the clinical and therapeutic significance of neuroendocrine differentiation in NSCLC is not firmly established. These tumors are referred to collectively as NSCLC with neuroendocrine differentiation.</p>

1561</section>

1562<section id="_466">

1563<h4 id="_466_toc">

1564Carcinomas with pleomorphic, sarcomatoid, or sarcomatous elements</h4>

1565<p id="_467" tabindex="-1">

1566This is a group of rare tumors. Spindle cell carcinomas and giant cell carcinomas comprise only 0.4% of all lung malignancies, and carcinosarcomas comprise only 0.1% of all lung malignancies. In addition, this group of tumors reflects a continuum in histological heterogeneity, as well as epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation. On the basis of clinical and molecular data, biphasic pulmonary blastoma is regarded as part of the spectrum of carcinomas with pleomorphic, sarcomatoid, or sarcomatous elements.</p>

1567</section>

1568</section>

1569<section id="_484301">

1570<h3 id="_484301_toc">

1571Molecular Features</h3>

1572<p id="_484302" tabindex="-1">

1573The identification of mutations in lung cancer has led to the development of molecularly targeted therapy to improve the survival of subsets of patients with metastatic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

15742</a>

1575] In particular, subsets of adenocarcinoma now can be defined by specific mutations in genes encoding components of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and downstream mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK) and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinases (PI3K) signaling pathways. These mutations may define mechanisms of drug sensitivity and primary or acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors. Genomic alterations that can be targeted with approved therapies or for which treatments are under development include the following: </p>

1576<div class="pdq-content-list">

1577<ul id="_484303">

1578<li>

1579<em class="gene-name">

1580EGFR</em>

1581.</li>

1582<li>

1583<em class="gene-name">

1584ALK</em>

1585. </li>

1586<li>

1587<em class="gene-name">

1588BRAF</em>

1589. </li>

1590<li>

1591<em class="gene-name">

1592ROS1</em>

1593.</li>

1594<li>

1595<em class="gene-name">

1596RET</em>

1597.</li>

1598<li>

1599<em class="gene-name">

1600NTRK1</em>

1601, <em class="gene-name">

1602NTRK2</em>

1603, and <em class="gene-name">

1604NTRK3</em>

1605.</li>

1606<li>

1607<em class="gene-name">

1608MET</em>

1609. </li>

1610<li>

1611<em class="gene-name">

1612KRAS</em>

1613.</li>

1614<li>

1615<em class="gene-name">

1616HER2</em>

1617.</li>

1618</ul>

1619</div>

1620<p id="_484305" tabindex="-1">

1621<em class="gene-name">

1622EGFR</em>

1623 and <em class="gene-name">

1624ALK</em>

1625 mutations predominate in adenocarcinomas that develop in nonsmokers, and <em class="gene-name">

1626KRAS</em>

1627 and <em class="gene-name">

1628BRAF</em>

1629 mutations are more common in smokers or former smokers. <em class="gene-name">

1630EGFR</em>

1631 mutations strongly predict the improved response rate and progression-free survival of patients who take EGFR inhibitors. In a set of 2,142 lung adenocarcinoma specimens from patients treated at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, <em class="gene-name">

1632EGFR </em>

1633 exon 19 deletions and L858R were found in 15% of tumors from former smokers (181 of 1,218; 95% confidence interval [CI], 13%&#8211;17%), 6% from current smokers (20 of 344; 95% CI, 4%&#8211;9%), and 52% from never-smokers (302 of 580; 95% CI, 48%&#8211;56%; <em>

1634P</em>

1635 &lt; .001 for ever- vs. never-smokers).[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

16363</a>

1637] </p>

1638<p id="_484306" tabindex="-1">

1639Fusions of <em class="gene-name">

1640ALK</em>

1641 with <em class="gene-name">

1642EML4</em>

1643 genes form translocation products that occur in ranges from 3% to 7% in unselected NSCLC and are responsive to pharmacological inhibition of <em class="gene-name">

1644ALK</em>

1645 by agents such as crizotinib. Sensitizing fusions of <em class="gene-name">

1646ALK</em>

1647 with other genes have also been reported. </p>

1648</section>

1649<h6 do-not-show="toc">

1650References</h6>

1651<ol>

1652<li id="section_2.1">

1654[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1655</li>

1656<li id="section_2.2">

1657Pao W, Girard N: New driver mutations in non-small-cell lung cancer. Lancet Oncol 12 (2): 175-80, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21277552&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21277552&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1658[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1659</li>

1660<li id="section_2.3">

1662[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1665</div>

1668

1669

1670

1671 <section id="_470">

1672

1673 <h2>

1674Stage Information for NSCLC</h2>

1675

1676 <div id="_section_470" class="pdq-sections">

1677<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1678<h6>

1679In This Section</h6>

1680<ul>

1681<li>

1682<a href="#_471_toc">

1683General Staging Evaluation<ul>

1684<li>

1685<a href="#_479_toc">

1686Evaluation of mediastinal lymph node metastasis</a>

1687</li>

1688<li>

1689<a href="#_502_toc">

1690Evaluation of brain metastasis</a>

1691</li>

1692<li>

1693<a href="#_504_toc">

1694Evaluation of distant metastasis to sites other than the brain</a>

1695</li>

1696</ul>

1697</a>

1698</li>

1699<li>

1700<a href="#_506_toc">

1701The Revised International System for Staging Lung Cancer</a>

1702</li>

1703<li>

1704<a href="#_510_toc">

1705AJCC Stage Groupings and TNM Definitions</a>

1706</li>

1707</ul>

1708</nav>

1709<section id="_471">

1710<h3 id="_471_toc">

1711General Staging Evaluation</h3>

1712<p id="_4720" tabindex="-1">

1713In non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), the determination of stage has important therapeutic and prognostic implications. Careful initial diagnostic evaluation to define the location and to determine the extent of primary and metastatic tumor involvement is critical for the appropriate care of patients. </p>

1714<p id="_473" tabindex="-1">

1715In general, symptoms, physical signs, laboratory findings, and perceived risk of distant metastasis lead to an evaluation for distant metastatic disease. Additional tests such as bone scans and computed tomography (CT)/magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain may be performed if initial assessments suggest metastases or if patients with stage III disease are being evaluated for aggressive local and combined modality treatments.</p>

1716<p id="_4750" tabindex="-1">

1717Stage has a critical role in the selection of therapy. The stage of disease is based on a combination of clinical factors and pathological factors.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

17181</a>

1719] The distinction

1720between clinical stage and pathological stage should be considered when

1721evaluating reports of survival outcome.</p>

1722<p id="_476" tabindex="-1">

1723Procedures used to determine stage include the following:</p>

1724<div class="pdq-content-list">

1725<ul id="_412">

1726<li>

1727 History.</li>

1728<li>

1729Physical examination.</li>

1730<li>

1731Routine laboratory evaluations.</li>

1732<li>

1733Chest x-ray.</li>

1734<li>

1735Chest CT scan with infusion of contrast material.</li>

1736<li>

1737Fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (18F-FDG PET) scanning.</li>

1738</ul>

1739</div>

1740<p id="_477" tabindex="-1">

1741Procedures used to obtain tissue samples include bronchoscopy, mediastinoscopy, or anterior mediastinotomy.</p>

1742<p id="_485638" tabindex="-1">

1743Pathological staging of NSCLC requires examination of the tumor, knowledge of resection margins, and determination of lymph node status. </p>

1744<p id="_48553" tabindex="-1">

1745At diagnosis, patients with NSCLC can be divided into the following three groups that reflect both the

1746extent of the disease and the treatment approach:</p>

1747<div class="pdq-content-list">

1748<ol id="_484438">

1749<li>

1750Surgically resectable disease (generally stage I, stage II, and selected stage III tumors).<div class="pdq-content-list">

1751<ul id="_484439">

1752<li>

1753Has the best prognosis,

1754which depends on a variety of tumor and host factors.</li>

1755<li>

1756Patients with resectable

1757disease who have medical contraindications to surgery are candidates for

1758curative radiation therapy.</li>

1759<li>

1760Postoperative cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy may provide a survival advantage for patients with resected stage II or stage IIIA NSCLC.</li>

1761</ul>

1762</div>

1763</li>

1764<li>

1765Locally (T3&#8211;T4) and/or regionally (N2&#8211;N3) advanced disease. <div class="pdq-content-list">

1766<ul id="_484440">

1767<li>

1768Has a diverse natural history. </li>

1769<li>

1770Selected patients with locally advanced tumors may benefit from combined modality treatments.</li>

1771<li>

1772Patients with unresectable or N2&#8211;N3 disease are

1773treated with radiation therapy in

1774combination with chemotherapy.</li>

1775<li>

1776Selected patients

1777with T3 or N2 disease can be treated effectively with surgical resection and either preoperative or postoperative chemotherapy or chemoradiation therapy.</li>

1778</ul>

1779</div>

1780</li>

1781<li>

1782Distant metastatic disease (includes distant metastases [M1] that were found at the time of

1783diagnosis).<div class="pdq-content-list">

1784<ul id="_484441">

1785<li>

1786May be treated with systemic therapy (chemotherapy

1787and/or immunotherapy or targeted therapy). Radiation therapy can be used for palliation.</li>

1788</ul>

1789</div>

1790</li>

1791</ol>

1792</div>

1793</section>

1794<section id="_478">

1795<section id="_479">

1796<h4 id="_479_toc">

1797Evaluation of mediastinal lymph node metastasis</h4>

1798<section id="_480">

1799<h5 id="_480_toc">

1800Surgical evaluation</h5>

1801<p id="_481" tabindex="-1">

1802Surgical staging of the mediastinum is considered standard if accurate evaluation of the nodal status is needed to determine therapy. </p>

1803<p id="_4820" tabindex="-1">

1804Accurate staging of the mediastinal lymph nodes provides important prognostic information. </p>

1805<p id="_484321" tabindex="-1">

1806Evidence (nodal status):</p>

1807<div class="pdq-content-list">

1808<ol id="_484322">

1809<li>

1810The association between survival and the number of examined lymph nodes during surgery for patients with stage I NSCLC treated with definitive surgical resection was assessed from the population-based Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program database for the period from 1990 to 2000.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

18112</a>

1812] A total of 16,800 patients were included in the study.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1813<ol id="_485639" class="lower-alpha">

1814<li>

1815The overall survival analysis for patients without radiation therapy was done by comparing the reference group (one to four lymph nodes) with the following groups:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1816<ul id="_485640">

1817<li>

1818Patients with five to eight lymph nodes examined during surgery had a modest but statistically significant increase in survival, with a proportionate hazard ratio (HR) of 0.90 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.84&#8211;0.97). </li>

1819<li>

1820For patients with 9 to 12 examined lymph nodes, the HR was 0.86 (95% CI, 0.79&#8211;0.95). </li>

1821<li>

1822For patients with 13 to 16 examined lymph nodes, the HR was 0.78 (95% CI, 0.68&#8211;0.90). </li>

1823<li>

1824There appeared to be no incremental improvement after evaluating more than 16 lymph nodes. </li>

1825</ul>

1826</div>

1827<p id="_485641" tabindex="-1">

1828The corresponding results for lung cancer&#8211;specific mortality and for patients who received radiation therapy were not substantially different.</p>

1829</li>

1830<li>

1831These results indicate that patient survival following resection for NSCLC is associated with the number of lymph nodes evaluated during surgery. Because this is most likely the result of a reduction-of-staging error, namely, a decreased likelihood of missing positive lymph nodes with an increasing number of lymph nodes sampled, it suggests that an evaluation of nodal status should include 11 to 16 lymph nodes.</li>

1832</ol>

1833</div>

1834</li>

1835</ol>

1836</div>

1837</section>

1838<section id="_485">

1839<h5 id="_485_toc">

1840CT imaging</h5>

1841<p id="_486" tabindex="-1">

1842CT scanning is primarily used for determining the size of the tumor. The CT scan should extend inferiorly to include the liver and adrenal glands. MRI scans of the thorax and upper abdomen do not appear to yield advantages over CT scans.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

18433</a>

1844]</p>

1845<p id="_484324" tabindex="-1">

1846Evidence (CT scan):</p>

1847<div class="pdq-content-list">

1848<ol id="_484325">

1849<li>

1850A systematic review of the medical literature relating to the accuracy of CT scanning for noninvasive staging of the mediastinum in patients with lung cancer was conducted. In the 35 studies published between 1991 and June 2006, 5,111 evaluable patients were identified. Almost all studies specified that CT scanning was performed following the administration of intravenous contrast material and that a positive test result was defined as the presence of one or more lymph nodes that measured larger than 1 cm on the short-axis diameter.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

18514</a>

1852] <div class="pdq-content-list">

1853<ul id="_484326">

1854<li>

1855The median prevalence of mediastinal metastasis was 28% (range, 18%&#8211;56%).</li>

1856<li>

1857The pooled estimates of sensitivity and specificity of CT scanning for identifying mediastinal lymph node metastasis were 51% (95% CI, 47%&#8211;54%) for sensitivity and 86% (95% CI, 84%&#8211;88%) for specificity. Corresponding positive (3.4%) and negative (0.6%) likelihood ratios were provided.</li>

1858</ul>

1859</div>

1860</li>

1861<li>

1862The results from the systematic review are similar to those of a large meta-analysis that reported the median sensitivity and specificity of CT scanning for identifying malignant mediastinal nodes as 61% for sensitivity and 79% for specificity.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

18635</a>

1864]</li>

1865<li>

1866An earlier meta-analysis reported an average sensitivity rate of 64% and specificity rate of 74%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

18676</a>

1868]</li>

1869</ol>

1870</div>

1871</section>

1872<section id="_489">

1873<h5 id="_489_toc">

187418F-FDG PET scanning</h5>

1875<p id="_490" tabindex="-1">

1876The wider availability and use of 18F-FDG PET scanning for staging has modified the approach to staging mediastinal lymph nodes and distant metastases. </p>

1877<p id="_48538" tabindex="-1">

1878Randomized trials evaluating the utility of 18F-FDG PET scanning in potentially resectable NSCLC patients reported conflicting results in terms of the relative reduction in the number of noncurative thoracotomies.</p>

1879<p id="_48539" tabindex="-1">

1880Although the current evidence is conflicting, 18F-FDG PET scanning may improve results of early-stage lung cancer by identifying patients who have evidence of metastatic disease that is beyond the scope of surgical resection and that is not evident by standard preoperative staging procedures.</p>

1881<p id="_492" tabindex="-1">

1882Evidence (18F-FDG PET scan):</p>

1883<div class="pdq-content-list">

1884<ol id="_493">

1885<li>

1886A systematic review, an expansion of a health technology assessment conducted in 2001 by the Institute for Clinical and Evaluative Sciences, evaluated the accuracy and utility of 18F-FDG PET scanning in the diagnosis and staging of lung cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

18877</a>

1888] Through a systematic search of the literature, 12 evidence summary reports and 15 prospective studies of the diagnostic accuracy of 18F-FDG PET scanning were identified. <div class="pdq-content-list">

1889<ul id="_485642">

1890<li>

189118F-FDG PET scanning appears to be superior to CT imaging for mediastinal staging in NSCLC. </li>

1892<li>

189318F-FDG PET scanning also appears to have high sensitivity and reasonable specificity for differentiating benign from malignant lesions as small as 1 cm.</li>

1894</ul>

1895</div>

1896</li>

1897<li>

1898A systematic review of the medical literature relating to the accuracy of 18F-FDG PET scanning for noninvasive staging of the mediastinum in patients with lung cancer identified 44 studies published between 1994 and 2006 with 2,865 evaluable patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

18994</a>

1900] <div class="pdq-content-list">

1901<ul id="_485643">

1902<li>

1903The median prevalence of mediastinal metastases was 29% (range, 5%&#8211;64%). </li>

1904<li>

1905Pooled estimates of sensitivity and specificity for identifying mediastinal metastasis were 74% (95% CI, 69%&#8211;79%) for sensitivity and 85% (95% CI, 82%&#8211;88%) for specificity.</li>

1906<li>

1907Corresponding positive (4.9%) and negative (0.3%) likelihood ratios were provided for mediastinal staging with 18F-FDG PET scanning. </li>

1908<li>

1909These findings demonstrated that 18F-FDG PET scanning is more accurate than CT scanning for staging of the mediastinum in patients with lung cancer.</li>

1910</ul>

1911</div>

1912</li>

1913</ol>

1914</div>

1915<p id="_485745" tabindex="-1">

1916Decision analyses demonstrate that 18F-FDG PET scanning may reduce the overall costs of medical care by identifying patients with falsely negative CT scans in the mediastinum or otherwise undetected sites of metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

19178</a>

1918-<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

191910</a>

1920] Studies concluded that the money saved by forgoing mediastinoscopy in 18F-FDG PET-positive mediastinal lesions was not justified because of the unacceptably high number of false-positive results.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

19218</a>

1922-<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

192310</a>

1924] A randomized study found that the addition of 18F-FDG PET scanning to conventional staging was associated with significantly fewer thoracotomies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

192511</a>

1926] A second randomized trial evaluating the impact of 18F-FDG PET scanning on clinical management found that 18F-FDG PET scanning provided additional information regarding appropriate stage but did not lead to significantly fewer thoracotomies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

192712</a>

1928]</p>

1929</section>

1930<section id="_497">

1931<h5 id="_497_toc">

1932Combination of CT imaging and 18F-FDG PET scanning</h5>

1933<p id="_498" tabindex="-1">

1934The combination of CT imaging and 18F-FDG PET scanning has greater sensitivity and specificity than CT imaging alone.[<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

193513</a>

1936]</p>

1937<p id="_499" tabindex="-1">

1938Evidence (CT/18F-FDG PET scan):</p>

1939<div class="pdq-content-list">

1940<ol id="_500">

1941<li>

1942If there is no evidence of distant metastatic disease on CT scan, 18F-FDG PET scanning complements CT scan staging of the mediastinum. Numerous nonrandomized studies of 18F-FDG PET scanning have evaluated mediastinal lymph nodes using surgery (i.e., mediastinoscopy and/or thoracotomy with mediastinal lymph node dissection) as the gold standard of comparison. </li>

1943<li>

1944A meta-analysis evaluated the conditional test performance of 18F-FDG PET scanning and CT scanning. <div class="pdq-content-list">

1945<ul id="_485644">

1946<li>

1947The median sensitivity and specificity of 18F-FDG PET scans were reported as 100% for sensitivity and 78% for specificity in patients with enlarged lymph nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

19485</a>

1949] </li>

1950<li>

195118F-FDG PET scanning is considered very accurate in identifying malignant nodal involvement when lymph nodes are enlarged. However, 18F-FDG PET scanning will falsely identify a malignancy in approximately one-fourth of patients with lymph nodes that are enlarged for other reasons, usually as a result of inflammation or infection.[<a href="#cit/section_3.14">

195214</a>

1953,<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

195415</a>

1955]</li>

1956</ul>

1957</div>

1958 </li>

1959<li>

1960The median sensitivity and specificity of 18F-FDG PET scanning in patients with normal-sized mediastinal lymph nodes were 82% for sensitivity and 93% for specificity.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

19615</a>

1962] These data indicate that nearly 20% of patients with normal-sized lymph nodes but with malignant involvement had falsely negative 18F-FDG PET scan findings.</li>

1963</ol>

1964</div>

1965<p id="_501" tabindex="-1">

1966For patients with clinically operable NSCLC, the evidence supports performing a biopsy of mediastinal lymph nodes that are found to be larger than 1 cm in shortest transverse axis on chest CT scan or are found to be positive on 18F-FDG PET scan. Negative 18F-FDG PET scanning does not preclude biopsy of radiographically enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes. Mediastinoscopy is necessary for the detection of cancer in mediastinal lymph nodes when the results of the CT scan and 18F-FDG PET scan do not corroborate each other.</p>

1967</section>

1968</section>

1969<section id="_502">

1970<h4 id="_502_toc">

1971Evaluation of brain metastasis</h4>

1972<p id="_503" tabindex="-1">

1973Patients at risk of brain metastases may be staged with CT or MRI scans. </p>

1974<p id="_485747" tabindex="-1">

1975Evidence (staging with CT or MRI):</p>

1976<div class="pdq-content-list">

1977<ol id="_485748">

1978<li>

1979One study randomly assigned 332 patients with potentially operable NSCLC and no neurological symptoms to brain CT or MRI imaging to detect occult brain metastasis before lung surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

198016</a>

1981]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1982<ul id="_485749">

1983<li>

1984MRI showed a trend towards a higher preoperative detection rate than CT scan (<em>

1985P</em>

1986 = .069), with an overall detection rate of approximately 7% from pretreatment to 12 months after surgery. </li>

1987<li>

1988Patients with stage I or stage II disease had a detection rate of 4% (i.e., 8 detections out of 200 patients); however, individuals with stage III disease had a detection rate of 11.4% (i.e., 15 detections out of 132 patients). </li>

1989<li>

1990The mean maximal diameter of the brain metastases was significantly smaller in the MRI group.</li>

1991</ul>

1992</div>

1993 <p id="_485750" tabindex="-1">

1994Whether the improved detection rate of MRI translates into improved outcome remains unknown. Not all patients are able to tolerate MRI, and for these patients contrast-enhanced CT scan is a reasonable substitute.</p>

1995</li>

1996</ol>

1997</div>

1998</section>

1999<section id="_504">

2000<h4 id="_504_toc">

2001Evaluation of distant metastasis to sites other than the brain</h4>

2002<p id="_505" tabindex="-1">

2003Numerous nonrandomized, prospective, and retrospective studies have demonstrated that 18F-FDG PET scanning offers diagnostic advantages over conventional imaging in staging distant metastatic disease; however, standard 18F-FDG PET scans have limitations. 18F-FDG PET scans may not extend below the pelvis and may not detect bone metastases in the long bones of the lower extremities. Because the metabolic tracer used in 18F-FDG PET scanning accumulates in the brain and urinary tract, 18F-FDG PET scanning is not reliable for detection of metastases in these sites.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

200416</a>

2005]</p>

2006</section>

2007</section>

2008<section id="_506">

2009<h3 id="_506_toc">

2010The Revised International System for Staging Lung Cancer</h3>

2011<p id="_547" tabindex="-1">

2012The Revised International System for Staging Lung Cancer, based on information from a clinical database of more than 5,000 patients, was adopted in 2010 by

2013the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and the Union Internationale Contre le

2014Cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

201517</a>

2016,<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

201718</a>

2018] These revisions provide greater prognostic specificity for

2019patient groups; however, the correlation between stage and prognosis predates the widespread availability of PET imaging. </p>

2020</section>

2021<section id="_510">

2022<h3 id="_510_toc">

2023AJCC Stage Groupings and TNM Definitions</h3>

2024<p id="_485400" tabindex="-1">

2025The AJCC has designated staging by TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) classification to define NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

202618</a>

2027]</p>

2028<table id="_485788" class="table-default expandable-container">

2029<caption>

2030Table 1. Definitions of Primary Tumor (T) for Lung Cancer<span class="sup">

2031a</span>

2032</caption>

2033<colgroup>

2034<col width="6.23%">

2035<col width="19.70%">

2036<col width="74.06%">

2037</colgroup>

2038<THead>

2039<tr>

2040<th colspan="2">

2041T Category</th>

2042<th>

2043T Criteria</th>

2044</tr>

2045</THead>

2046<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2047<tr>

2048<td colspan="3">

2049<span class="sup">

2050a</span>

2051Reprinted with permission from AJCC: Lung. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2052AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2053. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 431&#8211;56.</td>

2054</tr>

2055</TFoot>

2056<tbody>

2057<tr>

2058<td colspan="2">

2059TX</td>

2060<td>

2061Primary tumor cannot be assessed, or tumor proven by the presence of malignant cells in sputum or bronchial washings but not visualized by imaging or bronchoscopy.</td>

2062</tr>

2063<tr>

2064<td colspan="2">

2065T0</td>

2066<td>

2067No evidence of primary tumor.</td>

2068</tr>

2069<tr>

2070<td colspan="2">

2071Tis</td>

2072<td>

2073Carcinoma <em>

2074in situ</em>

2075; SCIS =Squamous cell carcinoma <em>

2076in situ</em>

2077; AIS: Adenocarcinoma<em>

2078 in situ</em>

2079; Adenocarcinoma with pure lepidic pattern, &#8804;3 cm in greatest dimension.</td>

2080</tr>

2081<tr>

2082<td colspan="2">

2083T1</td>

2084<td>

2085Tumor &#8804;3 cm in greatest dimension, surrounded by lung or visceral pleura, without bronchoscopic evidence of invasion more proximal than the lobar bronchus (i.e., not in the main bronchus).</td>

2086</tr>

2087<tr>

2088<td>

2089&#160;</td>

2090<td>

2091T1mi</td>

2092<td>

2093Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma: adenocarcinoma (&#8804;3 cm in greatest dimension) with a predominantly lepidic pattern and &#8804;5 mm invasion in greatest dimension.</td>

2094</tr>

2095<tr>

2096<td>

2097&#160;</td>

2098<td>

2099T1a</td>

2100<td>

2101Tumor &#8804;1 cm in greatest dimension. A superficial, spreading tumor of any size whose invasive component is limited to the bronchial wall and may extend proximal to the main bronchus also is classified as T1a, but these tumors are uncommon.</td>

2102</tr>

2103<tr>

2104<td>

2105&#160;</td>

2106<td>

2107T1b</td>

2108<td>

2109Tumor &gt;1 cm but &#8804;2 cm in greatest dimension.</td>

2110</tr>

2111<tr>

2112<td>

2113&#160;</td>

2114<td>

2115T1c</td>

2116<td>

2117Tumor &gt;2 cm but &#8804;3 cm in greatest dimension.</td>

2118</tr>

2119<tr>

2120<td colspan="2">

2121T2</td>

2122<td>

2123Tumor &gt;3 cm but &#8804;5 cm or having any of the following features: involves the main bronchus regardless of distance to the carina, but without involvement of the carina; invades visceral pleura (PL1 or PL2); associated with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis that extends to the hilar region, involving part or all of the lung. T2 tumors with these features are classified as T2a if &#8804;4 cm or if the size cannot be determined and T2b if &gt;4 cm but &#8804;5 cm.</td>

2124</tr>

2125<tr>

2126<td>

2127&#160;</td>

2128<td>

2129T2a</td>

2130<td>

2131Tumor &gt;3 cm but &#8804;4 cm in greatest dimension.</td>

2132</tr>

2133<tr>

2134<td>

2135&#160;</td>

2136<td>

2137T2b</td>

2138<td>

2139Tumor &gt;4 cm but &#8804;5 cm in greatest dimension.</td>

2140</tr>

2141<tr>

2142<td colspan="2">

2143T3</td>

2144<td>

2145Tumor &gt;5 cm but &#8804;7 cm in greatest dimension or directly invading any of the following: parietal pleura (PL3), chest wall (including superior sulcus tumors), phrenic nerve, parietal pericardium; or separate tumor nodule(s) in the same lobe as the primary.</td>

2146</tr>

2147<tr>

2148<td colspan="2">

2149T4</td>

2150<td>

2151Tumor &gt;7 cm or tumor of any size invading one or more of the following: diaphragm, mediastinum, heart, great vessels, trachea, recurrent laryngeal nerve, esophagus, vertebral body, or carina; separate tumor nodule(s) in an ipsilateral lobe different from that of the primary.</td>

2152</tr>

2153</tbody>

2154</table>

2155<table id="_485771" class="table-default expandable-container">

2156<caption>

2157Table 2. Definitions of Regional Lymph Node (N) for Lung Cancer<span class="sup">

2158a</span>

2159</caption>

2160<colgroup>

2161<col width="26.04%">

2162<col width="73.95%">

2163</colgroup>

2164<THead>

2165<tr>

2166<th>

2167N Category</th>

2168<th>

2169N Criteria </th>

2170</tr>

2171</THead>

2172<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2173<tr>

2174<td colspan="2">

2175<span class="sup">

2176a</span>

2177Reprinted with permission from AJCC: Lung. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2178AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2179. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 431&#8211;56.</td>

2180</tr>

2181</TFoot>

2182<tbody>

2183<tr>

2184<td>

2185NX</td>

2186<td>

2187Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.</td>

2188</tr>

2189<tr>

2190<td>

2191N0</td>

2192<td>

2193No regional lymph node metastasis.</td>

2194</tr>

2195<tr>

2196<td>

2197N1</td>

2198<td>

2199Metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary nodes, including involvement by direct extension.</td>

2200</tr>

2201<tr>

2202<td>

2203N2</td>

2204<td>

2205Metastasis in ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph node(s).</td>

2206</tr>

2207<tr>

2208<td>

2209N3</td>

2210<td>

2211Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph node(s).</td>

2212</tr>

2213</tbody>

2214</table>

2215<table id="_485772" class="table-default expandable-container">

2216<caption>

2217Table 3. Definitions of Distant Metastasis (M) for Lung Cancer<span class="sup">

2218a</span>

2219</caption>

2220<colgroup>

2221<col width="5.86%">

2222<col width="20.65%">

2223<col width="73.47%">

2224</colgroup>

2225<THead>

2226<tr>

2227<th colspan="2">

2228M Category</th>

2229<th>

2230M Criteria</th>

2231</tr>

2232</THead>

2233<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2234<tr>

2235<td colspan="3">

2236<span class="sup">

2237a</span>

2238Reprinted with permission from AJCC: Lung. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2239AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2240. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 431&#8211;56.</td>

2241</tr>

2242</TFoot>

2243<tbody>

2244<tr>

2245<td colspan="2">

2246M0</td>

2247<td>

2248No distant metastasis.</td>

2249</tr>

2250<tr>

2251<td colspan="2">

2252M1</td>

2253<td>

2254Distant metastasis.</td>

2255</tr>

2256<tr>

2257<td>

2258&#160;</td>

2259<td>

2260M1a</td>

2261<td>

2262Separate tumor nodule(s) in a contralateral lobe; tumor with pleural or pericardial nodules or malignant pleural or pericardial effusion. Most pleural (pericardial) effusions with lung cancer are a result of the tumor. In a few patients, however, multiple microscopic examinations of pleural (pericardial) fluid are negative for tumor, and the fluid is nonbloody and not an exudate. If these elements and clinical judgment dictate that the effusion is not related to the tumor, the effusion should be excluded as a staging descriptor.</td>

2263</tr>

2264<tr>

2265<td>

2266&#160;</td>

2267<td>

2268M1b</td>

2269<td>

2270Single extrathoracic metastases in a single organ (including involvement of a single nonregional node).</td>

2271</tr>

2272<tr>

2273<td>

2274&#160;</td>

2275<td>

2276M1c</td>

2277<td>

2278Multiple extrathoracic metastases in a single organ or in multiple organs.</td>

2279</tr>

2280</tbody>

2281</table>

2282<table id="_485773" class="table-default expandable-container">

2283<caption>

2284Table 4. AJCC Prognostic Stage Groups for Lung Cancer<span class="sup">

2285a</span>

2286</caption>

2287<colgroup>

2288<col width="33.33%">

2289<col width="33.33%">

2290<col width="33.33%">

2291</colgroup>

2292<THead>

2293<tr>

2294<th>

2295Stage</th>

2296<th>

2297TNM Classification</th>

2298<th>

2299Illustration</th>

2300</tr>

2301</THead>

2302<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2303<tr>

2304<td colspan="3">

2305T = primary tumor; N = regional lymph node; M = distant metastasis.</td>

2306</tr>

2307<tr>

2308<td colspan="3">

2309<span class="sup">

2310a</span>

2311Reprinted with permission from AJCC: Lung. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2312AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2313. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 431&#8211;56.</td>

2314</tr>

2319Occult carcinoma</td>

2321TX, N0, M0</td>

2323&#160;</td>

2369<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/794784.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2370Enlarge</a>

2371<img id="_485549" alt="Two-panel drawing of stage IB lung cancer; the panel on the left shows a tumor (larger than 3 cm but not larger than 4 cm) in the right lung. Also shown are the pleura and diaphragm. The panel on the right shows a primary tumor (4 cm or smaller) in the left lung and cancer in (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the inner membrane covering the lung (inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina and a rib (inset) are also shown." title="Two-panel drawing of stage IB lung cancer; the panel on the left shows a tumor (larger than 3 cm but not larger than 4 cm) in the right lung. Also shown are the pleura and diaphragm. The panel on the right shows a primary tumor (4 cm or smaller) in the left lung and cancer in (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the inner membrane covering the lung (inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina and a rib (inset) are also shown." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/794784-750.jpg">

2372</figure>

2384<img id="_485550" alt="Stage IIA lung cancer; drawing shows a primary tumor (larger than 4 cm but not larger than 5 cm) in the left lung and cancer in (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the inner membrane covering the lung (inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (inset) are also shown." title="Stage IIA lung cancer; drawing shows a primary tumor (larger than 4 cm but not larger than 5 cm) in the left lung and cancer in (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the inner membrane covering the lung (inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (inset) are also shown." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/520465-750.jpg">

2395<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682110.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2397<img id="_485551" alt="Stage IIB lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the right lung and cancer in lymph nodes in the same lung as the primary tumor. Also shown are the trachea, main bronchus, pleura, and diaphragm." title="Stage IIB lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the right lung and cancer in lymph nodes in the same lung as the primary tumor. Also shown are the trachea, main bronchus, pleura, and diaphragm." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682110-750.jpg">

2398</figure>

2399<figure id="figure_485552" class="image-center">

2400<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795027.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2401Enlarge</a>

2402<img id="_485552" alt="Stage IIB lung cancer (2); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 5 cm but not larger than 7 cm) in the left lung (top inset) and (b) a separate tumor in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (c) the chest wall and the membranes covering the lung and chest wall (middle inset); (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm; and (e) the sac around the heart (bottom inset). The pleura, diaphragm, heart, and a rib (middle inset) are also shown." title="Stage IIB lung cancer (2); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 5 cm but not larger than 7 cm) in the left lung (top inset) and (b) a separate tumor in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (c) the chest wall and the membranes covering the lung and chest wall (middle inset); (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm; and (e) the sac around the heart (bottom inset). The pleura, diaphragm, heart, and a rib (middle inset) are also shown." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795027-750.jpg">

2403</figure>

2428IIIA</td>

2429<td>

2430T1a, N2, M0</td>

2431<td rowspan="8">

2432<figure id="figure_485553" class="image-center">

2433<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/521911.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2434Enlarge</a>

2435<img id="_485553" alt="Stage IIIA lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the left lung (top inset) and cancer in lymph nodes around the trachea. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the membrane covering the lung (bottom inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (bottom inset) are also shown." title="Stage IIIA lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the left lung (top inset) and cancer in lymph nodes around the trachea. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the membrane covering the lung (bottom inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (bottom inset) are also shown." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/521911-750.jpg">

2436</figure>

2437<figure id="figure_485554" class="image-center">

2438<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682116.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2439Enlarge</a>

2440<img id="_485554" alt="Stage IIIA lung cancer (2); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 5 cm but not larger than 7 cm) in the left lung and cancer in lymph nodes in the lung or near the bronchus on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is (b) separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor and cancer that has spread to (c) the chest wall and the membranes covering the lung and chest wall (top right inset); (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm; and (e) the sac around the heart (bottom right inset). The trachea, left main bronchus, diaphragm, heart, and a rib (top right inset) are also shown." title="Stage IIIA lung cancer (2); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 5 cm but not larger than 7 cm) in the left lung and cancer in lymph nodes in the lung or near the bronchus on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is (b) separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung as the primary tumor and cancer that has spread to (c) the chest wall and the membranes covering the lung and chest wall (top right inset); (d) the nerve that controls the diaphragm; and (e) the sac around the heart (bottom right inset). The trachea, left main bronchus, diaphragm, heart, and a rib (top right inset) are also shown." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682116-750.jpg">

2441</figure>

2442<figure id="figure_485555" class="image-center">

2443<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682121.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2444Enlarge</a>

2445<img id="_485555" alt="Stage IIIA lung cancer (3); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 7 cm) in the left lung and (b) separate tumors in a different lobe of the lung with the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer that has spread to the (c) trachea, (d) carina, (e) esophagus, (f) breastbone, (g) diaphragm, (h) heart, and (i) the aorta and vena cava." title="Stage IIIA lung cancer (3); drawing shows (a) a primary tumor (larger than 7 cm) in the left lung and (b) separate tumors in a different lobe of the lung with the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer that has spread to the (c) trachea, (d) carina, (e) esophagus, (f) breastbone, (g) diaphragm, (h) heart, and (i) the aorta and vena cava." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682121-750.jpg">

2446</figure>

2478<td rowspan="7">

2479IIIB</td>

2480<td>

2481T1a, N3, M0</td>

2482<td rowspan="7">

2483<figure id="figure_485556" class="image-center">

2484<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/521915.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2485Enlarge</a>

2486<img id="_485556" alt="Stage IIIB lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the left lung and cancer in lymph nodes above the collarbone on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor and in lymph nodes on the opposite side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the membrane covering the lung. Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (inset) are also shown." title="Stage IIIB lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the left lung and cancer in lymph nodes above the collarbone on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor and in lymph nodes on the opposite side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the membrane covering the lung. Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (inset) are also shown." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/521915-750.jpg">

2487</figure>

2488<figure id="figure_485557" class="image-center">

2489<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682124.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2490Enlarge</a>

2491<img id="_485557" alt="Stage IIIB lung cancer (2); drawing shows a primary tumor in the left lung and (a) a separate tumor in a different lobe of the lung with the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer in lymph nodes on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. The lymph nodes with cancer are around the trachea or where the trachea divides into the bronchi. Also shown is (b) cancer that has spread to the following: the chest wall and the lining of the chest wall and lung, the nerve that controls the voice box, the trachea, the carina, the esophagus, the breastbone, the diaphragm, the nerve that controls the diaphragm, the aorta and vena cava, the heart, and the sac around the heart." title="Stage IIIB lung cancer (2); drawing shows a primary tumor in the left lung and (a) a separate tumor in a different lobe of the lung with the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer in lymph nodes on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. The lymph nodes with cancer are around the trachea or where the trachea divides into the bronchi. Also shown is (b) cancer that has spread to the following: the chest wall and the lining of the chest wall and lung, the nerve that controls the voice box, the trachea, the carina, the esophagus, the breastbone, the diaphragm, the nerve that controls the diaphragm, the aorta and vena cava, the heart, and the sac around the heart." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/682124-750.jpg">

2492</figure>

2493</td>

2525<figure id="figure_485558" class="image-center">

2526<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/796021.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2527Enlarge</a>

2528<img id="_485558" alt="Stage IIIC lung cancer; drawing shows a primary tumor in the left lung and (a) separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung with the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer in lymph nodes above the collarbone on the same side and opposite side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is (b) cancer that has spread to the following: the chest wall and the lining of the chest wall and lung, the nerve that controls the voice box, the trachea, the carina, the esophagus, the breastbone, the diaphragm, the nerve that controls the diaphragm, the heart, the aorta and vena cava, and the sac around the heart." title="Stage IIIC lung cancer; drawing shows a primary tumor in the left lung and (a) separate tumors in the same lobe of the lung with the primary tumor. Also shown is cancer in lymph nodes above the collarbone on the same side and opposite side of the chest as the primary tumor. Also shown is (b) cancer that has spread to the following: the chest wall and the lining of the chest wall and lung, the nerve that controls the voice box, the trachea, the carina, the esophagus, the breastbone, the diaphragm, the nerve that controls the diaphragm, the heart, the aorta and vena cava, and the sac around the heart." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/796021-750.jpg">

2546IVA</td>

2547<td>

2548Any T, Any N, M1a</td>

2549<td rowspan="2">

2550<figure id="figure_485559" class="image-center">

2551<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/794785.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2552Enlarge</a>

2553<img id="_485559" alt="Stage IVA lung cancer; drawing shows a primary tumor in the right lung and (a) a tumor in the left lung. Also shown is (b) fluid or cancer nodules around the lungs or heart (inset), and (c) other organs or tissues where lung cancer may spread, including the brain, adrenal gland, kidney, liver, bone, and distant lymph nodes." title="Stage IVA lung cancer; drawing shows a primary tumor in the right lung and (a) a tumor in the left lung. Also shown is (b) fluid or cancer nodules around the lungs or heart (inset), and (c) other organs or tissues where lung cancer may spread, including the brain, adrenal gland, kidney, liver, bone, and distant lymph nodes." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/794785-750.jpg">

2554</figure>

2555</td>

2561<tr>

2562<td>

2563IVB</td>

2564<td>

2565Any T, Any N, M1c</td>

2566<td>

2567<figure id="figure_485560" class="image-center">

2568<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/521926.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2569Enlarge</a>

2570<img id="_485560" alt="Stage IVB lung cancer; drawing shows a primary cancer in the right lung and other parts of the body where lung cancer may spread, including the brain, adrenal gland, kidney, liver, distant lymph nodes, and bone. An inset shows cancer cells spreading from the lung, through the blood and lymph system, to another part of the body where metastatic cancer has formed." title="Stage IVB lung cancer; drawing shows a primary cancer in the right lung and other parts of the body where lung cancer may spread, including the brain, adrenal gland, kidney, liver, distant lymph nodes, and bone. An inset shows cancer cells spreading from the lung, through the blood and lymph system, to another part of the body where metastatic cancer has formed." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/521926-750.jpg">

2571</figure>

2572</td>

2576</section>
