2611</li>

2612<li id="section_3.9">

2613Scott WJ, Shepherd J, Gambhir SS: Cost-effectiveness of FDG-PET for staging non-small cell lung cancer: a decision analysis. Ann Thorac Surg 66 (6): 1876-83; discussion 1883-5, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9930463&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9930463&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2614[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2615</li>

2616<li id="section_3.10">

2617Gambhir SS, Hoh CK, Phelps ME, et al.: Decision tree sensitivity analysis for cost-effectiveness of FDG-PET in the staging and management of non-small-cell lung carcinoma. J Nucl Med 37 (9): 1428-36, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8790186&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8790186&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2618[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2619</li>

2620<li id="section_3.11">

2621van Tinteren H, Hoekstra OS, Smit EF, et al.: Effectiveness of positron emission tomography in the preoperative assessment of patients with suspected non-small-cell lung cancer: the PLUS multicentre randomised trial. Lancet 359 (9315): 1388-93, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11978336&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11978336&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2622[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2623</li>

2624<li id="section_3.12">

2625Viney RC, Boyer MJ, King MT, et al.: Randomized controlled trial of the role of positron emission tomography in the management of stage I and II non-small-cell lung cancer. J Clin Oncol 22 (12): 2357-62, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15197196&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15197196&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2626[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2627</li>

2628<li id="section_3.13">

2629Vansteenkiste JF, Stroobants SG, De Leyn PR, et al.: Lymph node staging in non-small-cell lung cancer with FDG-PET scan: a prospective study on 690 lymph node stations from 68 patients. J Clin Oncol 16 (6): 2142-9, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9626214&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9626214&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2630[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2631</li>

2632<li id="section_3.14">

2633Roberts PF, Follette DM, von Haag D, et al.: Factors associated with false-positive staging of lung cancer by positron emission tomography. Ann Thorac Surg 70 (4): 1154-9; discussion 1159-60, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11081861&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11081861&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2634[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2635</li>

2636<li id="section_3.15">

2637Liewald F, Grosse S, Storck M, et al.: How useful is positron emission tomography for lymphnode staging in non-small-cell lung cancer? Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 48 (2): 93-6, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11028710&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11028710&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2638[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2639</li>

2640<li id="section_3.16">

2641Yokoi K, Kamiya N, Matsuguma H, et al.: Detection of brain metastasis in potentially operable non-small cell lung cancer: a comparison of CT and MRI. Chest 115 (3): 714-9, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10084481&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10084481&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2642[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2643</li>

2644<li id="section_3.17">

2645Mountain CF: Revisions in the International System for Staging Lung Cancer. Chest 111 (6): 1710-7, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9187198&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9187198&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2646[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2647</li>

2648<li id="section_3.18">

2649Lung. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. 8th ed. Springer; 2017, pp. 431&#8211;56.</li>

2650</ol>

2651</div>

2652

2653 </section>

2654

2655

2656

2657 <section id="_514">

2658

2659 <h2>

2660Treatment Option Overview for NSCLC</h2>

2661

2662 <div id="_section_514" class="pdq-sections">

2663<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

2664<h6>

2665In This Section</h6>

2666<ul>

2667<li>

2668<a href="#_TrialSearch_514_sid_4_toc">

2669Current Clinical Trials</a>

2670</li>

2671</ul>

2672</nav>

2673<p id="_515" tabindex="-1">

2674In non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), results of standard treatment are poor

2675except for the most localized cancers. All newly diagnosed patients with NSCLC

2676are potential candidates for studies evaluating new forms of treatment.

2677</p>

2678<p id="_485762" tabindex="-1">

2679Treatment decisions are based on some of the following factors:</p>

2680<div class="pdq-content-list">

2681<ul id="_485763">

2682<li>

2683Knowledge of histological type.</li>

2684<li>

2685Tumor size and location.</li>

2686<li>

2687Involvement of pleura.</li>

2688<li>

2689Surgical margins.</li>

2690<li>

2691Status and location of lymph nodes by station.</li>

2692<li>

2693Tumor grade.</li>

2694<li>

2695Lymphovascular invasion.</li>

2696</ul>

2697</div>

2698<p id="_516" tabindex="-1">

2699Surgery is potentially the most curative therapeutic option for this disease. Postoperative chemotherapy may provide an additional benefit to patients with resected NSCLC. Radiation therapy combined with chemotherapy can produce a cure in a small number of patients and can provide palliation in most patients. Prophylactic cranial irradiation may reduce the incidence of brain metastases, but there is no evidence of a survival benefit and the effect of prophylactic cranial irradiation on quality of life is not known.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

27001</a>

2701,<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

27022</a>

2703] In patients with advanced-stage disease, chemotherapy or epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) kinase inhibitors offer modest

2704improvements in median survival, although overall survival is poor.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

27053</a>

2706,<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

27074</a>

2708] </p>

2709<p id="_517" tabindex="-1">

2710Chemotherapy has produced short-term improvement in

2711disease-related symptoms in patients with advanced NSCLC. Several clinical trials have attempted to assess the impact of chemotherapy on tumor-related symptoms and quality of life. In total, these studies suggest that tumor-related symptoms may be controlled by chemotherapy without adversely affecting overall quality of life;[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

27125</a>

2713,<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

27146</a>

2715] however, the impact of chemotherapy on quality of life requires more

2716study.

2717 In general, medically eligible older patients with good performance status obtain the same benefits from treatment as younger patients. </p>

2718<p id="_484309" tabindex="-1">

2719The identification of gene mutations in lung cancer has led to the development of molecularly targeted therapy to improve the survival of subsets of patients with metastatic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

27207</a>

2721] In particular, genetic abnormalities in <em class="gene-name">

2722EGFR</em>

2723, <em class="gene-name">

2724MAPK</em>

2725, and <em class="gene-name">

2726PI3K</em>

2727 signaling pathways in subsets of NSCLC may define mechanisms of drug sensitivity and primary or acquired resistance to kinase inhibitors. <em class="gene-name">

2728EGFR</em>

2729 mutations strongly predict the improved response rate and progression-free survival of inhibitors of EGFR. Fusions of <em class="gene-name">

2730ALK</em>

2731 with <em class="gene-name">

2732EML4</em>

2733 and other genes form translocation products that occur in ranges from 3% to 7% in unselected NSCLC and are responsive to pharmacological inhibition of ALK by agents such as alectinib. The <em class="gene-name">

2734MET</em>

2735 oncogene encodes hepatocyte growth factor receptor. Amplification of this gene has been associated with secondary resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Recurrent fusions involving the <em class="gene-name">

2736ROS1</em>

2737 gene are observed in up to 2% of NSCLCs and are responsive to treatment with crizotinib and entrectinib. <em class="gene-name">

2738NTRK</em>

2739 gene fusions can occur in up to 1% of NSCLCs and can be treated with the TRK inhibitors, larotrectinib and entrectinib. For more information, see the <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484301">

2740Molecular Features</a>

2741 section.</p>

2742<p id="_48598" tabindex="-1">

2743The treatment options for each stage of NSCLC are presented in <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485436">

2744Table 5</a>

2745.</p>

2746<table id="_485436" class="table-default expandable-container">

2747<caption>

2748Table 5. Treatment Options for NSCLC</caption>

2749<colgroup>

2750<col width="28.57%">

2751<col width="22.32%">

2752<col width="49.10%">

2753</colgroup>

2754<THead>

2755<tr>

2756<th colspan="2" align="Center" scope="col">

2757Stage (<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_510">

2758TNM Definitions</a>

2759)</th>

2760<th align="Center" scope="col">

2761Treatment Options </th>

2762</tr>

2763</THead>

2861<tr>

2990RET</em>

3090HER2</em>

3098</tr>

3099<tr>

3100<td>

3101<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485692">

3102Everolimus</a>

3103 (for patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional, neuroendocrine tumors)</td>

3104</tr>

3105</tbody>

3106</table>

3107<p id="_48571" tabindex="-1">

3108In addition to the treatment options presented in Table 5, treatment options under clinical evaluation include the following:</p>

3109<div class="pdq-content-list">

3110<ul id="_495">

3111<li>

3112Combining local treatment (surgery).</li>

3113<li>

3114Regional

3115treatment (radiation therapy).</li>

3116<li>

3117Systemic treatments (chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and targeted agents).</li>

3118<li>

3119Developing more effective systemic therapy.</li>

3120</ul>

3121</div>

3122<section id="_TrialSearch_514_sid_4">

3123<h3 id="_TrialSearch_514_sid_4_toc">

3124Current Clinical Trials</h3>

3125<p id="_TrialSearch_514_22" tabindex="-1">

3126Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

3127advanced clinical trial search</a>

3128 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

3129General information</a>

3130 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

3131</section>

3132<h6 do-not-show="toc">

3133References</h6>

3134<ol>

3135<li id="section_4.1">

3136Lester JF, MacBeth FR, Coles B: Prophylactic cranial irradiation for preventing brain metastases in patients undergoing radical treatment for non-small-cell lung cancer: a Cochrane Review. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 63 (3): 690-4, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15913909&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15913909&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3137[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3138</li>

3139<li id="section_4.2">

3140P&#246;ttgen C, Eberhardt W, Grannass A, et al.: Prophylactic cranial irradiation in operable stage IIIA non small-cell lung cancer treated with neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy: results from a German multicenter randomized trial. J Clin Oncol 25 (31): 4987-92, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17971598&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17971598&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3141[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3142</li>

3153[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3161[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3162</li>

3163</ol>

3164</div>

3165

3166 </section>

3167

3168

3169

3170 <section id="_524">

3171

3172 <h2>

3173Treatment of Occult NSCLC</h2>

3174

3175 <div id="_section_524" class="pdq-sections">

3176<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

3177<h6>

3178In This Section</h6>

3179<ul>

3180<li>

3181<a href="#_484546_toc">

3182Treatment Options for Occult NSCLC</a>

3183</li>

3184<li>

3185<a href="#_TrialSearch_524_sid_5_toc">

3186Current Clinical Trials</a>

3187</li>

3188</ul>

3189</nav>

3190<p id="_525" tabindex="-1">

3191In occult lung cancer, a diagnostic evaluation often includes chest x-ray and

3192selective bronchoscopy with close follow-up (e.g., computed tomography scan),

3193when needed, to define the site and nature of the primary tumor; tumors

3194discovered in this fashion are generally early stage and curable by surgery.</p>

3195<p id="_48509" tabindex="-1">

3196After discovery of the primary tumor, treatment involves establishing

3197the stage of the tumor. Therapy is identical to that recommended for other non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients with similar-stage disease.

3198</p>

3199<section id="_484546">

3200<h3 id="_484546_toc">

3201Treatment Options for Occult NSCLC</h3>

3202<p id="_484547" tabindex="-1">

3203Treatment options for <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

3204occult NSCLC</a>

3205 include the following:</p>

3206<div class="pdq-content-list">

3207<ol id="_484548">

3208<li>

3209Surgery.</li>

3210</ol>

3211</div>

3212</section>

3213<section id="_TrialSearch_524_sid_5">

3214<h3 id="_TrialSearch_524_sid_5_toc">

3215Current Clinical Trials</h3>

3216<p id="_TrialSearch_524_22" tabindex="-1">

3217Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

3218advanced clinical trial search</a>

3219 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

3220General information</a>

3221 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

3222</section>

3223</div>

3224

3225 </section>

3226

3227

3228

3229 <section id="_526">

3230

3231 <h2>

3232Treatment of Stage 0 NSCLC</h2>

3233

3234 <div id="_section_526" class="pdq-sections">

3235<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

3236<h6>

3237In This Section</h6>

3238<ul>

3239<li>

3240<a href="#_48544_toc">

3241Treatment Options for Stage 0 NSCLC<ul>

3242<li>

3243<a href="#_531_toc">

3244Surgery</a>

3245</li>

3246<li>

3247<a href="#_535_toc">

3248Endobronchial therapies </a>

3249</li>

3250</ul>

3251</a>

3252</li>

3253<li>

3254<a href="#_TrialSearch_526_sid_6_toc">

3255Current Clinical Trials</a>

3256</li>

3257</ul>

3258</nav>

3259<p id="_528" tabindex="-1">

3260Stage 0 non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) frequently progresses to invasive cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

32611</a>

3262-<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

32633</a>

3264] Patients may be offered surveillance bronchoscopies and, if lesions are detected, potentially curative therapies.</p>

3265<section id="_48544">

3266<h3 id="_48544_toc">

3267Treatment Options for Stage 0 NSCLC</h3>

3268<p id="_48575" tabindex="-1">

3269Treatment options for <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

3270stage 0 NSCLC</a>

3271 include the following:</p>

3272<div class="pdq-content-list">

3273<ol id="_530">

3274<li>

3275<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_531">

3276Surgery</a>

3277.</li>

3278<li>

3279<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_535">

3280Endobronchial therapies</a>

3281, including photodynamic therapy, electrocautery, cryotherapy, and neodymium-doped yttrium aluminum garnet (Nd-YAG) laser therapy.</li>

3282</ol>

3283</div>

3284<section id="_531">

3285<h4 id="_531_toc">

3286Surgery</h4>

3287<p id="_532" tabindex="-1">

3288Segmentectomy or wedge resection are used to preserve maximum normal pulmonary tissue because patients with stage 0 NSCLC are at a high risk of second lung cancers. Because these tumors are by definition noninvasive and incapable of metastasizing, they should be curable with surgical resection; however, such lesions, when identified, are often centrally located and may require a lobectomy. </p>

3289</section>

3290<section id="_535">

3291<h4 id="_535_toc">

3292Endobronchial therapies </h4>

3293<p id="_5360" tabindex="-1">

3294Patients with central lesions may be candidates for curative endobronchial therapy. Endobronchial therapies that preserve lung function include photodynamic therapy, electrocautery, cryotherapy, and Nd-YAG laser therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

32953</a>

3296-<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

32976</a>

3298]</p>

3299<p id="_5370" tabindex="-1">

3300Evidence (endobronchial therapies):</p>

3301<div class="pdq-content-list">

3302<ol id="_5380">

3303<li>

3304Small case series have reported high complete response rates and long-term survival in selected patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

33057</a>

3306,<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

33078</a>

3308][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3309Level of evidence C2</a>

3310]</li>

3311</ol>

3312</div>

3313<p id="_5390" tabindex="-1">

3314 Efficacy of these treatment modalities in the management of patients with early

3315NSCLC remains to be proven in definitive randomized controlled trials.</p>

3316<p id="_5400" tabindex="-1">

3317A high incidence of second primary cancers develop in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

33181</a>

3319,<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

33202</a>

3321]</p>

3322</section>

3323</section>

3324<section id="_TrialSearch_526_sid_6">

3325<h3 id="_TrialSearch_526_sid_6_toc">

3326Current Clinical Trials</h3>

3327<p id="_TrialSearch_526_22" tabindex="-1">

3328Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

3329advanced clinical trial search</a>

3330 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

3331General information</a>

3332 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

3333</section>

3334<h6 do-not-show="toc">

3335References</h6>

3336<ol>

Mayo Clin Proc 59 (7): 453-66, 1984.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=6738113&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=6738113&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3348</li>

3351[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3352</li>

3353<li id="section_6.5">

3355[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3356</li>

3357<li id="section_6.6">

Chest 120 (1): 26-31, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11451811&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11451811&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3359[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3360</li>

3361<li id="section_6.7">

3363[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3364</li>

3365<li id="section_6.8">

3366van Boxem AJ, Westerga J, Venmans BJ, et al.: Photodynamic therapy, Nd-YAG laser and electrocautery for treating early-stage intraluminal cancer: which to choose? Lung Cancer 31 (1): 31-6, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11162864&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11162864&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3367[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3368</li>

3369</ol>

3370</div>

3371

3372 </section>

3373

3374

3375

3376 <section id="_544">

3377

3378 <h2>

3379Treatment of Stages IA and IB NSCLC</h2>

3380

3381 <div id="_section_544" class="pdq-sections">

3382<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

3383<h6>

3384In This Section</h6>

3385<ul>

3386<li>

3387<a href="#_48545_toc">

3388Treatment Options for Stages IA and IB NSCLC<ul>

3389<li>

3390<a href="#_549_toc">

3391Surgery</a>

3392</li>

3393<li>

3394<a href="#_484247_toc">

3395Adjuvant therapy</a>

3396</li>

3397<li>

3398<a href="#_579_toc">

3399Radiation therapy</a>

3400</li>

3401</ul>

3402</a>

3403</li>

3404<li>

3405<a href="#_TrialSearch_544_sid_7_toc">

3406Current Clinical Trials</a>

3407</li>

3408</ul>

3409</nav>

3410<section id="_48545">

3411<h3 id="_48545_toc">

3412Treatment Options for Stages IA and IB NSCLC</h3>

3413<p id="_48576" tabindex="-1">

3414Treatment options for <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

3415stages IA non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)</a>

3416 and <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

3417IB NSCLC</a>

3418 include the following:</p>

3419<div class="pdq-content-list">

3420<ol id="_546">

3421<li>

3422<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_549">

3423Surgery</a>

3424.</li>

3425<li>

3426<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484247">

3427Adjuvant therapy</a>

3428.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3429<ul id="_485811">

3430<li>

3431 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485812">

3432Adjuvant chemotherapy</a>

3433 (for patients with large stage IB tumors).</li>

3434<li>

3435 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485698">

3436Adjuvant targeted therapy</a>

3437 (for patients with stage IB tumors with <em class="gene-name">

3438EGFR</em>

3439 mutations).</li>

3440</ul>

3441</div>

3442</li>

3443<li>

3444<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_579">

3445Radiation therapy</a>

3446 (for patients who cannot have surgery or choose not to have surgery).</li>

3447</ol>

3448</div>

3449<p id="_484327" tabindex="-1">

3450Chemotherapy and radiation therapy have not been shown to improve survival in patients with stage I NSCLC that has been completely resected.</p>

3451<section id="_549">

3452<h4 id="_549_toc">

3453Surgery</h4>

3454<p id="_550" tabindex="-1">

3455Surgery is the treatment of choice for patients with stage I NSCLC. A lobectomy or segmental, wedge, or sleeve resection may be performed as appropriate. Patients

3456with impaired pulmonary function are candidates for segmental or wedge

3457resection of the primary tumor. Careful preoperative assessment of the patient&#8217;s overall

3458medical condition, especially the patient&#8217;s pulmonary reserve, is critical in

3459considering the benefits of surgery. The immediate postoperative mortality

3460rate is age related, but a 3% to 5% mortality rate with lobectomy can be expected.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

34611</a>

3462]</p>

3463<p id="_556" tabindex="-1">

3464Evidence (surgery):</p>

3465<div class="pdq-content-list">

3466<ol id="_557">

3467<li>

3468The Lung Cancer Study Group conducted a

3469randomized study (LCSG-821) that compared lobectomy with limited resection for

3470patients with stage I lung cancer. Results of the study showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

34712</a>

3472]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3473<ul id="_484352">

3474<li>

3475A

3476reduction in local recurrence for patients treated with lobectomy compared with

3477those treated with limited excision.</li>

3478<li>

3479No significant difference in overall

3480survival (OS).</li>

3481</ul>

3482</div>

3483</li>

3484<li>

3485Similar results were reported from a nonrandomized

3486comparison of anatomic segmentectomy and lobectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

34873</a>

3488]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3489<ul id="_484353">

3490<li>

3491A survival advantage

3492was noted with lobectomy for patients with tumors larger than 3 cm

3493but not for those with tumors smaller than 3 cm.</li>

3494<li>

3495The rate of

3496locoregional recurrence was significantly less after lobectomy, regardless of

3497primary tumor size.</li>

3498</ul>

3499</div>

3500</li>

3501<li>

3502A study of stage I patients showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

35034</a>

3504]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3505<ul id="_484354">

3506<li>

3507Those treated with wedge or segmental resections had a local recurrence rate of 50% (i.e., 31 recurrences out of 62 patients) despite having undergone complete resections.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

35084</a>

3509]</li>

3510</ul>

3511</div>

3512</li>

3513<li>

3514The Cochrane Collaboration reviewed 11 randomized trials with a total of 1,910 patients who underwent surgical interventions for early-stage (I&#8211;IIIA) lung cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

35155</a>

3516] A pooled analysis of three trials reported the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

3517<ul id="_484355">

3518<li>

3519Four-year survival was superior in patients with resectable stage I, II, or IIIA NSCLC who underwent resection and complete ipsilateral mediastinal lymph node dissection (CMLND), compared with those who underwent resection and lymph node sampling; the hazard ratio (HR) was estimated to be 0.78 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.65&#8211;0.93, <em>

3520P</em>

3521 = .005).[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

35225</a>

3523][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3524Level of evidence A1</a>

3525]</li>

3526<li>

3527There was a significant reduction in any cancer recurrence (local or distant) in the CMLND group (relative risk [RR], 0.79; 95% CI, 0.66&#8211;0.95; <em>

3528P</em>

3529 = .01) that appeared mainly because of a reduction in the number of distant recurrences (RR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.61&#8211;1.00; <em>

3530P</em>

3531 = .05).</li>

3532<li>

3533There was no difference in operative mortality.</li>

3534<li>

3535Air leak lasting more than 5 days was significantly more common in patients assigned to CMLND (RR, 2.94; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;8.54; <em>

3536P</em>

3537 = .05). </li>

3538</ul>

3539</div>

3540</li>

3541<li>

3542CMLND versus lymph node sampling was evaluated in a large, randomized, phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003831">

3543ACOSOG-Z0030</a>

3544 [NCT00003831]).[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

35456</a>

3546,<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

35477</a>

3548]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3549<ul id="_484356">

3550<li>

3551Preliminary analyses of operative morbidity and mortality showed comparable rates from the procedures.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

35526</a>

3553,<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

35547</a>

3555]</li>

3556<li>

3557There was no difference in OS, disease-free survival (DFS), local recurrence, and regional recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

35587</a>

3559][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3560Level of evidence A1</a>

3561]</li>

3562</ul>

3563</div>

3564</li>

3565</ol>

3566</div>

3567<p id="_484616" tabindex="-1">

3568Current evidence suggests that lung cancer resection combined with CMLND is not associated with improvement in survival compared with lung cancer resection combined with systematic sampling of mediastinal lymph nodes in patients with stage I, II, or IIIA NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

35697</a>

3570][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3571Level of evidence A1</a>

3572]</p>

3573<p id="_564" tabindex="-1">

3574Conclusions about the efficacy of surgery for patients with local and locoregional NSCLC are limited by the small number of participants studied to date and the potential methodological weaknesses of the trials.</p>

3575</section>

3576<section id="_484247">

3577<h4 id="_484247_toc">

3578Adjuvant therapy</h4>

3579<p id="_484248" tabindex="-1">

3580Many patients who have surgery subsequently develop regional or distant

3581metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

35828</a>

3583] Such patients are candidates for entry into clinical trials evaluating postoperative treatment with chemotherapy or radiation

3584therapy following surgery. At present, neither chemotherapy nor radiation therapy has been found to improve survival in patients with stage I NSCLC that has been completely resected.</p>

3585<section id="_485812">

3586<h5 id="_485812_toc">

3587Adjuvant chemotherapy</h5>

3588<p id="_485813" tabindex="-1">

3589Based on a meta-analysis, postoperative chemotherapy is not recommended outside of a clinical trial for patients with completely resected stage I NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

35909</a>

3591] However, there may be some benefit of adjuvant chemotherapy in patients with stage IB tumors that are larger than 4 cm.</p>

3592<p id="_485814" tabindex="-1">

3593Evidence (adjuvant chemotherapy for stage IB NSCLC):</p>

3594<div class="pdq-content-list">

3595<ol id="_485815">

3596<li>

3597The Cancer and Leukemia Group B study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002852">

3598CALGB-9633</a>

3599 [NCT00002852]) addressed the results of adjuvant carboplatin and paclitaxel versus observation for OS in 344 patients with resected stage IB (i.e., pathological T2, N0) NSCLC. Within 4 to 8 weeks of resection, patients were randomly assigned to postoperative chemotherapy or observation.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

360010</a>

3601]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3602<ul id="_485816">

3603<li>

3604Survival was not significantly different (HR, 0.83; 90% CI, 0.64&#8211;1.08; <em>

3605P</em>

3606 = .12) at a median follow-up of 74 months.</li>

3607<li>

3608Grades 3 to 4 neutropenia were the predominant toxicity; there were no treatment-related deaths.</li>

3609<li>

3610A post-hoc exploratory analysis demonstrated a significant survival difference in favor of postoperative chemotherapy for patients who had tumors 4 cm or larger in diameter (HR, 0.69; 90% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.99; <em>

3611P</em>

3612 = .043). </li>

3613</ul>

3614</div>

3615</li>

3616</ol>

3617</div>

3618<p id="_485817" tabindex="-1">

3619Given the magnitude of observed survival differences, CALGB-9633 may have been underpowered to detect small but clinically meaningful improvements in survival. In addition, the use of a carboplatin versus a cisplatin combination might have affected the results. At present, there is no reliable evidence that postoperative chemotherapy improves survival of patients with stage IB NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

362010</a>

3621][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3622Level of evidence A1</a>

3623]</p>

3624</section>

3625<section id="_485698">

3626<h5 id="_485698_toc">

3627Adjuvant targeted therapy (for patients with stage IB NSCLC with <em class="gene-name">

3628EGFR</em>

3629 mutations)

3630</h5>

3631<p id="_485699" tabindex="-1">

3632Adjuvant targeted therapy with osimertinib for patients with <em class="gene-name">

3633EGFR</em>

3634-mutated NSCLC and resected stage IB NSCLC was studied in a phase III clinical trial and was found to significantly increase DFS.</p>

3635<p id="_485700" tabindex="-1">

3636Evidence (adjuvant targeted therapy with osimertinib for stage IB <em class="gene-name">

3637EGFR</em>

3638-mutated NSCLC):</p>

3639<div class="pdq-content-list">

3640<ol id="_485701">

3641<li>

3642 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02511106">

3643ADAURA</a>

3644 (NCT02511106) phase III, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial randomly assigned 682 patients with surgically resected stage IB to stage IIIA NSCLC with <em class="gene-name">

3645EGFR</em>

3646-sensitizing mutations (centrally determined, deletion in exon 19 or L858R mutation in exon 21) to receive either osimertinib 80 mg by mouth daily or a placebo for 3 years. Standard postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy was allowed but not mandatory; decisions regarding adjuvant chemotherapy were made by the physician and patient before trial enrollment. The primary end point was DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

364711</a>

3648][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3649Level of evidence B1</a>

3650]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3651<ul id="_485702">

3652<li>

3653 After a planned review by the independent data monitoring committee, the trial was unblinded at the trial level 2 years early because of evidence of an efficacy benefit.</li>

3654<li>

3655 A prespecified hierarchical testing procedure was used in the statistical analysis. If significance was shown for DFS among patients with stage II to stage IIIA disease, then DFS was tested for the entire study population (stages IB&#8722;IIIA). If this result was significant, then OS was tested, although the trial was not powered for OS.</li>

3656<li>

3657 For patients with stage II to stage IIIA disease, the DFS was significantly improved with osimertinib treatment (HR, 0.17; 99.06% CI, 0.11&#8722;0.26; <em>

3658P</em>

3659 &lt; .001).</li>

3660<li>

3661 Osimertinib treatment also improved DFS for the entire study population (stages IB&#8722;IIIA) (HR, 0.20; 99.12% CI, 0.14&#8722;0.30; <em>

3662P</em>

3663 &lt; .001).</li>

3664<li>

3665 Osimertinib treatment improved DFS in all predefined subgroups, including in patients with stage IB disease and in patients who did or did not receive adjuvant chemotherapy. </li>

3666<li>

3667 OS data are immature as of October 29, 2020, and follow-up is ongoing.</li>

3668<li>

3669 The adverse event profile is consistent with other studies that used osimertinib. </li>

3670</ul>

3671</div>

3672</li>

3673</ol>

3674</div>

3675</section>

3676<section id="_484249">

3677<h5 id="_484249_toc">

3678 Adjuvant external radiation therapy </h5>

3679<p id="_484250" tabindex="-1">

3680The value of postoperative (adjuvant) radiation therapy (PORT) has been evaluated and has not been found to improve the outcome of patients with completely resected stage I NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

368112</a>

3682]</p>

3683</section>

3684<section id="_484617">

3685<h5 id="_484617_toc">

3686Adjuvant brachytherapy </h5>

3687<p id="_484618" tabindex="-1">

3688The value of intraoperative (adjuvant) brachytherapy applied to the suture line has been evaluated in patients undergoing sublobar resections for stage I NSCLC to improve local control; it has not been found to improve outcomes. </p>

3689<p id="_484619" tabindex="-1">

3690Evidence (adjuvant brachytherapy):</p>

3691<div class="pdq-content-list">

3692<ol id="_484620">

3693<li>

3694 A phase III trial that randomly assigned 222 patients to undergo sublobar resection with or without suture line brachytherapy reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

369513</a>

3696]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3697<ul id="_484621">

3698<li>

3699 No difference in the primary end point of local recurrence (5-year estimate, 14.0% vs. 16.7%; <em>

3700P</em>

3701 = .59). </li>

3702<li>

3703 No difference in OS rates (5-year estimate, 61.4% vs. 55.6%; <em>

3704P</em>

3705 = .38).[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

370613</a>

3707][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3708Level of evidence B1</a>

3709] vs. [<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3710Level of evidence A1</a>

3711]</li>

3712</ul>

3713</div>

3714</li>

3715</ol>

3716</div>

3717</section>

3718</section>

3719<section id="_579">

3720<h4 id="_579_toc">

3721Radiation therapy</h4>

3722<p id="_580" tabindex="-1">

3723A substantial number of patients are ineligible for standard surgical resection because of comorbid conditions that are associated with unacceptably high perioperative risk. Patients with potentially resectable tumors with medical contraindications to surgery or those with inoperable stage I disease and with sufficient pulmonary reserve

3724may be candidates for radiation therapy with curative intent.[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

372514</a>

3726-<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

372716</a>

3728] Nonrandomized observational studies comparing treatment outcomes associated with resection, radiation therapy, and observation have demonstrated shorter survival times and higher mortality for patients who undergo observation only.[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

372914</a>

3730,<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

373117</a>

3732]</p>

3733<section id="_484570">

3734<h5 id="_484570_toc">

3735Conventional radiation therapy</h5>

3736<p id="_484571" tabindex="-1">

3737Historically, conventional primary radiation therapy consisted of approximately 60 Gy to 70 Gy delivered

3738with megavoltage equipment to the midplane of the known tumor volume using

3739conventional fractionation (1.8&#8211;2.0 Gy per day). </p>

3740<p id="_485650" tabindex="-1">

3741Improvements in radiation techniques include planning techniques to account for tumor motion, more conformal planning techniques (e.g., 3-D conformal radiation therapy and intensity-modulated radiation therapy), and image guidance during treatment. Modern approaches to delivery of external-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) include hypofractionated radiation therapy and stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT). However, there are limited reliable data from comparative trials to determine which approaches yield superior outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

374215</a>

3743,<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

374416</a>

3745]</p>

3746<p id="_484624" tabindex="-1">

3747Evidence (conventional radiation therapy):</p>

3748<div class="pdq-content-list">

3749<ol id="_484625">

3750<li>

3751In the largest retrospective conventional radiation

3752therapy series, patients with inoperable disease were treated with definitive

3753radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

375418</a>

3755-<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

375620</a>

3757] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3758<ul id="_485752">

3759<li>

3760Patients achieved 5-year survival rates of 10% to 30%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

376118</a>

3762-<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

376320</a>

3764]</li>

3765<li>

3766Several

3767series demonstrated that patients with T1, N0 tumors had better outcomes, and 5-year survival rates of 30% to 60% were found in this subgroup.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

376818</a>

3769,<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

377019</a>

3771,<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

377221</a>

3773] </li>

3774<li>

3775However, local-only failure occurs in as many as 50% of patients treated with conventional radiation therapy to doses in the range of 60 Gy to 65 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

377622</a>

3777,<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

377823</a>

3779]</li>

3780</ul>

3781</div>

3782</li>

3783<li>

3784A single

3785report of patients older than 70 years who had resectable lesions

3786 smaller than 4 cm but who had medically inoperable disease or who

3787refused surgery reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

378821</a>

3789]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3790<ul id="_484626">

3791<li>

3792Survival at 5 years after radiation therapy with curative

3793intent was comparable with a historical control group of patients of similar age

3794who were resected with curative intent.</li>

3795</ul>

3796</div>

3797</li>

3798<li>

3799A small case series using matched controls reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

38004</a>

3801]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3802<ul id="_484627">

3803<li>

3804The addition of endobronchial brachytherapy improved local disease control compared with EBRT.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

38054</a>

3806][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3807Level of evidence C2</a>

3808]</li>

3809</ul>

3810</div>

3811</li>

3812</ol>

3813</div>

3814</section>

3815<section id="_484630">

3816<h5 id="_484630_toc">

3817Hypofractionated radiation therapy</h5>

3818<p id="_484631" tabindex="-1">

3819Hypofractionated radiation therapy involves the delivery of a slightly higher dose of radiation therapy per day (e.g., 2.4&#8211;4.0 Gy) over a shorter period of time compared with conventionally fractionated radiation therapy. Multiple prospective phase I/II trials have demonstrated that hypofractionated radiation therapy to a dose of 60 Gy to 70 Gy delivered over 3 to 4 weeks with 2.4 Gy to 4.0 Gy per day resulted in a low incidence of moderate to severe toxicity, 2-year OS rates of 50% to 60%, and 2-year tumor local control of 80% to 90%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

382024</a>

3821-<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

382226</a>

3823][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3824Level of evidence C1</a>

3825]</p>

3826</section>

3827<section id="_484632">

3828<h5 id="_484632_toc">

3829Stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT)</h5>

3830<p id="_484633" tabindex="-1">

3831SBRT involves the delivery of highly conformal, high-dose radiation therapy over an extremely hypofractionated course (e.g., one to five treatments) delivered over 1 to 2 weeks. Commonly used regimens include 18 Gy &#215; 3, 12 Gy to 12.5 Gy &#215; 4, and 10 Gy to 12 Gy &#215; 5, and deliver a substantially higher biologically effective dose compared with historic conventional radiation therapy regimens. </p>

3832<p id="_484634" tabindex="-1">

3833Multiple prospective phase I/II trials and institutional series have demonstrated that SBRT results in a low incidence of pulmonary toxicity (&lt;10% risk of symptomatic radiation pneumonitis), 2-year OS rates of 50% to 60%, and 2-year tumor control of 90% to 95%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

383427</a>

3835-<a href="#cit/section_7.33">

383633</a>

3837][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3838Level of evidence C1</a>

3839]</p>

3840<p id="_484635" tabindex="-1">

3841Evidence (SBRT):</p>

3842<div class="pdq-content-list">

3843<ol id="_484636">

3844<li>

3845Early phase I/II trials from Indiana University identified the maximum tolerated dose of three-fraction SBRT at 18 Gy &#215; 3 for T1 tumors.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3846<ul id="_484637">

3847<li>

3848This regimen resulted in a 2-year OS rate of 55% and 2-year local tumor control of 95%.</li>

3849<li>

3850An unacceptably high incidence (8.6%) of grade 5 toxicity was observed in patients with central tumors (defined as within 2 cm of the tracheobronchial tree from the trachea to the level of the lobar bronchi).[<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

385128</a>

3852]</li>

3853</ul>

3854</div>

3855</li>

3856<li>

3857A subsequent multicenter trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00087438">

3858RTOG-0236</a>

3859 [NCT00087438]) studied the 18 Gy &#215; 3 regimen in 55 patients with peripheral T1 to T2 tumors only.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3860<ul id="_484638">

3861<li>

3862This trial demonstrated a 3-year OS rate of 56% and 3-year primary tumor control of 98%. </li>

3863<li>

3864The incidence of moderate to severe toxicity was low, with grade 3 toxicity in 24% of patients, grade 4 toxicity in 4% of patients, and no grade 5 toxicity, with a 4% incidence of grade 3 radiation pneumonitis.[<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

386532</a>

3866]</li>

3867</ul>

3868</div>

3869</li>

3870<li>

3871In the largest reported series from VU University Medical Center Amsterdam, 676 patients with T1 to T2 tumors were treated with three-, five-, and eight-fraction SBRT using a risk-adapted approach (a tailored fractionation regimen based on tumor proximity to critical organs).<div class="pdq-content-list">

3872<ul id="_484639">

3873<li>

3874With a median follow-up of 32.9 months, the median OS was 40.7 months, and 2-year local tumor control was 95%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.33">

387533</a>

3876]</li>

3877</ul>

3878</div>

3879</li>

3880<li>

3881 While central location is a contraindication to three-fraction SBRT based on data from the Indiana phase II study, a subsequent systematic review of published reports of 315 patients with 563 central tumors demonstrated a much lower incidence of severe toxicity, including a 1% to 5% risk of grade 5 events with more protracted SBRT regimens (e.g., four to ten fractions).[<a href="#cit/section_7.34">

388234</a>

3883] </li>

3884<li>

3885A multicenter phase I/II trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00750269">

3886RTOG-0813</a>

3887 [NCT00750269]) is ongoing to identify the maximum tolerated dose for a five-fraction SBRT regimen for central tumors. </li>

3888</ol>

3889</div>

3890<p id="_484640" tabindex="-1">

3891A randomized trial of hypofractionated radiation therapy versus SBRT (LUSTRE [<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01968941">

3892NCT01968941</a>

3893]) is ongoing to determine the optimal radiation therapy regimen, but SBRT has been widely adopted for patients with medically inoperable stage I NSCLC.</p>

3894</section>

3895</section>

3896</section>

3897<section id="_TrialSearch_544_sid_7">

3898<h3 id="_TrialSearch_544_sid_7_toc">

3899Current Clinical Trials</h3>

3900<p id="_TrialSearch_544_22" tabindex="-1">

3901Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

3902advanced clinical trial search</a>

3903 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

3904General information</a>

3905 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

3906</section>

3907<h6 do-not-show="toc">

3929</li>

Ann Thorac Surg 81 (3): 1013-9; discussion 1019-20, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16488712&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16488712&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3932[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3933</li>

J Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 141 (3): 662-70, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21335122&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21335122&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3936[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3937</li>

3938<li id="section_7.8">

3939Martini N, Bains MS, Burt ME, et al.: Incidence of local recurrence and second primary tumors in resected stage I lung cancer. J Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 109 (1): 120-9, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7815787&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7815787&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3940[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3941</li>
