4050

4051

4052

4053 <section id="_48552">

4054

4055 <h2>

4056Treatment of Stages IIA and IIB NSCLC</h2>

4057

4058 <div id="_section_48552" class="pdq-sections">

4059<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

4060<h6>

4061In This Section</h6>

4062<ul>

4063<li>

4064<a href="#_48546_toc">

4065Treatment Options for Stages IIA and IIB NSCLC<ul>

4066<li>

4067<a href="#_595_toc">

4068Surgery with or without adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy</a>

4069</li>

4070<li>

4071<a href="#_627_toc">

4072Radiation therapy</a>

4073</li>

4074</ul>

4075</a>

4076</li>

4077<li>

4078<a href="#_TrialSearch_48552_sid_8_toc">

4079Current Clinical Trials</a>

4080</li>

4081</ul>

4082</nav>

4083<section id="_48546">

4084<h3 id="_48546_toc">

4085Treatment Options for Stages IIA and IIB NSCLC</h3>

4086<p id="_48578" tabindex="-1">

4087Treatment options for <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

4088stages IIA non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)</a>

4089 and <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

4090IIB NSCLC</a>

4091 include the following:</p>

4092<div class="pdq-content-list">

4093<ol id="_592">

4094<li>

4095<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_595">

4096Surgery with or without adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy</a>

4097.<div class="pdq-content-list">

4098<ul id="_485419">

4099<li>

4100<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485753">

4101Surgery alone</a>

4102.</li>

4103<li>

4104<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485420">

4105Adjuvant chemotherapy</a>

4106.</li>

4107<li>

4108<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485703">

4109Adjuvant targeted therapy</a>

4110 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

4111EGFR</em>

4112 mutations).</li>

4113<li>

4114<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485871">

4115Adjuvant immunotherapy</a>

4116.</li>

4117<li>

4118<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485933">

4119Adjuvant radiation therapy</a>

4120.

4121</li>

4122<li>

4123<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484203">

4124Neoadjuvant chemotherapy</a>

4125.</li>

4126<li>

4127<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485939">

4128Neoadjuvant immunotherapy with chemotherapy</a>

4129.</li>

4130</ul>

4131</div>

4132</li>

4133<li>

4134<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_627">

4135Radiation therapy</a>

4136 (for patients who cannot have surgery).</li>

4137<li>

4138Clinical trials of radiation therapy after curative surgery.</li>

4139</ol>

4140</div>

4141<p id="_484328" tabindex="-1">

4142Adjuvant radiation therapy has not been shown to improve outcomes in patients with stage II NSCLC.</p>

4143<section id="_595">

4144<h4 id="_595_toc">

4145Surgery with or without adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy</h4>

4146<section id="_485753">

4147<h5 id="_485753_toc">

4148Surgery alone</h5>

4149<p id="_485754" tabindex="-1">

4150Surgery is the treatment of choice for patients with stage II NSCLC. A lobectomy, pneumonectomy, segmental resection, wedge resection, or sleeve resection may be performed as appropriate. Careful preoperative assessment of the patient&#8217;s overall

4151medical condition, especially the patient&#8217;s pulmonary reserve, is critical in

4152considering the benefits of surgery. In addition to the immediate and age-related postoperative mortality

4153rate, a 5% to 8% mortality rate with pneumonectomy or a 3% to 5% mortality rate with

4154lobectomy can be expected.

4155</p>

4156<p id="_485755" tabindex="-1">

4157Evidence (surgery):</p>

4158<div class="pdq-content-list">

4159<ol id="_485756">

4160<li>

4161The Cochrane Collaboration reviewed 11 randomized trials with a total of 1,910 patients who underwent surgical interventions for early-stage (I&#8211;IIIA) lung cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

41621</a>

4163] A pooled analysis of three trials reported the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

4164<ul id="_485757">

4165<li>

4166Four-year survival was superior in patients with resectable stage I, II, or IIIA NSCLC who underwent resection and complete ipsilateral mediastinal lymph node dissection (CMLND), compared with those who underwent resection and lymph node sampling; the hazard ratio (HR) was estimated to be 0.78 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.65&#8211;0.93; <em>

4167P</em>

4168 = .005).[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

41691</a>

4170][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4171Level of evidence A1</a>

4172]</li>

4173<li>

4174There was a significant reduction in any cancer recurrence (local or distant) in the CMLND group (relative risk [RR], 0.79; 95% CI, 0.66&#8211;0.95; <em>

4175P</em>

4176 = .01) that appeared mainly as the result of a reduction in the number of distant recurrences (RR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.61&#8211;1.00; <em>

4177P</em>

4178 = .05).</li>

4179<li>

4180There was no difference in operative mortality.</li>

4181<li>

4182Air leak lasting more than 5 days was significantly more common in patients assigned to CMLND (RR, 2.94; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;8.54; <em>

4183P</em>

4184 = .05).</li>

4185</ul>

4186</div>

4187</li>

4188<li>

4189CMLND versus lymph node sampling was evaluated in a large randomized phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003831">

4190ACOSOG-Z0030</a>

4191 [NCT00003831]).[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

41922</a>

4193]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4194<ul id="_485758">

4195<li>

4196Preliminary analyses of operative morbidity and mortality showed comparable rates from the procedures.[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

41972</a>

4198]</li>

4199<li>

4200There was no difference in overall survival (OS), disease-free survival (DFS), local recurrence, and regional recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

42013</a>

4202][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4203Level of evidence A1</a>

4204]</li>

4205</ul>

4206</div>

4207</li>

4208</ol>

4209</div>

4210<p id="_485759" tabindex="-1">

4211Evidence suggests that lung cancer resection combined with CMLND is not associated with improvement in survival compared with lung cancer resection combined with systematic sampling of mediastinal lymph nodes in patients with stage I, II, or IIIA NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

42123</a>

4213][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4214Level of evidence A1</a>

4215]</p>

4216<p id="_604" tabindex="-1">

4217Conclusions about the efficacy of surgery for patients with local and locoregional NSCLC are limited by the small number of participants studied and potential methodological weaknesses of the trials.</p>

4218</section>

4219<section id="_485420">

4220<h5 id="_485420_toc">

4221Adjuvant chemotherapy</h5>

4222<p id="_485421" tabindex="-1">

4223The preponderance of evidence indicates that postoperative cisplatin combination chemotherapy provides a significant survival advantage to patients with resected stage II NSCLC. Preoperative chemotherapy may also provide survival benefit. The optimal sequence of surgery and chemotherapy and the benefits and risks of postoperative radiation therapy in patients with resectable NSCLC remain to be determined. </p>

4224<p id="_485422" tabindex="-1">

4225After surgery, many patients develop regional or distant

4226metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

42274</a>

4228] Several randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses have evaluated the use of postoperative chemotherapy in patients with stage I, II, and IIIA NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

42295</a>

4230-<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

423111</a>

4232]</p>

4233<p id="_485423" tabindex="-1">

4234Evidence (adjuvant chemotherapy):</p>

4235<div class="pdq-content-list">

4236<ol id="_485424">

4237<li>

4238Data on individual patient outcomes were collected and pooled into a meta-analysis from the five largest trials (4,584 patients) of cisplatin-based chemotherapy in patients with completely resected NSCLC that were conducted after 1995.[<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

42397</a>

4240]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4241<ul id="_485425">

4242<li>

4243With a median follow-up time of 5.2 years, the overall HR<sub>

4244death</sub>

4245 was 0.89 (95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.96; <em>

4246P</em>

4247 = .005), corresponding to a 5-year absolute benefit of 5.4% from chemotherapy.</li>

4248<li>

4249The benefit varied with stage (test for trend, <em>

4250P</em>

4251 = .04; HR for stage IA, 1.40; 95% CI, 0.95&#8211;2.06; HR for stage IB, 0.93; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;1.10; HR for stage II, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.95; and HR for stage III, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.72&#8211;0.94).</li>

4252<li>

4253The effect of chemotherapy did not vary significantly (test for interaction, <em>

4254P</em>

4255 = .11) with the associated drugs, including vinorelbine (HR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;0.91), etoposide or vinca alkaloid (HR, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.80&#8211;1.07), or other drugs (HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.13). </li>

4256<li>

4257The greater effect on survival observed with the doublet of cisplatin plus vinorelbine compared with other regimens should be interpreted cautiously as the total dose of cisplatin received was significantly higher in patients treated with vinorelbine.</li>

4258</ul>

4259</div>

4260</li>

4261<li>

4262The meta-analysis [<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

42637</a>

4264] and the individual studies [<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

42655</a>

4266,<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

426712</a>

4268] support the administration of postoperative cisplatin-based chemotherapy in combination with vinorelbine.<div class="pdq-content-list">

4269<ol id="_485426" class="lower-alpha">

4270<li>

4271Superior OS for the trial population and patients with stage II disease was reported for the Lung Adjuvant Cisplatin Evaluation (LACE) pooled analysis (pooled HR, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.95); the Adjuvant Navelbine International Trialist Association (ANITA) trial (HR, 0.71; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;1.03); and the National Cancer Institute of Canada Clinical Trials Group JBR.10 trial (HR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.85).</li>

4272<li>

4273Chemotherapy effect was higher in patients with better performance status.</li>

4274<li>

4275There was no interaction between chemotherapy effect and any of the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

4276<ul id="_485427">

4277<li>

4278Sex.</li>

4279<li>

4280Age.</li>

4281<li>

4282Histology.</li>

4283<li>

4284Type of surgery.</li>

4285<li>

4286Planned radiation therapy.</li>

4287<li>

4288Planned total dose of cisplatin.</li>

4289</ul>

4290</div>

4291</li>

4292</ol>

4293</div>

4294</li>

4295<li>

4296In a retrospective analysis of a phase III trial of postoperative cisplatin and vinorelbine, patients older than 65 years were found to benefit from treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

429713</a>

4298]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4299<ul id="_485428">

4300<li>

4301Chemotherapy significantly prolonged OS for patients older than 65 years (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.38&#8211;0.98; <em>

4302P</em>

4303 = .04).</li>

4304<li>

4305There were no significant differences in toxic effects, hospitalization, or treatment-related death by age group, although patients older than 65 years received less treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

430613</a>

4307]</li>

4308</ul>

4309</div>

4310</li>

4311<li>

4312Several other randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses have evaluated the use of postoperative chemotherapy in patients with stages I, II, and IIIA NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

43135</a>

4314-<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

431511</a>

4316]</li>

4317</ol>

4318</div>

4319<p id="_485429" tabindex="-1">

4320Based on these data, patients with completely resected stage II lung cancer may benefit from postoperative cisplatin-based chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

432113</a>

4322][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4323Level of evidence A1</a>

4324]</p>

4325</section>

4326<section id="_485703">

4327<h5 id="_485703_toc">

4328Adjuvant targeted therapy (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

4329EGFR</em>

4330 mutations)

4331</h5>

4332<p id="_485704" tabindex="-1">

4333Adjuvant targeted therapy with osimertinib for patients with <em class="gene-name">

4334EGFR</em>

4335-mutated NSCLC and resected stage II NSCLC was studied in a phase III clinical trial and was found to significantly increase DFS.</p>

4336<p id="_485705" tabindex="-1">

4337Evidence (adjuvant targeted therapy with osimertinib for stages IIA and IIB <em class="gene-name">

4338EGFR</em>

4339-mutated NSCLC):</p>

4340<div class="pdq-content-list">

4341<ol id="_485706">

4342<li>

4343 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02511106">

4344ADAURA</a>

4345 (NCT02511106) phase III, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial randomly assigned 682 patients with surgically resected stage IB to stage IIIA NSCLC with <em class="gene-name">

4346EGFR</em>

4347-sensitizing mutations (centrally determined, deletion in exon 19 or L858R mutation in exon 21) to receive osimertinib 80 mg by mouth daily or a placebo for 3 years. Standard postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy was allowed but not mandatory; decisions regarding adjuvant chemotherapy were made by the physician and patient before trial enrollment. The primary end point was DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

434814</a>

4349][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4350Level of evidence B1</a>

4351]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4352<ul id="_485707">

4353<li>

4354 After a planned review by the independent data monitoring committee, the trial was unblinded at the trial level 2 years early because of evidence of an efficacy benefit.</li>

4355<li>

4356 A prespecified hierarchical testing procedure was used in the statistical analysis. If significance was shown for DFS among patients with stage II to stage IIIA disease, then DFS was tested for the entire study population (stages IB&#8722;IIIA). If this result was significant, then OS was tested, although the trial was not powered for OS.</li>

4357<li>

4358 For patients with stage II to stage IIIA disease, the DFS was significantly improved with osimertinib treatment (HR, 0.17; 99.06% CI, 0.11&#8722;0.26; <em>

4359P</em>

4360 &lt; .001).</li>

4361<li>

4362 Osimertinib treatment also improved DFS for the entire study population (stages IB&#8722;IIIA) (HR, 0.20; 99.12% CI, 0.14-0.30; <em>

4363P</em>

4364 &lt; .001).</li>

4365<li>

4366 Osimertinib treatment improved DFS in all predefined subgroups, including in patients with stage IB disease and in patients who did or did not receive adjuvant chemotherapy. </li>

4367<li>

4368 OS data are immature as of October 29, 2020, and follow-up is ongoing.</li>

4369<li>

4370 The adverse event profile is consistent with other studies that used osimertinib. </li>

4371</ul>

4372</div>

4373</li>

4374</ol>

4375</div>

4376</section>

4377<section id="_485871">

4378<h5 id="_485871_toc">

4379Adjuvant immunotherapy</h5>

4380<p id="_485872" tabindex="-1">

4381Adjuvant immunotherapy with atezolizumab for patients with resected stage IB to IIIA NSCLC was studied in a phase III clinical trial and was found to significantly increase DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

438215</a>

4383]</p>

4384<p id="_485873" tabindex="-1">

4385Evidence (adjuvant immunotherapy with atezolizumab for stages IIA and IIB NSCLC):</p>

4386<div class="pdq-content-list">

4387<ol id="_485874">

4388<li>

4389 <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02486718">

4390IMpower010</a>

4391 (NCT02486718) was a phase III, multicenter, open-label trial that randomly assigned 1,005 patients with surgically resected stage IB (tumor &gt;4 cm) to stage IIIA NSCLC. Patients received atezolizumab (1,200 mg every 21 days intravenously) or best supportive care for 16 cycles or 1 year after standard adjuvant platinum-based chemotherapy. Patients were enrolled after resection if they were eligible for cisplatin-based chemotherapy and were randomized after completion of chemotherapy if they remained eligible and did not experience disease progression. The primary end point was investigator-assessed DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

439215</a>

4393]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4394<ul id="_485875">

4395<li>

4396 The primary end point was tested hierarchically, first in the stage II to IIIA population subgroup whose tumors expressed PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells (using the SP263 antibody), then in all patients in the stage II to IIIA population, and finally in the intention-to-treat (ITT) population (stage IB to IIIA). Of the 882 patients who were randomly assigned and had stage II to IIIA disease, 476 had tumors expressing PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells per SP263.[<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

439715</a>

4398][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4399Level of evidence B1</a>

4400]</li>

4401<li>

4402 After a median follow-up of 32.2 months, atezolizumab treatment improved DFS compared with best supportive care in patients in the stage II to IIIA population whose tumors expressed PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.50&#8211;0.88; <em>

4403P</em>

4404 = .0039). At 24 months, the DFS rate was 74.6% for the atezolizumab group and 61.0% for the best supportive care group.</li>

4405<li>

4406 Atezolizumab also improved DFS in all patients in the stage II to IIIA population (HR, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;0.96; <em>

4407P</em>

4408 = .020). At 24 months, the DFS rate was 70.2% for the atezolizumab group and 61.6% for the best supportive care group.</li>

4409<li>

4410 In the ITT population, which included patients with stage IB to IIIA disease, HR for DFS was 0.81 (95% CI, 0.67&#8211;0.99; <em>

4411P</em>

4412 = .040). However, the boundary for statistical significance for DFS was not crossed.</li>

4413<li>

4414 OS data are immature.</li>

4415<li>

4416 No new safety signals were noted. </li>

4417</ul>

4418</div>

4419</li>

4420</ol>

4421</div>

4422<p id="_485876" tabindex="-1">

4423Atezolizumab was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for adjuvant treatment of patients with stage II to IIIA NSCLC whose tumors express PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells.</p>

4424</section>

4425<section id="_485933">

4426<h5 id="_485933_toc">

4427Adjuvant radiation therapy</h5>

4428<p id="_485934" tabindex="-1">

4429The value of postoperative (adjuvant) radiation therapy (PORT) has been evaluated.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

443016</a>

4431]</p>

4432<p id="_485935" tabindex="-1">

4433Evidence (adjuvant radiation therapy):</p>

4434<div class="pdq-content-list">

4435<ol id="_485936">

4436<li>

4437A meta-analysis, based on the results of ten randomized controlled trials and 2,232 individuals, reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

443816</a>

4439]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4440<ul id="_485937">

4441<li>

4442An 18% relative increase in the risk of death for patients who received PORT compared with surgery alone (HR, 1.18; <em>

4443P</em>

4444 = .002). This is equivalent to an absolute detriment of 6% at 2 years (95% CI, 2%&#8211;9%), reducing OS from 58% to 52%. Exploratory subgroup analyses suggested that this detrimental effect was most pronounced for patients with stage I/II, N0 to N1 disease, whereas for patients with stage III, N2 disease there was no clear evidence of an adverse effect.</li>

4445<li>

4446Results for local (HR, 1.13; <em>

4447P</em>

4448 = .02), distant (HR, 1.14; <em>

4449P</em>

4450 = .02), and overall (HR, 1.10; <em>

4451P</em>

4452 = .06) recurrence-free survival similarly showed a detriment of PORT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

445316</a>

4454][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4455Level of evidence A1</a>

4456]</li>

4457</ul>

4458</div>

4459</li>

4460</ol>

4461</div>

4462<p id="_485938" tabindex="-1">

4463Further analysis is needed to determine whether these outcomes can potentially be modified with technical improvements,

4464better definitions of target volumes, and limitation of cardiac volume in the

4465radiation portals.</p>

4466</section>

4467<section id="_484203">

4468<h5 id="_484203_toc">

4469Neoadjuvant chemotherapy</h5>

4470<p id="_484204" tabindex="-1">

4471The role of chemotherapy before surgery was tested in clinical trials. The proposed benefits of preoperative chemotherapy include the following:</p>

4472<div class="pdq-content-list">

4473<ul id="_484205">

4474<li>

4475A reduction in tumor size that may facilitate surgical resection.</li>

4476<li>

4477Early eradication of micrometastases.</li>

4478<li>

4479Better tolerability. </li>

4480</ul>

4481</div>

4482<p id="_484206" tabindex="-1">

4483Preoperative chemotherapy may, however, delay potentially curative surgery.</p>

4484<p id="_484207" tabindex="-1">

4485Evidence (neoadjuvant chemotherapy):</p>

4486<div class="pdq-content-list">

4487<ol id="_484208">

4488<li>

4489The Cochrane Collaboration reported a systematic review and meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials that included 988 patients and evaluated the addition of preoperative chemotherapy to surgery versus surgery alone. These trials evaluated patients with stages I, II, and IIIA NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_8.17">

449017</a>

4491]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4492<ul id="_484363">

4493<li>

4494Preoperative chemotherapy provided an absolute benefit in survival of 6% across all stages of disease, from 14% to 20% at 5 years (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;0.97; <em>

4495P</em>

4496 = .022).[<a href="#cit/section_8.17">

449717</a>

4498][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4499Level of evidence A1</a>

4500]</li>

4501<li>

4502This analysis was unable to address questions such as whether particular types of patients may benefit more or less from preoperative chemotherapy.</li>

4503</ul>

4504</div>

4505</li>

4506<li>

4507In the largest trial reported to date, 519 patients were randomly assigned to receive either surgery alone or three cycles of platinum-based chemotherapy followed by surgery. Most patients (61%) had clinical stage I disease; 31% had stage II disease; and 7% had stage III disease.[<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

450818</a>

4509]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4510<ul id="_484364">

4511<li>

4512No survival advantage was seen.[<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

451318</a>

4514]</li>

4515<li>

4516Postoperative complications were similar between groups, and no impairment of quality of life was observed.</li>

4517<li>

4518There was no evidence of a benefit in terms of OS (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.80&#8211;1.31; <em>

4519P</em>

4520 = .86).</li>

4521<li>

4522Updating the systematic review by addition of the present result suggests a 12% relative survival benefit with the addition of neoadjuvant (preoperative) chemotherapy (1,507 patients; HR, 0.88; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;1.01; <em>

4523P</em>

4524 = .07), equivalent to an absolute improvement in survival of 5% at 5 years.</li>

4525</ul>

4526</div>

4527</li>

4528</ol>

4529</div>

4530</section>

4531<section id="_485939">

4532<h5 id="_485939_toc">

4533Neoadjuvant immunotherapy with chemotherapy</h5>

4534<p id="_485940" tabindex="-1">

4535The CheckMate 816 trial evaluated the combination of nivolumab (an anti-programmed death 1 antibody) and platinum-based chemotherapy as neoadjuvant therapy in patients with resectable (&#8805;4 cm or node positive) NSCLC. Nivolumab therapy improved event-free survival (EFS) and pathological complete response rates compared with chemotherapy alone.</p>

4536<p id="_485941" tabindex="-1">

4537Evidence (neoadjuvant immunotherapy with platinum-based chemotherapy):</p>

4538<div class="pdq-content-list">

4539<ol id="_485942">

4540<li>

4541 <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02998528">

4542CheckMate 816</a>

4543 (NCT02998528) was a phase III open-label trial that enrolled 358 patients with resectable stage IB to stage IIIA NSCLC. Notably, patients with stage IB disease had tumors measuring at least 4 cm and were classified according to the AJCC 7th edition staging criteria used for this trial; these tumors are now classified as stage IIA according to the AJCC 8th edition staging criteria. Patients were randomly assigned to receive nivolumab (360 mg) in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy or platinum-doublet chemotherapy alone every 3 weeks for three cycles before undergoing definitive surgery. The primary end points were EFS (defined as the time from randomization to any progression of disease precluding surgery, progression or recurrence of disease after surgery, progression of disease in the absence of surgery, or death from any cause) and pathological complete response (defined as 0% residual viable tumor cells in the primary tumor and sampled lymph nodes) according to blinded independent central review.[<a href="#cit/section_8.19">

454419</a>

4545][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4546Level of evidence B1</a>

4547]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4548<ul id="_485943">

4549<li>

4550 With a minimum follow-up of 21 months, the median EFS was 31.6 months (95% CI, 30.2&#8211;not reached) in the nivolumab-plus-chemotherapy group and 20.8 months (95% CI, 14.0&#8211;26.7) in the chemotherapy-alone group (HR, 0.63; 97.38% CI, 0.43&#8211;0.91; <em>

4551P</em>

4552 = .005). </li>

4553<li>

4554The estimated percentage of patients surviving without disease progression or disease recurrence at 1 year was 76.1% for patients who received nivolumab plus chemotherapy and 63.4% for patients who received chemotherapy alone. The magnitude of benefit was greater in 1) patients with stage IIIA disease versus patients with stage IB or II disease (HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.37&#8211;0.80 vs. HR, 0.87; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;1.56), 2) patients with tumor PD-L1 expression &#8805;1% versus &lt;1% (HR, 0.41; 95% CI, 0.24&#8211;0.70 vs. HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.54&#8211;1.32), and 3) patients with nonsquamous histology versus squamous histology.</li>

4555<li>

4556 Pathological complete response was observed in 24% (95% CI, 18.0%&#8211; 31.0%) of patients who received nivolumab plus chemotherapy and 2.2% (95% CI, 0.6%&#8211;5.6%) of patients who received chemotherapy alone (odds ratio, 13.94; 99% CI, 3.49&#8211;55.75; <em>

4557P</em>

4558 &lt; .001).</li>

4559<li>

4560 Median OS was not reached in either group (HR<sub>

4561death</sub>

4562, 0.57; 99.67% CI, 0.30&#8211;1.07; <em>

4563P</em>

4564 = .008). </li>

4565<li>

4566 Grade 3 or 4 treatment-related adverse events occurred in 33.5% of patients in the nivolumab-plus-chemotherapy group and in 36.9% of patients in the chemotherapy-alone group. Treatment-related adverse events led to discontinuation of treatment in 10.2% of patients in the nivolumab-plus-chemotherapy group and in 9.7% of patients in the chemotherapy-alone group.</li>

4567</ul>

4568</div>

4569</li>

4570</ol>

4571</div>

4572<p id="_485944" tabindex="-1">

4573The FDA approved nivolumab in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy for neoadjuvant treatment of patients with resectable (tumors &#8805;4 cm or node positive) NSCLC.</p>

4574</section>

4575</section>

4576<section id="_627">

4577<h4 id="_627_toc">

4578Radiation therapy</h4>

4579<p id="_628" tabindex="-1">

4580Patients with potentially operable tumors with medical contraindications to surgery or those with inoperable stage II disease and with sufficient pulmonary reserve

4581are candidates for radiation therapy with curative intent.[<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

458220</a>

4583] Primary

4584radiation therapy often consists of approximately 60 Gy delivered with

4585megavoltage equipment to the midplane of the volume of the known tumor using

4586conventional fractionation. A boost to the cone down field of the primary

4587tumor is frequently used to enhance local control. Careful treatment

4588planning with precise definition of target volume and avoidance of critical

4589normal structures, to the extent possible, is needed for optimal results; this requires the use of a simulator.</p>

4590<p id="_630" tabindex="-1">

4591Among

4592patients with excellent performance status, a 3-year survival rate

4593of 20% may be expected if a course of radiation therapy with curative intent can be

4594completed.</p>

4595<p id="_631" tabindex="-1">

4596Evidence (radiation therapy):</p>

4597<div class="pdq-content-list">

4598<ol id="_632">

4599<li>

4600In the largest retrospective series reported to date, 152 patients

4601with medically inoperable NSCLC were treated with definitive radiation therapy. The study reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.21">

460221</a>

4603]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4604<ul id="_484368">

4605<li>

4606A 5-year OS rate of 10%.</li>

4607<li>

4608Forty-four patients with

4609T1 tumors achieved an actuarial DFS rate of 60%.</li>

4610<li>

4611This

4612retrospective study also suggested that improved DFS was

4613obtained with radiation therapy doses greater than 60 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.21">

461421</a>

4615]</li>

4616</ul>

4617</div>

4618</li>

4619</ol>

4620</div>

4621</section>

4622</section>

4623<section id="_TrialSearch_48552_sid_8">

4624<h3 id="_TrialSearch_48552_sid_8_toc">

4625Current Clinical Trials</h3>

4626<p id="_TrialSearch_48552_22" tabindex="-1">

4627Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

4628advanced clinical trial search</a>

4629 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

4630General information</a>

4631 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

4632</section>

4633<h6 do-not-show="toc">

4634References</h6>

4635<ol>

4636<li id="section_8.1">

4637Manser R, Wright G, Hart D, et al.: Surgery for early stage non-small cell lung cancer. Cochrane Database Syst Rev (1): CD004699, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15674959&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15674959&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4638[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4639</li>

4640<li id="section_8.2">

4641Allen MS, Darling GE, Pechet TT, et al.: Morbidity and mortality of major pulmonary resections in patients with early-stage lung cancer: initial results of the randomized, prospective ACOSOG Z0030 trial. Ann Thorac Surg 81 (3): 1013-9; discussion 1019-20, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16488712&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16488712&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4642[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4643</li>

4647</li>

4651</li>

N Engl J Med 352 (25): 2589-97, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15972865&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15972865&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4654[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4655</li>

4656<li id="section_8.6">

4657Arriagada R, Bergman B, Dunant A, et al.: Cisplatin-based adjuvant chemotherapy in patients with completely resected non-small-cell lung cancer. 4658[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4659</li>

4660<li id="section_8.7">

4661Pignon JP, Tribodet H, Scagliotti GV, et al.: Lung adjuvant cisplatin evaluation: a pooled analysis by the LACE Collaborative Group. 4663</li>

4666[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4667</li>

4675</li>

4691</li>

Lancet 398 (10308): 1344-1357, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34555333&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34555333&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4698[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4699</li>

4700<li id="section_8.17">

4701Burdett SS, Stewart LA, Rydzewska L: Chemotherapy and surgery versus surgery alone in non-small cell lung cancer. Cochrane Database Syst Rev (3): CD006157, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17636828&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17636828&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4705Gilligan D, Nicolson M, Smith I, et al.: Preoperative chemotherapy in patients with resectable non-small cell lung cancer: results of the MRC LU22/NVALT 2/EORTC 08012 multicentre randomised trial and update of systematic review. 4706[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

N Engl J Med 386 (21): 1973-1985, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35403841&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35403841&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4710[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4711</li>
