Am J Clin Oncol 8 (5): 362-70, 1985.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3933327&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3933327&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4714[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4715</li>

4716<li id="section_8.21">

4717Dosoretz DE, Katin MJ, Blitzer PH, et al.: Radiation therapy in the management of medically inoperable carcinoma of the lung: results and implications for future treatment strategies. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 24 (1): 3-9, 1992.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1324899&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1324899&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4718[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4719</li>

4720</ol>

4721</div>

4722

4723 </section>

4724

4725

4726

4727 <section id="_637">

4728

4729 <h2>

4730Treatment of Stage IIIA NSCLC</h2>

4731

4732 <div id="_section_637" class="pdq-sections">

4733<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

4734<h6>

4735In This Section</h6>

4736<ul>

4737<li>

4738<a href="#_652_toc">

4739Treatment Options for Resected/Resectable Stage IIIA NSCLC<ul>

4740<li>

4741<a href="#_658_toc">

4742Surgery</a>

4743</li>

4744<li>

4745<a href="#_484224_toc">

4746Neoadjuvant therapy</a>

4747</li>

4748<li>

4749<a href="#_484229_toc">

4750Adjuvant therapy</a>

4751</li>

4752</ul>

4753</a>

4754</li>

4755<li>

4756<a href="#_4825_toc">

4757Treatment Options for Unresectable Stage IIIA NSCLC<ul>

4758<li>

4759<a href="#_4846_toc">

4760Chemoradiation therapy</a>

4761</li>

4762<li>

4763<a href="#_4829_toc">

4764Radiation therapy</a>

4765</li>

4766</ul>

4767</a>

4768</li>

4769<li>

4770<a href="#_4861_toc">

4771Treatment Options for Superior Sulcus Tumors<ul>

4772<li>

4773<a href="#_484521_toc">

4774Surgery</a>

4775</li>

4776<li>

4777<a href="#_4874_toc">

4778Chemoradiation therapy followed by surgery</a>

4779</li>

4780<li>

4781<a href="#_485760_toc">

4782Radiation therapy alone</a>

4783</li>

4784</ul>

4785</a>

4786</li>

4787<li>

4788<a href="#_4881_toc">

4789Treatment Options for Tumors That Invade the Chest Wall</a>

4790</li>

4791<li>

4792<a href="#_TrialSearch_637_sid_9_toc">

4793Current Clinical Trials</a>

4794</li>

4795</ul>

4796</nav>

4797<p id="_639" tabindex="-1">

4798Patients with <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

4799stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)</a>

4800 are a heterogenous group. Patients may have metastases to ipsilateral mediastinal nodes, potentially resectable T3 tumors invading the chest wall, or mediastinal involvement with metastases to peribronchial or hilar lymph nodes (N1). Presentations of disease range from resectable tumors with microscopic metastases to lymph nodes to unresectable, bulky disease involving multiple nodal stations.</p>

4801<p id="_640" tabindex="-1">

4802Patients with clinical stage IIIA N2 disease have a 5-year overall survival (OS) rate of 10%

4803to 15%; however, patients with bulky mediastinal involvement (i.e., visible

4804on chest radiography) have a 5-year survival rate of 2% to 5%. Depending on

4805clinical circumstances, the principal forms of treatment that are considered

4806for patients with stage IIIA NSCLC are radiation

4807therapy, chemotherapy, surgery, and combinations of these modalities. </p>

4808<p id="_641" tabindex="-1">

4809Treatment options vary according to the location of the tumor and whether it is resectable.</p>

4810<section id="_652">

4811<h3 id="_652_toc">

4812Treatment Options for Resected/Resectable Stage IIIA NSCLC</h3>

4813<p id="_48581" tabindex="-1">

4814Treatment options for resected/resectable disease include the following:</p>

4815<div class="pdq-content-list">

4816<ol id="_484294">

4817<li>

4818<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_658">

4819Surgery with neoadjuvant or adjuvant therapy</a>

4820.</li>

4821<li>

4822<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484224">

4823Neoadjuvant therapy</a>

4824.<div class="pdq-content-list">

4825<ul id="_484369">

4826<li>

4827<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484225">

4828Neoadjuvant chemotherapy</a>

4829.</li>

4830<li>

4831<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484644">

4832Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy</a>

4833.</li>

4834<li>

4835<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485945">

4836Neoadjuvant immunotherapy with chemotherapy</a>

4837.

4838</li>

4839</ul>

4840</div>

4841</li>

4842<li>

4843<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484229">

4844Adjuvant therapy</a>

4845.<div class="pdq-content-list">

4846<ul id="_484370">

4847<li>

4848<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484230">

4849Adjuvant chemotherapy</a>

4850.</li>

4851<li>

4852<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485708">

4853Adjuvant targeted therapy</a>

4854 (for patients with EGFR mutations).</li>

4855<li>

4856<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485877">

4857Adjuvant immunotherapy</a>

4858.</li>

4859<li>

4860<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484279">

4861Adjuvant chemoradiation therapy</a>

4862.</li>

4863<li>

4864<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484236">

4865Adjuvant radiation therapy</a>

4866.</li>

4867</ul>

4868</div>

4869</li>

4870</ol>

4871</div>

4872<p id="_485652" tabindex="-1">

4873Despite careful preoperative staging, some patients will be found to have metastases to mediastinal N2 lymph nodes at thoracotomy. </p>

4874<p id="_657" tabindex="-1">

4875The preponderance of evidence indicates that postoperative cisplatin combination chemotherapy provides a significant survival advantage to patients with resected NSCLC with occult N2 disease discovered at surgery. The optimal sequence of surgery and chemotherapy and the benefits and risks of postoperative radiation therapy in patients with resectable NSCLC are yet to be determined. </p>

4876<section id="_658">

4877<h4 id="_658_toc">

4878Surgery</h4>

4879<p id="_659" tabindex="-1">

4880If complete resection of tumor and lymph nodes is possible, such patients may benefit from surgery followed by postoperative chemotherapy. Current evidence suggests that lung cancer resection combined with complete ipsilateral mediastinal lymph node dissection (CMLND) is not associated with improvement in survival compared with lung cancer resection combined with systematic sampling of mediastinal lymph nodes in patients with stage I, II, or IIIA NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

48811</a>

4882][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4883Level of evidence A1</a>

4884]</p>

4885<p id="_484642" tabindex="-1">

4886The addition of surgery to chemoradiation therapy for patients with stage IIIA NSCLC did not result in improved OS in a phase III trial but did improve progression-free survival (PFS) and local control.[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

48872</a>

4888][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4889Level of evidence B1</a>

4890]</p>

4891<p id="_660" tabindex="-1">

4892Evidence (surgery):</p>

4893<div class="pdq-content-list">

4894<ol id="_661">

4895<li>

4896The Cochrane Collaboration reviewed 11 randomized trials with a total of 1,910 patients who underwent surgical interventions for early-stage (I&#8211;IIIA) lung cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

48973</a>

4898] A pooled analysis of three trials reported the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

4899<ul id="_484371">

4900<li>

4901Four-year survival was superior in patients with resectable stage I, II, or IIIA NSCLC who underwent resection and CMLND, compared with those who underwent resection and lymph node sampling; the hazard ratio (HR) was estimated to be 0.78 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.65&#8211;0.93; <em>

4902P</em>

4903 = .005).[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

49043</a>

4905][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4906Level of evidence A1</a>

4907]</li>

4908</ul>

4909</div>

4910</li>

4911<li>

4912CMLND versus lymph node sampling was evaluated in a large randomized phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003831">

4913ACOSOG-Z0030</a>

4914). Preliminary analyses of operative morbidity and mortality showed comparable rates from the procedures.[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

49154</a>

4916]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4917<ul id="_484643">

4918<li>

4919There was no difference in OS, disease-free survival (DFS), local recurrence, and regional recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

49201</a>

4921][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4922Level of evidence A1</a>

4923]</li>

4924</ul>

4925</div>

4926</li>

4927</ol>

4928</div>

4929<p id="_664" tabindex="-1">

4930Conclusions about the efficacy of surgery for patients with local and locoregional NSCLC are limited by the small number of participants studied to date and by the potential methodological weaknesses of the trials.</p>

4931</section>

4932<section id="_484224">

4933<h4 id="_484224_toc">

4934Neoadjuvant therapy</h4>

4935<section id="_484225">

4936<h5 id="_484225_toc">

4937Neoadjuvant chemotherapy</h5>

4938<p id="_484226" tabindex="-1">

4939The role of chemotherapy before surgery in patients with stage IIIA NSCLC has been extensively tested in clinical trials. The proposed benefits of preoperative (neoadjuvant) chemotherapy include the following:</p>

4940<div class="pdq-content-list">

4941<ul id="_484227">

4942<li>

4943 A reduction in tumor size that may facilitate surgical resection.</li>

4944<li>

4945Early eradication of micrometastases.</li>

4946<li>

4947Better tolerability.</li>

4948</ul>

4949</div>

4950<p id="_484228" tabindex="-1">

4951Evidence (neoadjuvant chemotherapy):</p>

4952<div class="pdq-content-list">

4953<ol id="_668">

4954<li>

4955The Cochrane Collaboration provided a systematic review and meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials that included 988 patients and evaluated the addition of preoperative chemotherapy to surgery versus surgery alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

49565</a>

4957] These trials evaluated patients with stages I, II, and IIIA NSCLC.<div class="pdq-content-list">

4958<ul id="_484372">

4959<li>

4960Preoperative chemotherapy provided an absolute benefit in survival of 6% across all stages of disease, from 14% to 20% at 5 years (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;0.97; <em>

4961P</em>

4962 = .022).[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

49635</a>

4964][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4965Level of evidence A1</a>

4966] </li>

4967<li>

4968This analysis was unable to address questions such as whether particular types of patients may benefit more or less from preoperative chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

49696</a>

4970]</li>

4971</ul>

4972</div>

4973 </li>

4974<li>

4975In the largest trial reported to date, 519 patients were randomly assigned to receive either surgery alone or three cycles of platinum-based chemotherapy followed by surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

49767</a>

4977] Most patients (61%) had clinical stage I disease, 31% had stage II disease, and 7% had stage III disease. <div class="pdq-content-list">

4978<ul id="_484373">

4979<li>

4980Postoperative complications were similar between groups, and no impairment of quality of life was observed.</li>

4981<li>

4982There was no evidence of a benefit in terms of OS (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.80&#8211;1.31; <em>

4983P</em>

4984 = .86).</li>

4985<li>

4986Updating the systematic review by addition of the present result suggests a 12% relative survival benefit with the addition of preoperative chemotherapy (1,507 patients; HR, 0.88; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;1.01; <em>

4987P</em>

4988 = .07), equivalent to an absolute improvement in survival of 5% at 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

49897</a>

4990]</li>

4991</ul>

4992</div>

4993</li>

4994</ol>

4995</div>

4996</section>

4997<section id="_484644">

4998<h5 id="_484644_toc">

4999Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy</h5>

5000<p id="_484646" tabindex="-1">

5001Administering concurrent neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy before surgery may intensify treatment and increase the likelihood of downstaging the tumor burden. Commonly used regimens that have been tested in the phase II setting include cisplatin/etoposide (EP5050) and weekly carboplatin/paclitaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_9.8">

50028</a>

5003,<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

50049</a>

5005] In a randomized trial of neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy and surgery versus concurrent chemoradiation therapy alone, there was no difference in OS, but surgery improved PFS and local control.[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

50062</a>

5007][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5008Level of evidence B1</a>

5009]</p>

5010<p id="_484647" tabindex="-1">

5011Evidence (neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy):</p>

5012<div class="pdq-content-list">

5013<ol id="_484648">

5014<li>

5015 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002550">

5016Intergroup-0139</a>

5017 trial (NCT00002550) compared chemoradiation therapy alone with neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by surgery in 396 patients with stage IIIA (N2) NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

50182</a>

5019]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5020<ul id="_484649">

5021<li>

5022 Surgery did not improve OS (5-year OS rate, 27% vs. 20%; HR, 0.87; 0.70&#8211;1.10; <em>

5023P</em>

5024 = .24).</li>

5025<li>

5026 Surgery improved PFS (5-year PFS rate, 22% vs. 11%; HR, 0.77; 0.62&#8211;0.96; <em>

5027P</em>

5028 = .017) and decreased the risk of local recurrence (10% vs. 22%; <em>

5029P</em>

5030 = .002). </li>

5031<li>

5032 There was increased treatment mortality with neoadjuvant chemoradiation with surgery (8% vs. 2%), particularly in the subset of patients who underwent pneumonectomy.</li>

5033</ul>

5034</div>

5035</li>

5036</ol>

5037</div>

5038<p id="_484650" tabindex="-1">

5039A direct comparison of neoadjuvant chemotherapy versus neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy using modern treatment regimens has not been performed to date; the optimal neoadjuvant approach remains unclear.</p>

5040</section>

5041<section id="_485945">

5042<h5 id="_485945_toc">

5043Neoadjuvant immunotherapy with chemotherapy</h5>

5044<p id="_485946" tabindex="-1">

5045The CheckMate 816 trial evaluated the combination of nivolumab (an anti-programmed death 1 antibody) and platinum-based chemotherapy as neoadjuvant therapy in patients with resectable (&#8805;4 cm or node positive) NSCLC. Nivolumab therapy improved event-free survival (EFS) and pathological complete response rates compared with chemotherapy alone.</p>

5046<p id="_485947" tabindex="-1">

5047Evidence (neoadjuvant immunotherapy with platinum-based chemotherapy):</p>

5048<div class="pdq-content-list">

5049<ol id="_485948">

5050<li>

5051<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02998528">

5052CheckMate 816</a>

5053 (NCT02998528) was a phase III open-label trial that enrolled 358 patients with resectable stage IB to stage IIIA NSCLC. Importantly, patients with stage IB disease had tumors measuring at least 4 cm and were classified according to the AJCC 7th edition staging criteria used for this trial; those tumors are now classified as stage IIA according to the AJCC 8th edition staging criteria. Patients were randomly assigned to receive nivolumab (360 mg) in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy or platinum-doublet chemotherapy alone every 3 weeks for three cycles before undergoing definitive surgery. The primary end points were EFS (defined as the time from randomization to any progression of disease precluding surgery, progression or recurrence of disease after surgery, progression of disease in the absence of surgery, or death from any cause) and pathological complete response (defined as 0% residual viable tumor cells in the primary tumor and sampled lymph nodes) according to blinded independent central review.[<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

505410</a>

5055][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5056Level of evidence B1</a>

5057]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5058<ul id="_485949">

5059<li>

5060 With a minimum follow-up of 21 months, the median EFS was 31.6 months (95% CI, 30.2&#8211;not reached) in the nivolumab-plus-chemotherapy group and 20.8 months (95% CI, 14.0&#8211;26.7) in the chemotherapy-alone group (HR, 0.63; 97.38% CI, 0.43&#8211;0.91; <em>

5061P</em>

5062 = .005). </li>

5063<li>

5064The estimated percentage of patients surviving without disease progression or disease recurrence at 1 year was 76.1% for patients who received nivolumab plus chemotherapy and 63.4% for patients who received chemotherapy alone. The magnitude of benefit was greater in 1) patients with stage IIIA disease versus patients with stage IB or II disease (HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.37&#8211;0.80 vs. HR, 0.87; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;1.56), 2) patients with tumor PD-L1 expression &#8805;1% versus &lt;1% (HR, 0.41; 95% CI, 0.24&#8211;0.70 vs. HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.54&#8211;1.32), and 3) patients with nonsquamous histology versus squamous histology.</li>

5065<li>

5066 Pathological complete response was observed in 24% (95% CI, 18.0%&#8211; 31.0%) of patients who received nivolumab plus chemotherapy and 2.2% (95% CI, 0.6%&#8211;5.6%) of patients who received chemotherapy alone (odds ratio, 13.94; 99% CI, 3.49&#8211;55.75; <em>

5067P</em>

5068 &lt; .001).</li>

5069<li>

5070 Median OS was not reached in either group (HR<sub>

5071death</sub>

5072, 0.57; 99.67% CI, 0.30&#8211;1.07; <em>

5073P</em>

5074 = .008). </li>

5075<li>

5076 Grade 3 or 4 treatment-related adverse events occurred in 33.5% of patients in the nivolumab-plus-chemotherapy group and in 36.9% of patients in the chemotherapy-alone group. Treatment-related adverse events led to treatment discontinuation in 10.2% of patients in the nivolumab-plus-chemotherapy group and in 9.7% of patients in the chemotherapy-alone group.</li>

5077</ul>

5078</div>

5079</li>

5080</ol>

5081</div>

5082<p id="_485950" tabindex="-1">

5083The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved nivolumab in combination with platinum-doublet chemotherapy for neoadjuvant treatment of patients with resectable (tumors &#8805;4 cm or node positive) NSCLC.</p>

5084</section>

5085</section>

5086<section id="_484229">

5087<h4 id="_484229_toc">

5088Adjuvant therapy</h4>

5089<section id="_484230">

5090<h5 id="_484230_toc">

5091Adjuvant chemotherapy</h5>

5092<p id="_484231" tabindex="-1">

5093Patients with completely resected stage IIIA NSCLC may benefit from postoperative cisplatin-based chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

509411</a>

5095][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5096Level of evidence A1</a>

5097]</p>

5098<p id="_484232" tabindex="-1">

5099Evidence (adjuvant chemotherapy):</p>

5100<p id="_484233" tabindex="-1">

5101Evidence from randomized controlled clinical trials indicates that when stage IIIA NSCLC is encountered unexpectedly at surgery, chemotherapy given after complete resection improves survival.</p>

5102<p id="_484234" tabindex="-1">

5103Several randomized, controlled trials and meta-analyses have evaluated the use of postoperative chemotherapy in patients with stages I, II, and IIIA NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

510411</a>

5105-<a href="#cit/section_9.17">

510617</a>

5107]</p>

5108<div class="pdq-content-list">

5109<ol id="_484235">

5110<li>

5111 Data on individual patient outcomes from the five largest trials (4,584 patients) that were conducted after 1995 of cisplatin-based chemotherapy in patients with completely resected NSCLC were collected and pooled into a meta-analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

511211</a>

5113]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5114<ul id="_484807">

5115<li>

5116With a median follow-up of 5.2 years, the overall HR<sub>

5117death</sub>

5118 was 0.89 (95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.96; <em>

5119P</em>

5120 = .005), corresponding to a 5-year absolute benefit of 5.4% from chemotherapy.</li>

5121<li>

5122The effect of chemotherapy did not vary significantly (test for interaction, <em>

5123P</em>

5124 = .11) with the associated drugs, including vinorelbine (HR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;0.91), etoposide or vinca alkaloid (HR, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.80&#8211;1.07), or other drugs (HR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.13). </li>

5125<li>

5126The benefit varied with stage (HR for stage IIIA, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.72&#8211;0.94).</li>

5127<li>

5128The greater effect on survival observed with the doublet of cisplatin plus vinorelbine compared with other regimens should be interpreted with caution as the total dose of cisplatin received was significantly higher in patients treated with vinorelbine.</li>

5129</ul>

5130</div>

5131</li>

5132<li>

5133Two trials (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002823">

5134FRE-IALT</a>

5135 and the Adjuvant Navelbine International Trialist Association [ANITA] trial) reported significant OS benefits associated with postoperative chemotherapy in stage IIIA disease.[<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

51366</a>

5137,<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

513813</a>

5139]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5140<ol id="_676" class="lower-alpha">

5141<li>

5142For the subgroup of stage IIIA patients in the ANITA trial (n = 325), the HR was 0.69 (95% CI, 0.53&#8211;0.90), and the result for the FRE-IALT trial (n = 728) was HR, 0.79 (95% CI, 0.66&#8211;0.95).</li>

5143<li>

5144The chemotherapy effect was higher in patients with a better performance status.</li>

5145<li>

5146There was no interaction between the chemotherapy effect and any of the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5147<ul id="_472">

5148<li>

5149Sex.</li>

5150<li>

5151Age.</li>

5152<li>

5153Histology.</li>

5154<li>

5155Type of surgery.</li>

5156<li>

5157Planned radiation therapy.</li>

5158<li>

5159Planned total dose of cisplatin.</li>

5160</ul>

5161</div>

5162</li>

5163</ol>

5164</div>

5165</li>

5166<li>

5167In a retrospective analysis of a phase III trial of postoperative cisplatin and vinorelbine, patients older than 65 years were found to benefit from treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_9.18">

516818</a>

5169]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5170<ul id="_484808">

5171<li>

5172Chemotherapy significantly prolonged OS for patients older than 65 years (HR, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.38&#8211;0.98; <em>

5173P</em>

5174 = .04). </li>

5175<li>

5176There were no significant differences in toxic effects, hospitalization, or treatment-related death by age group, although patients older than 65 years received less treatment.</li>

5177</ul>

5178</div>

5179</li>

5180</ol>

5181</div>

5182</section>

5183<section id="_485708">

5184<h5 id="_485708_toc">

5185Adjuvant targeted therapy (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

5186EGFR</em>

5187 mutations)

5188</h5>

5189<p id="_485709" tabindex="-1">

5190Adjuvant targeted therapy with osimertinib for patients with <em class="gene-name">

5191EGFR</em>

5192-mutated NSCLC and resected stage IIIA NSCLC was studied in a phase III clinical trial and was found to significantly increase DFS.</p>

5193<p id="_485710" tabindex="-1">

5194Evidence (adjuvant targeted therapy with osimertinib for stage IIIA <em class="gene-name">

5195EGFR</em>

5196-mutated NSCLC):</p>

5197<div class="pdq-content-list">

5198<ol id="_485711">

5199<li>

5200 The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02511106">

5201ADAURA</a>

5202 (NCT02511106) phase III, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial randomly assigned 682 patients with surgically resected stage IB to stage IIIA NSCLC with <em class="gene-name">

5203EGFR</em>

5204-sensitizing mutations (centrally determined, deletion in exon 19 or L858R mutation in exon 21) to osimertinib 80 mg by mouth daily or a placebo for 3 years. Standard postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy was allowed but not mandatory; decisions regarding adjuvant chemotherapy were made by the physician and patient before trial enrollment. The primary end point was DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_9.19">

520519</a>

5206][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5207Level of evidence B1</a>

5208]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5209<ul id="_485712">

5210<li>

5211 After a planned review by the independent data monitoring committee, the trial was unblinded at the trial level 2 years early because of evidence of an efficacy benefit.</li>

5212<li>

5213 A prespecified hierarchical testing procedure was used in the statistical analysis. If significance was shown for DFS among patients with stage II to stage IIIA disease, then DFS was tested for the entire study population (stages IB&#8722;IIIA). If this result was significant, then OS was tested, although the trial was not powered for OS.</li>

5214<li>

5215 For patients with stage II to stage IIIA disease, the DFS was significantly improved with osimertinib treatment (HR, 0.17; 99.06% CI, 0.11&#8722;0.26; <em>

5216P</em>

5217 &lt; .001).</li>

5218<li>

5219 Osimertinib treatment also improved DFS for the entire study population (stages IB&#8722;IIIA) (HR, 0.20; 99.12% CI, 0.14&#8722;0.30; <em>

5220P</em>

5221 &lt; .001).</li>

5222<li>

5223 Osimertinib treatment improved DFS in all predefined subgroups, including in patients with stage IB disease and in patients who did or did not receive adjuvant chemotherapy. </li>

5224<li>

5225 OS data are immature as of October 29, 2020, and follow-up is ongoing.</li>

5226<li>

5227 The adverse event profile is consistent with other studies that used osimertinib. </li>

5228</ul>

5229</div>

5230</li>

5231</ol>

5232</div>

5233</section>

5234<section id="_485877">

5235<h5 id="_485877_toc">

5236Adjuvant immunotherapy</h5>

5237<p id="_485878" tabindex="-1">

5238Adjuvant immunotherapy with atezolizumab for patients with resected stage IB to IIIA NSCLC was studied in a phase III clinical trial and was found to significantly increase DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

523920</a>

5240]</p>

5241<p id="_485879" tabindex="-1">

5242Evidence (adjuvant immunotherapy with atezolizumab for patients with resected stage IIIA NSCLC):</p>

5243<div class="pdq-content-list">

5244<ol id="_485880">

5245<li>

5246 <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02486718">

5247IMpower010</a>

5248 (NCT02486718) was a phase III, multicenter, open-label trial that randomly assigned 1,005 patients with surgically resected stage IB (tumor &gt;4 cm) to stage IIIA NSCLC. Patients received atezolizumab (1,200 mg every 21 days intravenously) or best supportive care for 16 cycles or 1 year after standard adjuvant platinum-based chemotherapy. Patients were enrolled after resection if they were eligible for cisplatin-based chemotherapy and were randomized after completion of chemotherapy if they remained eligible and did not experience disease progression. The primary end point was investigator-assessed DFS.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

524920</a>

5250]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5251<ul id="_485881">

5252<li>

5253 The primary end point was tested hierarchically, first in the stage II to IIIA population subgroup whose tumors expressed PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells (using the SP263 antibody), then in all patients in the stage II to IIIA population, and finally in the intention-to-treat (ITT) population (stage IB to IIIA). Of the 882 patients who were randomly assigned and had stage II to IIIA disease, 476 had tumors expressing PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells per SP263.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

525420</a>

5255][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5256Level of evidence B1</a>

5257]</li>

5258<li>

5259 After a median follow-up of 32.2 months, atezolizumab treatment improved DFS compared with best supportive care in patients in the stage II to IIIA population whose tumors expressed PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.50&#8211;0.88; <em>

5260P</em>

5261 = .0039). At 24 months, the DFS rate was 74.6% for the atezolizumab group and 61.0% for the best supportive care group.</li>

5262<li>

5263 Atezolizumab also improved DFS in all patients in the stage II to IIIA population (HR, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;0.96; <em>

5264P</em>

5265 = .020). At 24 months, the DFS rate was 70.2% for the atezolizumab group and 61.6% for the best supportive care group.</li>

5266<li>

5267 In the ITT population, which included patients with stage IB to IIIA disease, HR for DFS was 0.81 (95% CI, 0.67&#8211;0.99; <em>

5268P</em>

5269 = .040). However, the boundary for statistical significance for DFS was not crossed.</li>

5270<li>

5271 OS data are immature.</li>

5272<li>

5273 No new safety signals were noted. </li>

5274</ul>

5275</div>

5276</li>

5277</ol>

5278</div>

5279</section>

5280<p id="_485882" tabindex="-1">

5281The FDA approved atezolizumab for adjuvant treatment of patients with stage II to IIIA NSCLC whose tumors express PD-L1 on at least 1% of tumor cells.</p>

5282<section id="_484279">

5283<h5 id="_484279_toc">

5284Adjuvant chemoradiation therapy</h5>

5285<p id="_484280" tabindex="-1">

5286Combination chemotherapy and radiation therapy administered before or following surgery should be viewed as investigational and requiring evaluation in future clinical trials.</p>

5287<p id="_484281" tabindex="-1">

5288Evidence (adjuvant chemoradiation therapy):</p>

5289<div class="pdq-content-list">

5290<ol id="_484282">

5291<li>

5292Five randomized trials have assessed the value of postoperative combination chemoradiation therapy versus radiation therapy following surgical resection.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

52935</a>

5294,<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

52957</a>

5296,<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

529721</a>

5298-<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

529923</a>

5300][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5301Level of evidence A1</a>

5302]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5303<ul id="_484809">

5304<li>

5305Only one trial reported improved DFS, and no trial reported improved OS.</li>

5306</ul>

5307</div>

5308</li>

5309<li>

5310Three trials have evaluated platinum-based combination chemotherapy followed by surgery versus platinum-based chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy (60&#8211;69.6 Gy) alone to determine whether surgery or radiation therapy was most efficacious.[<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

531123</a>

5312-<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

531325</a>

5314] Although the studies were small, enrolling 73 (Radiation Therapy Oncology Group [RTOG]) (RTOG 89-01), 107 (The University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center), and 333 (European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer [<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002623">

5315EORTC-08941</a>

5316; NCT00002623]) patients with stage IIIA (N2) disease, no trial reported a difference in local control or survival.[<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

531723</a>

5318-<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

531925</a>

5320][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5321Level of evidence A1</a>

5322]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5323<ol id="_4823" class="lower-alpha">

5324<li>

5325In the largest series (EORTC-08941), 579 patients with histologically- or cytologically-proven stage IIIA (N2) NSCLC were given three cycles of platinum-based induction chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

532625</a>

5327] The 333 responding patients were

5328subsequently randomly assigned to surgical resection or radiation therapy. Of the 154 patients (92%) who underwent surgery, 50% had a radical resection, 42% had a pathological downstaging, and 5% had a pathological complete response; 4% died after surgery. Postoperative (adjuvant) radiation therapy (PORT) was administered to 62 patients (40%) in the surgery arm. Among the 154 patients (93%) who received radiation therapy, overall compliance to the radiation therapy prescription was 55%, and grade 3 to 4 acute and late esophageal and pulmonary toxic effects occurred in 4% and 7% of patients; one patient died of radiation pneumonitis.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5329<ul id="_484375">

5330<li>

5331Median OS was 16.4 months for patients assigned to resection versus 17.5 months for patients assigned to radiation therapy; the 5-year OS rate was 15.7% for patients assigned to resection versus 14% for patients assigned to radiation therapy (HR, 1.06; 95% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.35).[<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

533225</a>

5333]</li>

5334<li>

5335Rates of PFS were also similar in both groups. In view of its low morbidity and mortality, it was concluded that radiation therapy should be considered the preferred locoregional treatment for these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

533625</a>

5337]</li>

5338</ul>

5339</div>

5340</li>

5341</ol>

5342</div>

5343</li>

5344</ol>

5345</div>

5346</section>

5347<section id="_484236">

5348<h5 id="_484236_toc">

5349Adjuvant radiation therapy </h5>

5350<p id="_484237" tabindex="-1">

5351The value of PORT has been assessed.[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

535221</a>

5353] Although some studies suggest that PORT can improve local control for node-positive patients whose tumors were resected, it remains controversial whether it can improve survival. The optimal dose of thoracic PORT is not known at this time. Most studies cited used doses ranging from 30 Gy to 60 Gy, typically provided in 2 Gy to 2.5 Gy fractions.[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

535421</a>

5355]</p>

5356<p id="_484238" tabindex="-1">

5357As referred to in the National Cancer Institute of Canada (NCIC) Clinical Trials Group JBR.10 study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002583">

5358NCT00002583</a>

5359), PORT may be considered in selected patients to reduce the risk of local recurrence, if any of the following are present:[<a href="#cit/section_9.18">

536018</a>

5361]</p>

5362<div class="pdq-content-list">

5363<ul id="_484239">

5364<li>

5365Involvement of multiple nodal stations.</li>

5366<li>

5367Extracapsular tumor spread.</li>

5368<li>

5369Close or microscopically positive resection margins.</li>

5370</ul>

5371</div>

5372<p id="_484240" tabindex="-1">

5373Evidence (adjuvant radiation therapy):</p>

5374<p id="_484274" tabindex="-1">

5375Evidence from one large meta-analysis, subset analyses of randomized trials, and one large population study suggest that PORT may reduce local recurrence. Results from these studies on the effect of PORT on OS are conflicting.</p>

5376<div class="pdq-content-list">

5377<ol id="_484241">

5378<li>

5379A meta-analysis of ten randomized trials that evaluated PORT versus surgery alone showed the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5380<ul id="_484376">

5381<li>

5382 No difference in OS for the entire PORT group or for the subset of N2 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

538313</a>

5384][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5385Level of evidence A1</a>

5386]</li>

5387</ul>

5388</div>

5389</li>

5390<li>

5391Results from a nonrandomized subanalysis of the ANITA trial, comparing 5-year OS in N2 patients who did or did not receive PORT, found the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

53926</a>

5393] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5394<ul id="_484377">

5395<li>

5396Higher survival rates in patients who received radiation therapy in the observation arm (21% in patients who received PORT vs. 17% in patients who did not receive PORT) and in the chemotherapy arm (47% with PORT vs. 34% without PORT); however, statistical tests of comparison were not conducted.[<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

53976</a>

5398]</li>

5399</ul>

5400</div>

5401</li>

5402<li>

5403Results from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program [<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

540422</a>

5405] suggest the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

5406<ul id="_484378">

5407<li>

5408The large SEER retrospective study (N = 7,465) found superior survival rates associated with radiation therapy in N2 disease (HR, 0.855; 95% CI, 0.762&#8211;0.959).</li>

5409</ul>

5410</div>

5411</li>

5412</ol>

5413</div>

5414<p id="_484242" tabindex="-1">

5415There is benefit of PORT in stage IIIA (N2) disease, and the role of PORT in early stages of NSCLC should be clarified in ongoing phase III trials. Further analysis is needed to determine whether these outcomes can be modified with technical improvements, better definitions of target volumes, and limitation of cardiac volume in the radiation portals.[<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

541613</a>

5417]</p>

5418</section>

5419</section>

5420</section>

5421<section id="_4825">

5422<h3 id="_4825_toc">

5423Treatment Options for Unresectable Stage IIIA NSCLC</h3>

5424<p id="_48582" tabindex="-1">

5425Treatment options for patients with unresectable stage IIIA NSCLC include the following:</p>

5426<div class="pdq-content-list">

5427<ol id="_4827">

5428<li>

5429<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4846">

5430Chemoradiation therapy</a>

5431.</li>

5432<li>

5433<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4829">

5434Radiation therapy</a>

5435.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5436<ul id="_484379">

5437<li>

5438<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4830">

5439Locally advanced unresectable tumors</a>

5440. </li>

5441<li>

5442<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4838">

5443Palliative treatment</a>

5444.</li>

5445</ul>

5446</div>

5447</li>

5448</ol>

5449</div>

5450<section id="_4846">

5451<h4 id="_4846_toc">

5452Chemoradiation therapy</h4>

5453<p id="_4847" tabindex="-1">

5454The addition of sequential and concurrent chemotherapy to radiation therapy has been evaluated in prospective randomized trials and meta-analyses. Overall, concurrent treatment may provide the greatest benefit in survival with an increase in toxic effects. </p>

5455<p id="_4848" tabindex="-1">

5456Concomitant platinum-based radiation chemotherapy may improve survival of patients with locally advanced NSCLC. However, the available data are insufficient to accurately define the size of such a potential treatment benefit and the optimal schedule of chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.26">

545726</a>

5458]</p>

5459<p id="_4849" tabindex="-1">

5460Evidence (chemoradiation therapy):</p>

5461<div class="pdq-content-list">

5462<ol id="_4850">

5463<li>

5464A meta-analysis of patient data from 11 randomized clinical trials showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.27">

546527</a>

5466]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5467<ul id="_484382">

5468<li>

5469Cisplatin-based combinations plus radiation therapy resulted in a 10% reduction in the risk of death compared with radiation therapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.27">

547027</a>

5471][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5472Level of evidence A1</a>

5473]</li>

5474</ul>

5475</div>

5476</li>

5477<li>

5478A meta-analysis of 13 trials (based on 2,214 evaluable patients) showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

547928</a>

5480]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5481<ul id="_484383">

5482<li>

5483The addition of concurrent chemotherapy to radical radiation therapy reduced the risk of death at 2 years (relative risk [RR], 0.93; 95% CI, 0.88&#8211;0.98; <em>

5484P</em>

5485 = .01).</li>

5486<li>

5487For the 11 trials with platinum-based chemotherapy, RR was 0.93 (95% CI, 0.87&#8211;0.99; <em>

5488P</em>

5489 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

549028</a>

5491]</li>

5492</ul>

5493</div>

5494</li>

5495<li>

5496A meta-analysis of individual data from 1,764 patients was based on nine trials and showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.26">

549726</a>

5498]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5499<ul id="_484384">

5500<li>

5501The HR<sub>

5502death</sub>

5503 among patients treated with radiation therapy and chemotherapy compared with radiation therapy alone was 0.89 (95% CI, 0.81&#8211;0.98; <em>

5504P</em>

5505 = .02), corresponding to an absolute benefit of chemotherapy of 4% at 2 years.</li>

5506<li>

5507The combination of platinum with etoposide appeared to be more effective than platinum alone.</li>

5508</ul>

5509</div>

5510</li>

5511</ol>

5512</div>

5513<section id="_4854">

5514<h5 id="_4854_toc">

5515Concurrent versus sequential chemoradiation therapy</h5>

5516<p id="_484540" tabindex="-1">

5517The results from two randomized trials (including <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01134861">

5518RTOG-9410</a>

5519 [NCT01134861]) and a meta-analysis indicate that concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy may provide greater survival benefit, albeit with more toxic effects, than sequential chemotherapy and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.29">

552029</a>

5521-<a href="#cit/section_9.31">

552231</a>

5523][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5524Level of evidence A1</a>

5525] </p>

5526<p id="_484539" tabindex="-1">

5527Evidence (concurrent vs. sequential chemoradiation therapy):</p>

5528<div class="pdq-content-list">

5529<ol id="_4857">

5530<li>

5531In the first trial, the combination of mitomycin C, vindesine, and cisplatin were given concurrently with split-course daily radiation therapy to 56 Gy compared with chemotherapy followed by continuous daily radiation therapy to 56 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.29">

553229</a>

5533]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5534<ul id="_484385">

5535<li>

5536Five-year OS rates favored concurrent therapy (27% vs. 9%).</li>

5537<li>

5538Myelosuppression was greater among patients in the concurrent arm, but treatment-related mortality was less than 1% in both arms.[<a href="#cit/section_9.29">

553929</a>

5540]</li>

5541</ul>

5542</div>

5543</li>

5544<li>

5545In the second trial, 610 patients were randomly assigned to sequential chemotherapy with cisplatin and vinblastine followed by 63 Gy of radiation therapy, concurrent chemoradiation therapy using the same regimen, or concurrent chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide with twice-daily radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.31">

554631</a>

5547]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5548<ul id="_484386">

5549<li>

5550Median and 5-year survival were superior in the concurrent chemotherapy with daily radiation therapy arm (17 months vs. 14.6 months and 16% vs. 10% for sequential regimen [<em>

5551P</em>

5552 = .046]).[<a href="#cit/section_9.31">

555331</a>

5554]</li>

5555</ul>

5556</div>

5557</li>

5558<li>

5559Two smaller studies also reported OS results that favored concurrent over sequential chemotherapy and radiation, although the results did not reach statistical significance.[<a href="#cit/section_9.30">

556030</a>

5561,<a href="#cit/section_9.32">

556232</a>

5563][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5564Level of evidence A1</a>

5565]</li>

5566<li>

5567A meta-analysis of three trials evaluated concurrent versus sequential treatment (711 patients).[<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

556828</a>

5569]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5570<ul id="_484387">

5571<li>

5572The analysis indicated a significant benefit of concurrent over sequential treatment (RR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;0.95; <em>

5573P</em>

5574 = .003). All studies used cisplatin-based regimens and once-daily radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

557528</a>

5576]</li>

5577<li>

5578More deaths (3% OS rate) were reported in the concurrent arm, but this did not reach statistical significance (RR, 1.60; CI, 0.75&#8211;3.44; <em>

5579P</em>

5580 = .2).</li>

5581<li>

5582There was more acute esophagitis (grade 3 or worse) with concurrent treatment (range, 17%&#8211;26%) compared with sequential treatment (range, 0%&#8211;4%; RR, 6.77; <em>

5583P</em>

5584 = .001). Overall, the incidence of neutropenia (grade 3 or worse) was similar in both arms.</li>

5585</ul>

5586</div>

5587</li>

5588</ol>

5589</div>

5590</section>

5591<section id="_484672">

5592<h5 id="_484672_toc">

5593Radiation therapy dose escalation for concurrent chemoradiation</h5>

5594<p id="_484673" tabindex="-1">

5595With improvement in radiation therapy&#8211;delivery technology in the 1990s, including tumor-motion management and image guidance, phase I/II trials demonstrated the feasibility of dose-escalation radiation therapy to 74 Gy with concurrent chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.33">

559633</a>

5597-<a href="#cit/section_9.35">

559835</a>

5599] However, a phase III trial of a conventional dose of 60 Gy versus dose escalation to 74 Gy with concurrent weekly carboplatin/paclitaxel did not demonstrate improved local control or PFS, and OS was worse with dose escalation (HR, 1.38; 95% CI, 1.09&#8211;1.76; <em>

5600P</em>

5601 = .004). There was a nonsignificant increase in grade 5 events with dose escalation (10% vs. 2%) and higher incidence of grade 3 esophagitis (21% vs. 7%; <em>

5602P</em>

5603 = .0003). Thus, there is no clear benefit in radiation dose escalation beyond 60 Gy for stage III NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_9.36">

560436</a>

5605][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5606Level of evidence A1</a>

5607]</p>

5608</section>

5609<section id="_484820">

5610<h5 id="_484820_toc">

5611Consolidation therapy following concurrent chemoradiation</h5>

5612<p id="_484821" tabindex="-1">

5613Evidence (consolidation therapy following concurrent chemoradiation):</p>

5614<div class="pdq-content-list">

5615<ol id="_484822">

5616<li>

5617The randomized phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00686959">

5618PROCLAIM</a>

5619 study [NCT00686959] enrolled 598 patients with newly diagnosed, stage IIIA/B, unresectable, nonsquamous NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_9.37">

562037</a>

5621] Patients were randomly assigned on a 1:1 ratio to either of two arms: <div class="pdq-content-list">

5622<ul id="_484832">

5623<li>

5624Arm A: Pemetrexed (500 mg/m<span class="sup">

56252</span>

5626) and cisplatin (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

56272</span>

5628) intravenously every 3 weeks for three cycles plus concurrent thoracic radiation therapy (60 to 66 Gy) followed by pemetrexed consolidation every 3 weeks for four cycles.</li>

5629<li>

5630Arm B: Standard therapy with etoposide (50 mg/m<span class="sup">

56312</span>

5632) and cisplatin (50 mg/m<span class="sup">

56332</span>

5634) intravenously every 4 weeks for two cycles plus concurrent thoracic radiation therapy (60 to 66 Gy) followed by two cycles of consolidation platinum-based doublet chemotherapy. </li>

5635</ul>

5636</div>

5637<p id="_484833" tabindex="-1">

5638The primary objective was OS. The study was designed as a superiority trial with 80% power to detect an OS HR of 0.74 with a type 1 error of .05. This study randomly assigned 598 patients (arm A, 301; arm B, 297) and treated 555 patients (arm A, 283; arm B, 272).</p>

5639<div class="pdq-content-list">

5640<ul id="_484823">

5641<li>

5642Enrollment was stopped early because of futility.</li>

5643<li>

5644OS in arm A was not superior to arm B (HR, 0.98; 95% CI, 0.79&#8211;1.20; median, 26.8 vs. 25.0 months; <em>

5645P</em>

5646 = .831). </li>

5647<li>

5648Arm A had a significantly lower incidence of any drug-related grade 3 to 4 adverse events (64.0% vs. 76.8%; <em>

5649P</em>

5650 = .001), including neutropenia (24.4% vs. 44.5%; <em>

5651P</em>

5652 &lt; .001), during the overall treatment period.</li>

5653</ul>

5654</div>

5655</li>

5656</ol>

5657</div>

5658</section>

5659<section id="_484677">

5660<section id="_485454">

5661<h6 id="_485454_toc">

5662Consolidation immunotherapy </h6>

5663<section id="_485455">

5664<h6 id="_485455_toc">

5665Durvalumab</h6>

5666<p id="_485456" tabindex="-1">

5667Durvalumab is a selective human IgG1 monoclonal antibody that blocks programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) binding to programmed death 1 (PD-1) and CD80, allowing T cells to recognize and kill tumor cells.[<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

566838</a>

5669] </p>

5670<p id="_485457" tabindex="-1">

5671Evidence (durvalumab following concurrent chemoradiation):</p>

5672<div class="pdq-content-list">

5673<ol id="_485458">

5674<li>

5675 The phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02125461">

5676PACIFIC</a>

5677 trial (NCT02125461) enrolled 713 patients with stage III NSCLC whose disease had not progressed after two or more cycles of platinum-based chemoradiation therapy. Patients were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive durvalumab (10 mg/kg intravenously) or placebo (every 2 weeks for up to 12 months).[<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

567838</a>

5679] The coprimary end points were PFS assessed by blinded independent central review and OS (unplanned for the interim analysis).<div class="pdq-content-list">

5680<ul id="_485459">

5681<li>

5682 At the interim analysis, the coprimary end point of PFS was met. The median PFS was 16.8 months with durvalumab versus 5.6 months with placebo (HR, 0.52; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.65; <em>

5683P</em>

5684 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

568538</a>

5686][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5687Level of evidence B1</a>

5688] The 18-month PFS rate was 44.2% with durvalumab versus 27% with placebo.</li>

5689<li>

5690 PFS benefit was seen across all prespecified subgroups and was irrespective of PD-L1 expression before chemoradiation therapy or smoking status. <em class="gene-name">

5691EGFR</em>

5692 mutations were observed in 6% of patients (29 treated with durvalumab vs. 14 treated with placebo). The unstratified HR for the <em class="gene-name">

5693EGFR</em>

5694-mutated subgroup was 0.76 (95% CI, 0.35&#8211;1.64).</li>

5695<li>

5696 Grade 3 or 4 adverse events occurred in 29.9% of patients treated with durvalumab and in 26.1% of patients treated with placebo. The most common adverse event of grade 3 or 4 was pneumonia in 4.4% of the patients who received durvalumab and in 3.8% of the patients who received placebo.</li>

5697<li>

5698 OS was not assessed at the interim analysis.</li>

5699</ul>

5700</div>

5701</li>

5702</ol>

5703</div>

5704</section>

5705</section>

5706<section id="_485460">

5707<h6 id="_485460_toc">

5708Other systemic consolidation therapies </h6>

5709<p id="_485653" tabindex="-1">

5710The addition of induction chemotherapy before concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy has not been shown to improve survival.[<a href="#cit/section_9.39">

571139</a>

5712][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5713Level of evidence A1</a>

5714] </p>

5715<p id="_485461" tabindex="-1">

5716 Randomized trials of other consolidation systemic therapies, including docetaxel,[<a href="#cit/section_9.40">

571740</a>

5718] gefitinib,[<a href="#cit/section_9.41">

571941</a>

5720] and tecemotide (MUC1 antigen-specific immunotherapy) [<a href="#cit/section_9.42">

572142</a>

5722] have not shown an improvement in OS.[<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5723Level of evidence A1</a>

5724]</p>

5725</section>

5726</section>

5727</section>

5728<section id="_4829">

5729<h4 id="_4829_toc">

5730Radiation therapy</h4>

5731<section id="_4830">

5732<h5 id="_4830_toc">

5733Locally advanced unresectable tumors</h5>

5734<p id="_4831" tabindex="-1">

5735Radiation therapy alone may provide benefit to patients with locally advanced unresectable stage IIIA NSCLC. </p>

5736<p id="_4833" tabindex="-1">

5737Radiation therapy with traditional dose and fractionation schedules (1.8&#8211;2.0 Gy per fraction per day to 60&#8211;70 Gy in 6&#8211;7 weeks) results in reproducible long-term survival benefit in 5% to 10% of patients and significant palliation of symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_9.43">

573843</a>

5739]</p>

5740<p id="_4834" tabindex="-1">

5741Evidence (radiation therapy for locally advanced unresectable tumor):</p>

5742<div class="pdq-content-list">

5743<ol id="_4835">

5744<li>

5745One prospective randomized clinical study showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

574644</a>

5747]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5748<ul id="_484380">

5749<li>

5750Radiation therapy given continuously (including weekends) as three daily fractions (continuous hyperfractionated accelerated radiation therapy) improved OS compared with radiation therapy given as one daily fraction.[<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

575144</a>

5752][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5753Level of evidence A1</a>

5754]</li>

5755<li>

5756Patterns of failure for patients treated with radiation therapy alone included both locoregional and distant failures.</li>

5757</ul>

5758</div>

5759</li>

5760</ol>

5761</div>

5762<p id="_4837" tabindex="-1">

5763Although patients with unresectable stage IIIA disease may benefit from radiation therapy, long-term outcomes have generally been poor because of local and systemic relapse.</p>

5764</section>

5765<section id="_4838">

5766<h5 id="_4838_toc">

5767Palliative treatment</h5>

5768<p id="_4839" tabindex="-1">

5769Radiation therapy may be effective in palliating symptomatic local involvement with NSCLC, such as the following:</p>

5770<div class="pdq-content-list">

5771<ul id="_4840">

5772<li>

5773Tracheal, esophageal, or bronchial compression.</li>

5774<li>

5775Pain.</li>

5776<li>

5777Vocal cord paralysis.</li>

5778<li>

5779Hemoptysis.</li>

5780<li>

5781Superior vena cava syndrome.</li>

5782</ul>

5783</div>

5784<p id="_4841" tabindex="-1">

5785In some cases, endobronchial laser therapy and/or brachytherapy has been used to alleviate proximal obstructing lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

578645</a>

5787] </p>

5788<p id="_4843" tabindex="-1">

5789Evidence (radiation therapy for palliative treatment):</p>

5790<div class="pdq-content-list">

5791<ol id="_4844">

5792<li>

5793 A systematic review identified six randomized trials of high-dose rate endobronchial brachytherapy (HDREB) alone or with external-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) or laser therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.46">

579446</a>

5795]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5796<ul id="_484381">

5797<li>

5798Better overall symptom palliation and fewer re-treatments were required in previously untreated patients using EBRT alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.46">

579946</a>

5800][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5801Level of evidence A3</a>

5802]</li>

5803<li>

5804Although EBRT is frequently prescribed for symptom palliation, there is no consensus about when the fractionation scheme should be used.</li>

5805<li>

5806For EBRT, different multifraction regimens appear to provide similar symptom relief;[<a href="#cit/section_9.47">

580747</a>

5808-<a href="#cit/section_9.52">

580952</a>

5810] however, single-fraction radiation therapy may be insufficient for symptom relief compared with hypofractionated or standard regimens, as seen in the NCIC Clinical Trials Group trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003685">

5811NCT00003685</a>

5812).[<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

581349</a>

5814][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5815Level of evidence A3</a>

5816] </li>

5817<li>

5818Evidence of a modest increase in survival in patients with better performance status given high-dose EBRT is available.[<a href="#cit/section_9.47">

581947</a>

5820,<a href="#cit/section_9.48">

582148</a>

5822][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5823Level of evidence A1</a>

5824] </li>

5825<li>

5826HDREB provided palliation of symptomatic patients with recurrent endobronchial obstruction previously treated by EBRT, when it was technically feasible. </li>

5827</ul>

5828</div>

5829</li>

5830</ol>

5831</div>

5832</section>

5833</section>

5834</section>

5835<section id="_4861">

5836<h3 id="_4861_toc">

5837Treatment Options for Superior Sulcus Tumors</h3>

5838<p id="_48583" tabindex="-1">

5839Treatment options for superior sulcus tumors include the following:</p>

5840<div class="pdq-content-list">

5841<ol id="_4863">

5842<li>

5843<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484521">

5844Surgery</a>

5845. </li>

5846<li>

5847<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4874">

5848Chemoradiation therapy followed by surgery</a>

5849.</li>

5850<li>

5851<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485760">

5852Radiation therapy alone</a>

5853.</li>

5854</ol>

5855</div>

5856<p id="_4864" tabindex="-1">

5857 NSCLC of the superior sulcus, frequently termed Pancoast tumors, occurs in less than 5% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.53">

585853</a>

5859,<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

586054</a>

5861] Superior sulcus tumors usually arise from the apex of the lung and are challenging to treat because of their proximity to structures at the thoracic inlet. At this location, tumors may invade the parietal pleura, chest wall, brachial plexus, subclavian vessels, stellate ganglion, and adjacent vertebral bodies. However, Pancoast tumors are amenable to curative treatment, especially in

5862patients with T3, N0 disease. </p>

5863<p id="_4865" tabindex="-1">

5864Adverse prognostic factors include the presence of <em>

5865mediastinal nodal metastases (N2 disease), spine or subclavian-vessel involvement (T4 disease),</em>

5866 and limited resection (R1 or R2).</p>

5867<section id="_484521">

5868<h4 id="_484521_toc">

5869Surgery</h4>

5870<p id="_484522" tabindex="-1">

5871Evidence (surgery):</p>

5872<div class="pdq-content-list">

5873<ol id="_484455">

5874<li>

5875Retrospective case series have reported that complete resection was achieved in only 64% of T3, N0 tumors and 39% of T4, N0 tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.55">

587655</a>

5877]</li>

5878</ol>

5879</div>

5880</section>

5881<section id="_4874">

5882<h4 id="_4874_toc">

5883Chemoradiation therapy followed by surgery</h4>

5884<p id="_4876" tabindex="-1">

5885Evidence (chemoradiation therapy):</p>

5886<div class="pdq-content-list">

5887<ol id="_4877">

5888<li>

5889Two large, prospective, multicenter phase II trials have evaluated induction chemoradiation therapy followed by resection.[<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

589056</a>

5891,<a href="#cit/section_9.57">

589257</a>

5893]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5894<ol id="_4878" class="lower-alpha">

5895<li>

5896In the first trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002642">

5897NCT00002642</a>

5898), 110 eligible patients were enrolled with mediastinoscopy negative, clinical T3&#8211;4, N0&#8211;1 tumors of the superior sulcus.[<a href="#cit/section_9.57">

589957</a>

5900] Induction treatment was two cycles of etoposide and cisplatin with 45 Gy of concurrent radiation therapy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5901<ul id="_484388">

5902<li>

5903The induction regimen was well tolerated, and only five participants had grade 3 or higher toxic effects. </li>

5904<li>

5905Induction chemoradiation therapy could sterilize the primary lesion. Induction therapy was completed by 104 patients (95%). Of the 95 patients eligible for surgery, 88 (80%) underwent thoracotomy, two (1.8%) died postoperatively, and 83 (76%) had complete resections.</li>

5906<li>

5907Pathological complete response or minimal microscopic disease was seen in 61 (56%) resection specimens. Pathological complete response led to better survival than when any residual disease was present (<em>

5908P</em>

5909 = .02).</li>

5910<li>

5911Five-year survival was 44% for all patients and 54% after complete resection, with no difference between T3 and T4 tumors. Disease progression occurred mainly in distant sites.</li>

5912</ul>

5913</div>

5914 </li>

5915<li>

5916 In the second trial, 75 patients were enrolled and treated with induction therapy with mitomycin C, vindesine, and cisplatin combined with 45 Gy of radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

591756</a>

5918] Fifty-seven patients (76%) underwent surgical resection, and complete resection was achieved in 51 patients (68%).<div class="pdq-content-list">

5919<ul id="_484389">

5920<li>

5921There were 12 patients with pathological complete response.</li>

5922<li>

5923Major postoperative morbidity, including chylothorax, empyema, pneumonitis, adult respiratory distress syndrome, and bleeding, was observed in eight patients. There were three treatment-related deaths.</li>

5924<li>

5925At 3 years, the DFS rate was 49%, and the OS rate was 61%; at 5 years, the DFS rate was 45%, and the OS rate was 56%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

592656</a>

5927][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5928Level of evidence C2</a>

5929]</li>

5930</ul>

5931</div>

5932</li>

5933</ol>

5934</div>

5935</li>

5936</ol>

5937</div>

5938<section id="_484688">

5939<h5 id="_484688_toc">

5940Radiation therapy dose escalation for concurrent chemoradiation</h5>

5941<p id="_484690" tabindex="-1">

5942With improvement in radiation therapy&#8211;delivery technology in the 1990s, including tumor-motion management and image guidance, phase I/II trials demonstrated the feasibility of dose-escalation radiation therapy to 74 Gy with concurrent chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.33">

594333</a>

5944-<a href="#cit/section_9.35">

594535</a>

5946] However, a phase III trial of a conventional dose of 60 Gy versus dose escalation to 74 Gy with concurrent weekly carboplatin/paclitaxel did not demonstrate improved local control or PFS, and OS was worse with dose escalation (HR, 1.38 [1.09&#8211;1.76]; <em>

5947P</em>

5948 = .004). There was a nonsignificant increase in grade 5 events with dose escalation (10% vs. 2%) and higher incidence of grade 3 esophagitis (21% vs. 7%; <em>

5949P</em>

5950 = .0003). Thus, there is no clear benefit in radiation dose escalation beyond 60 Gy for stage III NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_9.36">

595136</a>

5952][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5953Level of evidence A1</a>

5954]</p>

5955</section>

5956</section>

5957<section id="_485760">

5958<h4 id="_485760_toc">

5959Radiation therapy alone</h4>

5960<p id="_485774" tabindex="-1">

5961While radiation therapy is an integral part of the treatment of Pancoast tumors, variations in dose, treatment technique, and staging that were used in various published series make it difficult to determine its effectiveness.[<a href="#cit/section_9.53">

596253</a>

5963,<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

596454</a>

5965]</p>

5966<p id="_485776" tabindex="-1">

5967Small, retrospective series of radiation therapy in patients who were only clinically staged have reported 5-year survival rates of 0% to 40%, depending on T stage, total radiation dose, and other prognostic factors. Induction radiation therapy and en bloc resection was shown to be potentially curative.</p>

5968<p id="_485777" tabindex="-1">

5969Evidence (radiation therapy):</p>

5970<div class="pdq-content-list">

5971<ol id="_485778">

5972<li>

5973In the preoperative setting, a dose of 45 Gy over 5 weeks is generally recommended, while a dose of approximately 61 Gy is required when using definitive radiation therapy as the primary modality.[<a href="#cit/section_9.53">

597453</a>

5975,<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

597654</a>

5977]</li>

5978</ol>

5979</div>

5980</section>

5981</section>

5982<section id="_4881">

5983<h3 id="_4881_toc">

5984Treatment Options for Tumors That Invade the Chest Wall</h3>

5985<p id="_484329" tabindex="-1">

5986Treatment options for tumors that invade the chest wall include the following:</p>

5987<div class="pdq-content-list">

5988<ol id="_484330">

5989<li>

5990Surgery.</li>

5991<li>

5992Surgery and radiation therapy.</li>

5993<li>

5994 Radiation therapy alone.

5995</li>

5996<li>

5997Chemotherapy combined with radiation therapy and/or surgery.</li>

5998</ol>

5999</div>

6000<p id="_484462" tabindex="-1">

6001Selected patients with bulky primary tumors that directly invade the chest wall

6002can obtain long-term survival with surgical management provided that their

6003tumor is completely resected.

6004</p>

6005<p id="_484463" tabindex="-1">

6006Evidence (radical surgery): </p>

6007<div class="pdq-content-list">

6008<ol id="_484541">

6009<li>

6010In a small case series of 97 patients, the 5-year survival rate of patients who had completely resected T3, N0, M0 disease was 44.2%. For patients with completely resected T3, N1, M0 disease, the 5-year survival rate was 40.0%. In patients with completely resected T3, N2, M0 disease, the 5-year survival rate was 6.2%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.58">

601158</a>

6012][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6013Level of evidence C2</a>

6014]</li>

6015<li>

6016In a small case series of 104 patients, the 5-year survival rate of patients who had completely resected T3, N0, M0 disease was 67.3%. For patients with completely resected T3, N1, M0 disease, the 5-year survival rate was 100.0%. In patients with completely resected T3, N2, M0 disease, the 5-year survival rate was 17.9%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.59">

601759</a>

6018][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6019Level of evidence C2</a>

6020]</li>

6021<li>

6022In a case series of 309 patients treated at three centers, patients who underwent en bloc resection had superior outcomes compared with patients who underwent extrapleural resections (60.3% vs. 39.1%; <em>

6023P</em>

6024 = .03).[<a href="#cit/section_9.60">

602560</a>

6026][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6027Level of evidence C2</a>

6028]</li>

6029</ol>

6030</div>

6031<p id="_484470" tabindex="-1">

6032 Adjuvant chemotherapy is recommended, and radiation therapy is reserved for cases with unclear resection margins. Survival rates were lower in patients who underwent incomplete resection and had mediastinal lymph node involvement. Combined-modality approaches have been evaluated to improve ability to achieve complete resection.</p>

6033</section>

6034<section id="_TrialSearch_637_sid_9">

6035<h3 id="_TrialSearch_637_sid_9_toc">

6036Current Clinical Trials</h3>

6037<p id="_TrialSearch_637_22" tabindex="-1">

6038Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6039advanced clinical trial search</a>

6040 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6041General information</a>

6042 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6043</section>

6119<li id="section_9.19">

6121[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6122</li>

6123<li id="section_9.20">

6124Felip E, Altorki N, Zhou C, et al.: Adjuvant atezolizumab after adjuvant chemotherapy in resected stage IB-IIIA non-small-cell lung cancer (IMpower010): a randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 3 trial. Lancet 398 (10308): 1344-1357, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34555333&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34555333&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6125[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6126</li>

6127<li id="section_9.21">

6128PORT Meta-analysis Trialists Group: Postoperative radiotherapy for non-small cell lung cancer. Cochrane Database Syst Rev (2): CD002142, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15846628&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15846628&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6129[PUBMED Abstract]</a>
