6283<li id="section_9.60">

6284Doddoli C, D'Journo B, Le Pimpec-Barthes F, et al.: Lung cancer invading the chest wall: a plea for en-bloc resection but the need for new treatment strategies. Ann Thorac Surg 80 (6): 2032-40, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16305839&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16305839&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6285[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6286</li>

6287</ol>

6288</div>

6289

6290 </section>

6291

6292

6293

6294 <section id="_4889">

6295

6296 <h2>

6297Treatment of Stages IIIB and IIIC NSCLC</h2>

6298

6299 <div id="_section_4889" class="pdq-sections">

6300<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6301<h6>

6302In This Section</h6>

6303<ul>

6304<li>

6305<a href="#_48549_toc">

6306Treatment Options for Stages IIIB and IIIC NSCLC<ul>

6307<li>

6308<a href="#_484283_toc">

6309Sequential or concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy</a>

6310</li>

6311<li>

6312<a href="#_4912_toc">

6313Radiation therapy alone</a>

6314</li>

6315</ul>

6316</a>

6317</li>

6318<li>

6319<a href="#_TrialSearch_4889_sid_10_toc">

6320Current Clinical Trials</a>

6321</li>

6322</ul>

6323</nav>

6324<p id="_4891" tabindex="-1">

6325On the basis of the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program registry, the estimated incidence of <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

6326stage IIIB non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)</a>

6327 is 17.6%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

63281</a>

6329] The anticipated 5-year survival rate for most patients who present with clinical stage IIIB NSCLC is 3% to 7%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

63302</a>

6331] In small case series, selected patients with T4, N0&#8211;1 disease, solely as the result of satellite tumor nodule(s) within the primary lobe, had 5-year survival rates of 20%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.3">

63323</a>

6333,<a href="#cit/section_10.4">

63344</a>

6335][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6336Level of evidence C1</a>

6337]</p>

6338<section id="_48549">

6339<h3 id="_48549_toc">

6340Treatment Options for Stages IIIB and IIIC NSCLC</h3>

6341<p id="_48590" tabindex="-1">

6342Treatment options for <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

6343stages IIIB NSCLC</a>

6344 and <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

6345IIIC NSCLC</a>

6346 include the following:</p>

6347<div class="pdq-content-list">

6348<ol id="_4893">

6349<li>

6350<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484283">

6351Sequential or concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy</a>

6352.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6353<ol id="_485818" class="lower-alpha">

6354<li>

6355<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484651">

6356Radiation therapy dose escalation for concurrent chemoradiation</a>

6357.</li>

6358<li>

6359<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484656">

6360Systemic consolidation therapy before or after concurrent chemoradiation therapy</a>

6361.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6362<ul id="_485819">

6363<li>

6364 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485462">

6365Consolidation immunotherapy</a>

6366.</li>

6367<li>

6368 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485468">

6369Other systemic consolidation therapies</a>

6370.</li>

6371</ul>

6372</div>

6373</li>

6374</ol>

6375</div>

6376</li>

6377<li>

6378<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4912">

6379Radiation therapy alone</a>

6380.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6381<ul id="_484390">

6382<li>

6383<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4914">

6384For treatment of locally advanced unresectable tumor in patients who are not candidates for chemotherapy</a>

6385.</li>

6386<li>

6387<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4920">

6388For patients requiring palliative treatment</a>

6389.</li>

6390</ul>

6391</div>

6392</li>

6393<li>

6394New fractionation schedules (under clinical evaluation).</li>

6395<li>

6396Radiosensitizers (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02186847">

6397NCT02186847</a>

6398) (under clinical evaluation).</li>

6399<li>

6400Combined-modality approaches (under clinical evaluation).</li>

6401<li>

6402Incorporation of targeted agents into combined modality therapy in patients with <em class="gene-name">

6403EGFR</em>

6404-mutant or <em class="gene-name">

6405ALK</em>

6406-translocated tumors (RTOG-1306 [<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01822496">

6407NCT01822496</a>

6408]; 11-464 [<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01553942">

6409NCT01553942</a>

6410]) (under clinical evaluation).</li>

6411<li>

6412 Adaptive radiation therapy using positron emission tomography&#8211;based response assessment during treatment (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01507428">

6413RTOG-1106/ACRIN-6697</a>

6414) (under clinical evaluation).</li>

6415</ol>

6416</div>

6417<p id="_4894" tabindex="-1">

6418In general, patients with stages IIIB and IIIC NSCLC do not benefit from

6419surgery alone and are best managed by initial chemotherapy, chemotherapy plus

6420radiation therapy, or radiation therapy alone, depending on the following:</p>

6421<div class="pdq-content-list">

6422<ul id="_4895">

6423<li>

6424Sites of tumor

6425involvement.</li>

6426<li>

6427The patient's performance status.</li>

6428</ul>

6429</div>

6430<p id="_4896" tabindex="-1">

6431Most patients with excellent performance status are candidates for combined-modality chemotherapy and radiation therapy with the following exceptions:</p>

6432<div class="pdq-content-list">

6433<ul id="_4898">

6434<li>

6435Selected patients with T4, N0 disease may be treated with combined-modality therapy and surgery similar to patients with superior sulcus tumors.</li>

6436</ul>

6437</div>

6438<p id="_485928" tabindex="-1">

6439Patients with stages IIIB or IIIC NSCLC are candidates for clinical trials, which may lead to improvement in the control of disease.</p>

6440<section id="_484283">

6441<h4 id="_484283_toc">

6442Sequential or concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy</h4>

6443<p id="_484284" tabindex="-1">

6444Many randomized

6445studies of patients with unresectable stage III NSCLC show that treatment with

6446 preoperative or concurrent cisplatin-based chemotherapy and radiation therapy to the chest is

6447associated with improved survival compared with treatment that uses radiation therapy

6448alone. Although patients with unresectable stages IIIB or IIIC disease may benefit from radiation therapy, long-term outcomes have generally been poor, often the result of local and systemic relapse. The addition of sequential and concurrent chemotherapy to radiation therapy has been evaluated in prospective randomized trials. </p>

6449<p id="_484285" tabindex="-1">

6450Evidence (sequential or concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy):</p>

6451<div class="pdq-content-list">

6452<ol id="_484286">

6453<li>

6454A meta-analysis of patient data from 11 randomized clinical trials showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

64555</a>

6456]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6457<ul id="_484810">

6458<li>

6459Cisplatin-based combinations plus radiation therapy resulted in a 10% reduction in the risk of death compared with radiation therapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

64605</a>

6461][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6462Level of evidence A1</a>

6463]</li>

6464</ul>

6465</div>

6466</li>

6467<li>

6468A meta-analysis of 13 trials (based on 2,214 evaluable patients) showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

64696</a>

6470]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6471<ul id="_484811">

6472<li>

6473The addition of concurrent chemotherapy to radical radiation therapy reduced the risk of death at 2 years (relative risk [RR], 0.93; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.88&#8211;0.98; <em>

6474P</em>

6475 = .01).</li>

6476<li>

6477For the 11 trials with platinum-based chemotherapy, RR was 0.93 (95% CI, 0.87&#8211;0.99; <em>

6478P</em>

6479 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

64806</a>

6481]</li>

6482</ul>

6483</div>

6484</li>

6485<li>

6486A meta-analysis of individual data from 1,764 patients evaluated nine trials.[<a href="#cit/section_10.7">

64877</a>

6488]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6489<ul id="_484812">

6490<li>

6491The hazard ratio (HR)<sub>

6492death</sub>

6493 among patients treated with radiation therapy and chemotherapy compared with radiation therapy alone was 0.89 (95% CI, 0.81&#8211;0.98; <em>

6494P</em>

6495 = .02) corresponding to an absolute benefit of chemotherapy of 4% at 2 years. </li>

6496<li>

6497The combination of platinum with etoposide appeared to be more effective than platinum alone. Concomitant platinum-based chemotherapy and radiation therapy may improve survival of patients with locally advanced NSCLC. However, the available data are insufficient to accurately define the size of such a potential treatment benefit and the optimal schedule of chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.7">

64987</a>

6499]</li>

6500</ul>

6501</div>

6502</li>

6503<li>

6504The results from two randomized trials (including <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01134861">

6505RTOG-9410</a>

6506 [NCT01134861]) and a meta-analysis indicate that concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy provide greater survival benefit, albeit with more toxic effects, than sequential chemotherapy and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

65078</a>

6508-<a href="#cit/section_10.10">

650910</a>

6510][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6511Level of evidence A1</a>

6512]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6513<ol id="_484290" class="lower-alpha">

6514<li>

6515In the first trial, the combination of mitomycin C, vindesine, and cisplatin were given concurrently with split-course daily radiation therapy to 56 Gy compared with chemotherapy followed by continuous daily radiation therapy to 56 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

65168</a>

6517]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6518<ul id="_484391">

6519<li>

6520Five-year overall survival (OS) rates favored concurrent therapy (27% vs. 9%). </li>

6521<li>

6522Myelosuppression was greater among patients in the concurrent arm, but treatment-related mortality was less than 1% in both arms.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

65238</a>

6524]</li>

6525</ul>

6526</div>

6527</li>

6528<li>

6529In the second trial, 610 patients were randomly assigned to sequential chemotherapy with cisplatin and vinblastine followed by 63 Gy of radiation therapy, concurrent chemoradiation therapy using the same regimen, or concurrent chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide with twice-daily radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.9">

65309</a>

6531,<a href="#cit/section_10.10">

653210</a>

6533]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6534<ul id="_484392">

6535<li>

6536Median and 5-year survival were superior in the concurrent chemotherapy with daily radiation therapy arm (17 months vs. 14.6 months and 16% vs. 10% for sequential regimen [<em>

6537P</em>

6538 = .046]).</li>

6539</ul>

6540</div>

6541</li>

6542<li>

6543Two smaller studies also reported OS results that favored concurrent over sequential chemotherapy and radiation, although the results did not reach statistical significance.[<a href="#cit/section_10.10">

654410</a>

6545][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6546Level of evidence A1</a>

6547]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.11">

654811</a>

6549]</li>

6550</ol>

6551</div>

6552</li>

6553<li>

6554A meta-analysis of three trials evaluated concurrent versus sequential treatment (711 patients).[<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

65556</a>

6556]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6557<ul id="_484813">

6558<li>

6559The analysis indicated a significant benefit of concurrent versus sequential treatment (RR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;0.95; <em>

6560P</em>

6561 = .003). All used cisplatin-based regimens and once-daily radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

65626</a>

6563]</li>

6564<li>

6565More deaths (3% overall) were reported in the concurrent arm, but this did not reach statistical significance (RR, 1.60; CI, 0.75&#8211;3.44;

6566<em>

6567P</em>

6568 = .2).</li>

6569<li>

6570There was more acute esophagitis (grade 3 or worse) with concurrent treatment (range, 17%&#8211;26%) compared with sequential treatment (range, 0%&#8211;4%; RR, 6.77; <em>

6571P</em>

6572 = .001). Overall, the incidence of neutropenia (grade 3 or worse) was similar in both arms.</li>

6573</ul>

6574</div>

6575</li>

6576</ol>

6577</div>

6578<section id="_484651">

6579<h5 id="_484651_toc">

6580Radiation therapy dose escalation for concurrent chemoradiation</h5>

6581<p id="_484652" tabindex="-1">

6582With improvement in radiation therapy&#8211;delivery technology in the 1990s, including tumor-motion management and image guidance, phase I/II trials demonstrated the feasibility of dose-escalation radiation therapy to 74 Gy with concurrent chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.12">

658312</a>

6584-<a href="#cit/section_10.14">

658514</a>

6586] However, a phase III trial of a conventional dose of 60 Gy versus dose escalation to 74 Gy with concurrent weekly carboplatin/paclitaxel did not demonstrate improved local control or progression-free survival (PFS), and OS was worse with dose escalation (HR, 1.38 [1.09&#8211;1.76]; <em>

6587P</em>

6588 = .004). There was a nonsignificant increase in grade 5 events with dose escalation (10% vs. 2%) and higher incidence of grade 3 esophagitis (21% vs. 7%; <em>

6589P</em>

6590 = .0003).[<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

659115</a>

6592][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6593Level of evidence A1</a>

6594] </p>

6595</section>

6596<section id="_484656">

6597<h5 id="_484656_toc">

6598Systemic consolidation therapy before or after concurrent chemoradiation therapy</h5>

6599<section id="_485462">

6600<h6 id="_485462_toc">

6601Consolidation immunotherapy </h6>

6602<section id="_485463">

6603<h6 id="_485463_toc">

6604Durvalumab</h6>

6605<p id="_485464" tabindex="-1">

6606Durvalumab is a selective human IgG1 monoclonal antibody that blocks programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) binding to programmed death 1 (PD-1) and CD80, allowing T cells to recognize and kill tumor cells.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

660716</a>

6608]</p>

6609<p id="_485465" tabindex="-1">

6610Evidence (durvalumab):</p>

6611<div class="pdq-content-list">

6612<ol id="_485466">

6613<li>

6614The phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02125461">

6615PACIFIC</a>

6616 trial (NCT02125461) enrolled 713 patients with stage III NSCLC whose disease had not progressed after two or more cycles of platinum-based chemoradiation therapy. Patients were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive durvalumab (10 mg/kg intravenously) or placebo (every 2 weeks for up to 12 months).[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

661716</a>

6618] The coprimary end points were PFS assessed by blinded independent central review and OS (unplanned for the interim analysis).<div class="pdq-content-list">

6619<ul id="_485467">

6620<li>

6621 At the interim analysis, the coprimary end point of PFS was met. The median PFS was 16.8 months with durvalumab versus 5.6 months with placebo (HR, 0.52; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.65; <em>

6622P</em>

6623 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

662416</a>

6625][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6626Level of evidence B1</a>

6627] The 18-month PFS rate was 44.2% with durvalumab versus 27% with placebo.</li>

6628<li>

6629 PFS benefit was seen across all prespecified subgroups and was irrespective of PD-L1 expression before chemoradiation therapy or smoking status. <em class="gene-name">

6630EGFR</em>

6631 mutations were observed in 6% of patients (29 treated with durvalumab vs. 14 treated with placebo). The unstratified HR for the <em class="gene-name">

6632EGFR</em>

6633-mutated subgroup was 0.76 (95% CI, 0.35&#8211;1.64).</li>

6634<li>

6635 Grade 3 or 4 adverse events occurred in 29.9% of patients treated with durvalumab and in 26.1% of patients treated with placebo. The most common adverse event of grade 3 or 4 was pneumonia in 4.4% of patients treated with durvalumab and in 3.8% of patients treated with placebo.</li>

6636<li>

6637 OS was not assessed at the interim analysis.</li>

6638</ul>

6639</div>

6640</li>

6641</ol>

6642</div>

6643</section>

6644</section>

6645<section id="_485468">

6646<h6 id="_485468_toc">

6647Other systemic consolidation therapies</h6>

6648<p id="_485658" tabindex="-1">

6649The addition of induction chemotherapy before concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy has not been shown to improve survival.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

665017</a>

6651][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6652Level of evidence A1</a>

6653] </p>

6654<p id="_485469" tabindex="-1">

6655 Randomized trials of other consolidation systemic therapies, including docetaxel,[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

665618</a>

6657] gefitinib,[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

665819</a>

6659] and tecemotide (MUC1 antigen-specific immunotherapy) [<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

666020</a>

6661] have not shown an improvement in OS.[<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6662Level of evidence A1</a>

6663]</p>

6664</section>

6665<p id="_484658" tabindex="-1">

6666The role of consolidation systemic therapy after concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy for unresectable NSCLC remains unclear. Phase III trials of consolidation systemic therapy including conventional chemotherapy (docetaxel),[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

666718</a>

6668] tyrosine kinase inhibitors (gefitinib),[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

666919</a>

6670] and immunotherapy (tecemotide: MUC1 antigen-specific immunotherapy) [<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

667120</a>

6672] have not shown an improvement in OS.[<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6673Level of evidence A1</a>

6674]</p>

6675</section>

6676</section>

6677<section id="_4912">

6678<h4 id="_4912_toc">

6679Radiation therapy alone</h4>

6680<section id="_4914">

6681<h5 id="_4914_toc">

6682For treatment of locally advanced unresectable tumor in patients who are not candidates for chemotherapy </h5>

6683<p id="_48591" tabindex="-1">

6684Radiation therapy alone may provide benefit to patients with locally advanced unresectable stage III NSCLC. </p>

6685<p id="_4916" tabindex="-1">

6686Radiation therapy with traditional dose and fractionation schedules (1.8&#8211;2.0 Gy per fraction per day to 60&#8211;70 Gy in 6&#8211;7 weeks) results in reproducible long-term survival benefit in 5% to 10% of patients and significant palliation of symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

668721</a>

6688]</p>

6689<p id="_4917" tabindex="-1">

6690Evidence (radiation therapy for locally advanced unresectable tumor):</p>

6691<div class="pdq-content-list">

6692<ol id="_4918">

6693<li>

6694One prospective randomized clinical study showed the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

6695<ul id="_484393">

6696<li>

6697Radiation therapy given as three daily fractions improved OS compared with radiation therapy given as one daily fraction.[<a href="#cit/section_10.22">

669822</a>

6699][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6700Level of evidence A1</a>

6701]</li>

6702<li>

6703Patterns of failure for patients treated with radiation therapy alone included both locoregional and distant failures.</li>

6704</ul>

6705</div>

6706</li>

6707</ol>

6708</div>

6709</section>

6710<section id="_4920">

6711<h5 id="_4920_toc">

6712For patients requiring palliative treatment</h5>

6713<p id="_4921" tabindex="-1">

6714Radiation therapy may be effective in palliating symptomatic local involvement with NSCLC, such as the following:</p>

6715<div class="pdq-content-list">

6716<ul id="_48400">

6717<li>

6718Tracheal, esophageal, or bronchial compression.</li>

6719<li>

6720Pain.</li>

6721<li>

6722Vocal cord paralysis.</li>

6723<li>

6724Hemoptysis.</li>

6725<li>

6726Superior vena cava syndrome.</li>

6727</ul>

6728</div>

6729<p id="_4923" tabindex="-1">

6730 In some cases, endobronchial laser therapy and/or brachytherapy has been used to alleviate proximal obstructing lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

673123</a>

6732]</p>

6733<p id="_4924" tabindex="-1">

6734Evidence (radiation therapy for palliative treatment):</p>

6735<div class="pdq-content-list">

6736<ol id="_4925">

6737<li>

6738A systematic review identified six randomized trials of high-dose rate endobronchial brachytherapy (HDREB) alone or with external-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) or laser therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

673924</a>

6740]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6741<ul id="_484394">

6742<li>

6743Better overall symptom palliation and fewer re-treatments were required in previously untreated patients using EBRT alone.[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

674424</a>

6745][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6746Level of evidence A3</a>

6747]</li>

6748<li>

6749HDREB provided palliation of symptomatic patients with recurrent endobronchial obstruction previously treated by EBRT, when it was technically feasible. </li>

6750<li>

6751Although EBRT is frequently prescribed for symptom palliation, there is no consensus about when the fractionation scheme should be used.</li>

6752<li>

6753Although different multifraction regimens appear to provide similar symptom relief,[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

675425</a>

6755-<a href="#cit/section_10.30">

675630</a>

6757] single-fraction radiation may be insufficient for symptom relief compared with hypofractionated or standard regimens, as shown in the National Cancer Institute of Canada Clinical Trials Group trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003685">

6758NCT00003685</a>

6759).[<a href="#cit/section_10.27">

676027</a>

6761][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6762Level of evidence A3</a>

6763]</li>

6764<li>

6765Evidence of a modest increase in survival in patients with better performance status given high-dose radiation therapy is available.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

676625</a>

6767,<a href="#cit/section_10.26">

676826</a>

6769][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6770Level of evidence A1</a>

6771]</li>

6772</ul>

6773</div>

6774 </li>

6775</ol>

6776</div>

6777<p id="_48402" tabindex="-1">

6778Patients with stages IIIB or IIIC disease with poor performance status are candidates

6779for chest radiation therapy to palliate pulmonary symptoms (e.g., cough, shortness of

6780breath, hemoptysis, or pain).[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

678121</a>

6782][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6783Level of evidence C1</a>

6784] For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/cardiopulmonary-hp-pdq">

6785Cardiopulmonary Syndromes</a>

6786 and <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/pain/pain-hp-pdq">

6787Cancer Pain</a>

6788.</p>

6789</section>

6790</section>

6791</section>

6792<section id="_TrialSearch_4889_sid_10">

6793<h3 id="_TrialSearch_4889_sid_10_toc">

6794Current Clinical Trials</h3>

6795<p id="_TrialSearch_4889_22" tabindex="-1">

6796Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6797advanced clinical trial search</a>

6798 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6799General information</a>

6800 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6801</section>

6932 <section id="_48406">

6933

6934 <h2>

6935Treatment of Newly Diagnosed Stage IV, Relapsed, and Recurrent NSCLC</h2>

6936

6937 <div id="_section_48406" class="pdq-sections">

6938<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6939<h6>

6940In This Section</h6>

6941<ul>

6942<li>

6943<a href="#_484855_toc">

6944Factors Affecting Treatment Selection<ul>

6945<li>

6946<a href="#_484856_toc">

6947History and molecular features</a>

6948</li>

6949<li>

6950<a href="#_484858_toc">

6951Age and comorbidity</a>

6952</li>

6953<li>

6954<a href="#_485032_toc">

6955Performance status</a>

6956</li>

6957</ul>

6958</a>

6959</li>

6960<li>

6961<a href="#_48550_toc">

6962Treatment Options for Newly Diagnosed Stage IV, Relapsed, and Recurrent NSCLC (First-Line Therapy)<ul>

6963<li>

6964<a href="#_48414_toc">

6965Cytotoxic combination chemotherapy </a>

6966</li>

6967<li>

6968<a href="#_48622_toc">

6969Combination chemotherapy with monoclonal antibodies</a>

6970</li>

6971<li>

6972<a href="#_484890_toc">

6973Maintenance therapy after first-line chemotherapy (for patients with stable or responding disease after four cycles of platinum-based combination chemotherapy)</a>

6974</li>

6975<li>

6976<a href="#_48630_toc">

6977EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors</a>

6978</li>

6979<li>

6980<a href="#_485042_toc">

6981ALK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

6982ALK</em>

6983 translocations) </a>

6984</li>

6985<li>

6986<a href="#_485568_toc">

6987BRAF V600E and MEK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

6988BRAF</em>

6989 V600E mutations)</a>

6990</li>

6991<li>

6992<a href="#_484928_toc">

6993ROS1 inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

6994ROS1</em>

6995 rearrangements) </a>

6996</li>

6997<li>

6998<a href="#_485512_toc">

6999NTRK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7000NTRK</em>

7001 fusions)</a>

7002</li>

7003<li>

7004<a href="#_485713_toc">

7005RET inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7006RET</em>

7007 fusions) </a>

7008</li>

7009<li>

7010<a href="#_485795_toc">

7011MET inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7012MET</em>

7013 exon 14 skipping mutations)</a>

7014</li>

7015<li>

7016<a href="#_484931_toc">

7017Immune checkpoint inhibitors with or without chemotherapy </a>

7018</li>

7019<li>

7020<a href="#_485671_toc">

7021Everolimus</a>

7022</li>

7023<li>

7024<a href="#_484480_toc">

7025Local therapies and special considerations</a>

7026</li>

7027</ul>

7028</a>

7029</li>

7030<li>

7031<a href="#_TrialSearch_48406_sid_11_toc">

7032Current Clinical Trials</a>

7033</li>

7034</ul>

7035</nav>

7036<section id="_484855">

7037<h3 id="_484855_toc">

7038Factors Affecting Treatment Selection</h3>

7039<p id="_485820" tabindex="-1">

7040Forty percent of patients with newly diagnosed non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) have <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

7041stage IV disease</a>

7042. Treatment goals are to prolong survival and control disease-related symptoms. Treatment options include cytotoxic chemotherapy, targeted agents, and immunotherapy. Factors influencing treatment selection include comorbidity, performance status, histology, and molecular and immunologic features of the cancer. Therefore, assessment of tumor-genomic changes and programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression is critical before initiating therapy. Radiation therapy and surgery are generally used in selective cases for symptom palliation.</p>

7043<p id="_485660" tabindex="-1">

7044Factors that affect selection of treatment include the following:</p>

7045<div class="pdq-content-list">

7046<ul id="_485661">

7047<li>

7048<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484856">

7049History and molecular features</a>

7050.</li>

7051<li>

7052<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484858">

7053Age and comorbidity</a>

7054.</li>

7055<li>

7056<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485032">

7057Performance status</a>

7058.</li>

7059</ul>

7060</div>

7061<section id="_484856">

7062<h4 id="_484856_toc">

7063History and molecular features</h4>

7064<p id="_485862" tabindex="-1">

7065Patients with nonsquamous cell histology, good performance status, no history of hemoptysis or other bleeding, or recent history of cardiovascular events may benefit from the addition of bevacizumab to paclitaxel and carboplatin. Patients with tumors harboring sensitizing mutations in exons 19 or 21 of <em class="gene-name">

7066EGFR</em>

7067, particularly those from East Asia, never smokers, and those with adenocarcinoma may benefit from epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) as an alternative to first- or second-line chemotherapy. Patients with tumors harboring <em class="gene-name">

7068ALK</em>

7069 translocations, <em class="gene-name">

7070ROS1</em>

7071 rearrangements, or <em class="gene-name">

7072NTRK</em>

7073 fusions may benefit from anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), ROS1, or neurotrophic tyrosine kinase (NTRK) inhibitors as an alternative to first- or second-line chemotherapy. Patients with tumors expressing PD-L1 (&gt;50% by immunohistochemistry) have improved survival with pembrolizumab. The addition of pembrolizumab to carboplatin plus pemetrexed chemotherapy for nonsquamous advanced lung cancer improves survival irrespective of PD-L1 expression.[<a href="#cit/section_11.1">

70741</a>

7075][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7076Level of evidence A1</a>

7077] Second-line systemic therapy with nivolumab, docetaxel, pemetrexed, or pembrolizumab for PD-L1&#8722;positive tumors also improves survival in patients with good performance status (who have not received the same or a similar agent in the first-line setting).[<a href="#cit/section_11.2">

70782</a>

7079][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7080Level of evidence A1</a>

7081] </p>

7082<p id="_485863" tabindex="-1">

7083The role of systemic therapy in patients with an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status below 2 is less certain.</p>

7084<p id="_484857" tabindex="-1">

7085Patients with adenocarcinoma may benefit from pemetrexed [<a href="#cit/section_11.3">

70863</a>

7087] and bevacizumab, as well as from combination chemotherapy with pembrolizumab. Patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, well-differentiated, nonfunctional, neuroendocrine tumors benefit from the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor, everolimus. </p>

7088</section>

7089<section id="_484858">

7090<h4 id="_484858_toc">

7091Age and comorbidity</h4>

7092<p id="_484859" tabindex="-1">

7093Evidence supports the concept that older patients with good performance status and limited comorbidity may benefit from combination chemotherapy. Age alone should not dictate treatment-related decisions in patients with advanced NSCLC. Older patients with a good performance status enjoy longer survival and a better quality of life when treated with chemotherapy compared with supportive care alone. Caution should be exercised when extrapolating data for patients aged 70 to 79 years to patients aged 80 years or older because only a very small number of patients aged 80 years or older have been enrolled in clinical trials, and the benefit in this group is uncertain.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

70944</a>

7095,<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

70965</a>

7097]</p>

7098<p id="_484860" tabindex="-1">

7099Evidence (age and comorbidity):</p>

7100<div class="pdq-content-list">

7101<ol id="_484861">

7102<li>

7103Platinum-containing combination chemotherapy regimens provide clinical benefit when compared with supportive care or single-agent therapy; however, such treatment may be contraindicated in some older patients because of the age-related reduction in the functional reserve of many organs and/or comorbid conditions. Approximately two-thirds of patients with NSCLC are aged 65 years or older, and approximately 40% are aged 70 years or older.[<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

71046</a>

7105] Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program data suggest that the percentage of patients older than 70 years is closer to 50%.</li>

7106<li>

7107A review of the SEER Medicare data from 1994 to 1999 found a much lower rate of chemotherapy use than expected for the overall population.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

71087</a>

7109] The same data suggested that older patients may have more comorbidities or a higher rate of functional compromise that would make study participation difficult, if not contraindicated; lack of clinical trial data may influence decisions to treat individual patients with standard chemotherapy.</li>

7110<li>

7111Single-agent chemotherapy and combination chemotherapy clearly benefit at least some older patients. In the Elderly Lung Cancer Vinorelbine Italian Study, 154 patients who were older than 70 years were randomly assigned to vinorelbine or supportive care.[<a href="#cit/section_11.8">

71128</a>

7113]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7114<ul id="_484862">

7115<li>

7116Patients who were treated with vinorelbine had a 1-year survival rate of 32%, compared with 14% for those who were treated with supportive care alone. Quality-of-life parameters were also significantly improved in the chemotherapy arm, and toxic effects were acceptable.</li>

7117</ul>

7118</div>

7119</li>

7120<li>

7121A trial from Japan compared single-agent docetaxel with vinorelbine in 180 patients older than 70 years with good performance status.[<a href="#cit/section_11.9">

71229</a>

7123]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7124<ul id="_484863">

7125<li>

7126Response rates (22% vs. 10%) and progression-free survival (PFS) (5.4 months vs. 3.1 months) were significantly better with docetaxel, but median survival (14.3 months vs. 9.9 months) and 1-year survival rates (59% vs. 37%) did not reach statistical significance.</li>

7127</ul>

7128</div>

7129</li>

7130<li>

7131Retrospective data analyzing and comparing younger (age &lt;70 years) patients with older (age &#8805;70 years) patients who participated in large randomized trials of doublet combinations have also shown that older patients may derive the same survival benefit, but with a higher risk of toxic effects in the bone marrow.[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

71324</a>

7133,<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

71345</a>

7135,<a href="#cit/section_11.10">

713610</a>

7137-<a href="#cit/section_11.13">

713813</a>

7139]</li>

7140</ol>

7141</div>

7142</section>

7143<section id="_485032">

7144<h4 id="_485032_toc">

7145Performance status</h4>

7146<p id="_485033" tabindex="-1">

7147Performance status is among the most important prognostic factors for survival of patients with NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_11.14">

714814</a>

7149] The benefit of therapy for this group of patients has been evaluated through retrospective analyses and prospective clinical trials.</p>

7150<p id="_485034" tabindex="-1">

7151The results support further evaluation of chemotherapeutic

7152approaches for both metastatic and locally advanced NSCLC; however, the efficacy of current platinum-based chemotherapy combinations is such

7153that no specific regimen can be regarded as standard therapy. Outside of a

7154clinical trial setting, chemotherapy should be given only to patients with good

7155performance status and evaluable tumor lesions, who desire this treatment after

7156being fully informed of its anticipated risks and limited benefits.

7157 </p>

7158<p id="_485662" tabindex="-1">

7159Randomized controlled trials of patients with stage IV disease and good performance status have shown that cisplatin-based

7160chemotherapy improves survival and palliates disease-related symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_11.2">

71612</a>

7162][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7163Level of evidence A1</a>

7164] </p>

7165<p id="_485035" tabindex="-1">

7166Evidence (performance status):</p>

7167<div class="pdq-content-list">

7168<ol id="_485036">

7169<li>

7170The Cancer and Leukemia Group B trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003117">

7171CLB-9730</a>

7172 [NCT00003117]), which compared carboplatin and paclitaxel with single-agent paclitaxel, enrolled 99 patients with a performance status of 2 (18% of the study's population).[<a href="#cit/section_11.12">

717312</a>

7174]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7175<ul id="_485037">

7176<li>

7177When compared with patients with a performance status of 0 to 1, who had a median survival of 8.8 months and a 1-year survival rate of 38%, the corresponding median survival figures for patients with a performance status of 2 were 3.0 months and a 1-year survival rate of 14%; this demonstrates the poor prognosis conferred by a lower performance status. These differences were statistically significant.</li>

7178<li>

7179When patients with a performance status of 2 were analyzed by treatment arm, those who received combination chemotherapy had a significantly higher response rate (24% vs. 10%), longer median survival (4.7 months vs. 2.4 months), and a superior 1-year survival rate (18% vs. 10%), compared with those who were treated with single-agent paclitaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_11.12">

718012</a>

7181]</li>

7182</ul>

7183</div>

7184</li>

7185<li>

7186A phase III trial compared single-agent pemetrexed with the combination of carboplatin and pemetrexed in 205 patients with a performance status of 2 who had not had any previous chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.15">

718715</a>

7188][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7189Level of evidence A1</a>

7190]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7191<ul id="_485038">

7192<li>

7193 Median overall survival (OS) was 5.3 months for the pemetrexed-alone group and 9.3 months for the carboplatin-and-pemetrexed group (hazard ratio [HR], 0.62; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.46&#8211;0.83; <em>

7194P</em>

7195 = .001).</li>

7196<li>

7197Median PFS was 2.8 months for the pemetrexed-alone group and 5.8 months for the carboplatin-and-pemetrexed group (<em>

7198P</em>

7199 &lt; .001).</li>

7200<li>

7201The response rates were 10.3% for the pemetrexed-alone group and 23.8% for the carboplatin-and-pemetrexed group (<em>

7202P</em>

7203 = .032).</li>

7204<li>

7205Side effects were more frequent in the combination arm, as expected.</li>

7206</ul>

7207</div>

7208<p id="_485039" tabindex="-1">

7209This study, which was performed in eight centers in Brazil and one center in the United States, reported rates of OS and PFS that were higher than has historically been noted in most, although not all, other published studies. This may indicate differences in patient selection.</p>

7210</li>

7211<li>

7212A subset analysis of 68 patients with a performance status of 2 from a trial that randomly assigned more than 1,200 patients to four platinum-based regimens has been published.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7213<ul id="_485040">

7214<li>

7215Despite a high incidence of adverse events, including five deaths, the final analysis showed that the overall toxic effects experienced by patients with a performance status of 2 was not significantly different from that experienced by patients with a performance status of 0 to 1.</li>

7216<li>

7217An efficacy analysis demonstrated an overall response rate of 14%, median survival time of 4.1 months, and a 1-year survival rate of 19%; all were substantially inferior to the patients with performance status of 0 to 1.</li>

7218</ul>

7219</div>

7220</li>

7221<li>

7222A phase II randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00006004">

7223E-1599</a>

7224 [NCT00006004]) of attenuated dosages of cisplatin plus gemcitabine and carboplatin plus paclitaxel included 102 patients with a performance status of 2.[<a href="#cit/section_11.16">

722516</a>

7226]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7227<ul id="_485041">

7228<li>

7229Response rates were 25% in the cisplatin-plus-gemcitabine arm and 16% in the carboplatin-plus-paclitaxel arm; median survival times were 6.8 months in the cisplatin-plus-gemcitabine arm and 6.1 months in the carboplatin-plus-paclitaxel arm; 1-year survival rates were 25% in the cisplatin-plus-gemcitabine arm and 19% in the carboplatin-plus-paclitaxel arm. None of these differences was statistically significant, but the survival figures were longer than expected, based on historical controls.</li>

7230</ul>

7231</div>

7232</li>

7233<li>

7234Results from two trials suggest that patients with a performance status of 2 may experience symptom improvement.[<a href="#cit/section_11.17">

723517</a>

7236,<a href="#cit/section_11.18">

723718</a>

7238]</li>

7239</ol>

7240</div>

7241</section>

7242</section>

7243<section id="_48550">

7244<h3 id="_48550_toc">

7245Treatment Options for Newly Diagnosed Stage IV, Relapsed, and Recurrent NSCLC (First-Line Therapy)</h3>

7246<p id="_48595" tabindex="-1">

7247Treatment options for patients with newly diagnosed <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

7248stage IV</a>

7249, relapsed, and recurrent disease include the following: </p>

7250<div class="pdq-content-list">

7251<ol id="_48410">

7252<li>

7253<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_48414">

7254Cytotoxic combination chemotherapy</a>

7255 with platinum (cisplatin or carboplatin) and paclitaxel, gemcitabine, docetaxel, vinorelbine, irinotecan, protein-bound paclitaxel, or pemetrexed. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7256<ul id="_485270">

7257<li>

7258<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_48414">

7259Combination chemotherapy</a>

7260.</li>

7261<li>

7262<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485264">

7263Drug and dose schedule</a>

7264.</li>

7265</ul>

7266</div>

7267</li>

7268<li>

7269 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_48622">

7270Combination chemotherapy with monoclonal antibodies</a>

7271.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7272<ul id="_485271">

7273<li>

7274<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484874">

7275Bevacizumab</a>

7276.</li>

7277<li>

7278<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484880">

7279Cetuximab</a>

7280.</li>

7281<li>

7282<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484885">

7283Necitumumab</a>

7284.</li>

7285</ul>

7286</div>

7287</li>

7288<li>

7289<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484890">

7290Maintenance therapy after first-line chemotherapy </a>

7291 (for patients with stable or responding disease after four cycles of platinum-based combination chemotherapy). <div class="pdq-content-list">

7292<ul id="_485272">

7293<li>

7294Maintenance therapy following first-line chemotherapy.</li>

7295<li>

7296Pemetrexed following first-line platinum-based combination chemotherapy.</li>

7297</ul>

7298</div>

7299</li>

7300<li>

7301<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_48630">

7302Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI)</a>

7303 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7304EGFR</em>

7305 mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7306<ul id="_485273">

7307<li>

7308<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485472">

7309Osimertinib</a>

7310.</li>

7311<li>

7312 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485666">

7313Dacomitinib</a>

7314.</li>

7315<li>

7316<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484907">

7317Gefitinib</a>

7318.</li>

7319<li>

7320<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484914">

7321Erlotinib</a>

7322.</li>

7323<li>

7324<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484919">

7325Afatinib</a>

7326.</li>

7327</ul>

7328</div>

7329 </li>

7330<li>

7331<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485042">

7332Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) inhibitors </a>

7333(for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7334ALK</em>

7335 translocations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7336<ul id="_485274">

7337<li>

7338<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485477">

7339Alectinib</a>

7340.</li>

7341<li>

7342<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485790">

7343Lorlatinib</a>

7344.</li>

7345<li>

7346<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485043">

7347Crizotinib</a>

7348.</li>

7349<li>

7350<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485108">

7351Ceritinib</a>

7352.</li>

7353<li>

7354<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485531">

7355Brigatinib</a>

7356.</li>

7357</ul>

7358</div>

7359 </li>

7360<li>

7361<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485568">

7362BRAF V600E and MEK inhibitors</a>

7363 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7364BRAF</em>

7365 V600E mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7366<ul id="_485565">

7367<li>

7368<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485570">

7369Dabrafenib and trametinib</a>

7370.</li>

7371</ul>

7372</div>

7373</li>

7374<li>

7375<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484928">

7376ROS1 inhibitors</a>

7377 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7378ROS1</em>

7379 rearrangements).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7380<ul id="_485275">

7381<li>

7382<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485566">

7383Entrectinib</a>

7384. </li>

7385<li>

7386<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484929">

7387Crizotinib</a>

7388.</li>

7389</ul>

7390</div>

7391</li>

7392<li>

7393<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485512">

7394Neurotrophic tyrosine kinase (NTRK) inhibitors</a>

7395 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7396NTRK</em>

7397 fusions).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7398<ul id="_485526">

7399<li>

7400<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485513">

7401Larotrectinib</a>

7402.</li>

7403<li>

7404 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485579">

7405Entrectinib</a>

7406.</li>

7407</ul>

7408</div>

7409</li>

7410<li>

7411<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485713">

7412RET inhibitors</a>

7413 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7414RET</em>

7415 fusions).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7416<ul id="_485738">

7417<li>

7418<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485715">

7419Selpercatinib</a>

7420.</li>

7421<li>

7422 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485883">

7423Pralsetinib</a>

7424.

7425</li>

7426</ul>

7427</div>

7428 </li>

7429<li>

7430<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485795">

7431MET inhibitors</a>

7432 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

7433MET</em>

7434 exon 14 skipping mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7435<ul id="_485789">

7436<li>

7437 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485797">

7438Tepotinib</a>

7439. </li>

7440<li>

7441 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485801">

7442Capmatinib</a>

7443. </li>

7444</ul>

7445</div>

7446 </li>

7447<li>

7448<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484931">

7449Immune checkpoint inhibitors with or without chemotherapy</a>

7450.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7451<ul id="_485276">

7452<li>

7453<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484932">

7454Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy</a>

7455.</li>

7456<li>

7457<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485520">

7458Pembrolizumab alone</a>

7459.</li>

7460<li>

7461<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485959">

7462Cemiplimab-rwlc plus chemotherapy</a>

7463.</li>

7464<li>

7465<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485964">

7466Cemiplimab-rwlc alone</a>

7467.</li>

7468<li>

7469<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485969">

7470Tremelimumab</a>

7471.</li>

7472<li>

7473 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485805">

7474Atezolizumab alone</a>

7475.</li>

7476</ul>

7477</div>

7478</li>

7479<li>

7480<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485671">

7481Everolimus</a>

7482 (for patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional, neuroendocrine tumors).</li>

7483<li>

7484<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_484480">

7485Local therapies and special considerations</a>

7486.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7487<ul id="_485107">

7488<li>

7489<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485098">

7490Endobronchial laser therapy and/or brachytherapy</a>

7491 (for obstructing lesions).[<a href="#cit/section_11.19">

749219</a>

7493]</li>

7494<li>

7495<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485102">

7496External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT)</a>

7497 (primarily for palliation of local symptomatic tumor growth).[<a href="#cit/section_11.20">

749820</a>

7499-<a href="#cit/section_11.22">

750022</a>

7501]</li>

7502<li>

7503<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485337">

7504Treatment of second primary tumor.</a>

7505</li>

7506<li>

7507<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485339">

7508Treatment of brain metastases.</a>

7509</li>

7510</ul>

7511</div>

7512</li>

7513<li>

7514Clinical trials can be considered as first-line therapy.</li>

7515</ol>

7516</div>

7517<section id="_48414">

7518<h4 id="_48414_toc">

7519Cytotoxic combination chemotherapy </h4>

7520<section id="_485252">

7521<h5 id="_485252_toc">

7522Combination chemotherapy</h5>

7523<p id="_485253" tabindex="-1">

7524The type and number of chemotherapy drugs to be used for the treatment of patients with advanced NSCLC has been extensively evaluated in randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses. </p>

7525<p id="_485254" tabindex="-1">

7526Several randomized trials have evaluated various drugs combined with either cisplatin or carboplatin in previously untreated patients with advanced NSCLC. On the basis of meta-analyses of the trials, the following conclusions can be drawn:</p>

7527<div class="pdq-content-list">

7528<ul id="_485255">

7529<li>

7530Certain three-drug combinations that add so-called targeted agents may result in superior survival.</li>

7531<li>

7532EGFR inhibitors may benefit selected patients with <em class="gene-name">

7533EGFR</em>

7534 mutations. </li>

7535<li>

7536Maintenance chemotherapy after four cycles of platinum combination chemotherapy may improve PFS and OS.</li>

7537<li>

7538Platinum combinations with vinorelbine, paclitaxel, docetaxel, gemcitabine, irinotecan, protein-bound paclitaxel, and pemetrexed yield similar improvements in survival. Types and frequencies of toxic effects differ, and these may determine the preferred regimen for an individual patient. Patients with adenocarcinoma may benefit from pemetrexed.</li>

7539<li>

7540Cisplatin and carboplatin yield similar improvements in outcome with different toxic effects. Some, but not all, trials and meta-analyses of trials suggest that outcomes with cisplatin may be superior, although with a higher risk of certain toxicities such as nausea and vomiting.</li>

7541<li>

7542Nonplatinum combinations offer no advantage to platinum-based chemotherapy, and some studies demonstrate inferiority.</li>

7543<li>

7544Three-drug combinations of the commonly used chemotherapy drugs do not result in superior survival and are more toxic than two-drug combinations.</li>

7545</ul>

7546</div>

7547<p id="_485256" tabindex="-1">

7548Evidence (combination chemotherapy):</p>

7549<div class="pdq-content-list">

7550<ol id="_485257">

7551<li>

7552The Cochrane Collaboration reviewed data from all randomized controlled trials published between January 1980 and June 2006, comparing a doublet regimen with a single-agent regimen or comparing a triplet regimen with a doublet regimen in patients with advanced NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_11.23">

755323</a>

7554] Sixty-five trials (13,601 patients) were identified.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7555<ul id="_485258">

7556<li>

7557In the trials that compared a doublet regimen with a single-agent regimen, a significant increase was observed in tumor response (odds ratio [OR], 0.42; 95% CI, 0.37&#8211;0.47; <em>

7558P</em>

7559 &lt; .001) and 1-year survival (OR, 0.80; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;0.91; <em>

7560P</em>

7561 &lt; .001) in favor of the doublet regimen. The absolute benefit in 1-year survival was 5%, which corresponds to an increase in 1-year survival from 30% with a single-agent regimen to 35% with a doublet regimen. The rates of grades 3 and 4 toxic effects caused by doublet regimens were statistically increased compared with rates after single-agent therapy, with ORs ranging from 1.2 to 6.2. Infection rates did not increase in doublet regimens.</li>

7562<li>

7563There was no increase in 1-year survival (OR, 1.01; 95% CI, 0.85&#8211;1.21; <em>

7564P</em>

7565 = .88) for triplet regimens versus doublet regimens. The median survival ratio was 1.00 (95% CI, 0.94&#8211;1.06; <em>

7566P</em>

7567 = .97).</li>

7568</ul>

7569</div>

7570</li>

7571<li>

7572Several meta-analyses have evaluated whether cisplatin or carboplatin regimens are superior, with variable results.[<a href="#cit/section_11.24">

757324</a>

7574-<a href="#cit/section_11.26">

757526</a>

7576] One meta-analysis reported individual patient data for 2,968 patients entered in nine randomized trials.[<a href="#cit/section_11.24">

757724</a>

7578]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7579<ul id="_485259">

7580<li>

7581The objective response rate was higher for patients treated with cisplatin (30%) than for patients treated with carboplatin (24%); (OR, 1.37; 95% CI, 1.16&#8211;1.61; <em>

7582P</em>

7583 &lt; .001).</li>

7584<li>

7585Carboplatin treatment was associated with a nonstatistically significant increase in the hazard of mortality relative to treatment with cisplatin (HR, 1.07; 95% CI, 0.99&#8211;1.15; <em>

7586P</em>

7587 = .100). </li>

7588<li>

7589In patients with nonsquamous cell tumors and in patients treated with third-generation chemotherapy, carboplatin-based chemotherapy was associated with a statistically significant increase in mortality (HR, 1.12; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.23 in patients with nonsquamous cell tumors and HR, 1.11; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.21 in patients treated with third-generation chemotherapy).</li>

7590<li>

7591Treatment-related toxic effects were also assessed in the meta-analysis. More thrombocytopenia was seen with carboplatin than with cisplatin (12% vs. 6%; OR, 2.27; 95% CI, 1.71&#8211;3.01; <em>

7592P</em>

7593 &lt; .001), but

7594cisplatin caused more nausea and vomiting (8% vs. 18%; OR, 0.42; 95% CI, 0.33&#8211;0.53; <em>

7595P </em>

7596&lt; .001) and renal toxic effects (0.5% vs. 1.5%; OR, 0.37; 95% CI, 0.15&#8211;0.88; <em>

7597P</em>

7598 = .018).</li>

7599<li>

7600The authors concluded that treatment with cisplatin was not associated with a substantial increase in the overall risk of severe toxic effects. This comprehensive individual-patient meta-analysis is consistent with the conclusions of other meta-analyses that were based on essentially the same clinical trials, but which used only published data.</li>

7601</ul>

7602</div>

7603</li>

7604<li>

7605Three literature-based meta-analyses have trials that compared platinum with nonplatinum combinations.[<a href="#cit/section_11.27">

760627</a>

7607-<a href="#cit/section_11.29">

760829</a>

7609]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7610<ol id="_485260" class="lower-alpha">

7611<li>

7612The first meta-analysis identified 37 assessable trials that included 7,633 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_11.27">

761327</a>

7614]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7615<ul id="_485261">

7616<li>

7617A 62% increase in the OR for response was attributable to platinum-based therapy (OR, 1.62; 95% CI, 1.46&#8211;1.8; <em>

7618P</em>

7619 &lt; .001). The 1-year survival rate was increased by 5% with platinum-based regimens (34% vs. 29%; OR, 1.21; 95% CI, 1.09&#8211;1.35; <em>

7620P</em>

7621 = .003).</li>

7622<li>

7623No statistically significant increase in 1-year survival was found when platinum therapies were compared with third-generation-based combination regimens (OR, 1.11; 95% CI, 0.96&#8211;1.28; <em>

7624P</em>

7625 = .17).</li>

7626<li>

7627The toxic effects of platinum-based regimens was significantly higher for hematologic toxic effects, nephrotoxic effects, and nausea and vomiting but not for neurological toxic effects, febrile neutropenia rate, or toxic death rate. These results are consistent with the second literature-based meta-analysis. </li>

7628</ul>

7629</div>

7630</li>

7631<li>

7632The second meta-analysis identified 17 trials that included 4,920 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_11.28">

763328</a>

7634]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7635<ul id="_485262">

7636<li>

7637The use of platinum-based doublet regimens was associated with a slightly higher survival at 1 year (relative risk [RR], 1.08; 95% CI, 1.01%&#8211;1.16%; <em>

7638P</em>

7639 = .03) and a better partial response (RR, 1.11; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.21; <em>

7640P</em>

7641 = .02), with a higher risk of anemia, nausea, and neurological toxic effects. </li>

7642<li>

7643In subanalyses, cisplatin-based doublet regimens improved survival at 1 year (RR,

76441.16%; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;1.27; <em>

7645P</em>

7646 = .001), complete response (RR, 2.29; 95% CI, 1.08&#8211;4.88; <em>

7647P</em>

7648 = .03), and partial response (RR, 1.19; 95% CI, 1.07&#8211;1.32; <em>

7649P</em>

7650 = .002), with an increased risk of anemia, neutropenia, neurological toxic effects, and nausea.</li>

7651<li>

7652Conversely, carboplatin-based doublet regimens did not increase survival at 1 year (RR, 0.95; 95% CI, 0.85&#8211;1.07; <em>

7653P</em>

7654 = .43).</li>

7655</ul>

7656</div>

7657</li>

7658<li>

7659The third meta-analysis of phase III trials randomizing platinum-based versus nonplatinum combinations as first-line chemotherapy identified 14 trials.[<a href="#cit/section_11.29">

766029</a>

7661] Experimental arms were gemcitabine and vinorelbine (n = 4), gemcitabine and taxane (n = 7), gemcitabine and epirubicin (n = 1), paclitaxel and vinorelbine (n = 1), and gemcitabine and ifosfamide (n = 1). This meta-analysis was limited to the set of 11 phase III studies that used a platinum-based doublet (2,298 patients in the platinum-based arm and 2,304 patients in the nonplatinum arm).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7662<ul id="_485263">

7663<li>

7664Patients treated with a platinum-based regimen benefited from a statistically significant reduction in the risk of death at 1 year (OR, 0.88; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;0.99; <em>

7665P</em>

7666 = .044) and a lower risk of being refractory to chemotherapy (OR, 0.87; CI, 0.73&#8211;0.99;<em>

7667 P</em>

7668 = .049). </li>

7669<li>

7670Forty-four (1.9%) toxic-related deaths were reported for platinum-based regimens and 29 (1.3%) toxic-related deaths were reported for nonplatinum regimens (OR, 1.53; CI, 0.96&#8211;2.49; <em>

7671P</em>

7672 = .08). An increased risk of grade 3 to 4 gastrointestinal and hematologic toxic effects for patients treated with platinum-based chemotherapy was statistically demonstrated. There was no statistically significant increase in the risk of febrile neutropenia (OR, 1.23; CI, 0.94&#8211;1.60; <em>

7673P</em>

7674 = .063).</li>

7675</ul>

7676</div>

7677</li>

7678</ol>

7679</div>

7680</li>

7681</ol>

7682</div>

7683</section>

7684<section id="_485264">

7685<h5 id="_485264_toc">

7686Drug and dose schedule</h5>

7687<p id="_485265" tabindex="-1">

7688Among the active combinations, definitive recommendations regarding drug dose and schedule cannot be made, except for carboplatin, pemetrexed, and pembrolizumab for patients with nonsquamous tumor histology.</p>

7689<p id="_485266" tabindex="-1">

7690Evidence (drug and dose schedule):</p>

7691<div class="pdq-content-list">

7692<ol id="_485267">

7693<li>

7694One meta-analysis of seven trials that included 2,867 patients assessed the benefit of docetaxel versus vinorelbine.[<a href="#cit/section_11.30">

769530</a>

7696] Docetaxel was administered with a platinum agent in three trials, with gemcitabine in two trials, or as monotherapy in two trials. Vinca alkaloid (vinorelbine in six trials and vindesine in one trial) was administered with cisplatin in six trials or alone in one trial. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7697<ul id="_485268">

7698<li>

7699The pooled estimate for OS showed an 11% improvement in favor of docetaxel (HR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.96; <em>

7700P</em>

7701 = .004). Sensitivity analyses that considered only vinorelbine as a comparator or only the doublet regimens showed similar improvements. </li>

7702<li>

7703Grade 3 to 4 neutropenia and grade 3 to 4 serious adverse events were less frequent with docetaxel-based regimens (OR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.38&#8211;0.89; <em>

7704P</em>

7705 = .013) versus vinca alkaloid-based regimens (OR, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.55&#8211;0.84; <em>

7706P</em>

7707 &lt; .001).</li>

7708</ul>

7709</div>

7710</li>

7711<li>

7712Two randomized trials compared weekly versus every-3-week dosing of paclitaxel and carboplatin, which reported no significant difference in efficacy and better tolerability for weekly administration.[<a href="#cit/section_11.31">

771331</a>

7714,<a href="#cit/section_11.32">

771532</a>

7716] Although meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials suggest that cisplatin combinations may be superior to carboplatin or nonplatinum combinations, the clinical relevance of the differences in efficacy must be balanced against the anticipated tolerability, logistics of administration, and familiarity of the medical staff in making treatment decisions for individual patients. </li>

7717<li>

7718A large, noninferiority, phase III randomized study compared the OS in 1,725 chemotherapy-na&#239;ve patients with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC and a performance status of 0 to 1.[<a href="#cit/section_11.3">

77193</a>

7720] Patients received cisplatin 75 mg/m<span class="sup">

77212</span>

7722 on day 1 and gemcitabine 1,250 mg/m<span class="sup">

77232</span>

7724 on days 1 and 8 (n = 863) or cisplatin 75 mg/m<span class="sup">

77252</span>

7726 and pemetrexed 500 mg/m<span class="sup">

77272</span>

7728 on day 1 (n = 862) every 3 weeks for up to six cycles.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7729<ul id="_485269">

7730<li>

7731OS for cisplatin and pemetrexed (median survival, 10.3 months) was noninferior to cisplatin and gemcitabine (median survival, 10.3 months; HR, 0.94; 95% CI, 0.84%&#8211;1.05%).</li>

7732<li>

7733In patients with adenocarcinoma (n = 847), OS was statistically superior for cisplatin and pemetrexed (12.6 months) versus cisplatin and gemcitabine (10.9 months); in patients with large cell carcinoma (n = 153), OS was statistically superior for cisplatin and pemetrexed (10.4 months) versus cisplatin and gemcitabine (6.7 months).</li>

7734<li>

7735In contrast, in patients with squamous cell histology (n = 473), there was a significant improvement in survival with cisplatin and gemcitabine (10.8 months) versus cisplatin and pemetrexed (9.4 months). For cisplatin and pemetrexed, rates of grade 3 or 4 neutropenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia (<em>

7736P</em>

7737 &#8804; .001); febrile neutropenia (<em>

7738P</em>

7739 = .002); and alopecia (<em>

7740P</em>

7741 &lt; .001) were significantly lower, whereas grade 3 or 4 nausea (<em>

7742P</em>

7743 = .004) was more common.</li>

7744<li>

7745The results of this study suggested that the cisplatin and pemetrexed doublet is another alternative doublet for first-line chemotherapy

7746for advanced NSCLC. The results also suggested that there may be differences in outcome depending on histology.</li>

7747</ul>

7748</div>

7749</li>

7750</ol>

7751</div>

7752</section>

7753</section>

7754<section id="_48622">

7755<h4 id="_48622_toc">

7756Combination chemotherapy with monoclonal antibodies</h4>

7757<section id="_484874">

7758<h5 id="_484874_toc">

7759Bevacizumab</h5>

7760<p id="_485299" tabindex="-1">

7761Evidence (bevacizumab):</p>

7762<div class="pdq-content-list">

7763<ol id="_484876">

7764<li>

7765Two randomized trials have evaluated the addition of bevacizumab, an antibody targeting vascular endothelial growth factor, to standard first-line combination chemotherapy. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7766<ol id="_484877" class="lower-alpha">

7767<li>

7768In a randomized study of 878 patients with recurrent or advanced stage IIIB/IV NSCLC, 444 patients received paclitaxel and carboplatin alone, and 434 patients received paclitaxel and carboplatin plus bevacizumab.[<a href="#cit/section_11.33">

776933</a>

7770] Chemotherapy was administered every 3 weeks for six cycles, and bevacizumab was administered every 3 weeks until disease progression was evident or toxic effects were intolerable. Patients with squamous cell tumors, brain metastases, clinically significant hemoptysis, or inadequate organ function or performance status (ECOG performance status &gt;1) were excluded.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7771<ul id="_484878">

7772<li>

7773Median survival was 12.3 months in the group assigned to chemotherapy plus bevacizumab, as compared with 10.3 months in the chemotherapy-alone group (HR<sub>

7774death</sub>

7775, 0.79; <em>

7776P</em>

7777 = .003).</li>

7778<li>

7779Median PFS was 6.2 months in the group assigned to chemotherapy plus bevacizumab (HR<sub>

7780disease progression</sub>

7781, 0.66; <em>

7782P</em>

7783 &lt; .001), with a 35% response rate (<em>

7784P</em>

7785 &lt; .001), and 4.5 months in the chemotherapy-alone group (HR<sub>

7786disease progression</sub>

7787, 0.66; <em>

7788P</em>

7789 &lt; .001), with a 15% response rate (<em>

7790P</em>

7791 &lt; .001).</li>

7792<li>

7793Rates of clinically significant bleeding were 4.4% in the group assigned to chemotherapy plus bevacizumab and 0.7% in the chemotherapy-alone group (<em>

7794P</em>

7795 &lt; .001). There were 15 treatment-related deaths in the chemotherapy-plus-bevacizumab group, including five from pulmonary hemorrhage.</li>

7796<li>

7797For this subgroup of patients with NSCLC, the addition of bevacizumab to paclitaxel and carboplatin may provide survival benefit.[<a href="#cit/section_11.33">

779833</a>

7799][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7800Level of evidence A1</a>

7801]</li>

7802</ul>

7803</div>

7804</li>

7805<li>

7806Another randomized, phase III trial investigated the efficacy and safety of cisplatin-gemcitabine plus bevacizumab.[<a href="#cit/section_11.34">

780734</a>

7808] Patients were randomly assigned to receive cisplatin (80 mg/m<span class="sup">

78092</span>

7810) and gemcitabine (1,250 mg/m<span class="sup">

78112</span>

7812) for up to six cycles, plus low-dose bevacizumab (7.5 mg/kg), high-dose bevacizumab (15 mg/kg), or placebo every 3 weeks until disease progression. The primary end point was amended from OS to PFS during the course of the study. A total of 1,043 patients were accrued (placebo group, n = 347; low-dose group, n = 345; high-dose group, n = 351). <div class="pdq-content-list">

7813<ul id="_484879">

7814<li>

7815PFS was significantly prolonged with the addition of bevacizumab; the HRs for PFS were 0.75 in the low-dose group (median PFS, 6.7 months vs. 6.1 months for the placebo group; <em>

7816P</em>

7817 = .03) and 0.82 in the high-dose group compared with the placebo group (median PFS, 6.5 months vs. 6.1 months for the placebo group; <em>

7818P</em>

7819 = .03).[<a href="#cit/section_11.34">

782034</a>

7821][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7822Level of evidence A1</a>

7823]</li>

7824<li>

7825Objective response rates were also improved with the addition of bevacizumab, and they were 20.1% for placebo, 34.1% for low-dose bevacizumab, and 30.4% for high-dose bevacizumab plus cisplatin/gemcitabine.</li>

7826<li>

7827Incidence of grade 3 or greater adverse events was similar across arms.</li>

7828<li>

7829Grade 3 or greater pulmonary hemorrhage rates were 1.5% or less for all arms, despite 9% of patients receiving therapeutic anticoagulation. </li>

7830<li>

7831These results support the addition of bevacizumab to platinum-containing chemotherapy, but the results are far less impressive than when the carboplatin-paclitaxel combination was used.</li>

7832<li>

7833Furthermore, no significant difference in survival was shown in this study, as reported in abstract form.</li>

7834<li>

7835Altogether, these findings may suggest that the backbone of chemotherapy may be important when bevacizumab is added.</li>

7836</ul>

7837</div>

7838</li>

7839</ol>

7840</div>

7841</li>

7842</ol>

7843</div>

7844</section>

7845<section id="_484880">

7846<h5 id="_484880_toc">

7847Cetuximab</h5>

7848<p id="_485301" tabindex="-1">

7849Evidence (cetuximab):</p>

7850<div class="pdq-content-list">

7851<ol id="_484881">

7852<li>

7853Two trials have evaluated the addition of cetuximab to first-line combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.35">

785435</a>

7855,<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

785636</a>

7857]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7858<ol id="_484882" class="lower-alpha">

7859<li>

7860In the first trial,

7861676 chemotherapy-na&#239;ve patients with stage IIIB (pleural effusion) or stage IV NSCLC, without restrictions by histology or <em class="gene-name">

7862EGFR</em>

7863 expression,

7864received cetuximab with taxane (paclitaxel or docetaxel with carboplatin) or combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.35">

786535</a>

7866]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7867<ul id="_484883">

7868<li>

7869The addition of cetuximab did not result in a statistically significant improvement in PFS, the primary study end point, or OS.</li>

7870<li>

7871Median PFS was 4.40 months for patients in the cetuximab-chemotherapy arm versus 4.24 months for patients in the taxane-carboplatin arm (HR, 0.902; 95% CI, 0.761&#8211;1.069; <em>

7872P</em>

7873 = .236). </li>

7874<li>

7875Median OS was 9.69 months for patients in the cetuximab-chemotherapy arm versus 8.38 months for patients in the chemotherapy-alone arm (HR, 0.890; 95% CI, 0.754&#8211;1.051; <em>

7876P</em>

7877 = .169). </li>

7878<li>

7879 No significant associations were found between EGFR expression, <em class="gene-name">

7880EGFR</em>

7881 mutation, <em class="gene-name">

7882EGFR</em>

7883 copy number, or <em class="gene-name">

7884KRAS</em>

7885 mutations and PFS, OS, and response in the treatment-specific analyses.[<a href="#cit/section_11.37">

788637</a>

7887]</li>

7888</ul>

7889</div>

7890</li>

7891<li>

7892The second trial was composed of 1,125 chemotherapy-na&#239;ve patients with advanced EGFR-expressing stage IIIB/IV NSCLC treated with cisplatin-vinorelbine chemotherapy plus cetuximab or chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

789336</a>

7894]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7895<ul id="_484884">

7896<li>

7897The primary study end point, OS, was longer for patients treated with cetuximab and chemotherapy (median 11.3 months vs. 10.1 months; HR<sub>

7898death</sub>

7899, 0.871; 95% CI, 0.762&#8211;0.996; <em>

7900P</em>

7901 = .044).</li>

7902<li>

7903A survival benefit was seen in all histological subgroups; however, survival benefit was not seen in non-White or Asian patients. Only the interaction between the treatment and the ethnic origin was significant (<em>

7904P</em>

7905 = .011). </li>

7906<li>

7907The main cetuximab-related adverse event was acne-like rash (grade 3, 10%).</li>

7908</ul>

7909</div>

7910</li>

7911<li>

7912It is not clear whether the differences in outcome in these two studies are the result of differences in the study populations, tumor characterization for EGFR expression, or chemotherapy regimens.</li>

7913</ol>

7914</div>

7915</li>

7916</ol>

7917</div>

7918</section>

7919<section id="_484885">

7920<h5 id="_484885_toc">

7921Necitumumab</h5>

7922<p id="_485303" tabindex="-1">

7923Evidence (necitumumab):</p>

7924<div class="pdq-content-list">

7925<ol id="_484886">

7926<li>

7927Two phase III trials have evaluated the addition of the second-generation, recombinant, human immunoglobulin G1 EGFR antibody, necitumumab, to platinum-doublet chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of patients with advanced nonsquamous cell and squamous cell NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_11.38">

792838</a>

7929,<a href="#cit/section_11.39">

793039</a>

7931]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7932<ol id="_484887" class="lower-alpha">

7933<li>

7934The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00981058">

7935SQUIRE</a>

7936 trial (NCT00981058) randomly assigned 1,093 patients with advanced squamous NSCLC to receive either first-line chemotherapy with cisplatin and gemcitabine or the same regimen with the addition of necitumumab (800 mg on day 1 and day 8 of each cycle).[<a href="#cit/section_11.39">

793739</a>

7938]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7939<ul id="_484888">

7940<li>

7941Median OS was prolonged with the addition of necitumumab (11.5 months vs. 9.9 months; <em>

7942P</em>

7943 = .01). </li>

7944<li>

7945PFS was also prolonged with the addition of necitumumab (5.7 months vs. 5.5 months); however, the overall response rate was similar in both groups (31% vs. 28%). </li>

7946<li>

7947Grades 3 and 4 adverse events were higher in the necitumumab-containing arm (72% vs. 62%). </li>

7948<li>

7949Necitumumab is associated with higher toxicity and relatively modest benefit.</li>

7950</ul>

7951</div>

7952</li>

7953<li>

7954The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00982111">

7955INSPIRE</a>

7956 trial (NCT00982111) randomly assigned 633 patients with advanced nonsquamous NSCLC to receive either first-line chemotherapy with cisplatin and pemetrexed or to cisplatin and pemetrexed with the addition of necitumumab (800 mg on day 1 and day 8 of each cycle).[<a href="#cit/section_11.38">

795738</a>

7958]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7959<ul id="_484889">

7960<li>

7961This study showed no benefit from the addition of necitumumab to standard first-line chemotherapy for advanced nonsquamous NSCLC. </li>

7962<li>

7963OS was 11.3 months (95% CI, 9.5&#8211;13.4) for patients in the necitumumab-containing arm versus 11.5 months (95% CI, 10.1&#8211;13.1) for patients in the chemotherapy alone arm; <em>

7964P</em>

7965 = .96. Similarly, there was no difference between the arms in terms of objective response or PFS. </li>

7966<li>

7967Serious adverse events and rates of grades 3 and 4 adverse events, including thromboembolic events, were higher in patients in the necitumumab-containing arm; the incidence of treatment-related deaths was also higher (5% vs. 3%).</li>

7968<li>

7969On the basis of these results, necitumumab is not recommended as combination therapy with standard first-line chemotherapy for patients with advanced nonsquamous NSCLC.</li>

7970</ul>

7971</div>

7972</li>

7973</ol>

7974</div>

7975</li>

7976</ol>

7977</div>

7978</section>

7979</section>

7980<section id="_484890">

7981<h4 id="_484890_toc">

7982Maintenance therapy after first-line chemotherapy (for patients with stable or responding disease after four cycles of platinum-based combination chemotherapy)</h4>

7983<p id="_484891" tabindex="-1">

7984One extensively investigated treatment strategy in NSCLC is maintenance therapy after initial response to chemotherapy. Options for maintenance therapy that have been investigated include the following:</p>

7985<div class="pdq-content-list">
