7986<ul id="_484892">

7987<li>

7988Continuing the initial combination chemotherapy regimen.</li>

7989<li>

7990Continuing only single-agent chemotherapy.</li>

7991<li>

7992Introducing a new agent as <em>

7993maintenance</em>

7994.</li>

7995</ul>

7996</div>

7997<section id="_485277">

7998<p id="_485278" tabindex="-1">

7999Multiple randomized trials have evaluated the efficacy of continuing first-line combination cytotoxic chemotherapy beyond three to four cycles.</p>

8000<p id="_485279" tabindex="-1">

8001Evidence (maintenance therapy following first-line chemotherapy):</p>

8002<div class="pdq-content-list">

8003<ol id="_485280">

8004<li>

8005None of the trials of continued cytotoxic combinations showed a significant OS advantage with additional or longer durations beyond four cycles. For patients with nonsquamous NSCLC, two studies have demonstrated improved PFS and OS with either switch or continuous maintenance chemotherapy (e.g., maintenance pemetrexed after initial cisplatin and gemcitabine or maintenance pemetrexed after initial cisplatin and pemetrexed).[<a href="#cit/section_11.40">

800640</a>

8007]</li>

8008<li>

8009Three trials found statistically significantly improved PFS or time to progression with additional chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.41">

801041</a>

8011-<a href="#cit/section_11.43">

801243</a>

8013]</li>

8014<li>

8015No consistent improvement in quality of life was reported.[<a href="#cit/section_11.42">

801642</a>

8017,<a href="#cit/section_11.44">

801844</a>

8019,<a href="#cit/section_11.45">

802045</a>

8021]</li>

8022<li>

8023Chemotherapy-related toxicities were greater with prolonged chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.44">

802444</a>

8025,<a href="#cit/section_11.45">

802645</a>

8027]</li>

8028</ol>

8029</div>

8030<p id="_485281" tabindex="-1">

8031These data suggest that PFS and OS for patients with nonsquamous NSCLC may be improved either by continuing an effective chemotherapy beyond four cycles or by immediate initiation of alternative chemotherapy. The improvement in PFS, however, is tempered by an increase in adverse events including additional cytotoxic chemotherapy and no consistent improvement in quality of life. For patients who have stable disease or who respond to first-line therapy, evidence does not support the continuation of combination cytotoxic chemotherapy until disease progression or the initiation of a different chemotherapy before disease progression. Collectively, these trials suggest that first-line cytotoxic combination chemotherapy should be stopped at disease progression or after four cycles in patients whose disease is not responding to treatment; it can be administered for no more than six cycles.[<a href="#cit/section_11.41">

803241</a>

8033,<a href="#cit/section_11.42">

803442</a>

8035,<a href="#cit/section_11.44">

803644</a>

8037,<a href="#cit/section_11.45">

803845</a>

8039] For patients with nonsquamous NSCLC who have a response or stable disease after four to six cycles of platinum combination chemotherapy, maintenance chemotherapy with pemetrexed should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_11.40">

804040</a>

8041]</p>

8042</section>

8043<section id="_485282">

8044<p id="_485283" tabindex="-1">

8045Evidence (first-line platinum-based combination chemotherapy followed by pemetrexed):</p>

8046<p id="_485821" tabindex="-1">

8047The findings of two randomized trials (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00102804">

8048NCT00102804</a>

8049 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00789373">

8050NCT00789373</a>

8051) have shown improved outcomes with the addition of pemetrexed after standard first-line platinum-based combination chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.43">

805243</a>

8053,<a href="#cit/section_11.46">

805446</a>

8055]</p>

8056<div class="pdq-content-list">

8057<ol id="_485822">

8058<li>

8059In the first trial, 663 patients with stage IIIB/IV disease who had not progressed on four cycles of nonpemetrexed platinum&#8211;based chemotherapy were randomly assigned (in a 2:1 ratio) to receive pemetrexed or placebo until disease progression.[<a href="#cit/section_11.46">

806046</a>

8061]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8062<ul id="_485823">

8063<li>

8064Both the primary end point of PFS and the secondary end point of OS were statistically significantly prolonged with the addition of maintenance pemetrexed (median PFS, 4.3 months vs. 2.6 months; HR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.61; <em>

8065P</em>

8066 &lt; .0001; median OS, 13.4 months vs. 10.6 months; HR, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;0.95; <em>

8067P </em>

8068 = .012).</li>

8069<li>

8070Benefit was not seen in patients with squamous histology.</li>

8071<li>

8072Higher than grade 3 toxicity and treatment discontinuations that resulted from drug-related toxic effects were higher in the pemetrexed group than in the placebo group.</li>

8073<li>

8074No pemetrexed-related deaths occurred. </li>

8075<li>

8076Relatively fewer patients in the pemetrexed group than in the placebo group received systemic postdiscontinuation therapy (227 [51%] vs. 149 [67%]; <em>

8077P </em>

8078 = .0001). </li>

8079<li>

8080Quality of life during maintenance therapy with pemetrexed was similar to placebo, except for a small increase in loss of appetite and significantly delayed worsening of pain and hemoptysis as assessed using the Lung Cancer Symptom Scale.[<a href="#cit/section_11.47">

808147</a>

8082] The quality-of-life results require cautious evaluation because there was a high degree of censoring (&gt;50%) with the primary quality-of-life end point, which was time to worsening of symptoms.</li>

8083<li>

8084Trials have not evaluated maintenance pemetrexed versus pemetrexed at progression.</li>

8085</ul>

8086</div>

8087</li>

8088<li>

8089In the second trial, 539 patients with nonsquamous NSCLC with nonprogression after treatment with pemetrexed and cisplatin were randomly assigned to continued pemetrexed or placebo.[<a href="#cit/section_11.43">

809043</a>

8091]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8092<p class="pdq-list-title">

8093</p>

8094<ul id="_485824">

8095<li>

8096There was a statistically significant improvement in the primary end point of PFS (4.1 months vs. 2.8 months, HR, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.79) and in the secondary end point of OS (13.9 months vs. 11 months, HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;0.96).[<a href="#cit/section_11.40">

809740</a>

8098,<a href="#cit/section_11.43">

809943</a>

8100][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8101Level of evidence B1</a>

8102]</li>

8103</ul>

8104</div>

8105</li>

8106</ol>

8107</div>

8108</section>

8109</section>

8110<section id="_48630">

8111<h4 id="_48630_toc">

8112EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors</h4>

8113<p id="_48631" tabindex="-1">

8114Selected patients with activating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

8115EGFR</em>

8116 may benefit from single-agent EGFR TKIs. Randomized controlled trials of patients with chemotherapy-na&#239;ve NSCLC and <em class="gene-name">

8117EGFR</em>

8118 mutations have shown that EGFR inhibitors improved PFS but not OS and have favorable toxicity profiles compared with combination chemotherapy. </p>

8119<section id="_485472">

8120<h5 id="_485472_toc">

8121Osimertinib</h5>

8122<p id="_485473" tabindex="-1">

8123Evidence (osimertinib):</p>

8124<div class="pdq-content-list">

8125<ol id="_485474">

8126<li>

8127A phase III, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, controlled trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02296125">

8128FLAURA</a>

8129 [NCT02296125]) compared osimertinib, an oral, third-generation, irreversible EGFR TKI that inhibits both <em class="gene-name">

8130EGFR</em>

8131-TKI&#8211;sensitizing mutations and the <em class="gene-name">

8132EGFR</em>

8133 T790M resistance mutation, with standard of care EGFR TKIs (gefitinib or erlotinib) as first-line treatment of patients with previously untreated, <em class="gene-name">

8134EGFR</em>

8135 mutation-positive (exon 19 deletion or L858R), advanced NSCLC, as detected by a U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved test.[<a href="#cit/section_11.48">

813648</a>

8137] The 556 patients were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8138<ul id="_485475">

8139<li>

8140 Investigator-assessed PFS, the primary end point, was significantly longer with osimertinib (18.9 months vs. 10.2 months; HR, 0.46; 95% CI, 0.37&#8211;0.57, <em>

8141P</em>

8142 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.48">

814348</a>

8144][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8145Level of evidence B1</a>

8146]</li>

8147<li>

8148 The objective response rate was similar for both groups (80% for the osimertinib group vs. 76% for the standard EGFR TKI group).</li>

8149<li>

8150 Central nervous system (CNS) progression was observed less often in the osimertinib group compared with the standard EGFR TKI group (6% vs. 15%). </li>

8151<li>

8152 The median duration of response (DOR) was 17.2 months (95% CI, 13.8&#8211;22.0) with osimertinib versus 8.5 months (95% CI, 7.3&#8211;9.8) with standard EGFR TKIs.</li>

8153<li>

8154 Data on OS are immature.</li>

8155<li>

8156 Adverse events of grade 3 or higher were less frequent with osimertinib (34%) than with standard TKIs (45%).</li>

8157</ul>

8158</div>

8159</li>

8160</ol>

8161</div>

8162<p id="_485476" tabindex="-1">

8163The FDA approved osimertinib for first-line treatment of <em class="gene-name">

8164EGFR</em>

8165-mutant NSCLC (exon 19 deletion or L858R).</p>

8166<p id="_485678" tabindex="-1">

8167Longer PFS, activity against the <em class="gene-name">

8168EGFR</em>

8169 T790M mutation in addition to <em class="gene-name">

8170EGFR</em>

8171-TKI&#8722;sensitizing mutations, decreased frequency of CNS progression, and lower rates of serious adverse events make osimertinib the preferred choice for treatment of patients with <em class="gene-name">

8172EGFR</em>

8173-mutated NSCLC compared with first- and second-generation EGFR TKIs. </p>

8174</section>

8175<section id="_485666">

8176<h5 id="_485666_toc">

8177Dacomitinib</h5>

8178<p id="_485667" tabindex="-1">

8179Evidence (dacomitinib): </p>

8180<div class="pdq-content-list">

8181<ol id="_485668">

8182<li>

8183A multicenter, randomized, open-label, phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01774721">

8184ARCHER 1050</a>

8185 [NCT01774721]) compared dacomitinib, a second-generation, irreversible EGFR TKI, administered orally at a dose of 45 mg per day with gefitinib administered orally at a dose of 250 mg per day, as first-line therapy in patients with newly diagnosed advanced NSCLC harboring the following <em class="gene-name">

8186EGFR</em>

8187 mutations: exon 19 deletion or exon 21 L858R substitution mutations, as detected by an FDA-approved test.[<a href="#cit/section_11.49">

818849</a>

8189] Four hundred and fifty-two eligible patients were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio. The primary end point was PFS assessed by masked independent review in the intention-to-treat population. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8190<ul id="_485669">

8191<li>

8192 Median PFS was 14.7 months in the dacomitinib group and 9.2 months in the gefitinib group (HR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.47&#8722;0.74; <em>

8193P</em>

8194 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.49">

819549</a>

8196][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8197Level of evidence B1</a>

8198]</li>

8199<li>

8200 The objective response rate was similar between the two groups (75% for the dacomitinib group vs. 72% for the gefitinib group; <em>

8201P</em>

8202 = 0.42).</li>

8203<li>

8204 The median DOR was longer in the dacomitinib group (14.8 months vs. 8.3 months; HR, 0.4; 95% CI, 0.31&#8722;0.53; <em>

8205P</em>

8206 &lt; .0001). </li>

8207<li>

8208 The median OS was 34.1 months with dacomitinib vs. 26.8 months with gefitinib (HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.58&#8722;0.99; <em>

8209P</em>

8210 = .44).[<a href="#cit/section_11.49">

821149</a>

8212] </li>

8213<li>

8214 Grade 3 or higher adverse events of any cause occurred in 63% of patients who received dacomitinib and 41% of patients who received gefitinib. The most common grade 3 or 4 adverse events were dermatitis acneiform (14% in the dacomitinib group vs. none in the gefitinib group), diarrhea (8% vs. 1%), and raised alanine aminotransferase levels (1% vs. 8%). Serious treatment-related adverse events (TRAEs) were more frequent in the dacomitinib group (9% vs. 4%). Permanent discontinuation of the study drug because of TRAEs occurred more often in the dacomitinib group (10% vs. 7%). Dose reductions were also more frequent in the dacomitinib group (66% vs. 8%). </li>

8215</ul>

8216</div>

8217</li>

8218</ol>

8219</div>

8220<p id="_485670" tabindex="-1">

8221The FDA approved dacomitinib for first-line treatment of patients with metastatic NSCLC with <em class="gene-name">

8222EGFR</em>

8223 exon 19 deletion or exon 21 L858R substitution mutations as detected by an FDA-approved test. </p>

8224</section>

8225<section id="_484907">

8226<h5 id="_484907_toc">

8227Gefitinib</h5>

8228<p id="_485293" tabindex="-1">

8229Evidence (gefitinib):</p>

8230<div class="pdq-content-list">

8231<ol id="_484908">

8232<li>

8233A phase III, multicenter, randomized trial compared gefitinib with carboplatin plus paclitaxel as first-line treatment in clinically selected patients in East Asia who had advanced adenocarcinoma of the lung and had never smoked or were former light smokers.[<a href="#cit/section_11.50">

823450</a>

8235]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8236<ul id="_485826">

8237<li>

8238The study met its primary objective of demonstrating the superiority of gefitinib compared with the carboplatin-paclitaxel combination for PFS (HR<sub>

8239progression or death</sub>

8240, 0.74; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;0.85; <em>

8241P</em>

8242 &lt; .001). </li>

8243<li>

8244The median PFS was 5.7 months in the gefitinib group and 5.8 months in the carboplatin-paclitaxel group.[<a href="#cit/section_11.50">

824550</a>

8246][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8247Level of evidence B1</a>

8248] </li>

8249<li>

8250Following the time that chemotherapy was discontinued and while gefitinib was continued, the PFS curves clearly separated and favored gefitinib.</li>

8251<li>

8252The 12-month PFS rates were 24.9% with the gefitinib group and 6.7% with the carboplatin-paclitaxel group.</li>

8253<li>

8254More than 90% of the patients in the trial with mutations had either del19 or exon 21 L858R mutations, which have been shown to be sensitive to EGFR inhibitors. In the subgroup of patients with a mutation, PFS was significantly longer among those who received gefitinib (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.36&#8211;0.64; <em>

8255P</em>

8256 &lt; .001); however, in the subgroup of patients who were negative for a mutation, PFS was significantly longer in those who received the carboplatin-paclitaxel combination (HR with gefitinib, 2.85; 95% CI, 2.05&#8211;3.98; <em>

8257P</em>

8258 &lt; .001). There was a significant interaction between treatment and <em class="gene-name">

8259EGFR</em>

8260 mutation with respect to PFS (<em>

8261P</em>

8262 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.50">

826350</a>

8264] </li>

8265<li>

8266OS was similar for patients who received gefitinib and carboplatin-paclitaxel, with no significant difference between treatments overall (HR, 0.90; 95% CI, 0.79&#8211;1.02; <em>

8267P</em>

8268 = .109) or in <em class="gene-name">

8269EGFR</em>

8270 mutation&#8211;positive (HR, 1.00; 95% CI, 0.76&#8211;1.33; <em>

8271P</em>

8272 = .990) or <em class="gene-name">

8273EGFR</em>

8274 mutation&#8211;negative (HR, 1.18; 95% CI, 0.86&#8211;1.63; <em>

8275P</em>

8276 = .309; treatment by <em class="gene-name">

8277EGFR</em>

8278 mutation interaction <em>

8279P</em>

8280 = .480) subgroups. A high proportion (64.3%) of <em class="gene-name">

8281EGFR</em>

8282 mutation&#8211;positive patients randomly assigned to the carboplatin-paclitaxel regimen received subsequent EGFR TKIs. PFS was significantly longer with gefitinib for patients whose tumors had both high <em class="gene-name">

8283EGFR</em>

8284 gene copy number and <em class="gene-name">

8285EGFR</em>

8286 mutation (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.34&#8211;0.67) but significantly shorter when high <em class="gene-name">

8287EGFR</em>

8288 gene copy number was not accompanied by <em class="gene-name">

8289EGFR</em>

8290 mutation (HR, 3.85; 95% CI, 2.09&#8211;7.09).</li>

8291</ul>

8292</div>

8293</li>

8294<li>

8295A phase III trial from Japan prospectively confirmed that patients with NSCLC and <em class="gene-name">

8296EGFR</em>

8297 mutations have improved PFS but not OS when treated with gefitinib. The trial included 230 chemotherapy-na&#239;ve patients with metastatic NSCLC and <em class="gene-name">

8298EGFR</em>

8299 mutations who were randomly assigned to receive gefitinib or carboplatin-paclitaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_11.51">

830051</a>

8301]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8302<ul id="_485827">

8303<li>

8304In the planned interim analysis of data for the first 200 patients, PFS was significantly longer in the gefitinib group than in the standard-chemotherapy group (HR<sub>

8305death</sub>

8306 or disease progression with gefitinib, 0.36; <em>

8307P</em>

8308 &lt; .001), resulting in early termination of the study. </li>

8309<li>

8310The gefitinib group had a significantly longer median PFS (10.8 months vs. 5.4 months in the chemotherapy group; HR, 0.30; 95% CI, 0.22&#8211;0.41; <em>

8311P</em>

8312 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.51">

831351</a>

8314][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8315Level of evidence B1</a>

8316] The median OS was 30.5 months in the gefitinib group and 23.6 months in the standard chemotherapy group (<em>

8317P</em>

8318 = .31). </li>

8319</ul>

8320</div>

8321</li>

8322<li>

8323Another phase III trial from Japan also prospectively confirmed that patients with NSCLC and <em class="gene-name">

8324EGFR</em>

8325 mutations have improved PFS but not OS when treated with gefitinib. In the second trial, the West Japanese Oncology Group conducted a phase III study (WJTOG3405) in 177 chemotherapy-na&#239;ve patients aged 75 years or younger and diagnosed with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC or postoperative recurrence harboring <em class="gene-name">

8326EGFR</em>

8327 mutations (either the exon 19 deletion or L858R-point mutation).[<a href="#cit/section_11.52">

832852</a>

8329]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8330<ul id="_485828">

8331<li>

8332Patients were randomly assigned to receive either gefitinib or cisplatin plus docetaxel (administered every 21 days for three to six cycles). The primary end point was PFS. </li>

8333<li>

8334The gefitinib group had significantly longer PFS than the cisplatin-plus-docetaxel group, with a median PFS of 9.2 months (95% CI, 8.0&#8211;13.9) versus 6.3 months (range, 5.8&#8211;7.8 months; HR, 0.489; 95% CI, 0.336&#8211;0.710, log-rank; <em>

8335P</em>

8336 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.52">

833752</a>

8338][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8339Level of evidence B1</a>

8340]</li>

8341</ul>

8342</div>

8343</li>

8344</ol>

8345</div>

8346</section>

8347<section id="_484914">

8348<h5 id="_484914_toc">

8349Erlotinib</h5>

8350<p id="_485294" tabindex="-1">

8351Evidence (erlotinib):</p>

8352<div class="pdq-content-list">

8353<ol id="_484916">

8354<li>

8355In an open-label, randomized, phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00874419">

8356NCT00874419</a>

8357) from China, 165 patients older than 18 years with histologically confirmed stage IIIB/IV NSCLC and a confirmed activating mutation of <em class="gene-name">

8358EGFR</em>

8359 (i.e., exon 19 deletion or exon 21 L858R-point mutation) received either oral erlotinib (150 mg/day) until they experienced disease progression or unacceptable toxic effects, or up to four cycles of gemcitabine plus carboplatin.[<a href="#cit/section_11.53">

836053</a>

8361]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8362<ul id="_484917">

8363<li>

8364Median PFS was significantly longer in erlotinib-treated patients than in patients treated with chemotherapy (13.1 months [95% CI, 10.58&#8211;16.53] vs. 4.6 months [range, 4.21&#8211;5.42 months]; HR, 0.16; 95% CI, 0.10&#8211;0.26; <em>

8365P</em>

8366 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.53">

836753</a>

8368][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8369Level of evidence B1</a>

8370]</li>

8371</ul>

8372</div>

8373</li>

8374<li>

8375In a European study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00446225">

8376EURTAC</a>

8377 [NCT00446225]), 1,227 patients with advanced NSCLC were screened for <em class="gene-name">

8378EGFR</em>

8379 mutations. Of these, 174 patients with <em class="gene-name">

8380EGFR</em>

8381 mutations were randomly assigned to receive erlotinib or platinum-based chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.54">

838254</a>

8383] The primary end point was PFS. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8384<ul id="_484918">

8385<li>

8386In an interim analysis of the first 153 patients, PFS in the chemotherapy arm was 5.2 months (95% CI, 4.5&#8211;5.8) compared with 9.7 months (95% CI, 8.4&#8211;12.3) in the erlotinib arm (HR, 0.37; <em>

8387P</em>

8388 &lt; .0001). Median survival was 19.3 months in patients in the chemotherapy arm and 19.5 months in patients in the erlotinib arm (HR, 0.80; <em>

8389P</em>

8390 = .42).[<a href="#cit/section_11.55">

839155</a>

8392][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8393Level of evidence B1</a>

8394]</li>

8395</ul>

8396</div>

8397</li>

8398</ol>

8399</div>

8400</section>

8401<section id="_484919">

8402<h5 id="_484919_toc">

8403Afatinib</h5>

8404<p id="_485295" tabindex="-1">

8405Evidence (afatinib):</p>

8406<div class="pdq-content-list">

8407<ol id="_484921">

8408<li>

8409In an open-label, randomized, phase III study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00949650">

8410LUX-Lung 3</a>

8411 [NCT00949650]), 345 Asian (72%) and White (26%) patients with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC and confirmed <em class="gene-name">

8412EGFR</em>

8413 mutations (i.e., exon 19 deletion, L858R, or other [38 of 345 patients had other less-common mutations]) were screened, and 340 patients received at least one dose of study medication, which was either 40 mg of oral afatinib, an irreversible EGFR/human epidermal receptor TKI, daily or up to six cycles of cisplatin and pemetrexed for first-line treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.56">

841456</a>

8415]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8416<ol id="_484922" class="lower-alpha">

8417<li>

8418The primary end point was PFS. In this study, the afatinib group had significantly longer PFS than the cisplatin-plus-pemetrexed group, with a median PFS of 11.1 months for afatinib and 6.9 months for chemotherapy (HR, 0.58; 95% CI, 0.43&#8211;0.78; <em>

8419P</em>

8420 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.56">

842156</a>

8422][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8423Level of evidence B1</a>

8424]</li>

8425<li>

8426Assessment of OS was a secondary end point and was reported separately.[<a href="#cit/section_11.57">

842757</a>

8428] Similar to the PFS analysis, OS was stratified on the basis of <em class="gene-name">

8429EGFR</em>

8430-mutation type and ethnic origin.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8431<ul id="_484923">

8432<li>

8433With a median follow-up of 41 months, median OS was 28.2 months in patients in both arms (HR, 0.88; 95% CI, 0.66&#8211;1.17; <em>

8434P</em>

8435 = .39).</li>

8436<li>

8437In patients harboring common <em class="gene-name">

8438EGFR</em>

8439 mutations (i.e., exon 19 deletion and L858R), survival did not differ significantly between treatment arms (HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;1.06; <em>

8440P</em>

8441 = .11). However, prespecified subgroup analyses demonstrated a survival advantage with afatinib compared with chemotherapy in patients with tumors harboring the <em class="gene-name">

8442EGFR </em>

8443 del19 mutation (median OS, 33.3 months vs. 21.1 months; HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.36&#8211;0.79; <em>

8444P</em>

8445 = .0015) but no significant difference between treatment arms in patients with tumors harboring the L858R mutation (median OS, 27.6 months vs. 40.3 months; HR, 1.30; 95% CI, 0.80&#8211;2.11; <em>

8446P</em>

8447 = .29).</li>

8448<li>

8449First-line afatinib was associated with a significant survival advantage compared with chemotherapy in patients with NSCLC-harboring <em class="gene-name">

8450EGFR </em>

8451 del19 mutations but not in patients with <em class="gene-name">

8452EGFR</em>

8453 L858R mutations or in the overall <em class="gene-name">

8454EGFR</em>

8455&#8211;mutation-positive patient population.[<a href="#cit/section_11.57">

845657</a>

8457][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8458Level of evidence A1</a>

8459] </li>

8460</ul>

8461</div>

8462</li>

8463</ol>

8464</div>

8465</li>

8466<li>

8467In an open-label, randomized, phase III study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01121393">

8468LUX-Lung 6</a>

8469 [NCT01121393]), 364 East Asian patients with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC and confirmed <em class="gene-name">

8470EGFR</em>

8471 mutations (i.e., exon 19 deletion, L858R, or other) were randomly assigned (in a 2:1 ratio) to 40 mg of afatinib daily or gemcitabine and cisplatin for up to six cycles for first-line treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.58">

847258</a>

8473]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8474<ol id="_484924" class="lower-alpha">

8475<li>

8476The primary end point was PFS. Median PFS was significantly longer in the afatinib group (11.0 months; 95% CI, 9.7&#8211;13.7) than in the gemcitabine and cisplatin group (5.6 months, [range, 5.1&#8211;6.7 months]; HR, 0.28; 95% CI, 0.20&#8211;0.39; <em>

8477P</em>

8478 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.58">

847958</a>

8480][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8481Level of evidence B1</a>

8482] </li>

8483<li>

8484Assessment of OS was a prespecified secondary end point and was reported separately.[<a href="#cit/section_11.57">

848557</a>

8486] Similar to the PFS analysis, OS was stratified on the basis of <em class="gene-name">

8487EGFR</em>

8488-mutation type and ethnic origin.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8489<ul id="_484925">

8490<li>

8491With a median follow-up of 33 months, median OS was 23.1 months in patients in the afatinib arm and 23.5 months in patients in the chemotherapy arm (HR, 0.93; 95% CI, 0.72&#8211;1.22; <em>

8492P</em>

8493 = .61). </li>

8494<li>

8495In patients harboring common <em class="gene-name">

8496EGFR</em>

8497 mutations (i.e., exon 19 deletion and L858R), survival did not differ significantly between treatment arms (HR, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.62&#8211;1.09; <em>

8498P</em>

8499 = .18). However, prespecified subgroup analyses demonstrated a survival advantage with afatinib compared with chemotherapy in patients with tumors harboring the <em class="gene-name">

8500EGFR </em>

8501 del19 mutation (median OS, 31.4 months vs. 18.4 months; HR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.94; <em>

8502P</em>

8503 = .023), but no significant difference between treatment arms was seen in patients with tumors harboring the L858R mutation (median OS, 19.6 months vs. 24.3 months; HR, 1.22; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.83; <em>

8504P</em>

8505 = .34).</li>

8506<li>

8507First-line afatinib was associated with a significant survival advantage compared with chemotherapy in patients with NSCLC-harboring <em class="gene-name">

8508EGFR </em>

8509 del19 mutations but not in patients with <em class="gene-name">

8510EGFR</em>

8511 L858R mutations or in the overall <em class="gene-name">

8512EGFR</em>

8513-mutation-positive patient population.[<a href="#cit/section_11.57">

851457</a>

8515][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8516Level of evidence A1</a>

8517]</li>

8518</ul>

8519</div>

8520</li>

8521</ol>

8522</div>

8523</li>

8524</ol>

8525</div>

8526</section>

8527</section>

8528<section id="_485042">

8529<h4 id="_485042_toc">

8530ALK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8531ALK</em>

8532 translocations) </h4>

8533<section id="_485477">

8534<h5 id="_485477_toc">

8535Alectinib</h5>

8536<p id="_485478" tabindex="-1">

8537Evidence (alectinib):</p>

8538<div class="pdq-content-list">

8539<ol id="_485479">

8540<li>

8541 In an open-label, randomized, phase III study (the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02075840">

8542ALEX</a>

8543 trial [NCT02075840]), 303 patients with previously untreated, advanced <em class="gene-name">

8544ALK</em>

8545-rearranged NSCLC received either alectinib (600 mg twice a day) or crizotinib (250 mg twice a day).[<a href="#cit/section_11.59">

854659</a>

8547] The primary end point was investigator-assessed PFS.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8548<ul id="_485480">

8549<li>

8550 The rate of PFS was significantly higher with alectinib than crizotinib; the 12-month event-free survival rate was 68.4% for the alectinib group (95% CI, 61.0%&#8211;75.9%) compared with 48.7% for the crizotinib group (95% CI, 40.4%&#8211;56.9%) (HR, 0.47; 95% CI, 0.34&#8211;0.65; <em>

8551P</em>

8552 &lt; .001). The median PFS was not reached with alectinib. The results of independent review committee-assessed PFS were consistent.[<a href="#cit/section_11.59">

855359</a>

8554][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8555Level of evidence B1</a>

8556]</li>

8557<li>

8558CNS progression events were less frequent with alectinib (12%) than with crizotinib (45%) (HR, 0.16; 95% CI, 0.10&#8211;0.28; <em>

8559P</em>

8560 &lt;.001).</li>

8561<li>

8562 The response rate was similar for both groups, 82.9% for the alectinib group compared with 75.5% for the crizotinib group (<em>

8563P </em>

8564 = .09).</li>

8565<li>

8566 Grade 3 to 5 adverse events were less frequent with alectinib (41%) than with crizotinib (50%).</li>

8567</ul>

8568</div>

8569</li>

8570<li>

8571A second, open-label, randomized, phase III trial (J-ALEX) recruited 207 ALK-inhibitor&#8211;na&#239;ve Japanese patients with <em class="gene-name">

8572ALK</em>

8573-positive NSCLC who were chemotherapy-na&#239;ve or had received one previous chemotherapy regimen. Patients were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive alectinib (300 mg twice daily, which is the dose approved in Japan and is lower than the 600 mg twice daily dose approved elsewhere) versus crizotinib (250 mg twice daily).[<a href="#cit/section_11.60">

857460</a>

8575] The primary end point was PFS-assessed by an independent review committee. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8576<ul id="_485481">

8577<li>

8578 At data cutoff for the second primary interim analysis, the independent data monitoring committee determined that the primary end point was met (HR, 0.34; 99.7% CI, 0.17&#8211;0.71; <em>

8579P</em>

8580 &lt;.0001) and recommended immediate release of the data. Median PFS had not been reached with alectinib but was reached at 10.2 months with crizotinib.</li>

8581<li>

8582 Grade 3 or 4 adverse events occurred less frequently with alectinib (26% occurrence rate) than with crizotinib (52% occurrence rate).</li>

8583</ul>

8584</div>

8585</li>

8586</ol>

8587</div>

8588</section>

8589<section id="_485790">

8590<h5 id="_485790_toc">

8591Lorlatinib</h5>

8592<p id="_485791" tabindex="-1">

8593Evidence (lorlatinib):</p>

8594<div class="pdq-content-list">

8595<ol id="_485792">

8596<li>

8597 The phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03052608">

8598CROWN</a>

8599 trial (NCT03052608) included patients with advanced <em class="gene-name">

8600ALK</em>

8601-rearranged NSCLC who had received no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. The trial randomly assigned 296 patients to receive either lorlatinib (100 mg daily) or crizotinib (250 mg twice daily). The primary end point was PFS as determined by blinded independent central review.[<a href="#cit/section_11.61">

860261</a>

8603][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8604Level of evidence B1</a>

8605]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8606<ul id="_485793">

8607<li>

8608 A planned interim analysis was conducted after approximately 75% of expected events of disease progression or death had occurred. The percentage of patients alive without progression at 12 months was 78% (95% CI, 70%&#8211;84%) in the lorlatinib group and 39% (95% CI, 30%&#8211;48%) in the crizotinib group. The median PFS was not reached with lorlatinib. Objective responses occurred in 76% of patients who received lorlatinib and 58% of patients who received crizotinib.</li>

8609<li>

8610 Among patients with measurable brain metastases, intracranial responses occurred in 82% of patients who received lorlatinib and 23% of patients who received crizotinib. Seventy-one percent of patients who received lorlatinib had a complete intracranial response.</li>

8611<li>

8612 Lorlatinib was associated with more grade 3 to 4 adverse events than crizotinib (72% vs. 56%), the most common being altered lipid levels. Treatment discontinuation occurred in 7% of patients who received lorlatinib and 9% of patients who received crizotinib.</li>

8613</ul>

8614</div>

8615</li>

8616</ol>

8617</div>

8618<p id="_485794" tabindex="-1">

8619Both alectinib and lorlatinib show increased efficacy compared with crizotinib in previously untreated patients with <em class="gene-name">

8620ALK</em>

8621-translocated NSCLC.</p>

8622</section>

8623<section id="_485043">

8624<h5 id="_485043_toc">

8625Crizotinib</h5>

8626<p id="_485147" tabindex="-1">

8627Evidence (crizotinib):</p>

8628<div class="pdq-content-list">

8629<ol id="_485096">

8630<li>

8631In an open-label, randomized, phase III study, 343 patients with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC harboring translocations in <em class="gene-name">

8632ALK</em>

8633 received either 250 mg of crizotinib orally twice a day or the combination of pemetrexed and cisplatin or carboplatin for up to six cycles.[<a href="#cit/section_11.62">

863462</a>

8635] At the time of disease progression, patients on the chemotherapy arm were allowed to cross over to crizotinib; 60% of patients in the chemotherapy arm subsequently received crizotinib. The primary end point of this study was PFS.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8636<ul id="_485097">

8637<li>

8638The study met its primary end point and demonstrated that crizotinib is superior to chemotherapy in prolonging PFS (median, 10.9 months vs. 7.0 months; HR, 0.454; 95% CI, 0.346&#8211;0.596; <em>

8639P</em>

8640 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.63">

864163</a>

8642][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8643Level of evidence B1</a>

8644]</li>

8645</ul>

8646</div>

8647</li>

8648</ol>

8649</div>

8650</section>

8651<section id="_485108">

8652<h5 id="_485108_toc">

8653Ceritinib</h5>

8654<p id="_485148" tabindex="-1">

8655Evidence (ceritinib):</p>

8656<div class="pdq-content-list">

8657<ol id="_485109">

8658<li>

8659 In an open-label, randomized, phase III study, 376 patients with stage IIIB/IV <em class="gene-name">

8660ALK</em>

8661-rearranged nonsquamous NSCLC received either oral ceritinib 750 mg daily or platinum-based chemotherapy (cisplatin or carboplatin and pemetrexed) every 3 weeks for four cycles, followed by maintenance pemetrexed.[<a href="#cit/section_11.64">

866264</a>

8663] The primary end point was PFS and crossover from chemotherapy to ceritinib was allowed upon documented progression.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8664<ul id="_485110">

8665<li>

8666 Median PFS, assessed by blinded independent review, was 16.6 months in the ceritinib group and 8.1 months in the chemotherapy group (HR, 0.55; 95% CI, 0.42&#8211;0.73; <em>

8667P</em>

8668 &lt; .00001). </li>

8669<li>

8670The median OS was not reached with ceritinib, and it was 26.2 months with chemotherapy (HR, 0.73; 95% CI, 0.50&#8211;1.08; <em>

8671P</em>

8672 = .056).[<a href="#cit/section_11.64">

867364</a>

8674][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8675Level of evidence B1</a>

8676] </li>

8677</ul>

8678</div>

8679</li>

8680</ol>

8681</div>

8682</section>

8683<section id="_485531">

8684<h5 id="_485531_toc">

8685Brigatinib</h5>

8686<p id="_485532" tabindex="-1">

8687Evidence (brigatinib):</p>

8688<div class="pdq-content-list">

8689<ol id="_485533">

8690<li>

8691A phase II, open-label trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02094573">

8692NCT02094573</a>

8693) enrolled 222 patients with <em class="gene-name">

8694ALK</em>

8695-translocated locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC who had disease progression after crizotinib treatment. Patients were randomly assigned to receive 90 mg every day (n = 112; 109 treated) or 180 mg every day with a 7-day lead-in at 90 mg every day (n = 110).[<a href="#cit/section_11.65">

869665</a>

8697]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8698<ul id="_485534">

8699<li>

8700 The primary end point assessed by the investigators was objective response rate. The objective response rate was 45% (97.5% CI, 34%&#8211;56%) for patients who received the 90 mg dose and 54% (97.5% CI, 43%&#8211;65%) for patients who received the 180 mg dose. </li>

8701<li>

8702Median PFS was 9.2 months (95% CI, 7.4&#8211;15.6) for patients who received the 90 mg dose and 12.9 months (95% CI, 11.1&#8211;not reached) for patients who received the 180 mg dose. </li>

8703<li>

8704At data cutoff, the median DOR was 13.8 months (95% CI, 5.6&#8211;13.8) for patients who received the 90 mg dose and 11.1 months (95% CI, 9.2&#8211;13.8) for patients who received the 180 mg dose.[<a href="#cit/section_11.65">

870565</a>

8706][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8707Level of evidence B3</a>

8708]</li>

8709<li>

8710 The CNS objective response rate in patients with measurable CNS lesions was 42% in patients who received 90 mg every day (n = 26) and 67% in patients who received 180 mg every day (n = 18).</li>

8711<li>

8712 Common adverse events, which were mainly grade 1 or 2 and occurred in 27% to 38% of patients at the higher dose, were nausea, diarrhea, headache, and cough. A subset of pulmonary adverse events with early onset (median onset, day 2) occurred in 14 of 219 treated patients (all grades, 6%; grade &#8805;3, 3%); none occurred after escalation to 180 mg. These events included dyspnea, hypoxia, cough, pneumonia, or pneumonitis. They were managed with dose interruption. Seven of the 14 patients were successfully retreated with brigatinib.</li>

8713<li>

8714 The FDA-approved dose of brigatinib is 90 mg every day for 7 days; if tolerated, the dose is increased to 180 mg every day.</li>

8715</ul>

8716</div>

8717</li>

8718</ol>

8719</div>

8720</section>

8721</section>

8722<section id="_485568">

8723<h4 id="_485568_toc">

8724BRAF V600E and MEK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8725BRAF</em>

8726 V600E mutations)</h4>

8727<p id="_485569" tabindex="-1">

8728<em class="gene-name">

8729BRAF</em>

8730 V600E mutations occur in 1% to 2% of lung adenocarcinomas. </p>

8731<section id="_485570">

8732<h5 id="_485570_toc">

8733Dabrafenib and trametinib</h5>

8734<p id="_485571" tabindex="-1">

8735Evidence (dabrafenib and trametinib):</p>

8736<div class="pdq-content-list">

8737<ol id="_485572">

8738<li>

8739In a phase II, multicenter, nonrandomized, open-label study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01336634">

8740NCT01336634</a>

8741), 36 patients with previously untreated metastatic NSCLC who tested positive for <em class="gene-name">

8742BRAF</em>

8743 V600E mutations were treated with dabrafenib (a BRAF inhibitor) 150 mg twice a day and trametinib (a MEK inhibitor) 2 mg every day.[<a href="#cit/section_11.66">

874466</a>

8745] <em class="gene-name">

8746BRAF</em>

8747 V600E mutations were identified by the Oncomine Dx Target Test (ThermoFisher Scientific). The primary end point was investigator-assessed overall response.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8748<ul id="_485573">

8749<li>

8750The overall response rate was 64% (95% CI, 46%&#8211;79%). Six percent of patients had a complete response, and 58% of patients had a partial response.</li>

8751<li>

8752 The median investigator-assessed PFS was 10.9 months (95% CI, 7.0&#8211;16.6). The estimated median DOR was 10.4 months (95% CI, 8.3&#8211;17.9). At data cutoff, 47% of patients had died, and the median OS was 24.6 months (95% CI, 12.3&#8211;not estimable).</li>

8753<li>

8754 Sixty-nine percent of patients had at least one grade 3 or 4 adverse event, of which the most common were pyrexia, alanine aminotransferase increase, hypertension, or vomiting. Adverse events led to permanent discontinuation in 22% of patients, dose interruption or delay in 75% of patients, and dose reduction in 39% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_11.66">

875566</a>

8756][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8757Level of evidence C3</a>

8758] </li>

8759</ul>

8760</div>

8761</li>

8762</ol>

8763</div>

8764<p id="_485574" tabindex="-1">

8765The FDA approved the combination of dabrafenib and trametinib in the treatment of patients with NSCLC whose tumors harbor <em class="gene-name">

8766BRAF</em>

8767 V600E mutations as detected by an FDA-approved test.</p>

8768</section>

8769</section>

8770<section id="_484928">

8771<h4 id="_484928_toc">

8772ROS1 inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8773ROS1</em>

8774 rearrangements) </h4>

8775<p id="_485117" tabindex="-1">

8776<em class="gene-name">

8777ROS1</em>

8778 rearrangements occur in approximately 1% of patients with NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_11.67">

877967</a>

8780] The FDA approved crizotinib and entrectinib for use in patients with NSCLC and <em class="gene-name">

8781ROS1</em>

8782 rearrangements, with the latter appearing to have greater activity against intracranial disease. </p>

8783<section id="_485566">

8784<h5 id="_485566_toc">

8785Entrectinib </h5>

8786<p id="_485567" tabindex="-1">

8787The FDA approved entrectinib for treatment of patients with metastatic NSCLC whose tumors are <em class="gene-name">

8788ROS1</em>

8789-positive, regardless of the number of previous systemic therapies.</p>

8790<p id="_485575" tabindex="-1">

8791Evidence (entrectinib):</p>

8792<div class="pdq-content-list">

8793<ol id="_485576">

8794<li>

8795 The safety and clinical activity of entrectinib in <em class="gene-name">

8796ROS1</em>

8797 fusion-positive metastatic NSCLC was determined by integrated analysis of three multicenter, single-arm, open-label clinical trials (ALKA-372-001/EudraCT, 2012-000148-88, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02097810">

8798STARTRK-1</a>

8799 [NCT02097810], and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02568267">

8800STARTRK-2</a>

8801 [NCT02568267]).[<a href="#cit/section_11.68">

880268</a>

8803] Entrectinib was administered orally at a dose of at least 600 mg once daily. Primary end points were the objective response rate and the DOR determined by blinded independent central review. Of note, time-to-event end points are difficult to interpret in the absence of a control arm. Evaluation of tumor samples for the <em class="gene-name">

8804ROS1</em>

8805 gene fusion was conducted prospectively in local laboratories using either a FISH or next-generation sequencing (NGS) laboratory-developed test. <p id="_485577" tabindex="-1">

8806Seventeen (32%) patients had received no previous systemic therapy, 23 (43%) had received one previous therapy, and 13 (25%) had received two or more lines of treatment. CNS disease was present in 23 (43%) patients at baseline. Thirty-one (59%) patients were never-smokers and 52 (98%) patients had adenocarcinoma histology.</p>

8807<div class="pdq-content-list">

8808<ul id="_485578">

8809<li>

8810 The objective response rate in 53 efficacy-evaluable patients was 77% (95% CI, 64%&#8722;88%). Six percent of patients had a complete response and 72% had a partial response. Among patients with CNS disease at baseline, the objective response rate was 74% (95% CI, 52%&#8722;90%) and all patients had a partial response. Among patients without CNS disease at baseline, the overall response rate was 80% (95% CI, 61%&#8722;92%) (10% had a complete response and 70% had a partial response).[<a href="#cit/section_11.68">

881168</a>

8812][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8813Level of evidence C3</a>

8814] </li>

8815<li>

8816 The median DOR was 24.6 months (95% CI, 11.4&#8722;34.8) in efficacy-evaluable patients; 12.6 months (95% CI, 6.5&#8722;not estimable) in patients with baseline CNS disease, and 24.6 months (95% CI, 11.4&#8722;34.8) in those without CNS disease at baseline.</li>

8817<li>

8818 TRAEs were assessed in 134 patients in the safety-evaluable population. Grade 1 or 2 TRAEs were observed in 79 (59%) patients. Grade 3 or 4 TRAEs were observed in 46 (34%) patients. Fifteen (11%) patients had serious TRAEs. There were no treatment-related deaths.</li>

8819<li>

8820 The median PFS was 19 months (95% CI, 12.2&#8722;36.6) in efficacy-evaluable patients; 13.6 months (95% CI, 4.5&#8722;not estimable) in patients with baseline CNS disease, and 26.3 months (95% CI, 15.7&#8722;36.6) in patients with no baseline CNS disease.</li>

8821</ul>

8822</div>

8823</li>

8824</ol>

8825</div>

8826</section>

8827<section id="_484929">

8828<h5 id="_484929_toc">

8829Crizotinib</h5>

8830<p id="_485547" tabindex="-1">

8831Crizotinib was approved for patients with metastatic NSCLC whose tumors are <em class="gene-name">

8832ROS1</em>

8833-positive, regardless of the number of previous systemic therapies. </p>

8834<p id="_485149" tabindex="-1">

8835Evidence (crizotinib):</p>

8836<div class="pdq-content-list">

8837<ol id="_485118">

8838<li>

8839In an expansion cohort of a phase I study of crizotinib, 50 patients with advanced NSCLC who tested positive for <em class="gene-name">

8840ROS1</em>

8841 rearrangement were treated with oral crizotinib 250 mg twice daily.[<a href="#cit/section_11.69">

884269</a>

8843] <em class="gene-name">

8844ROS1</em>

8845 rearrangements were identified using break-apart FISH or reverse transcriptase&#8722;polymerase chain reaction assay. Seven patients (14%) had not had any previous treatment for advanced disease, 21 patients (42%) had one prior treatment, and 22 patients (44%) had more than one prior treatment. The primary end point was response rate. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8846<ul id="_485119">

8847<li>

8848 The overall response rate was 72% (95% CI, 58%&#8211;84%). Six percent of patients had a complete response, 66% had a partial response, and 18% had stable disease as their best response.</li>

8849<li>

8850Median PFS was 19.2 months (95% CI, 14.4&#8211;not reached). The estimated DOR was 17.6 months (95% CI, 14.5&#8211;not reached).[<a href="#cit/section_11.69">

885169</a>

8852][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8853Level of evidence C3</a>

8854]</li>

8855</ul>

8856</div>

8857</li>

8858<li>

8859 In a phase II, open-label, single-arm trial, 127 East Asian patients with <em class="gene-name">

8860ROS1</em>

8861-positive NSCLC were treated with crizotinib 250 mg twice daily.[<a href="#cit/section_11.70">

886270</a>

8863] Twenty-four patients (18.9%) had not had any previous treatment for advanced disease, 53 patients (41.7%) had one previous treatment, and 50 patients (39%) had two or three previous treatments. The primary end point was objective response rate by independent review.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8864<ul id="_485470">

8865<li>

8866The objective response rate was 71.7% (95% CI, 63.0%&#8211;79.3%). Response rates were similar, irrespective of the number of previous therapies. Complete responses occurred in 13.4% of patients, while 58.3% of patients had partial responses, and 16.5% of patients had stable disease as their best response.[<a href="#cit/section_11.70">

886770</a>

8868][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8869Level of evidence C3</a>

8870]</li>

8871<li>

8872 Median PFS was 15.9 months (95% CI, 12.9&#8211;24). The DOR was 19.7 months (95% CI, 14.1&#8211;not reached).</li>

8873<li>

8874 OS was 32.5 months (95% CI, 32.5&#8211;not reached).</li>

8875</ul>

8876</div>

8877</li>

8878</ol>

8879</div>

8880</section>

8881</section>

8882<section id="_485512">

8883<h4 id="_485512_toc">

8884NTRK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8885NTRK</em>

8886 fusions)</h4>

8887<p id="_485516" tabindex="-1">

8888Somatic gene fusions in <em class="gene-name">

8889NTRK</em>

8890 occur across a range of solid tumors including in fewer than 0.5% of NSCLC tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_11.71">

889171</a>

8892,<a href="#cit/section_11.72">

889372</a>

8894] These fusions appear to occur more frequently in nonsmokers with lung adenocarcinoma.

8895</p>

8896<section id="_485513">

8897<h5 id="_485513_toc">

8898Larotrectinib</h5>

8899<p id="_485514" tabindex="-1">

8900Evidence (larotrectinib):</p>

8901<div class="pdq-content-list">

8902<ol id="_485515">

8903<li>

8904Larotrectinib was studied in three protocols: a phase I study involving adults, a phase I/II study involving children, and a phase II study involving adolescents and adults.[<a href="#cit/section_11.73">

890573</a>

8906] Fusions were confirmed in the tumors using either FISH or NGS methods. The primary end point for the combined analysis was objective response rate by independent review and was conducted with input from regulators with the goal of excluding a lower bound of less than 30% for response rate.

8907In total, 55 patients with a median age of 45 years (range, 4 months&#8210;76 years) were enrolled across 17 different <em class="gene-name">

8908NTRK</em>

8909 fusion-positive tumor types. All patients had either metastatic disease (82%) or locally advanced unresectable disease (18%). Enrolled patients had received a median of two previous systemic therapies.

8910<div class="pdq-content-list">

8911<ul id="_485517">

8912<li>

8913The objective response rate was 75% (95% CI, 61%&#8210;75%) and 73% of these responses lasted at least 6 months.[<a href="#cit/section_11.73">

891473</a>

8915][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8916Level of evidence C3</a>

8917] </li>

8918<li>

8919Treatment was well tolerated with 93% of adverse events being grade 1 to 2; the most common grade 3 to 4 adverse events were anemia (11% of patients), transaminitis (7%), and neutropenia (7%).</li>

8920</ul>

8921</div>

8922</li>

8923</ol>

8924</div>

8925<p id="_485518" tabindex="-1">

8926The FDA <a href="https://www.fda.gov/drugs/informationondrugs/approveddrugs/ucm626720.htm" title="https://www.fda.gov/drugs/informationondrugs/approveddrugs/ucm626720.htm">

8927approved</a>

8928 larotrectinib for the treatment of patients who have locally advanced or metastatic tumors that harbor an <em class="gene-name">

8929NTRK</em>

8930 gene fusion without a known acquired resistance mutation, and who have no satisfactory alternative treatments or whose cancer has progressed following treatment.</p>

8931</section>

8932<section id="_485579">

8933<h5 id="_485579_toc">

8934Entrectinib </h5>

8935<p id="_485580" tabindex="-1">

8936The FDA granted accelerated approval to entrectinib for the treatment of solid tumors that have an <em class="gene-name">

8937NTRK</em>

8938 gene fusion without a known acquired resistance mutation, are metastatic, have progressed after treatment, have no satisfactory alternative therapy, or for cases in which surgical resection is likely to result in severe morbidity.</p>

8939<p id="_485581" tabindex="-1">

8940Evidence (entrectinib): </p>

8941<div class="pdq-content-list">

8942<ol id="_485582">

8943<li>

8944 The safety and clinical activity of entrectinib in NTRK inhibitor-na&#239;ve patients with metastatic or locally-advanced solid tumors (including NSCLC) harboring <em class="gene-name">

8945NTRK1</em>

8946, <em class="gene-name">

8947NTRK2</em>

8948, or <em class="gene-name">

8949NTRK3</em>

8950 gene fusions was determined by integrated analysis of three early-phase, multicenter, single-arm, open-label clinical trials (ALKA-372-001/EudraCT, 2012-000148-88, STARTRK-1 [NCT02097810], and STARTRK-2 [NCT02568267]).[<a href="#cit/section_11.74">

895174</a>

8952] Treatment consisted of entrectinib administered orally at a dose of at least 600 mg once per day. The primary end points were objective response rate and median DOR, which were assessed by blinded independent central review. Of note, time-to-event end points are difficult to interpret in the absence of a control arm. Identification of positive <em class="gene-name">

8953NTRK</em>

8954 gene fusion status was conducted prospectively in local laboratories or a central laboratory using various nucleic acid&#8211;based tests. <p id="_485583" tabindex="-1">

8955Of 54 patients in the <em class="gene-name">

8956NTRK</em>

8957 gene fusion-positive efficacy-evaluable population, 20 (37%) had received no previous systemic therapy, 11 (20%) had received one previous systemic therapy, and 23 (43%) had received two or more systemic therapies. Twelve (22%) patients had CNS disease at baseline. Ten (19%) patients had NSCLC. Fifty-two (96%) patients had an <em class="gene-name">

8958NTRK</em>

8959 gene fusion detected by NGS and 2 (4%) had an <em class="gene-name">

8960NTRK</em>

8961 gene fusion detected by other nucleic acid&#8211;based tests.</p>

8962<div class="pdq-content-list">

8963<ul id="_485584">

8964<li>

8965 The objective response rate in 54 patients was 57% (95% CI, 43.2%&#8722;70.8%). Seven percent of patients had a complete response and 50% had a partial response. In patients with baseline CNS disease, 50% achieved a response (all partial responses), whereas in patients without baseline CNS disease, 60% achieved a response (10% complete response; 50% partial response).[<a href="#cit/section_11.74">

896674</a>

8967][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8968Level of evidence C3</a>

8969]</li>

8970<li>

8971 The median DOR in efficacy-evaluable patients was 10.4 months (95% CI, 7.1&#8722;not estimable). In patients with baseline CNS disease DOR was not estimable, and in patients with no baseline CNS disease it was 12.9 months (95% CI, 7.1&#8722;not estimable).</li>

8972<li>

8973 Among 10 patients with NSCLC, the response rate was 70% (95% CI, 35%&#8722;93%) and DOR ranged between 1.9 months and 20.1 months. For more information, see the <a href="https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2019/212725s000lbl.pdf" title="https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2019/212725s000lbl.pdf">

8974prescribing information</a>

8975.</li>

8976<li>

8977 The safety-evaluable population consisted of 68 patients with <em class="gene-name">

8978NTRK</em>

8979 fusion-positive tumors. Most TRAEs were grade 1 or 2 and reversible. The most frequent grade 3 or 4 TRAEs were increased weight gain (10%) and anemia (12%). Serious TRAEs were reported in 7 (10%) patients. Three (4%) patients had dose interruptions and 27 (40%) patients had dose reductions due to TRAEs. There were no treatment-related deaths.</li>

8980<li>

8981 Median PFS was 11.2 months (95% CI, 8.0&#8722;14.9). In patients with baseline CNS disease, median PFS was 7.7 months (95% CI, 4.7&#8722;not estimable), and it was 12 months (95% CI, 8.7&#8722;15.7) in patients with no baseline CNS disease.</li>

8982</ul>

8983</div>

8984</li>

8985</ol>

8986</div>

8987</section>

8988</section>

8989<section id="_485713">

8990<h4 id="_485713_toc">

8991RET inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

8992RET</em>

8993 fusions) </h4>

8994<p id="_485714" tabindex="-1">

8995Somatic gene fusions of <em class="gene-name">

8996RET</em>

8997 occur in 1% to 2% of patients with NSCLC and in patients with thyroid cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_11.75">

899875</a>

8999] </p>

9000<section id="_485715">

9001<h5 id="_485715_toc">

9002Selpercatinib</h5>

9003<p id="_485716" tabindex="-1">

9004Evidence (selpercatinib):</p>

9005<div class="pdq-content-list">

9006<ol id="_485717">

9007<li>

9008 A phase I/II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03157128">

9009LIBRETTO-001</a>

9010 [NCT03157128]) enrolled patients with <em class="gene-name">

9011RET</em>

9012 fusion&#8722;positive solid tumors, medullary thyroid cancer, and other tumors with RET activation. One hundred forty-four patients had <em class="gene-name">

9013RET</em>

9014 fusion&#8722;positive NSCLC. <em class="gene-name">

9015RET</em>

9016 fusion status was determined by local molecular testing (NGS, FISH, or polymerase chain reaction assay) without central confirmation. The primary end point was objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_11.76">

901776</a>

9018][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9019Level of evidence C3</a>

9020]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9021<ul id="_485718">

9022<li>

9023 Among the 105 patients who had received previous treatment with platinum chemotherapy, the overall response rate was 64% (95% CI, 54%&#8722;73%), including 2% complete responses. The median DOR was 17.5 months (95% CI, 12.0&#8722;not estimable). Median PFS was 16.5 months (95% CI, 13.7&#8722;not estimable). </li>

9024<li>

9025 Among 39 previously untreated patients, the overall response rate was 85% (95% CI, 70%&#8722;94%). Median PFS was not reached at the time of follow-up.</li>

9026<li>

9027 Among 11 patients with measurable CNS disease, the objective intracranial response was 91%, including 27% complete responses.</li>

9028<li>

9029 Most adverse events were grade 1 to 2. Grade 3 to 4 events, regardless of attribution, included hypertension (14% of participants), increased alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (in 13%), increased aspartate aminotransferase (in 10%), hyponatremia (in 6%), and lymphopenia (in 6%). In the entire study cohort of 531 patients, dose reductions occurred in 30% of patients, while 2% discontinued selpercatinib because of treatment-related adverse events (increased ALT and hypersensitivity). </li>

9030</ul>

9031</div>

9032</li>

9033</ol>

9034</div>

9035</section>

9036<section id="_485883">

9037<h5 id="_485883_toc">

9038Pralsetinib</h5>

9039<p id="_485884" tabindex="-1">

9040Evidence (pralsetinib):</p>

9041<div class="pdq-content-list">

9042<ol id="_485885">

9043<li>

9044 A phase I/II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03037385">

9045ARROW</a>

9046 [NCT03037385]) enrolled patients with <em class="gene-name">

9047RET</em>

9048 fusion&#8722;positive solid tumors. Two hundred thirty-three patients had <em class="gene-name">

9049RET</em>

9050 fusion&#8722;positive NSCLC. <em class="gene-name">

9051RET</em>

9052 fusion status was determined by local molecular testing of tumor or circulating tumor nucleic acid (ctDNA) in blood, without central confirmation. The primary end point was objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_11.77">

905377</a>

9054][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9055Level of evidence C3</a>

9056]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9057<ul id="_485886">

9058<li>

9059Ninety-two patients who had received platinum-based chemotherapy and 29 patients who were treatment-naive (and not candidates for standard platinum-based treatment) received pralsetinib before the efficacy enrollment cutoff (July 11, 2019). Eighty-seven previously treated patients and 27 treatment-naive patients had centrally adjudicated baseline measurable disease, and thus formed the efficacy cohort. </li>

9060<li>

9061 The overall response rate was 61% (95% CI, 50%&#8211;71%) in the 87 patients who had received platinum-based chemotherapy, including complete responses in 6%. The median duration of response was not reached (15.2 months&#8211;not estimable).</li>

9062<li>

9063 The overall response rate was 70% (95% CI, 50%&#8211;86%) in the 27 treatment-naive patients, including complete responses in 11%. The median duration of response was 9.0 months (6.3&#8211;not estimable).</li>

9064<li>

9065 In the 233-patient safety cohort, 93% had treatment-related adverse events, including 48% with grade 3 or worse events. The most common grade 3 or worse treatment-related adverse events were neutropenia (18%), hypertension (11%), and anemia (10%). Dose reductions occurred in 38% of patients, and 6% discontinued treatment because of adverse events.</li>

9066</ul>

9067</div>

9068</li>

9069</ol>

9070</div>

9071</section>

9072</section>

9073<section id="_485795">

9074<h4 id="_485795_toc">

9075MET inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

9076MET</em>

9077 exon 14 skipping mutations)</h4>

9078<p id="_485796" tabindex="-1">

9079Dysregulation of the <em class="gene-name">

9080MET</em>

9081 proto-oncogene resulting from disruption of distinct splice sites leads to loss of <em class="gene-name">

9082MET</em>

9083 exon 14 and enhanced <em class="gene-name">

9084MET</em>

9085 signaling. These <em class="gene-name">

9086MET</em>

9087 alterations drive tumor proliferation, survival, invasion, and metastasis, and occur in 3% to 4% of patients with NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_11.78">

908878</a>

9089] </p>

9090<section id="_485797">

9091<h5 id="_485797_toc">

9092Tepotinib</h5>

9093<p id="_485798" tabindex="-1">

9094Evidence (tepotinib):</p>

9095<div class="pdq-content-list">

9096<ol id="_485799">

9097<li>

9098 An open-label phase II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02864992">

9099VISION</a>

9100 [NCT02864992]) enrolled patients with <em class="gene-name">

9101MET</em>

9102 exon 14 skipping mutations. The trial included 152 patients who received tepotinib (500 mg orally once daily). <em class="gene-name">

9103MET</em>

9104 status was determined centrally, either via liquid biopsy (from circulating free DNA obtained from plasma; n = 66) or via tissue biopsy (n = 60). Twenty-seven patients had positive results from both methods. The primary end point was objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_11.79">

910579</a>

9106][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9107Level of evidence C3</a>

9108] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9109<ul id="_485800">

9110<li>

9111 Among the 99 patients who had been followed for at least 9 months (i.e., the efficacy population), the objective response rate as assessed by independent review was 46% (95% CI, 36%&#8211;57%), with a median DOR of 11.1 months (95% CI, 7.2&#8211;not estimable). Response rates were similar in the liquid biopsy and tissue biopsy groups. </li>

9112<li>

9113 Responses were similar regardless of prior therapy.</li>

9114<li>

9115 Grade 3 or higher adverse events occurred in 28% of patients, including peripheral edema in 7% of patients. Adverse events led to therapy discontinuation in 11% of patients. </li>

9116</ul>

9117</div>

9118</li>

9119</ol>

9120</div>

9121</section>

9122<section id="_485801">

9123<h5 id="_485801_toc">

9124Capmatinib</h5>

9125<p id="_485802" tabindex="-1">

9126Evidence (capmatinib):</p>

9127<div class="pdq-content-list">

9128<ol id="_485803">

9129<li>

9130 A phase II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02414139">

9131GEOMETRY</a>

9132 [NCT02414139]) evaluated capmatinib (400 mg orally twice daily) in patients with <em class="gene-name">

9133MET</em>

9134 exon 14 skipping mutations or <em class="gene-name">

9135MET</em>

9136 amplification. <em class="gene-name">

9137MET</em>

9138 status was performed centrally. A total of 364 patients were enrolled. The primary end point was overall response.[<a href="#cit/section_11.80">

913980</a>

9140][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9141Level of evidence C3</a>

9142]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9143<ul id="_485804">

9144<li>

9145 Of the 69 patients with <em class="gene-name">

9146MET</em>

9147 exon 14 skipping mutations who had received one or two prior lines of therapy, the overall response rate was 41% (95% CI, 29%&#8211;53%). The median DOR was 9.7 months (95% CI, 5.6&#8211;13.0).</li>

9148<li>

9149 Of the 28 patients with <em class="gene-name">

9150MET</em>

9151 exon 14 skipping mutations who had not received any prior treatment, the overall response rate was 68% (95% CI, 48%&#8211;84%). The median DOR was 12.6 months (95% CI, 5.6&#8211;not estimable).</li>

9152<li>

9153 Response rates in patients with <em class="gene-name">

9154MET</em>

9155 amplification without the exon 14 skipping mutation did not meet the prespecified threshold for clinically relevant activity.</li>

9156<li>

9157 Grade 3 to 4 adverse events of occurred in 67% of patients. The most common events, regardless of causality, were peripheral edema, nausea, vomiting, and increased creatinine. Adverse events led to therapy discontinuation 11% of patients.</li>

9158</ul>

9159</div>

9160</li>

9161</ol>

9162</div>

9163</section>

9164</section>

9165<section id="_484931">

9166<h4 id="_484931_toc">

9167Immune checkpoint inhibitors with or without chemotherapy </h4>

9168<p id="_485519" tabindex="-1">

9169Pembrolizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that inhibits the interaction between the programmed death protein 1 (PD-1) coinhibitory immune checkpoint expressed on tumor cells and infiltrating immune cells and its ligands, PD-L1 and PD-L2.[<a href="#cit/section_11.81">

917081</a>

9171]</p>

9172<section id="_484932">

9173<h5 id="_484932_toc">

9174Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy</h5>

9175<p id="_485451" tabindex="-1">

9176Evidence (pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy):</p>

9177<div class="pdq-content-list">

9178<ol id="_485452">

9179<li>

9180A phase III double-blind trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02578680">

9181KEYNOTE-189</a>

9182 [NCT02578680]) randomly assigned, in a 2:1 ratio, 616 patients with metastatic nonsquamous NSCLC without sensitizing <em class="gene-name">

9183EGFR</em>

9184 mutations or <em class="gene-name">

9185ALK</em>

9186 rearrangements who had received no previous treatment for metastatic disease. Patients received pemetrexed and a platinum-based drug plus either 200 mg of pembrolizumab or placebo every 3 weeks for 4 cycles, followed by pembrolizumab or placebo for up to a total of 35 cycles plus pemetrexed maintenance.[<a href="#cit/section_11.1">

91871</a>

9188] Crossover to pembrolizumab monotherapy was permitted after verified progression among patients in the placebo-containing combination group. The primary end points were OS and PFS as assessed by blinded independent central committee radiological review.<div class="pdq-content-list">

9189<ul id="_485453">

9190<li>

9191After a median follow-up of 23.1 months, the median OS was 22.0 months (95% CI, 19.5&#8722;25.2) in the pembrolizumab combination group compared with 10.7 months (8.7&#8722;13.6) in the placebo combination group (HR, 0.56; 95% CI, 0.45&#8722;0.70).[<a href="#cit/section_11.82">

919282</a>

9193][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9194Level of evidence A1</a>

9195]</li>

9196<li>

9197 Median PFS was 9.0 months (95% CI, 8.1&#8722;9.9) in the pembrolizumab combination group and 4.9 months (4.7&#8722;5.5) in the placebo combination group (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.40&#8722;0.58).</li>

9198<li>

9199 Improvement in survival was seen across all PD-L1 categories and in the presence of liver/brain metastases.</li>

9200<li>

9201 Adverse events of grade 3 or higher occurred with similar frequency in both treatment groups (71.9% in the pembrolizumab combination group vs. 66.8% in the placebo combination group). </li>

9202<li>

9203 Analysis of key patient-reported outcomes revealed that global health status/quality-of-life scores, as measured by the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality-of-Life Questionnaire-Core 30 (QLQ-C30) and Lung Cancer 13 (QLQ-LC13) instruments, were better maintained in the pembrolizumab chemotherapy group (between-group difference: 5.3 points [1.1&#8722;9.5]; <em>

9204P</em>

9205 = .014). Median time to deterioration in cough, chest pain, or dyspnea was not reached (95% CI, 10.2 months&#8722;not reached) with pembrolizumab chemotherapy, and was 7.0 months (4.8 months&#8722;not reached) with placebo plus pemetrexed-platinum (HR, 0.81 [95% CI, 0.60&#8211;1.09]; <em>

9206P</em>

9207 = .16).[<a href="#cit/section_11.83">

920883</a>

9209]</li>

9210</ul>

9211</div>

9212</li>

9213</ol>

9214</div>

9215</section>

9216<section id="_485520">

9217<h5 id="_485520_toc">

9218Pembrolizumab alone</h5>

9219<p id="_485521" tabindex="-1">

9220Evidence (pembrolizumab alone):</p>

9221<div class="pdq-content-list">

9222<ol id="_485522">

9223<li>

9224A phase III open-label study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02142738">

9225KEYNOTE-024</a>

9226) randomly assigned 305 patients with previously untreated, advanced NSCLC with PD-L1 expression on 50% or more tumor cells and no sensitizing <em class="gene-name">

9227EGFR</em>

9228 mutations or <em class="gene-name">

9229ALK</em>

9230 translocations to either intravenous pembrolizumab (200 mg every 3 weeks for up to 35 cycles) or platinum-based chemotherapy (four to six cycles, investigator&#8217;s choice; pemetrexed maintenance was allowed for nonsquamous tumors).[<a href="#cit/section_11.81">

923181</a>

9232] The primary end point was PFS.<div class="pdq-content-list">

9233<ol id="_485523" class="lower-alpha">

9234<li>

9235PD-L1 expression was centrally assessed using the PD-L1 immunohistochemistry 22C3 pharmDx assay (Dako North America). PD-L1 tumor expression of 50% or more was found in 30.2% of 1,653 patient samples that were examined.</li>

9236<li>

9237 Pembrolizumab demonstrated significant improvement in median PFS (10.3 months vs. 6.0 months; HR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.37&#8211;0.68; <em>

9238P</em>

9239 &lt; .001). The overall response rate (44.8% vs. 27.8%), the median DOR (not reached, [range 1.9&#8211;14.5 months] vs. 6.3 months [range, 2.1&#8211;12.6 months]), and the estimated rate of OS at 6 months (80.2% vs. 72.4%; HR, 0.60; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.89; <em>

9240P</em>

9241 = .005) were all higher with pembrolizumab than with chemotherapy.</li>

9242<li>

9243Further follow up of this study confirmed an OS advantage in favor of pembrolizumab; the median OS for patients who received pembrolizumab was 30 months (95% CI, 18.3 months&#8211;not reached) versus 14.2 months for patients who received chemotherapy, with a 75% crossover to immunotherapy afterwards, suggesting the crossover did not impact survival.[<a href="#cit/section_11.84">

924484</a>

9245]</li>

9246<li>

9247Adverse events (any grade) were less frequent with pembrolizumab than with chemotherapy (73.4% vs. 90.0%).<div class="pdq-content-list">

9248<ul id="_485524">

9249<li>

9250Grade 3 to 5 adverse events occurred in 26.6% of patients treated with pembrolizumab and 53.3% of patients treated with chemotherapy. </li>

9251<li>

9252Grade 3 or 4 immune-related events occurred in 9.7% of patients treated with pembrolizumab and 0.7% of patients treated with chemotherapy. </li>

9253<li>

9254The most common grade 3 or 4 immune-related events associated with pembrolizumab were severe skin reactions (3.9%), pneumonitis (2.6%), and colitis (1.3%). </li>

9255<li>

9256There were no grade 5 immune-related events.</li>

9257</ul>

9258</div>

9259</li>

9260<li>

9261Pembrolizumab treatment demonstrated significant improvement in PFS, OS, and DOR with less frequent adverse events compared with chemotherapy treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.81">

926281</a>

9263][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9264Level of evidence B1</a>

9265]</li>

9266</ol>

9267</div>

9268</li>

9269</ol>

9270</div>

9271</section>

9272<p id="_485525" tabindex="-1">

9273The FDA approved pembrolizumab in combination with pemetrexed and carboplatin as first-line treatment of patients with metastatic nonsquamous NSCLC, regardless of PD-L1 expression. The FDA also approved pembrolizumab as a first-line monotherapy for patients with NSCLC whose tumors express PD-L1 (&#8805;50% staining as determined by a test approved by the FDA). Patients with <em class="gene-name">

9274EGFR</em>

9275 or <em class="gene-name">

9276ALK</em>

9277 genomic tumor aberrations should have disease progression on FDA-approved therapies before receiving pembrolizumab (see the FDA label for <a href="https://www.fda.gov/Drugs/InformationOnDrugs/ApprovedDrugs/ucm558048.htm" title="https://www.fda.gov/Drugs/InformationOnDrugs/ApprovedDrugs/ucm558048.htm">

9278pembrolizumab</a>

9279).</p>

9280<section id="_485959">

9281<h5 id="_485959_toc">

9282Cemiplimab-rwlc plus chemotherapy</h5>

9283<p id="_485960" tabindex="-1">

9284Evidence (cemiplimab-rwlc plus chemotherapy):</p>

9285<div class="pdq-content-list">

9286<ol id="_485961">

9287<li>

9288A phase III, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03409614">

9289EMPOWER-Lung 3</a>

9290 [NCT03409614]) examined cemiplimab-rwlc plus platinum-doublet chemotherapy in 466 patients with stage III or IV advanced NSCLC. Patients had not received previous chemotherapy and had no <em class="gene-name">

9291EGFR</em>

9292, <em class="gene-name">

9293ALK</em>

9294, or <em class="gene-name">

9295ROS1</em>

9296 genomic tumor aberrations. Patients were randomly assigned (2:1) to receive cemiplimab-rwlc 350 mg (n = 312) or placebo (n = 154) every 3 weeks for up to 108 weeks along with four cycles of platinum-doublet chemotherapy. Patients also received pemetrexed maintenance as indicated. The primary end point was OS. The trial met preset OS efficacy criteria and was stopped early on the recommendation of the independent data monitoring committee.[<a href="#cit/section_11.85">

929785</a>

9298][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9299Level of evidence A1</a>

9300]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9301<ul id="_485962">

9302<li>

9303The median OS was 21.9 months (95% CI, 15.5&#8211;not evaluable [NE]) in the cemiplimab-rwlc-plus-chemotherapy group and 13 months (95% CI, 11.9&#8211;16.1) in the placebo-plus-chemotherapy group (HR, 0.71; 95% CI, 0.53&#8211;0.93; <em>

9304P</em>

9305 = .014).</li>

9306<li>
