9307The secondary end point of median PFS was 8.2 months (95% CI, 6.4&#8211;9.3) in the cemiplimab-rwlc-plus-chemotherapy group and 5.0 months (95% CI, 4.3&#8211;6.2) in the placebo-plus-chemotherapy group (HR, 0.56; 95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.70; <em>

9308P</em>

9309 &lt; .0001).</li>

9310<li>

9311Another secondary end point, the estimated proportion of patients alive at 12 months, was 65.7% (95% CI, 59.9%&#8211;70.9%) in the cemiplimab-rwlc-plus-chemotherapy group and 56.1% (95% CI, 47.5%&#8211;63.8%) in the placebo-plus-chemotherapy group.</li>

9312<li>

9313Grade 3 or greater adverse events occurred in 43.6% (136 of 312) of patients who received cemiplimab-rwlc plus chemotherapy and 31.4% (48 of 153) of patients who received placebo plus chemotherapy.</li>

9314<li>

9315The most common (&#8805;15%) adverse reactions were alopecia, musculoskeletal pain, nausea, fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, and decreased appetite.</li>

9316</ul>

9317</div>

9318</li>

9319</ol>

9320</div>

9321<p id="_485963" tabindex="-1">

9322The FDA approved cemiplimab-rwlc in combination with platinum-based chemotherapy for adult patients with advanced NSCLC and no <em class="gene-name">

9323EGFR</em>

9324, <em class="gene-name">

9325ALK</em>

9326, or <em class="gene-name">

9327ROS1</em>

9328 aberrations.</p>

9329</section>

9330<section id="_485964">

9331<h5 id="_485964_toc">

9332Cemiplimab-rwlc alone</h5>

9333<p id="_485965" tabindex="-1">

9334Evidence (cemiplimab-rwlc alone):</p>

9335<div class="pdq-content-list">

9336<ol id="_485966">

9337<li>

9338A phase III open-label study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03088540">

9339EMPOWER-Lung 1</a>

9340 [NCT03088540]) enrolled 710 patients with advanced NSCLC and PD-L1 tumor expression of at least 50%. Patients were randomly assigned (1:1) to receive cemiplimab-rwlc 350mg every 3 weeks for up to 108 weeks or platinum-doublet chemotherapy. Patients could cross over from chemotherapy to cemiplimab-rwlc in the event of disease progression. Primary end points were OS and PFS per blinded independent central review.[<a href="#cit/section_11.86">

934186</a>

9342][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9343Level of evidence A1</a>

9344]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9345<ul id="_485967">

9346<li>

9347The median OS was 22.1 months (95% CI, 17.7&#8211;NE) for patients in the cemiplimab-rwlc group and 14.3 months (95% CI, 11.7&#8211;19.2) for patients in the chemotherapy group (HR, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.53&#8211;0.87; <em>

9348P</em>

9349 = .0022).</li>

9350<li>

9351The median PFS per blinded independent central review was 6.2 months (95% CI, 4.5&#8211;8.3) in the cemiplimab-rwlc group and 5.6 months (95% CI, 4.5&#8211;6.1) in the chemotherapy group (HR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.72; <em>

9352P</em>

9353 &lt; .0001).</li>

9354<li>

9355Grade 3 to 4 treatment-emergent adverse events occurred in 28% of patients who received cemiplimab-rwlc and 39% patients who received chemotherapy.</li>

9356<li>

9357The most common adverse reactions (&gt;10%) with cemiplimab-rwlc were musculoskeletal pain, rash, anemia, fatigue, decreased appetite, pneumonia, and cough.</li>

9358</ul>

9359</div>

9360</li>

9361</ol>

9362</div>

9363<p id="_485968" tabindex="-1">

9364The FDA approved cemiplimab-rwlc for patients with advanced NSCLC (locally advanced who are not candidates for surgical resection or definitive chemoradiation or metastatic) and PD-L1 tumor expression of at least 50% with no <em class="gene-name">

9365EGFR</em>

9366, anaplastic <em class="gene-name">

9367ALK</em>

9368, or <em class="gene-name">

9369ROS1</em>

9370 genomic aberrations.</p>

9371</section>

9372<section id="_485969">

9373<h5 id="_485969_toc">

9374Tremelimumab</h5>

9375<p id="_485970" tabindex="-1">

9376Tremelimumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody against cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated antigen 4 (CTLA-4). It is an immune checkpoint blocker.</p>

9377<section id="_485971">

9378<h6 id="_485971_toc">

9379Durvalumab plus tremelimumab plus chemotherapy</h6>

9380<p id="_485972" tabindex="-1">

9381Evidence (durvalumab plus tremelimumab plus chemotherapy):</p>

9382<div class="pdq-content-list">

9383<ol id="_485973">

9384<li>

9385<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03164616">

9386POSEIDON</a>

9387 (NCT03164616), a phase III open-label trial, studied tremelimumab plus durvalumab and chemotherapy, durvalumab plus chemotherapy, and chemotherapy alone as first-line therapy in patients with metastatic NSCLC. The primary end points were PFS and OS for durvalumab plus chemotherapy versus chemotherapy. Key alpha-controlled secondary end points were PFS and OS for tremelimumab plus durvalumab and chemotherapy versus chemotherapy. Patients were randomly assigned (1:1:1) to one of the following three arms:[<a href="#cit/section_11.87">

938887</a>

9389][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9390Level of evidence B1</a>

9391]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9392<ol id="_485974" class="lower-alpha">

9393<li>

9394Arm 1: Tremelimumab 75 mg plus durvalumab 1,500 mg with platinum-based chemotherapy for up to four 21-day cycles followed by durvalumab once every 4 weeks until progression and one additional tremelimumab dose at week 16.</li>

9395<li>

9396Arm 2: Durvalumab plus chemotherapy for up to four 21-day cycles followed by durvalumab once every 4 weeks until progression.</li>

9397<li>

9398Arm 3: Platinum-based chemotherapy for up to six 21-day cycles (with or without maintenance pemetrexed).</li>

9399</ol>

9400</div>

9401<p id="_485975" tabindex="-1">

9402The following results were observed:</p>

9403<div class="pdq-content-list">

9404<ul id="_485976">

9405<li>

9406Treatment with durvalumab significantly improved PFS compared with chemotherapy alone. The median PFS was 5.5 months for patients who received durvalumab plus chemotherapy and 4.8 months for patients who received chemotherapy alone (HR, 0.74; 95% CI, 0.62&#8211;0.89; <em>

9407P</em>

9408 = .0009). </li>

9409<li>

9410A trend for improved OS did not reach statistical significance for patients in arms 2 and 3. The median OS was 13.3 months for patients who received durvalumab plus chemotherapy and 11.7 months for patients who received chemotherapy alone. (HR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.72&#8211;1.02; <em>

9411P</em>

9412 = .0758). The 24-month OS rate was 29.6% in the durvalumab-plus-chemotherapy arm and 22.1% in the chemotherapy-alone arm.</li>

9413<li>

9414Both PFS and OS were significantly improved when tremelimumab therapy was added to durvalumab and chemotherapy compared with chemotherapy alone. The median PFS was 6.2 months for patients who received tremelimumab plus durvalumab and chemotherapy and 4.8 months for patients who received chemotherapy alone (HR, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.60&#8211;0.86; <em>

9415P</em>

9416 = .0003). The median OS was 14.0 months in the tremelimumab arm and 11.7 months in the chemotherapy-alone arm (HR, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;0.92; <em>

9417P</em>

9418 = .0030). The 24-month OS rate was 32.9% in the tremelimumab-plus durvalumab-and-chemotherapy arm and 22.1% in the chemotherapy-alone arm. In addition, this combination demonstrated consistent OS results across levels of PD-L1 expression.</li>

9419<li>

9420Grade 3 to 4 treatment-related events occurred in 51.8% of patients who received tremelimumab plus durvalumab and chemotherapy, 14.1% of patients who received durvalumab and chemotherapy, and 9.9% of patients who received chemotherapy alone.</li>

9421</ul>

9422</div>

9423</li>

9424</ol>

9425</div>

9426<p id="_485977" tabindex="-1">

9427The FDA approved tremelimumab in combination with durvalumab and platinum-based chemotherapy for adult patients with metastatic NSCLC with no sensitizing <em class="gene-name">

9428EGFR</em>

9429 or <em class="gene-name">

9430ALK</em>

9431 genomic tumor aberrations. The approval is based on a comparison of treatment arms one and three.</p>

9432</section>

9433</section>

9434<section id="_485805">

9435<h5 id="_485805_toc">

9436Atezolizumab alone</h5>

9437<p id="_485806" tabindex="-1">

9438Evidence (atezolizumab alone):</p>

9439<div class="pdq-content-list">

9440<ol id="_485807">

9441<li>

9442 A phase III open-label study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02409342">

9443IMpower110</a>

9444 [NCT02409342]) included 572 patients with previously untreated metastatic nonsquamous or squamous NSCLC. Patients had PD-L1 expression on at least 1% of tumor cells or on at least 1% of tumor-infiltrating immune cells. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either atezolizumab (1,200 mg intravenously) or platinum-based chemotherapy (4 or 6 cycles) once every 3 weeks. The primary end point was overall survival in the PD-L1&#8211;selected population that excluded sensitizing <em class="gene-name">

9445EGFR</em>

9446 mutations or <em class="gene-name">

9447ALK</em>

9448 translocations.[<a href="#cit/section_11.88">

944988</a>

9450][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9451Level of evidence A1</a>

9452]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9453<ul id="_485808">

9454<li>

9455 PD-L1 expression was assessed by the SP142 immunohistochemical assay. High expression was defined as more than 50% of tumor cells or more than 10% of tumor-infiltrating immune cells expressing PD-L1.</li>

9456<li>

9457 In the 205 patients with high PD-L1 expression, the median OS was 20.2 months for patients who received atezolizumab and 13.1 months for patients who received chemotherapy (HR<sub>

9458death</sub>

9459, 0.59; <em>

9460P</em>

9461 = .01).</li>

9462<li>

9463 Grade 3 to 4 adverse events occurred in 30.1% of patients who received atezolizumab and 52.5% of patients who received chemotherapy.</li>

9464</ul>

9465</div>

9466 </li>

9467</ol>

9468</div>

9469<p id="_485809" tabindex="-1">

9470Atezolizumab monotherapy is approved for first-line treatment of patients with high PD-L1 expression as defined in the IMpower110 trial, in the absence of <em class="gene-name">

9471EGFR</em>

9472 or <em class="gene-name">

9473ALK</em>

9474 genomic aberrations. </p>

9475</section>

9476</section>

9477<section id="_485671">

9478<h4 id="_485671_toc">

9479Everolimus</h4>

9480<p id="_485672" tabindex="-1">

9481Everolimus is used for patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional, neuroendocrine tumors.</p>

9482<p id="_485673" tabindex="-1">

9483Everolimus, an oral mTOR inhibitor, is clinically active against advanced pancreatic and nonpancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_11.89">

948489</a>

9485] Based on the results of the RADIANT-4 clinical trial,[<a href="#cit/section_11.89">

948689</a>

9487] the FDA approved everolimus for the treatment of adult patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, progressive, well-differentiated (low or intermediate grade), nonfunctional neuroendocrine tumors of lung or gastrointestinal origin.</p>

9488<p id="_485674" tabindex="-1">

9489 Evidence (everolimus):</p>

9490<div class="pdq-content-list">

9491<ol id="_485675">

9492<li>

9493A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01524783">

9494RADIANT-4</a>

9495 [NCT01524783]) evaluated everolimus in patients older than 18 years with advanced, progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional neuroendocrine tumors of lung or gastrointestinal origin.[<a href="#cit/section_11.89">

949689</a>

9497] Eligible patients were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to received everolimus 10 mg daily orally or placebo, both with best supportive care. A total of 302 patients were enrolled (205 in the everolimus arm and 97 in the placebo arm), including 90 patients with neuroendocrine tumors of lung origin (63 in the everolimus arm and 27 in the placebo arm). The primary end point was PFS assessed by central radiology review in the intention-to-treat population. <div class="pdq-content-list">

9498<ul id="_485676">

9499<li>

9500 Median PFS was 11.0 months in the everolimus arm and 3.9 months in the placebo group (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.35&#8722;0.67; <em>

9501P</em>

9502 &lt; .00001).[<a href="#cit/section_11.89">

950389</a>

9504][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9505Level of evidence B1</a>

9506]</li>

9507<li>

9508 In a post hoc analysis of the lung subgroup, median PFS by central review was 9.2 months in the everolimus arm and 3.6 months in the placebo arm (HR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.28&#8722;0.88).[<a href="#cit/section_11.89">

950989</a>

9510]</li>

9511<li>

9512 The objective response rate was 2% in patients who received everolimus and 1% in patients who received placebo. Disease stabilization was observed in 81% of patients in the everolimus arm and 64% of patients in the placebo arm. </li>

9513<li>

9514 The median duration of treatment was longer in the patients who received everolimus compared with those who received placebo (40.4 weeks vs. 19.6 weeks). </li>

9515<li>

9516 A planned interim analysis of OS showed a 36% reduction in the estimated risk of death with everolimus relative to placebo (HR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.40&#8722;1.05). These results were not statistically significant. </li>

9517<li>

9518 The most common TRAEs were stomatitis, diarrhea, fatigue, infections, rash, and peripheral edema. The most common drug-related grade 3 or 4 adverse events were stomatitis, diarrhea, infections, anemia, and fatigue. Grade 3 or 4 adverse events resulted in treatment discontinuation in 12% of patients in the everolimus group and 3% of patients in the placebo group. </li>

9519</ul>

9520</div>

9521</li>

9522</ol>

9523</div>

9524</section>

9525<section id="_484480">

9526<h4 id="_484480_toc">

9527Local therapies and special considerations</h4>

9528<section id="_485098">

9529<h5 id="_485098_toc">

9530Endobronchial laser therapy and/or brachytherapy (for obstruction lesions)</h5>

9531<p id="_485099" tabindex="-1">

9532Radiation therapy may be effective in palliating symptomatic patients with local involvement of NSCLC with any of the following:</p>

9533<div class="pdq-content-list">

9534<ul id="_485100">

9535<li>

9536Tracheal, esophageal, or bronchial compression.</li>

9537<li>

9538 Pain.</li>

9539<li>

9540Vocal cord paralysis.</li>

9541<li>

9542Hemoptysis.</li>

9543<li>

9544Superior vena cava syndrome.</li>

9545</ul>

9546</div>

9547<p id="_485101" tabindex="-1">

9548In some cases, endobronchial laser therapy and/or brachytherapy have been used to alleviate proximal obstructing lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_11.19">

954919</a>

9550]</p>

9551</section>

9552<section id="_485102">

9553<h5 id="_485102_toc">

9554EBRT (primarily for palliation of local symptomatic tumor growth)</h5>

9555<p id="_485103" tabindex="-1">

9556Although EBRT is frequently prescribed for symptom palliation, there is no consensus on which fractionation scheme should be used. Although different multifraction regimens appear to provide similar symptom relief,[<a href="#cit/section_11.90">

955790</a>

9558-<a href="#cit/section_11.95">

955995</a>

9560] single-fraction radiation may be insufficient for symptom relief compared with hypofractionated or standard regimens, as evidenced in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003685">

9561NCT00003685</a>

9562 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_11.20">

956320</a>

9564][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9565Level of evidence A3</a>

9566] Evidence of a modest increase in survival in patients with a better performance status given high-dose radiation therapy is available.[<a href="#cit/section_11.22">

956722</a>

9568,<a href="#cit/section_11.96">

956996</a>

9570][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9571Level of evidence A1</a>

9572] In closely observed asymptomatic patients, treatment may often be appropriately deferred until symptoms or signs of a progressive tumor develop.</p>

9573<p id="_485104" tabindex="-1">

9574Evidence (radiation therapy):</p>

9575<div class="pdq-content-list">

9576<ol id="_485105">

9577<li>

9578A systematic review identified six randomized trials of high-dose rate endobronchial brachytherapy (HDREB) alone or with EBRT or laser therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.97">

957997</a>

9580]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9581<ul id="_485106">

9582<li>

9583Better overall symptom palliation and fewer re-treatments were required in previously untreated patients using EBRT alone.[<a href="#cit/section_11.97">

958497</a>

9585][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9586Level of evidence A3</a>

9587]</li>

9588<li>

9589HDREB provided palliation of symptomatic patients with recurrent endobronchial obstruction previously treated by EBRT, when it was technically feasible.</li>

9590</ul>

9591</div>

9592</li>

9593</ol>

9594</div>

9595</section>

9596<section id="_485337">

9597<h5 id="_485337_toc">

9598Treatment of second primary tumor</h5>

9599<p id="_485338" tabindex="-1">

9600A solitary pulmonary metastasis from an initially resected bronchogenic

9601carcinoma is unusual. The lung is frequently the site of second primary

9602malignancies in patients with primary lung cancers. Whether the

9603new lesion is a new primary cancer or a metastasis may be difficult to determine. Studies

9604have indicated that in most patients the new lesion is a second

9605primary tumor, and after its resection, some patients may achieve long-term

9606survival. Thus, if the first primary tumor has been controlled, the second

9607primary tumor should be resected, if possible.[<a href="#cit/section_11.98">

960898</a>

9609,<a href="#cit/section_11.99">

961099</a>

9611]

9612</p>

9613</section>

9614<section id="_485339">

9615<h5 id="_485339_toc">

9616Treatment of brain metastases</h5>

9617<p id="_485340" tabindex="-1">

9618Patients who present with a solitary cerebral metastasis after resection of a

9619primary NSCLC lesion and who have no evidence of extracranial tumor can achieve

9620prolonged disease-free survival with surgical excision of the brain metastasis

9621and postoperative whole-brain radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.100">

9622100</a>

9623,<a href="#cit/section_11.101">

9624101</a>

9625] Unresectable brain metastases

9626in this setting may be treated with stereotactic radiosurgery.[<a href="#cit/section_11.102">

9627102</a>

9628]</p>

9629<p id="_485341" tabindex="-1">

9630 Approximately 50% of patients treated with resection and postoperative

9631radiation therapy will develop recurrence in the brain; some of these patients

9632will be suitable for additional treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.103">

9633103</a>

9634] In those selected patients with

9635good performance status and without progressive metastases outside of the

9636brain, treatment options include reoperation or stereotactic radiation surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_11.102">

9637102</a>

9638,<a href="#cit/section_11.103">

9639103</a>

9640] For most patients, additional radiation therapy can be considered; however, the

9641palliative benefit of this treatment is limited.[<a href="#cit/section_11.104">

9642104</a>

9643][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9644Level of evidence C2</a>

9645]</p>

9646</section>

9647</section>

9648</section>

9649<section id="_TrialSearch_48406_sid_11">

9650<h3 id="_TrialSearch_48406_sid_11_toc">

9651Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9652<p id="_TrialSearch_48406_22" tabindex="-1">

9653Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9654advanced clinical trial search</a>

9655 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9656General information</a>

9657 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9658</section>

9762[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

9763</li>

10071 </section>

10072

10073

10074

10075 <section id="_48457">

10076

10077 <h2>

10078Treatment of Progressive Stage IV, Relapsed, and Recurrent NSCLC</h2>

10079

10080 <div id="_section_48457" class="pdq-sections">

10081<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10082<h6>

10083In This Section</h6>

10084<ul>

10085<li>

10086<a href="#_48551_toc">

10095</li>

10099</li>

10100<li>

10101<a href="#_485587_toc">

10102BRAF V600E and MEK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10103BRAF</em>

10104 V600E mutations)</a>

10105</li>

10109</li>

10113NTRK</em>

10114 fusions)</a>

10115</li>

10119RET</em>

10121</li>

10125MET</em>

10127</li>

10131KRAS</em>

10133</li>

10137HER2</em>

10138-mutations)</a>

10149</a>

10156</nav>

10157<section id="_48551">

10158<h3 id="_48551_toc">

10159Treatment Options for Progressive Stage IV, Relapsed, and Recurrent NSCLC (Second-Line Therapy)</h3>

10160<p id="_485314" tabindex="-1">

10161Treatment options for patients with progressive <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485773">

10162stage IV</a>

10163, relapsed, and recurrent non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) (second-line therapy and beyond) include the following:</p>

10164<div class="pdq-content-list">

10165<ol id="_485152">

10166<li>

10167<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485162">

10168Chemotherapy</a>

10169.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10170<ul id="_485153">

10171<li>

10172<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485164">

10173 Docetaxel</a>

10174.</li>

10175<li>

10176 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485222">

10177Docetaxel plus ramucirumab</a>

10178.</li>

10179<li>

10180<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485226">

10181 Pemetrexed</a>

10182.</li>

10183</ul>

10184</div>

10185</li>

10186<li>

10187<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485167">

10188Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-directed therapy</a>

10189.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10190<ol id="_485154" class="lower-alpha">

10191<li>

10192<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485229">

10193EGFR-directed therapy after first-line chemotherapy</a>

10194 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10195EGFR</em>

10196-sensitizing mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10197<ul id="_485155">

10198<li>

10199<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485230">

10200Erlotinib</a>

10201.</li>

10202<li>

10203<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485236">

10204Gefitinib</a>

10205.</li>

10206<li>

10207<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485242">

10208Afatinib</a>

10209.</li>

10210</ul>

10211</div>

10212</li>

10213<li>

10214<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485247">

10215EGFR-directed therapy</a>

10216 (for patients with acquired <em class="gene-name">

10217EGFR</em>

10218 T790M mutations after previous EGFR-directed therapy).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10219<ul id="_485156">

10220<li>

10221<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485248">

10222Osimertinib</a>

10223.</li>

10224</ul>

10225</div>

10226</li>

10227<li>

10228<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485908">

10229 EGFR-directed therapy after first-line chemotherapy</a>

10230 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10231EGFR</em>

10232 exon 20 insertion mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10233<ul id="_485906">

10234<li>

10235 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485909">

10236Amivantamab</a>

10237.</li>

10238<li>

10239 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485914">

10240Mobocertinib</a>

10241.</li>

10242</ul>

10243</div>

10244</li>

10245</ol>

10246</div>

10247</li>

10248<li>

10249<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485170">

10250Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)-directed tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs)</a>

10251.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10252<ol id="_485157" class="lower-alpha">

10253<li>

10254<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485188">

10255ALK-directed TKIs after first-line chemotherapy</a>

10256.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10257<ul id="_485158">

10258<li>

10259<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485189">

10260Crizotinib</a>

10261.</li>

10262</ul>

10263</div>

10264</li>

10265<li>

10266<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485194">

10267ALK-directed TKIs after prior ALK TKI therapy</a>

10268.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10269<ul id="_485159">

10270<li>

10271 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485195">

10272Ceritinib</a>

10273.</li>

10274<li>

10275 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485199">

10276Alectinib</a>

10277. </li>

10278<li>

10279<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485376">

10280Brigatinib</a>

10281.</li>

10282<li>

10283 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485535">

10284Lorlatinib</a>

10285.</li>

10286</ul>

10287</div>

10288</li>

10289</ol>

10290</div>

10291</li>

10292<li>

10293<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485587">

10294BRAF V600E and MEK inhibitors</a>

10295 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10296BRAF</em>

10297 V600E mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10298<ul id="_485585">

10299<li>

10300<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485589">

10301Dabrafenib and trametinib</a>

10302.</li>

10303</ul>

10304</div>

10305</li>

10306<li>

10307<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485173">

10308ROS1-directed therapy</a>

10309.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10310<ul id="_485160">

10311<li>

10312<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485594">

10313 Entrectinib</a>

10314.</li>

10315<li>

10316<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485204">

10317Crizotinib</a>

10318.</li>

10319</ul>

10320</div>

10321</li>

10322<li>

10323<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485600">

10324Neurotrophic tyrosine kinase (NTRK) inhibitors</a>

10325 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10326NTRK</em>

10327 fusions).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10328<ul id="_485586">

10329<li>

10330 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485603">

10331Larotrectinib</a>

10332. </li>

10333<li>

10334 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485608">

10335Entrectinib</a>

10336. </li>

10337</ul>

10338</div>

10339</li>

10340<li>

10341 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485719">

10342RET inhibitors</a>

10343 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10344RET</em>

10345 fusions).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10346<ul id="_485739">

10347<li>

10348<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485721">

10349Selpercatinib</a>

10350.</li>

10351<li>

10352<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485887">

10353Pralsetinib</a>

10354.</li>

10355</ul>

10356</div>

10357 </li>

10358<li>

10359 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485850">

10360MET inhibitors</a>

10361 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10362MET</em>

10363 exon 14 skipping mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10364<ul id="_485810">

10365<li>

10366 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485852">

10367Tepotinib</a>

10368. </li>

10369<li>

10370 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485856">

10371Capmatinib</a>

10372. </li>

10373</ul>

10374</div>

10375</li>

10376<li>

10377<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485865">

10378KRAS G12C inhibitors</a>

10379 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10380KRAS</em>

10381 G12C mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10382<ul id="_485864">

10383<li>

10384<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485923">

10385 Adagrasib</a>

10386.

10387</li>

10388<li>

10389<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485867">

10390Sotorasib</a>

10391. </li>

10392</ul>

10393</div>

10394</li>

10395<li>

10396<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485952">

10397 HER2-targeted therapy</a>

10398 (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10399HER2</em>

10400 mutations).<div class="pdq-content-list">

10401<ul id="_485951">

10402<li>

10403<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485954">

10404 Trastuzumab deruxtecan</a>

10405.</li>

10406</ul>

10407</div>

10408</li>

10409<li>

10410<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485176">

10411Immunotherapy</a>

10412.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10413<ul id="_485161">

10414<li>

10415<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485177">

10416 Nivolumab</a>

10417. </li>

10418<li>

10419<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485185">

10420 Pembrolizumab</a>

10421. </li>

10422<li>

10423 <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485214">

10424Atezolizumab</a>

10425. </li>

10426</ul>

10427</div>

10428</li>

10429<li>

10430<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485692">

10431Everolimus</a>

10432 (for patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional, neuroendocrine tumors).

10433</li>

10434<li>

10435Clinical trials can be considered as second-line therapy.</li>

10436</ol>

10437</div>

10438<section id="_485162">

10439<h4 id="_485162_toc">

10440Chemotherapy</h4>

10441<p id="_485163" tabindex="-1">

10442The use of chemotherapy has produced objective responses and small improvement

10443in survival for patients with metastatic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_12.1">

104441</a>

10445][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10446Level of evidence A1</a>

10447] In studies that have examined symptomatic response, improvement in subjective

10448symptoms has been reported to occur more frequently than objective

10449response.[<a href="#cit/section_12.2">

104502</a>

10451,<a href="#cit/section_12.3">

104523</a>

10453] Informed patients with good performance status and

10454symptomatic recurrence can be offered treatment with a platinum-based

10455chemotherapy regimen for palliation of symptoms. For patients who have

10456relapsed after platinum-based chemotherapy, second-line therapy can be

10457considered.</p>

10458<section id="_485164">

10459<h5 id="_485164_toc">

10460Docetaxel</h5>

10461<p id="_485165" tabindex="-1">

10462Evidence (docetaxel):</p>

10463<div class="pdq-content-list">

10464<ol id="_485166">

10465<li>

10466Two prospective randomized studies have shown an improvement in

10467survival with the use of docetaxel compared with vinorelbine, ifosfamide, or best

10468supportive care;[<a href="#cit/section_12.4">

104694</a>

10470,<a href="#cit/section_12.5">

104715</a>

10472] however, criteria for the selection of appropriate

10473patients for second-line treatment are not well defined.[<a href="#cit/section_12.6">

104746</a>

10475]</li>

10476<li>

10477A meta-analysis of five trials of 865 patients assessing the efficacy and safety of docetaxel administered weekly or every 3 weeks has been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_12.7">

104787</a>

10479] In that analysis, the following was shown:<div class="pdq-content-list">

10480<ul id="_485221">

10481<li>

10482Median survival was 27.4 weeks for patients treated every 3 weeks and 26.1 weeks for patients treated weekly (<em>

10483P</em>

10484 = .24, log-rank test).</li>

10485<li>

10486Significantly less severe neutropenia and febrile neutropenia were reported with weekly docetaxel (<em>

10487P</em>

10488 &lt; .001 for both); however, no significant differences were observed for anemia, thrombocytopenia, and nonhematologic toxic effects. </li>

10489</ul>

10490</div>

10491</li>

10492</ol>

10493</div>

10494</section>

10495<section id="_485222">

10496<h5 id="_485222_toc">

10497Docetaxel plus ramucirumab</h5>

10498<p id="_485223" tabindex="-1">

10499Evidence (docetaxel plus ramucirumab):</p>

10500<div class="pdq-content-list">

10501<ol id="_485224">

10502<li>

10503In a double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase III study, 1,253 patients with an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 to 1 who had progressive disease after first-line chemotherapy were randomly assigned to receive docetaxel and placebo or docetaxel and ramucirumab.[<a href="#cit/section_12.8">

105048</a>

10505][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10506Level of evidence A1</a>

10507] Ramucirumab is a human immunoglobulin G1 monoclonal antibody that targets the extracellular domain of vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2. The primary end point of the study was overall survival (OS), with secondary end points of progression-free survival (PFS) and objective response rate. The study enrolled patients with either nonsquamous or squamous NSCLC; however, patients with poorly controlled hypertension, gastrointestinal perforation or fistulae, arterial thromboembolic event within 6 months (before random assignment), gross hemoptysis within 2 months, or grade 3 to 4 gastrointestinal bleeding within 3 months were excluded. In addition, the trial did not include patients with tumors that had major blood vessel involvement or intratumor cavitation. <div class="pdq-content-list">

10508<ul id="_485225">

10509<li>

10510 The addition of ramucirumab to docetaxel compared with placebo plus docetaxel led to an increase in median OS (10.5 months vs. 9.1 months; hazard ratio [HR], 0.86; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.75&#8211;0.98), objective response rate (23% vs. 14%), and PFS (4.5 months vs. 3 months). The improvement in OS from the addition of ramucirumab appeared consistent across subgroups including squamous and nonsquamous histologies. </li>

10511<li>

10512Grade 3 to 4 treatment-related adverse events (TRAEs) occurred in 79% of patients who received docetaxel and ramucirumab as compared with 71% of patients who received docetaxel and placebo. Febrile neutropenia, fatigue, and hypertension were among the toxicities that were more common with the addition of ramucirumab to docetaxel. There was no significant difference in the incidence of grades 3 to 4 hemorrhage between the groups. </li>

10513<li>

10514On the basis of this study, the addition of ramucirumab to docetaxel chemotherapy can be considered for patients with good performance status with advanced NSCLC who have progressive disease after first-line chemotherapy. </li>

10515</ul>

10516</div>

10517</li>

10518</ol>

10519</div>

10520</section>

10521<section id="_485226">

10522<h5 id="_485226_toc">

10523Pemetrexed</h5>

10524<p id="_485227" tabindex="-1">

10525Evidence (pemetrexed):</p>

10526<div class="pdq-content-list">

10527<ol id="_485228">

10528<li>

10529A randomized phase III trial of 571 patients was designed to demonstrate the noninferiority of pemetrexed compared with docetaxel.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10530<ul id="_485663">

10531<li>

10532The trial showed no difference in response rates, PFS, or OS between treatments.[<a href="#cit/section_12.9">

105339</a>

10534][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10535Level of evidence A1</a>

10536] </li>

10537<li>

10538Of note, patients with squamous histology benefited from docetaxel, and those with nonsquamous histologies appeared to benefit more from pemetrexed.[<a href="#cit/section_12.10">

1053910</a>

10540]</li>

10541</ul>

10542</div>

10543</li>

10544</ol>

10545</div>

10546</section>

10547</section>

10548<section id="_485167">

10549<h4 id="_485167_toc">

10550Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-directed therapy</h4>

10551<p id="_485907" tabindex="-1">

10552Advanced NSCLC that contains characteristic mutations in <em class="gene-name">

10553EGFR</em>

10554, most commonly exon 19 deletions or exon 21 L858R mutations, is highly sensitive to EGFR TKIs. The standard approach to decide whether to use an EGFR TKI for the treatment of a patient with advanced NSCLC is to analyze the tumor for the presence or absence of a driver mutation in <em class="gene-name">

10555EGFR</em>

10556. <em class="gene-name">

10557EGFR</em>

10558 exon 20 insertions are uncommon mutations that are not sensitive to the EGFR TKIs used for the treatment of NSCLC with <em class="gene-name">

10559EGFR</em>

10560-sensitizing mutations.

10561

10562</p>

10563<section id="_485229">

10564<h5 id="_485229_toc">

10565EGFR-directed therapy after first-line chemotherapy (for patients with EGFR-sensitizing mutations)</h5>

10566<section id="_485230">

10567<h6 id="_485230_toc">

10568Erlotinib</h6>

10569<p id="_485231" tabindex="-1">

10570Evidence (erlotinib):</p>

10571<p id="_485829" tabindex="-1">

10572Two randomized placebo-controlled trials indicated that erlotinib prolongs survival and time to deterioration in symptoms in patients with NSCLC after first-line or second-line chemotherapy compared with placebo [<a href="#cit/section_12.11">

1057311</a>

10574,<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

1057512</a>

10576] but does not improve survival compared with standard second-line chemotherapy with docetaxel or pemetrexed.[<a href="#cit/section_12.13">

1057713</a>

10578]</p>

10579<div class="pdq-content-list">

10580<ol id="_485830">

10581<li>

10582A trial of erlotinib versus best supportive care included 731 patients; 49% had received two previous chemotherapy regimens, and 93% had received platinum-based chemotherapy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10583<ul id="_485831">

10584<li>

10585OS was 6.7 months among those who had received two previous chemotherapy regimens and 4.7 months among those who had received platinum-based chemotherapy. The HR was 0.70 (<em>

10586P</em>

10587 &lt; .001) in favor of erlotinib.[<a href="#cit/section_12.11">

1058811</a>

10589][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10590Level of evidence A1</a>

10591]</li>

10592</ul>

10593</div>

10594</li>

10595<li>

10596In a second trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00556322">

10597NCT00556322</a>

10598), which was designed to show the superiority of erlotinib versus standard second-line chemotherapy after disease progression on first-line platinum combination therapy, 424 patients were randomly assigned. <div class="pdq-content-list">

10599<ul id="_485832">

10600<li>

10601There was no difference in the primary end point of OS (median OS, 5.3 months vs. 5.5 months; HR, 0.96; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;1.19).[<a href="#cit/section_12.13">

1060213</a>

10603][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10604Level of evidence A1</a>

10605]</li>

10606</ul>

10607</div>

10608</li>

10609</ol>

10610</div>

10611</section>

10612<section id="_485236">

10613<h6 id="_485236_toc">

10614Gefitinib</h6>

10615<p id="_485237" tabindex="-1">

10616Evidence (gefitinib):</p>

10617<div class="pdq-content-list">

10618<ol id="_485238">

10619<li>

10620A randomized phase III trial evaluated gefitinib versus placebo in 1,692 patients with previously treated NSCLC and showed the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

10621<ul id="_485239">

10622<li>

10623Gefitinib did not improve OS.</li>

10624<li>

10625Median survival did not differ significantly between the groups in the overall population (5.6 months for gefitinib and 5.1 months for placebo; HR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.77&#8211;1.02; <em>

10626P</em>

10627 = .087) or among the 812 patients with adenocarcinoma (6.3 months vs. 5.4 months; HR, 0.84; CI, 0.68&#8211;1.03; <em>

10628P</em>

10629 = .089). </li>

10630<li>

10631Preplanned subgroup analyses showed significantly longer survival in the gefitinib group than in the placebo group for never-smokers (n = 375; 95% CI, 0.67 [0.49&#8211;0.92]; <em>

10632P</em>

10633 = .012; median survival 8.9 months vs. 6.1 months) and for patients of Asian origin (n = 342; 95% CI, 0.66 [0.48&#8211;0.91]; <em>

10634P</em>

10635 = .01; median survival 9.5 months vs. 5.5 months).[<a href="#cit/section_12.14">

1063614</a>

10637][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10638Level of evidence A1</a>

10639]</li>

10640</ul>

10641</div>

10642</li>

10643<li>

10644In a large randomized trial, gefitinib was compared with docetaxel in patients with locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC who had been pretreated with platinum-based chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.15">

1064515</a>

10646] The primary objective was to compare OS between the groups with coprimary analyses to assess noninferiority in the overall population and superiority in patients with high <em class="gene-name">

10647EGFR</em>

10648 gene copy number in the intention-to-treat population. The 1,466 patients were randomly assigned to receive gefitinib (250 mg per day by mouth; n = 733) or docetaxel (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

106492</span>

10650 intravenously [IV] every 3 weeks; n = 733). <div class="pdq-content-list">

10651<ul id="_485240">

10652<li>

10653Noninferiority of gefitinib compared with docetaxel was confirmed for OS (HR, 1.020; 95% CI, 0.905&#8211;1.150). However, superiority of gefitinib in patients with high <em class="gene-name">

10654EGFR</em>

10655 gene copy number (85 patients vs. 89 patients) was not proven (HR, 1.09; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;1.51; <em>

10656P</em>

10657 = .62).</li>

10658<li>

10659In the gefitinib group, the most common adverse events were rash or acne (49% vs. 10%) and diarrhea (35% vs. 25%). In the docetaxel group, neutropenia (5% vs. 74%), asthenia (25% vs. 47%), and alopecia (3% vs. 36%) were most common.</li>

10660<li>

10661This trial established noninferior survival of patients treated with gefitinib compared with docetaxel, suggesting that gefitinib is a valid treatment for pretreated patients with advanced

10662NSCLC.</li>

10663</ul>

10664</div>

10665</li>

10666</ol>

10667</div>

10668<p id="_485241" tabindex="-1">

10669Objective response to erlotinib and gefitinib is more likely in

10670patients who have never smoked, are female, are of East Asian race, or have adenocarcinoma or bronchioloalveolar carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_12.16">

1067116</a>

10672-<a href="#cit/section_12.22">

1067322</a>

10674] Responses may be associated with the presence of sensitizing mutations in the tyrosine kinase domain of <em class="gene-name">

10675EGFR</em>

10676 [<a href="#cit/section_12.17">

1067717</a>

10678-<a href="#cit/section_12.19">

1067919</a>

10680,<a href="#cit/section_12.21">

1068121</a>

10682,<a href="#cit/section_12.22">

1068322</a>

10684] and with the absence of <em class="gene-name">

10685KRAS</em>

10686 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_12.20">

1068720</a>

10688-<a href="#cit/section_12.22">

1068922</a>

10690][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10691Level of evidence C2</a>

10692] Survival benefit may be greater in patients with EGFR protein expression by immunohistochemistry or increased <em class="gene-name">

10693EGFR</em>

10694 gene copy number by fluorescence <em>

10695in situ</em>

10696 hybridization studies (FISH),[<a href="#cit/section_12.21">

1069721</a>

10698,<a href="#cit/section_12.22">

1069922</a>

10700] but the clinical utility of EGFR testing by immunohistochemistry has been questioned.[<a href="#cit/section_12.23">

1070123</a>

10702]</p>

10703</section>

10704<section id="_485242">

10705<h6 id="_485242_toc">

10706Afatinib</h6>

10707<p id="_485244" tabindex="-1">

10708Evidence (afatinib):</p>

10709<div class="pdq-content-list">

10710<ol id="_485245">

10711<li>

10712Afatinib, an irreversible inhibitor of the ErbB-family of receptors, has been compared with erlotinib as second-line treatment in patients with advanced squamous cell carcinoma. In a randomized, controlled, phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01523587">

10713LUX-Lung 8</a>

10714 [NCT01523587]), patients with stage IIIB/IV squamous cell NSCLC with disease progression after frontline platinum-based chemotherapy were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive afatinib (398 patients, 40 mg by mouth every day) or erlotinib (397 patients, 150 mg by mouth every day).[<a href="#cit/section_12.24">

1071524</a>

10716][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10717Level of evidence B1</a>

10718] The primary end point was PFS. Secondary end points included OS and response rate.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10719<ul id="_485246">

10720<li>

10721After a median follow-up of 6.7 months, the PFS was 2.4 months versus 1.9 months (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.68&#8211;1.00). </li>

10722<li>

10723After a median follow-up of 18.4 months, the median OS was significantly longer in the afatinib arm (7.9 months vs. 6.8 months; HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;0.95; <em>

10724P</em>

10725 = .007). Survival at 6 months (63.6% vs. 54.6%; <em>

10726P</em>

10727 = .009), 12 months (36.4% vs. 28.2%; <em>

10728P</em>

10729 = .015), and 18 months (22% vs. 14.4%; <em>

10730P</em>

10731 = .013) were all significantly better in patients who received afatinib. </li>

10732<li>

10733 There was no significant difference in response rate between the two arms (6% vs. 3%; <em>

10734P</em>

10735 = .551). </li>

10736<li>

10737 The frequency of adverse events was similar between the two groups with 57% of the patients experiencing a rate of grade 3 or higher adverse events. Grade 3 treatment-related diarrhea and stomatitis occurred more frequently with afatinib; however, grade 3 rash or acne were more common in patients who received erlotinib.</li>

10738<li>

10739 Afatinib, as compared with erlotinib, represents another option for the second-line treatment of patients with stage IV squamous cell NSCLC. </li>

10740</ul>

10741</div>

10742</li>

10743</ol>

10744</div>

10745</section>

10746</section>

10747<section id="_485247">

10748<h5 id="_485247_toc">

10749EGFR-directed therapy (for patients with acquired <em class="gene-name">

10750EGFR</em>

10751 T790M mutations after previous EGFR-directed therapy) </h5>

10752<section id="_485248">

10753<h6 id="_485248_toc">

10754Osimertinib</h6>

10755<p id="_485249" tabindex="-1">

10756Evidence (osimertinib):</p>

10757<div class="pdq-content-list">

10758<ol id="_485250">

10759<li>

10760An open-label phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02151981">

10761AURA 3</a>

10762 [NCT02151981]) studied osimertinib in patients with NSCLC and <em class="gene-name">

10763EGFR</em>

10764-sensitizing mutations whose disease had progressed after first-line EGFR inhibitors and who had the T790M <em class="gene-name">

10765EGFR</em>

10766 resistance mutation as determined by the cobas&#174; EGFR Mutation Test.[<a href="#cit/section_12.25">

1076725</a>

10768] The trial randomly assigned 419 patients (in a 2:1 ratio) to receive either osimertinib 80 mg by mouth every day or pemetrexed plus carboplatin or cisplatin IV every 3 weeks for up to six cycles; maintenance pemetrexed was allowed for the chemotherapy group. The primary end point was PFS.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10769<ul id="_485251">

10770<li>

10771Osimertinib was superior to chemotherapy in prolonging median PFS (10.1 months vs. 4.4 months; HR, 0.30; 95% CI, 0.23&#8211;0.41; <em>

10772P</em>

10773 &lt; .001). </li>

10774<li>

10775The objective response was 71% with osimertinib versus 31% with platinum therapy (odds ratio for objective response, 5.39; 95% CI, 3.47&#8211;8.48; <em>

10776P</em>

10777 &lt; .001). </li>

10778<li>

10779Among 144 patients with central nervous system (CNS) metastases, median PFS duration was 8.5 months with osimertinib versus 4.2 months with platinum therapy (HR, 0.32; 95% CI, 0.21&#8211;0.49). </li>

10780<li>

10781Adverse events of grade 3 or greater occurred in 23% of osimertinib-treated patients versus 47% of platinum-treated patients.[<a href="#cit/section_12.25">

1078225</a>

10783][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10784Level of evidence B1</a>

10785]</li>

10786</ul>

10787</div>

10788</li>

10789</ol>

10790</div>

10791</section>

10792</section>

10793<section id="_485908">

10794<h5 id="_485908_toc">

10795EGFR-directed therapy after first-line chemotherapy (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

10796EGFR</em>

10797 exon 20 insertion mutations)</h5>

10798<section id="_485909">

10799<h6 id="_485909_toc">

10800 Amivantamab</h6>

10801<p id="_485910" tabindex="-1">

10802Evidence (amivantamab):</p>

10803<div class="pdq-content-list">

10804<ol id="_485911">

10805<li>

10806 A phase I, open-label, dose-escalation, and dose-expansion study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02609776">

10807CHRYSALIS</a>

10808 [NCT02609776]) investigated amivantamab, an EGFR-MET bispecific antibody, in several different patient groups. A total of 114 patients with <em class="gene-name">

10809EGFR</em>

10810 exon 20 insertion mutations who had received previous platinum-based chemotherapy received the recommended phase II dose of amivantamab (1,050 mg [1,400 mg if &gt;80 kg] IV) once weekly for the first 4 weeks and then once every 2 weeks starting at week 5. The primary end point for the dose-expansion group was overall response rate.[<a href="#cit/section_12.26">

1081126</a>

10812][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10813Level of evidence C3</a>

10814]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10815<ul id="_485912">

10816<li>

10817 At the time of clinical data cutoff, 81 patients were evaluable with at least three disease assessments. The overall response rate was 40% (95% CI, 29%&#8211;51%), including three complete responses. The median duration of response was 11.1 months (95% CI, 6.9&#8211;not reached). The clinical benefit rate (including patients with stable disease) was 74% (95% CI, 63%&#8211;83%).</li>

10818<li>

10819 The median PFS was 8.3 months (95% CI, 6.5&#8211;10.9); OS data are not mature.</li>

10820<li>

10821 The most common adverse events were rash (86%), infusion-related reactions (66%), and paronychia (45%). Patients experienced adverse events related to both EGFR inhibition (rash, paronychia, stomatitis, pruritus, diarrhea) and MET inhibition (hypoalbuminemia, peripheral edema). Grade 3 or greater adverse events occurred in 35% of patients, with rash (4%) and infusion reactions (3%) as the most common.</li>

10822<li>

10823 The infusion reactions occurred primarily with the first exposure to amivantamab. The administration of the first dose was split over 2 days to minimize this toxicity.</li>

10824</ul>

10825</div>

10826 </li>

10827</ol>

10828</div>

10829<p id="_485913" tabindex="-1">

10830 The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) granted accelerated approval to amivantamab for the treatment of patients with <em class="gene-name">

10831EGFR</em>

10832 exon 20 mutations whose disease has progressed on or after platinum-based therapy. </p>

10833</section>

10834<section id="_485914">

10835<h6 id="_485914_toc">

10836 Mobocertinib</h6>

10837<p id="_485915" tabindex="-1">

10838Evidence (mobocertinib):</p>

10839<div class="pdq-content-list">

10840<ol id="_485916">

10841<li>

10842 A phase I/II, open-label, dose-escalation, and dose-expansion clinical trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02716116">

10843NCT02716116</a>

10844) examined mobocertinib therapy in multiple molecularly and histologically defined subgroups of patients. The three-part study included a dose-escalation cohort, an expansion cohort in the defined subgroups, and an extension cohort (EXCLAIM). A total of 114 patients with <em class="gene-name">

10845EGFR</em>

10846 exon 20 insertion mutations who were previously treated with platinum-containing regimens were treated with mobocertinib (160 mg orally) once daily. The primary end point was overall response, assessed by an independent central review committee.[<a href="#cit/section_12.27">

1084727</a>

10848][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10849Level of evidence C3</a>

10850]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10851<ul id="_485917">

10852<li>

10853 The overall response rate was 28% (95% CI, 20%&#8211;37%), with a median duration of response of 17.5 months (95% CI, 7.4&#8211;20.3).</li>

10854<li>

10855 The median PFS was 7.3 months (95% CI, 5.5&#8211;9.2), and the median OS was 24.0 months (95% CI, 14.6&#8211;28.8).</li>

10856<li>

10857 The most common adverse events were diarrhea (91% any grade, 21% grade &gt;3) and rash (45%). Most adverse events were grade 1 to 2 and controlled with dose modification, supportive care, or drug discontinuation. Treatment was discontinued by 17% of participants because of adverse events. One patient died of cardiac failure that was deemed to be treatment related.</li>

10858</ul>

10859</div>

10860</li>

10861</ol>

10862</div>

10863<p id="_485918" tabindex="-1">

10864The FDA granted accelerated approval to mobocertinib for the treatment of patients with <em class="gene-name">

10865EGFR</em>

10866 exon 20 mutations whose disease has progressed on or after platinum-based therapy.</p>

10867</section>

10868</section>

10869</section>

10870<section id="_485170">

10871<h4 id="_485170_toc">

10872ALK-directed tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs)</h4>

10873<section id="_485188">

10874<h5 id="_485188_toc">

10875ALK-directed TKIs after first-line chemotherapy</h5>

10876<section id="_485189">

10877<h6 id="_485189_toc">

10878Crizotinib</h6>

10879<p id="_485190" tabindex="-1">

10880Evidence (crizotinib):</p>

10881<div class="pdq-content-list">

10882<ol id="_485191">

10883<li>

10884A study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00585195">

10885NCT00585195</a>

10886) that screened 1,500 patients with NSCLC for <em class="gene-name">

10887ALK</em>

10888 rearrangements identified 82 patients with advanced <em class="gene-name">

10889ALK</em>

10890-positive disease who were enrolled in a clinical trial that was an expanded cohort study instituted after phase I dose escalation had established a recommended dose of crizotinib dual and ALK inhibitor of 250 mg twice a day in 28-day cycles.[<a href="#cit/section_12.28">

1089128</a>

10892] Most of the patients had received previous treatment. <div class="pdq-content-list">

10893<ul id="_485192">

10894<li>

10895At a mean treatment duration of 6.4 months, the overall response rate was 57% (47 of 82 patients, with 46 confirmed partial responses, and one confirmed complete response); 27 patients (33%) had stable disease.[<a href="#cit/section_12.28">

1089628</a>

10897][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10898Level of evidence C2</a>

10899]</li>

10900<li>

10901The estimated probability of 6-month PFS was 72%.</li>

10902<li>

10903The 1-year OS rate was 74% (95% CI, 63%&#8211;82%), and the 2-year OS rate was 54% (40%&#8211;66%). </li>

10904<li>

10905Survival in 30 <em class="gene-name">

10906ALK</em>

10907-positive patients who were given crizotinib in the second-line or third-line setting was significantly longer than in 23 <em class="gene-name">

10908ALK</em>

10909-positive controls identified from a different cohort given any second-line therapy (median OS not reached [95% CI, 14 months&#8211;not reached] vs. 6 months [95% CI, 4&#8211;17], 1-year OS rate, 70% [95% CI, 50%&#8211;83%] vs. 44% [95% CI, 23%&#8211;64%], and 2-year OS rate, 55% [33%&#8211;72%] vs. 12% [2%&#8211;30%]; HR, 0.36; 95% CI, 0.17&#8211;0.75; <em>

10910P</em>

10911 = .004).[<a href="#cit/section_12.29">

1091229</a>

10913][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10914Level of evidence C2</a>

10915]</li>

10916<li>

10917Common toxicities were grade 1 or 2 (mild) gastrointestinal side effects. </li>

10918<li>

10919Patients with <em class="gene-name">

10920ALK</em>

10921 rearrangements tended to be younger than those without the rearrangements; most of the patients had little or no exposure to tobacco; and the patients had adenocarcinomas.</li>

10922</ul>

10923</div>

10924</li>

10925<li>

10926 In an open-label, randomized, phase III study, 347 patients with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC-harboring translocations in <em class="gene-name">

10927ALK</em>

10928, who had received one previous regimen of platinum-based chemotherapy, received either crizotinib (250 mg by mouth twice a day) or chemotherapy (pemetrexed 500 mg/m<span class="sup">

109292</span>

10930 if pemetrexed-na&#239;ve or docetaxel 75 mg/m<span class="sup">

109312</span>

10932 IV every 21 days).[<a href="#cit/section_12.30">

1093330</a>

10934]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10935<ul id="_485193">

10936<li>

10937The primary end point was PFS. Median PFS was significantly longer in favor of crizotinib (7.7 months vs. 3.0 months, <em>

10938P</em>

10939 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_12.30">

1094030</a>

10941][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10942Level of evidence B1</a>

10943] </li>

10944<li>

10945OS, a secondary end point, was not significantly different, but there was significant crossover in the design.</li>

10946</ul>

10947</div>

10948</li>

10949</ol>

10950</div>

10951</section>

10952</section>

10953<section id="_485194">

10954<h5 id="_485194_toc">

10955ALK-directed TKIs after prior ALK TKI therapy</h5>

10956<section id="_485195">

10957<h6 id="_485195_toc">

10958Ceritinib</h6>

10959<p id="_485196" tabindex="-1">

10960Evidence (ceritinib):</p>

10961<div class="pdq-content-list">

10962<ol id="_485197">

10963<li>

10964A single-arm open-label trial enrolled 163 patients with <em class="gene-name">

10965ALK</em>

10966-translocated stage IIIB/IV NSCLC who had disease progression while receiving crizotinib or were intolerant to the drug.[<a href="#cit/section_12.31">

1096731</a>

10968] The primary end point was objective response rate according to Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors (RECIST, version 1.0) with a secondary end point of duration of response (DOR). <div class="pdq-content-list">

10969<ul id="_485198">

10970<li>

10971The objective response rate by blinded independent review was 43.6% (95% CI, 36%&#8211;52%), and the median DOR was 7.1 months (range, 5.6&#8211;not estimable).[<a href="#cit/section_12.31">

1097231</a>

10973][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10974Level of evidence C3</a>

10975] </li>

10976<li>

10977Of note, 38% of patients required dose modification because of gastrointestinal toxicity; elevation of alanine transaminase to more than five times the upper limit of normal occurred in 27% of patients.</li>

10978</ul>

10979</div>

10980</li>

10981</ol>

10982</div>

10983</section>

10984<section id="_485199">

10985<h6 id="_485199_toc">

10986Alectinib</h6>

10987<p id="_485200" tabindex="-1">

10988Evidence (alectinib):</p>

10989<div class="pdq-content-list">

10990<ol id="_485201">

10991<li>

10992A phase II open-label trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01871805">

10993NCT01871805</a>

10994) enrolled 87 patients with <em class="gene-name">

10995ALK</em>

10996-translocated stage IIIB/IV NSCLC who had disease progression after crizotinib treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_12.32">

1099732</a>

10998]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10999<ul id="_485202">

11000<li>

11001 The primary end point was objective response according to RECIST (version 1.1). At the time of primary end point analysis of this ongoing study, 48% of patients (95% CI, 36%&#8211;60%) had a confirmed partial response, and 32% had stable disease by blinded independent review. The median DOR was 13.5 months (95% CI, 6.7&#8211;not estimable). The estimated median PFS was 8.1 months (95% CI, 6.2&#8211;12.6).[<a href="#cit/section_12.32">

1100232</a>

11003][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11004Level of evidence C3</a>

11005]</li>

11006<li>

11007Sixteen patients had measurable CNS disease at baseline, of whom 11 had received prior radiation therapy. The CNS overall response rate was 75% (95% CI, 48%&#8211;93%), with 25% of the patients attaining complete response and 50% of the patients attaining partial response.</li>

11008<li>

11009The most common side effects were grade 1 or 2 in severity; the most frequent adverse events, occurring in 23% to 36% of patients, were constipation, fatigue, myalgia, and peripheral edema. Dose interruption was needed in 36% of patients, and dose reduction occurred in 16%.</li>

11010</ul>

11011</div>

11012</li>

11013<li>

11014 A second phase II, open-label trial enrolled 138 patients with <em class="gene-name">

11015ALK</em>

11016-positive stage IIIB/IV NSCLC who had disease progression on crizotinib.[<a href="#cit/section_12.33">

1101733</a>

11018]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11019<ul id="_485203">

11020<li>

11021 The primary end point was objective response rate by independent central review. The objective response rate was 50% (95% CI, 41%&#8211;59%). Median DOR was 11.2 months (95% CI, 9.6&#8211;not reached). Median PFS was 8.9 months (95% CI, 5.6&#8211;11.3).[<a href="#cit/section_12.33">

1102233</a>

11023][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11024Level of evidence C3</a>

11025]</li>

11026<li>

11027 CNS objective response rate in 35 patients with measurable CNS lesions was 57% (95% CI, 39%&#8211;74%).</li>

11028<li>

11029 Common adverse events that were mainly grade 1 or 2, which occurred in 25% to 33% of patients, were constipation, fatigue, and peripheral edema. </li>

11030</ul>

11031</div>

11032</li>

11033</ol>

11034</div>

11035</section>

11036<section id="_485376">

11037<h6 id="_485376_toc">

11038Brigatinib</h6>

11039<p id="_485377" tabindex="-1">

11040Evidence (brigatinib):</p>

11041<div class="pdq-content-list">

11042<ol id="_485378">

11043<li>

11044 A phase II open-label trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02094573">

11045NCT02094573</a>

11046) enrolled 222 patients with <em class="gene-name">

11047ALK</em>

11048-translocated locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC who had disease progression after crizotinib treatment. Patients were randomly assigned to receive 90 mg every day (n = 112; 109 treated) or 180 mg every day with a 7-day lead-in at 90 mg every day (n = 110).[<a href="#cit/section_12.34">

1104934</a>

11050]

11051

11052<div class="pdq-content-list">

11053<ul id="_485379">

11054<li>

11055 The primary end point assessed by the investigators was objective response rate. The objective response rate was 45% (97.5% CI, 34%&#8211;56%) for patients who received the 90 mg dose and 54% (97.5% CI, 43%&#8211;65%) for patients who received the 180 mg dose. </li>

11056<li>

11057Median PFS was 9.2 months (95% CI, 7.4&#8211;15.6) for patients who received the 90 mg dose and 12.9 months (95% CI, 11.1&#8211;not reached) for patients who received the 180 mg dose. </li>

11058<li>

11059At data cutoff, the median DOR was 13.8 months (95% CI, 5.6&#8211;13.8) for patients who received the 90 mg dose and 11.1 months (95% CI, 9.2&#8211;13.8) for patients who received the 180 mg dose.[<a href="#cit/section_12.34">

1106034</a>

11061][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11062Level of evidence B3</a>

11063]</li>

11064<li>

11065 The CNS objective response rate in patients with measurable CNS lesions was 42% in patients who received 90 mg every day (n = 26) and 67% in patients who received 180 mg every day (n = 18).</li>

11066<li>

11067 Common adverse events, which were mainly grade 1 or 2 and occurred in 27% to 38% of patients at the higher dose, were nausea, diarrhea, headache, and cough. A subset of pulmonary adverse events with early onset (median onset, day 2) occurred in 14 of 219 treated patients (all grades, 6%; grade &#8805;3, 3%); none occurred after escalation to 180 mg. These events included dyspnea, hypoxia, cough, pneumonia, or pneumonitis. They were managed with dose interruption. Seven of the 14 patients were successfully retreated with brigatinib.</li>

11068<li>

11069 The FDA-approved dose of brigatinib is 90 mg every day for 7 days; if tolerated, the dose is increased to 180 mg every day.</li>

11070</ul>

11071</div>

11072</li>

11073</ol>

11074</div>

11075</section>

11076<section id="_485535">

11077<h6 id="_485535_toc">

11078Lorlatinib</h6>

11079<p id="_485537" tabindex="-1">

11080Evidence (lorlatinib):</p>

11081<div class="pdq-content-list">

11082<ol id="_485538">

11083<li>

11084 In an open-label ongoing phase II study with multiple cohorts, patients with metastatic <em class="gene-name">

11085ALK</em>

11086-rearranged NSCLC were enrolled into six <em class="gene-name">

11087ALK</em>

11088 expansion (EXP) cohorts on the basis of their <em class="gene-name">

11089ALK</em>

11090 status and treatment history.[<a href="#cit/section_12.35">

1109135</a>

11092] They received lorlatinib 100 mg once daily continuously in 21-day cycles. The primary end point was overall and intracranial tumor response by independent central review, as assessed in key pooled subgroups.[<a href="#cit/section_12.35">

1109335</a>

11094][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11095Level of evidence C3</a>

11096]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11097<ol id="_485539" class="lower-alpha">

11098<li>

11099The number of patients treated, the objective response, and the intracranial response rates in each cohort or pooled cohorts are as follows:<div class="pdq-content-list">

11100<ol id="_485540" class="lower-roman">

11101<li>

11102EXP1 (n = 30, treatment na&#239;ve).<div class="pdq-content-list">

11103<ul id="_485541">

11104<li>

11105Objective response rate, 90.0% (95% CI, 73.5%&#8210;97.9%).</li>

11106<li>

11107Intracranial response rate (n = 3), 66.7% (95% CI, 9.4%&#8210;99.2%).</li>

11108</ul>

11109</div>

11110</li>

11111<li>

11112EXP2 (n = 27, previous crizotinib only) and EXP3A (n = 32, previous crizotinib and chemotherapy).<div class="pdq-content-list">

11113<ul id="_485542">

11114<li>

11115Objective response rate, 69.5% (95% CI, 56.1%&#8210;80.8%).</li>

11116<li>

11117 Intracranial response rate (n = 23), 87.0% (95% CI, 66.4%&#8210;97.2%).</li>

11118</ul>

11119</div>

11120</li>

11121<li>

11122EXP3B (n = 28, one previous second-generation ALK inhibitor with or without chemotherapy).<div class="pdq-content-list">

11123<ul id="_485543">

11124<li>

11125Objective response rate, 32.1% (95% CI, 15.9%&#8210;52.4%).</li>

11126<li>

11127Intracranial response rate (n = 9), 55.6% (95% CI, 21.2%&#8210;86.3%).</li>

11128</ul>

11129</div>

11130</li>

11131<li>

11132EXP4 (n = 65, two previous ALK inhibitors with or without chemotherapy) and EXP5 (n = 46, three previous lines of ALK inhibitors, with or without chemotherapy).<div class="pdq-content-list">

11133<ul id="_485544">

11134<li>

11135Objective response rate, 38.7% (95% CI, 29.6%&#8210;48.5%).</li>

11136<li>

11137Intracranial response rate (n = 49), 53.1% (95% CI, 38.3%&#8210;67.5%).</li>

11138</ul>

11139</div>

11140</li>

11141</ol>

11142</div>

11143</li>

11144<li>

11145The median DOR has not been reached for any of the pooled cohorts.</li>

11146<li>

11147The most common adverse event was hypercholesterolemia (16% grade 3&#8211;4), and 3% of patients discontinued treatment due to adverse events. </li>

11148</ol>

11149</div>

11150</li>

11151</ol>

11152</div>

11153</section>

11154</section>

11155</section>

11156<section id="_485587">

11157<h4 id="_485587_toc">

11158BRAF V600E and MEK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

11159BRAF</em>

11160 V600E mutations)</h4>

11161<p id="_485588" tabindex="-1">

11162<em class="gene-name">

11163BRAF</em>

11164 V600E mutations occur in 1% to 2% of lung adenocarcinomas.</p>

11165<section id="_485589">

11166<h5 id="_485589_toc">

11167Dabrafenib and trametinib</h5>

11168<p id="_485590" tabindex="-1">

11169Evidence (dabrafenib and trametinib):</p>

11170<div class="pdq-content-list">

11171<ol id="_485591">

11172<li>

11173 In a phase II, multicenter, nonrandomized, open-label study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01336634">

11174NCT01336634</a>

11175), 57 patients with progression after at least one to three previous platinum-containing regimens for treatment of metastatic NSCLC, who tested positive for <em class="gene-name">

11176BRAF</em>

11177 V600E mutations, were treated with dabrafenib (a <em class="gene-name">

11178BRAF</em>

11179 inhibitor) 150 mg twice a day and trametinib (a <em class="gene-name">

11180MEK</em>

11181 inhibitor) 2 mg every day.[<a href="#cit/section_12.36">

1118236</a>

11183] <em class="gene-name">

11184BRAF</em>

11185 V600E mutations were ascertained by local testing. The primary end point was investigator-assessed overall response.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11186<ul id="_485592">

11187<li>

11188 The overall response rate was 63.2% (95% CI, 49.3%&#8211;75.6%), as determined independently by investigator and independent review committee assessments. There were 2 out of 36 complete responses by investigator assessment; all responses were deemed partial by the independent review committee.</li>

11189<li>

11190 The median investigator-assessed PFS was 9.7 months (95% CI, 6.9&#8211;19.6 months). The estimated median DOR was 9.0 months (95% CI, 6.9&#8211;18.3). The OS data are immature.</li>

11191<li>

11192 Forty-nine percent of patients had at least one grade 3 or 4 adverse event, the most common of which were neutropenia, hyponatremia, and anemia.[<a href="#cit/section_12.36">

1119336</a>

11194][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11195Level of evidence C3</a>

11196] </li>

11197</ul>

11198</div>

11199</li>

11200</ol>

11201</div>

11202<p id="_485593" tabindex="-1">

11203The FDA approved the combination of dabrafenib and trametinib for patients with NSCLC whose tumors harbor <em class="gene-name">

11204BRAF</em>

11205 V600E mutations as detected by an FDA-approved test.</p>

11206</section>

11207</section>

11208<section id="_485173">

11209<h4 id="_485173_toc">

11210ROS1-directed therapy</h4>

11211<p id="_485175" tabindex="-1">

11212<em class="gene-name">

11213ROS1</em>

11214 rearrangements occur in approximately 1% of patients with NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_12.37">

1121537</a>

11216] Crizotinib and entrectinib are approved for use in patients with NSCLC with <em class="gene-name">

11217ROS1</em>

11218 rearrangements, with the latter appearing to have greater activity against intracranial disease.</p>

11219<section id="_485594">

11220<h5 id="_485594_toc">

11221Entrectinib </h5>

11222<p id="_485595" tabindex="-1">

11223The FDA approved entrectinib for treatment of patients with metastatic NSCLC whose tumors are <em class="gene-name">

11224ROS1</em>

11225-positive, regardless of the number of previous systemic therapies. </p>

11226<p id="_485596" tabindex="-1">

11227Evidence (entrectinib):</p>

11228<div class="pdq-content-list">

11229<ol id="_485597">

11230<li>

11231 The safety and clinical activity of entrectinib in <em class="gene-name">

11232ROS1</em>

11233 fusion-positive metastatic NSCLC was determined by integrated analysis of three multicenter, single-arm, open-label clinical trials (ALKA-372-001/EudraCT, 2012-000148-88, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02097810">

11234STARTRK-1</a>

11235 [NCT02097810], and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02568267">

11236STARTRK-2</a>

11237 [NCT02568267]).[<a href="#cit/section_12.38">

1123838</a>

11239] Entrectinib was administered orally at a dose of at least 600 mg once daily. Primary end points were the overall response rate and the DOR determined by blinded independent central review. Of note, time-to-event end points are difficult to interpret in the absence of a control arm. Evaluation of tumor samples for the <em class="gene-name">

11240ROS1</em>

11241 gene fusion was conducted prospectively in local laboratories using either a FISH or next-generation sequencing (NGS) laboratory-developed test. <p id="_485598" tabindex="-1">

11242Seventeen (32%) patients had received no previous systemic therapy, 23 (43%) had received one previous therapy, and 13 (25%) had received two or more lines of treatment. CNS disease was present in 23 (43%) patients at baseline. Thirty-one (59%) patients were never smokers and 52 (98%) patients had adenocarcinoma histology.</p>

11243<div class="pdq-content-list">

11244<ul id="_485599">

11245<li>

11246 The overall response rate in 53 efficacy-evaluable patients was 77% (95% CI, 64%&#8722;88%). Six percent of patients had a complete response and 72% had a partial response. Among patients with CNS disease at baseline, the overall response rate was 74% and all patients had a partial response. Among patients without CNS disease at baseline, the overall response rate was 80% (10% complete response rate; 70% partial response rate). [<a href="#cit/section_12.38">

1124738</a>

11248][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11249Level of evidence C3</a>

11250]</li>

11251<li>

11252 The median DOR was 24.6 months (95% CI, 11.4&#8722;34.8); 12.6 months (95% CI, 6.5&#8722;not estimable) in patients with baseline CNS disease, and 24.6 months (95% CI, 11.4&#8722;34.8) in those without CNS disease at baseline.</li>

11253<li>

11254TRAEs were assessed in 134 patients in the safety-evaluable population. Grade 1 or 2 TRAEs were observed in 79 (59%) patients. Grade 3 or 4 TRAEs were observed in 46 (34%) patients. Fifteen (11%) patients had serious TRAEs. There were no treatment-related deaths.</li>

11255<li>

11256 The median PFS was 19 months (95% CI, 12.2&#8722;36.6); 13.6 months (95% CI, 4.5&#8722;not estimable) in patients with baseline CNS disease, and 26.3 months (95% CI, 15.7&#8722;36.6) in patients with no baseline CNS disease.</li>

11257</ul>

11258</div>

11259</li>

11260</ol>

11261</div>

11262</section>

11263<section id="_485204">

11264<h5 id="_485204_toc">

11265Crizotinib</h5>

11266<p id="_485330" tabindex="-1">

11267 Crizotinib was approved for patients with metastatic NSCLC whose tumors are <em class="gene-name">

11268ROS1</em>

11269-positive, regardless of the number of previous systemic therapies. </p>

11270<p id="_485205" tabindex="-1">

11271Evidence (crizotinib):</p>

11272<div class="pdq-content-list">
