11273<ol id="_485206">

11274<li>

11275In an expansion cohort of a phase I study of crizotinib, 50 patients with advanced NSCLC who tested positive for <em class="gene-name">

11276ROS1</em>

11277 rearrangement were treated with oral crizotinib 250 mg twice daily.[<a href="#cit/section_12.39">

1127839</a>

11279] <em class="gene-name">

11280ROS1</em>

11281 rearrangements were identified using break-apart FISH or reverse transcriptase&#8722;polymerase chain reaction assay. Seven patients (14%) had not had any previous treatment for advanced disease, 21 patients (42%) had one previous treatment, and 22 patients (44%) had more than one previous treatment. The primary end point was response rate. <div class="pdq-content-list">

11282<ul id="_485207">

11283<li>

11284 The overall response rate was 72% (95% CI, 58%&#8211;84%). Six percent of patients had a complete response, 66% had a partial response, and 18% had stable disease as their best response.</li>

11285<li>

11286Median PFS was 19.2 months (95% CI, 14.4&#8211;not reached). The estimated DOR was 17.6 months (95% CI, 14.5&#8211;not reached).[<a href="#cit/section_12.39">

1128739</a>

11288][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11289Level of evidence C3</a>

11290]</li>

11291</ul>

11292</div>

11293</li>

11294<li>

11295In a phase II, open-label, single-arm trial, 127 East Asian patients with <em class="gene-name">

11296ROS1</em>

11297-positive NSCLC were treated with crizotinib 250 mg twice daily.[<a href="#cit/section_12.40">

1129840</a>

11299] Twenty-four patients (18.9%) had not had any previous treatment for advanced disease, 53 patients (41.7%) had one previous treatment, and 50 patients (39%) had two or three previous treatments. The primary end point was objective response rate by independent review.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11300<ul id="_485471">

11301<li>

11302The objective response rate was 71.7% (95% CI, 63.0%&#8211;79.3%). Response rates were similar, irrespective of the number of previous therapies. Complete responses occurred in 13.4% of patients, while 58.3% of patients had partial responses and 16.5% of patients had stable disease as their best response.[<a href="#cit/section_12.40">

1130340</a>

11304][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11305Level of evidence C3</a>

11306]</li>

11307<li>

11308 Median PFS was 15.9 months (95% CI, 12.9&#8211;24). The DOR was 19.7 months (95% CI, 14.1&#8211;not reached).</li>

11309<li>

11310 OS was 32.5 months (95% CI, 32.5&#8211;not reached).</li>

11311</ul>

11312</div>

11313</li>

11314</ol>

11315</div>

11316</section>

11317</section>

11318<section id="_485600">

11319<h4 id="_485600_toc">

11320NTRK inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

11321NTRK</em>

11322 fusions)</h4>

11323<p id="_485602" tabindex="-1">

11324Somatic gene fusions in <em class="gene-name">

11325NTRK</em>

11326 occur across a range of solid tumors including in fewer than 0.5% of NSCLC tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_12.41">

1132741</a>

11328,<a href="#cit/section_12.42">

1132942</a>

11330] These fusions appear to occur more frequently in nonsmokers with lung adenocarcinoma.</p>

11331<section id="_485603">

11332<h5 id="_485603_toc">

11333Larotrectinib</h5>

11334<p id="_485604" tabindex="-1">

11335Evidence (larotrectinib):</p>

11336<div class="pdq-content-list">

11337<ol id="_485605">

11338<li>

11339Larotrectinib was studied in three protocols: a phase I study involving adults, a phase I/II study involving children, and a phase II study involving adolescents and adults.[<a href="#cit/section_12.43">

1134043</a>

11341] Fusions were confirmed in the tumors using either FISH or NGS methods. The primary end point for the combined analysis was objective response rate by independent review and was conducted with input from regulators with the goal of excluding a lower bound of less than 30% for response rate.

11342In total, 55 patients with a median age of 45 years (range, 4 months&#8210;76 years) were enrolled across 17 different <em class="gene-name">

11343NTRK</em>

11344 fusion-positive tumor types. All patients had either metastatic disease (82%) or locally advanced unresectable disease (18%). Enrolled patients had received a median of two previous systemic therapies.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11345<ul id="_485606">

11346<li>

11347The objective response rate was 75% (95% CI, 61%&#8210;75%) and 73% of these responses lasted at least 6 months.[<a href="#cit/section_12.43">

1134843</a>

11349][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11350Level of evidence C3</a>

11351] </li>

11352<li>

11353Treatment was well tolerated with 93% of adverse events being grade 1 to 2; the most common grade 3 to 4 adverse events were anemia (11% of patients), transaminitis (7%), and neutropenia (7%).</li>

11354</ul>

11355</div>

11356

11357</li>

11358</ol>

11359</div>

11360<p id="_485607" tabindex="-1">

11361The FDA <a href="https://www.fda.gov/drugs/informationondrugs/approveddrugs/ucm626720.htm" title="https://www.fda.gov/drugs/informationondrugs/approveddrugs/ucm626720.htm">

11362approved</a>

11363 larotrectinib for the treatment of patients who have locally advanced or metastatic tumors that harbor an <em class="gene-name">

11364NTRK</em>

11365 gene fusion without a known acquired resistance mutation, and who have no satisfactory alternative treatments or whose cancer has progressed following treatment.</p>

11366</section>

11367<section id="_485608">

11368<h5 id="_485608_toc">

11369Entrectinib</h5>

11370<p id="_485609" tabindex="-1">

11371The FDA granted accelerated approval to entrectinib for the treatment of solid tumors that have an <em class="gene-name">

11372NTRK</em>

11373 gene fusion without a known acquired resistance mutation, are metastatic, have progressed after treatment, have no satisfactory alternative therapy, or for cases in which surgical resection is likely to result in severe morbidity.</p>

11374<p id="_485610" tabindex="-1">

11375Evidence (entrectinib):</p>

11376<div class="pdq-content-list">

11377<ol id="_485611">

11378<li>

11379The safety and clinical activity of entrectinib in NTRK inhibitor&#8211;na&#239;ve patients with metastatic or locally-advanced solid tumors (including NSCLC) harboring <em class="gene-name">

11380NTRK1</em>

11381, <em class="gene-name">

11382NTRK2</em>

11383, or <em class="gene-name">

11384NTRK3</em>

11385 gene fusions was determined by integrated analysis of three early-phase, multicenter, single-arm, open-label clinical trials (ALKA-372-001/EudraCT, 2012-000148-88, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02097810">

11386STARTRK-1</a>

11387 [NCT02097810], and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02568267">

11388STARTRK-2</a>

11389 [NCT02568267]).[<a href="#cit/section_12.44">

1139044</a>

11391] Treatment consisted of entrectinib administered orally at a dose of at least 600 mg once per day. The primary end points were objective response and median DOR, which were assessed by blinded independent central review. Of note, time-to-event end points are difficult to interpret in the absence of a control arm. Identification of positive <em class="gene-name">

11392NTRK</em>

11393 gene fusion status was conducted prospectively in local laboratories or a central laboratory using various nucleic acid&#8211;based tests. <p id="_485612" tabindex="-1">

11394Of 54 patients in the <em class="gene-name">

11395NTRK</em>

11396 gene fusion-positive efficacy-evaluable population, 20 (37%) had received no previous systemic therapy, 11 (20%) had received one previous systemic therapy, and 23 (43%) had received two or more systemic therapies. Twelve (22%) patients had CNS disease at baseline. Ten (19%) patients had NSCLC. Fifty-two (96%) patients had an <em class="gene-name">

11397NTRK</em>

11398 gene fusion detected by NGS and two (4%) had an <em class="gene-name">

11399NTRK</em>

11400 gene fusion detected by other nucleic acid&#8211;based tests.</p>

11401<div class="pdq-content-list">

11402<ul id="_485613">

11403<li>

11404 The objective response rate in 54 patients was 57% (95% CI, 43.2%&#8722;70.8%). Seven percent of patients had a complete response and 50% had a partial response. In patients with baseline CNS disease the overall response rate was 50% (all partial responses), whereas in patients without baseline CNS disease, the overall response rate was 60% (10% complete response; 50% partial response).[<a href="#cit/section_12.44">

1140544</a>

11406][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11407Level of evidence C3</a>

11408]</li>

11409<li>

11410 The median DOR was 10.4 months (95% CI, 7.1&#8722;not estimable). In patients with baseline CNS disease, the DOR was not estimable, whereas it was 12.9 months (95% CI, 7.1&#8722;not estimable) in patients with no baseline CNS disease.</li>

11411<li>

11412 Among 10 patients with NSCLC, the overall response rate was 70% (95% CI, 35%&#8722;93%) and the DOR ranged between 1.9 months and 20.1 months. For more information, see the <a href="https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2019/212725s000lbl.pdf" title="https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2019/212725s000lbl.pdf">

11413prescribing information</a>

11414.</li>

11415<li>

11416 The safety-evaluable population consisted of 68 patients with <em class="gene-name">

11417NTRK</em>

11418 fusion-positive tumors. Most TRAEs were grade 1 or 2 and reversible. The most frequent grade 3 or 4 TRAEs were increased weight gain (10%) and anemia (12%). Serious TRAEs were reported in 7 (10%) patients. Three (4%) patients had dose interruptions and 27 (40%) patients had dose reductions due to TRAEs. There were no treatment-related deaths.</li>

11419<li>

11420 Median PFS was 11.2 months (95% CI, 8.0&#8722;14.9). In patients with baseline CNS disease, median PFS was 7.7 months (95% CI, 4.7&#8722;not estimable), and it was 12 months (95% CI, 8.7&#8722;15.7) in patients with no baseline CNS disease.</li>

11421</ul>

11422</div>

11423</li>

11424</ol>

11425</div>

11426</section>

11427</section>

11428<section id="_485719">

11429<h4 id="_485719_toc">

11430RET inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

11431RET</em>

11432 fusions)</h4>

11433<p id="_485720" tabindex="-1">

11434Somatic gene fusions of <em class="gene-name">

11435RET</em>

11436 occur in 1% to 2% of patients with NSCLC and in patients with thyroid cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_12.45">

1143745</a>

11438] </p>

11439<section id="_485721">

11440<h5 id="_485721_toc">

11441Selpercatinib</h5>

11442<p id="_485722" tabindex="-1">

11443Evidence (selpercatinib):</p>

11444<div class="pdq-content-list">

11445<ol id="_485723">

11446<li>

11447 A phase I/II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03157128">

11448LIBRETTO-001</a>

11449 [NCT03157128]) enrolled patients with <em class="gene-name">

11450RET</em>

11451 fusion&#8722;positive solid tumors, medullary thyroid cancer, and other tumors with RET activation. One hundred forty-four patients had <em class="gene-name">

11452RET</em>

11453 fusion&#8722;positive NSCLC. <em class="gene-name">

11454RET</em>

11455 fusion status was determined by local molecular testing (NGS, FISH, or polymerase chain reaction assay) without central confirmation. The primary end point was objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_12.46">

1145646</a>

11457][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11458Level of evidence C3</a>

11459]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11460<ul id="_485724">

11461<li>

11462 Among the 105 patients who had received previous treatment with platinum chemotherapy, the overall response rate was 64% (95% CI, 54%&#8722;73%), including a 2% complete response rate. The median DOR was 17.5 months (95% CI, 12.0&#8722;not estimable). Median PFS was 16.5 months (95% CI, 13.7&#8722;not estimable). </li>

11463<li>

11464 Among 39 previously untreated patients, the overall response rate was 85% (95% CI, 70%&#8722;94%). Median PFS was not reached at the time of follow-up.</li>

11465<li>

11466 Among 11 patients with measurable CNS disease, the objective intracranial response rate was 91%, including a 27% complete response rate.</li>

11467<li>

11468 Most adverse events were grade 1 to 2. Incidences of grade 3 to 4 events, regardless of attribution, included hypertension (14%), increased alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (13%), increased aspartate aminotransferase (AST) (10%), hyponatremia (6%), and lymphopenia (6%). In the entire study cohort of 531 patients, dose reductions occurred in 30% of patients, while 2% discontinued selpercatinib because of treatment-related adverse events (increased ALT and hypersensitivity).</li>

11469</ul>

11470</div>

11471</li>

11472</ol>

11473</div>

11474</section>

11475<section id="_485887">

11476<h5 id="_485887_toc">

11477Pralsetinib</h5>

11478<p id="_485888" tabindex="-1">

11479Evidence (pralsetinib):</p>

11480<div class="pdq-content-list">

11481<ol id="_485889">

11482<li>

11483 A phase I/II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03037385">

11484ARROW</a>

11485 [NCT03037385]) enrolled patients with <em class="gene-name">

11486RET</em>

11487 fusion&#8722;positive solid tumors. Two hundred thirty-three patients had <em class="gene-name">

11488RET</em>

11489 fusion&#8722;positive NSCLC. <em class="gene-name">

11490RET</em>

11491 fusion status was determined by local molecular testing of tumor or circulating tumor nucleic acid (ctDNA) in blood, without central confirmation. The primary end point was objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_12.47">

1149247</a>

11493][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11494Level of evidence C3</a>

11495]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11496<ul id="_485890">

11497<li>

11498Ninety-two patients who had received platinum-based chemotherapy and 29 patients who were treatment-naive (and not candidates for standard platinum-based treatment) received pralsetinib before the efficacy enrollment cutoff (July 11, 2019). Eighty-seven previously treated patients and 27 treatment-naive patients had centrally adjudicated baseline measurable disease, and thus formed the efficacy cohort. </li>

11499<li>

11500 The overall response rate was 61% (95% CI, 50%&#8211;71%) in the 87 patients who had received platinum-based chemotherapy, including complete responses in 6%. The median duration of response was not reached (15.2 months&#8211;not estimable).</li>

11501<li>

11502 The overall response rate was 70% (95% CI, 50%&#8211;86%) in the 27 treatment-naive patients, including complete responses in 11%. The median duration of response was 9.0 months (6.3&#8211;not estimable).</li>

11503<li>

11504 In the 233-patient safety cohort, 93% had treatment-related adverse events, including 48% with grade 3 or worse events. The most common grade 3 or worse treatment-related adverse events were neutropenia (18%), hypertension (11%), and anemia (10%). Dose reductions occurred in 38% of patients, and 6% discontinued treatment because of adverse events.</li>

11505</ul>

11506</div>

11507</li>

11508</ol>

11509</div>

11510</section>

11511</section>

11512<section id="_485850">

11513<h4 id="_485850_toc">

11514MET inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

11515MET</em>

11516 exon 14 skipping mutations)</h4>

11517<p id="_485851" tabindex="-1">

11518Dysregulation of the <em class="gene-name">

11519MET</em>

11520 proto-oncogene resulting from disruption of distinct splice sites leads to loss of <em class="gene-name">

11521MET</em>

11522 exon 14 and enhanced <em class="gene-name">

11523MET</em>

11524 signaling. These <em class="gene-name">

11525MET</em>

11526 alterations drive tumor proliferation, survival, invasion, and metastasis, and occur in 3% to 4% of patients with NSCLC.[<a href="#cit/section_12.48">

1152748</a>

11528]</p>

11529<section id="_485852">

11530<h5 id="_485852_toc">

11531Tepotinib</h5>

11532<p id="_485853" tabindex="-1">

11533Evidence (tepotinib):</p>

11534<div class="pdq-content-list">

11535<ol id="_485854">

11536<li>

11537An open-label phase II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02864992">

11538VISION</a>

11539 [NCT02864992]) enrolled patients with <em class="gene-name">

11540MET</em>

11541 exon 14 skipping mutations. The trial included 152 patients who received tepotinib (500 mg orally once daily). <em class="gene-name">

11542MET</em>

11543 status was determined centrally either via liquid biopsy (from circulating free DNA obtained from plasma; n = 66) or via tissue biopsy (n = 60). Twenty-seven patients had positive results from both methods. The primary end point was objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_12.49">

1154449</a>

11545][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11546Level of evidence C3</a>

11547] <div class="pdq-content-list">

11548<ul id="_485855">

11549<li>

11550 Among the 99 patients who had been followed for at least 9 months (i.e., the efficacy population), the objective response rate as assessed by independent review was 46% (95% CI, 36%&#8211;57%), with a median DOR of 11.1 months (95% CI, 7.2 &#8211;not estimable). Response rates were similar in the liquid biopsy and tissue biopsy groups. </li>

11551<li>

11552 Responses were similar regardless of prior therapy.</li>

11553<li>

11554Grade 3 or higher adverse events occurred in 28% of patients, including peripheral edema in 7% of patients. Adverse events led to therapy discontinuation in 11% of patients. </li>

11555</ul>

11556</div>

11557</li>

11558</ol>

11559</div>

11560</section>

11561<section id="_485856">

11562<h5 id="_485856_toc">

11563Capmatinib</h5>

11564<p id="_485857" tabindex="-1">

11565Evidence (capmatinib):</p>

11566<div class="pdq-content-list">

11567<ol id="_485858">

11568<li>

11569A phase II study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02414193">

11570GEOMETRY</a>

11571 [NCT02414139]) evaluated capmatinib (400 mg orally twice daily) in patients with <em class="gene-name">

11572MET</em>

11573 exon 14 skipping mutations or <em class="gene-name">

11574MET</em>

11575 amplification. <em class="gene-name">

11576MET</em>

11577 status was determined centrally. A total of 364 patients were enrolled. The primary end point was overall response.[<a href="#cit/section_12.50">

1157850</a>

11579][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11580Level of evidence C3</a>

11581]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11582<ul id="_485859">

11583<li>

11584 Of the 69 patients with <em class="gene-name">

11585MET</em>

11586 exon 14 skipping mutations who had received one or two prior lines of therapy, the overall response rate was 41% (95% CI, 29%&#8211;53%). The median DOR was 9.7 months (95% CI, 5.6&#8211;13.0).</li>

11587<li>

11588 Of the 28 patients with <em class="gene-name">

11589MET</em>

11590 exon 14 skipping mutations who had not received any prior treatment, the overall response rate was 68% (95% CI, 48%&#8211;84%). The median DOR was 12.6 months (95% CI, 5.6&#8211;not estimable).</li>

11591<li>

11592 Response rates in patients with <em class="gene-name">

11593MET</em>

11594 amplification without the exon 14 skipping mutation did not meet the prespecified threshold for clinically relevant activity.</li>

11595<li>

11596 Grade 3 to 4 adverse events occurred in 67% of patients. The most common events, regardless of causality, were peripheral edema, nausea, vomiting, and increased creatinine. Adverse events led to therapy discontinuation in 11% of patients.</li>

11597</ul>

11598</div>

11599</li>

11600</ol>

11601</div>

11602</section>

11603</section>

11604<section id="_485865">

11605<h4 id="_485865_toc">

11606KRAS G12C inhibitors (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

11607KRAS</em>

11608 G12C mutations) </h4>

11609<p id="_485866" tabindex="-1">

11610Activating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

11611KRAS</em>

11612 are found in 25% to 30% of nonsquamous NSCLC, resulting in activation of downstream oncogenic pathways and uncontrolled growth. The G12C single-nucleotide variant, with glycine substituted by cysteine at codon 12, is the most frequent variant in NSCLC, occurring in approximately 13% of lung adenocarcinomas.[<a href="#cit/section_12.51">

1161351</a>

11614] </p>

11615<section id="_485923">

11616<h5 id="_485923_toc">

11617Adagrasib</h5>

11618<p id="_485924" tabindex="-1">

11619Evidence (adagrasib):</p>

11620<div class="pdq-content-list">

11621<ol id="_485925">

11622<li>

11623<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03785249">

11624KRYSTAL-1</a>

11625 (NCT03785249) was a phase I/II multiple expansion cohort clinical trial that investigated adagrasib (600 mg orally twice daily) in patients with advanced solid tumors. A phase II cohort of the trial included patients with NSCLC and <em class="gene-name">

11626KRAS</em>

11627 G12C mutations who were previously treated with platinum-based chemotherapy and anti&#8211;programmed death 1 (PD-1) or anti&#8211;programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) therapy. The cohort enrolled 116 patients; 98.3% had previously received both chemotherapy and immunotherapy. The primary end point was objective response assessed by blinded independent central review.[<a href="#cit/section_12.52">

1162852</a>

11629][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11630Level of evidence C3</a>

11631]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11632<ul id="_485926">

11633<li>

11634 Among 112 evaluable patients, the confirmed objective response rate was 42.9% (95% CI, 33.5%&#8211;52.6%), including one complete response (0.9%). The median DOR was 8.5 months (95% CI, 6.2&#8211;13.8). Disease control occurred in 79.5% of patients (95% CI, 70.8%&#8211;86.5%).</li>

11635<li>

11636 The median PFS was 6.5 months (95% CI, 4.7&#8211;8.4), and the median OS was 12.6 months (95% CI, 9.2&#8211;19.2).</li>

11637<li>

11638 Among 33 patients with previously treated stable CNS metastases, the intracranial confirmed objective response rate was 33.3% (95% CI, 18.0%&#8211;51.8%).</li>

11639<li>

11640 Grade 3 or higher adverse events occurred in 44.8% of patients and included two deaths. The most common adverse events were diarrhea, nausea, fatigue, vomiting, dyspnea, increased creatinine, increased ALT, increased AST, and decreased appetite. Adverse events led to therapy discontinuation in 6.9% of patients.</li>

11641</ul>

11642</div>

11643</li>

11644</ol>

11645</div>

11646<p id="_485927" tabindex="-1">

11647The FDA approved adagrasib for the treatment of adult patients with <em class="gene-name">

11648KRAS</em>

11649 G12C-mutated locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC, as determined by an FDA-approved test, who received at least one prior systemic therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.53">

1165053</a>

11651]</p>

11652</section>

11653<section id="_485867">

11654<h5 id="_485867_toc">

11655Sotorasib</h5>

11656<p id="_485868" tabindex="-1">

11657Evidence (sotorasib):</p>

11658<div class="pdq-content-list">

11659<ol id="_485869">

11660<li>

11661A phase II clinical trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03600883">

11662CodeBreaK 100</a>

11663 [NCT03600883]) evaluated sotorasib (960 mg orally once daily) in patients with <em class="gene-name">

11664KRAS</em>

11665 G12C mutations who were previously treated with standard therapies. A total of 126 patients were enrolled. Of 124 evaluable patients, most (81%) received prior platinum-based therapy and inhibitors of PD-1 or PD-L1. The primary end point was overall response according to independent central review.[<a href="#cit/section_12.51">

1166651</a>

11667][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11668Level of evidence C3</a>

11669]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11670<ul id="_485870">

11671<li>

11672For the 124 evaluable patients, the overall response rate was 37.1% (95% CI, 28.6%&#8211;46.2%), including complete responses in 3.2%. The median DOR was 11.1 months (95% CI, 6.9&#8211;could not be evaluated). Disease control occurred in 80.6% of patients (95% CI, 72.6%&#8211;87.2%).</li>

11673<li>

11674 Median PFS was 6.8 months (95% CI, 5.1&#8211;8.2) and median OS was 12.5 months (95% CI, 10.0&#8211;could not be evaluated).</li>

11675<li>

11676 Grade 3 to 4 adverse events occurred in 20.6% of patients. The most common adverse events that were considered treatment related were diarrhea, nausea, increases in ALT or AST, and fatigue. Adverse events led to therapy discontinuation in 7.1% of patients.</li>

11677</ul>

11678</div>

11679</li>

11680</ol>

11681</div>

11682<p id="_485891" tabindex="-1">

11683The FDA approved sotorasib for the treatment of adult patients with <em class="gene-name">

11684KRAS</em>

11685 G12C-mutated locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC, as determined by an FDA-approved test, who have received at least one prior systemic therapy.</p>

11686</section>

11687</section>

11688<section id="_485952">

11689<h4 id="_485952_toc">

11690HER2-targeted therapy (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

11691HER2</em>

11692-mutations)</h4>

11693<p id="_485953" tabindex="-1">

11694Mutations in the human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (<em class="gene-name">

11695HER2</em>

11696) gene are found in 1% to 4% of patients with nonsquamous NSCLC. These mutations are associated with female sex, Asian ethnicity, never-smoking status, a higher incidence of brain metastasis, moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma histology, and poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_12.54">

1169754</a>

11698,<a href="#cit/section_12.55">

1169955</a>

11700] </p>

11701<section id="_485954">

11702<h5 id="_485954_toc">

11703Trastuzumab deruxtecan </h5>

11704<p id="_485985" tabindex="-1">

11705Trastuzumab deruxtecan is an antibody-drug conjugate consisting of a humanized anti-HER2 monoclonal antibody linked to a topoisomerase I inhibitor.</p>

11706<p id="_485955" tabindex="-1">

11707Evidence (trastuzumab deruxtecan):</p>

11708<div class="pdq-content-list">

11709<ol id="_485956">

11710<li>

11711 <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03505710">

11712DESTINY-Lung01</a>

11713 (NCT03505710) was a multicenter, open-label, two-cohort, phase II clinical trial that investigated trastuzumab deruxtecan at a dose of 6.4 mg/kg of body weight. Enrolled patients had HER2-overexpressing or <em class="gene-name">

11714HER2</em>

11715-mutant unresectable or metastatic nonsquamous NSCLC with disease relapse during standard treatment or with disease refractory to standard treatment. Patients who had previously received a HER2 antibody or an antibody-drug conjugate were ineligible. However, those who had received a HER2 TKI were eligible. The primary end point was objective response as assessed by independent central review. Ninety-one patients with <em class="gene-name">

11716HER2</em>

11717-mutant NSCLC were enrolled; 95% had received previous platinum-based therapy, and 66% had received anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 immunotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.55">

1171855</a>

11719][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11720Level of evidence C3</a>

11721]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11722<ul id="_485957">

11723<li>

11724 All 91 patients were evaluable for response. The confirmed objective response rate was 55% (95% CI, 44%&#8211;65%), including one complete response (1%). The median DOR was 9.3 months (95% CI, 5.7&#8211;14.7). Disease control was observed in 92% of patients (95% CI, 85%&#8211;97%).</li>

11725<li>

11726 The median PFS was 8.2 months (95% CI, 6.0&#8211;11.9), and the median OS was 17.8 months (95% CI, 13.8&#8211;22.1).</li>

11727<li>

11728 Among 33 patients with CNS metastases at baseline, 14 had previously received radiation therapy to the brain, and 19 had not. Of these patients, 8 (57%) and 10 (53%), respectively, had a partial response. The median PFS for patients with CNS metastases at baseline was 7.1 months (95% CI, 5.5&#8211;9.8), and the median OS was 13.8 months (95% CI, 9.8&#8211;20.9).</li>

11729<li>

11730 Grade 3 or higher drug-related adverse events occurred in 46% of patients. The most common adverse events were nausea, fatigue, alopecia, vomiting, neutropenia, anemia, diarrhea, decreased appetite, leukopenia, and constipation. The most common grade 3 or higher drug-related adverse events were neutropenia (19%) and anemia (10%). </li>

11731<li>

11732 Drug-related adverse events led to treatment discontinuation in 23 patients (25%) and included pneumonitis in 12 patients (13%) and interstitial lung disease in 5 patients (5%).</li>

11733<li>

11734 There were two drug-related deaths caused by interstitial lung disease. </li>

11735</ul>

11736</div>

11737</li>

11738</ol>

11739</div>

11740<p id="_485958" tabindex="-1">

11741The FDA granted accelerated approval to trastuzumab deruxtecan for patients with unresectable or metastatic NSCLC whose tumors have activating <em class="gene-name">

11742HER2</em>

11743 mutations, as detected by an FDA-approved test, and who have received a prior systemic therapy. This approval was based on objective response rate and duration of response.</p>

11744</section>

11745</section>

11746<section id="_485176">

11747<h4 id="_485176_toc">

11748Immunotherapy</h4>

11749<p id="_485342" tabindex="-1">

11750Nivolumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody that inhibits the PD-1 coinhibitory immune checkpoint expressed on tumor cells and infiltrating immune cells.[<a href="#cit/section_12.56">

1175156</a>

11752,<a href="#cit/section_12.57">

1175357</a>

11754] Pembrolizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that inhibits the interaction between the PD-1 coinhibitory immune checkpoint expressed on tumor cells and infiltrating immune cells and its ligands, PD-L1 and PD-L2.[<a href="#cit/section_12.58">

1175558</a>

11756] Atezolizumab is a PD-L1&#8211;blocking antibody. </p>

11757<section id="_485177">

11758<h5 id="_485177_toc">

11759Nivolumab</h5>

11760<p id="_485179" tabindex="-1">

11761Evidence (nivolumab):</p>

11762<p id="_485833" tabindex="-1">

11763In two phase III clinical trials, one conducted in patients with advanced platinum-pretreated squamous NSCLC and the other trial conducted in patients with nonsquamous NSCLC, nivolumab demonstrated a significant improvement in OS compared with the previous standard treatment of docetaxel chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.56">

1176456</a>

11765,<a href="#cit/section_12.57">

1176657</a>

11767][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11768Level of evidence A1</a>

11769] In addition, the rates of grade 3 and 4 treatment-related toxicity in both trials were significantly lower with nivolumab than with docetaxel. Of note, all patients enrolled in phase III studies of nivolumab had an ECOG performance status of 0 or 1; patients with autoimmune disease, symptomatic interstitial lung disease, or those receiving systemic immunosuppression were excluded from enrollment.</p>

11770<div class="pdq-content-list">

11771<ol id="_485834">

11772<li>

11773A randomized, open-label, phase III trial randomly assigned 272 patients with advanced squamous cell NSCLC who had received one regimen of platinum-containing chemotherapy to receive either nivolumab (3 mg/kg every 2 weeks) or docetaxel (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

117742</span>

11775 every 3 weeks), administered until disease progression.[<a href="#cit/section_12.56">

1177656</a>

11777] The primary end point of this study was OS.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11778<ul id="_485835">

11779<li>

11780Nivolumab demonstrated a significant improvement in median OS compared with docetaxel (9.2 months vs. 6 months; <em>

11781P</em>

11782 &lt; .001). In addition, the response rate (20% vs. 9%; <em>

11783P</em>

11784 = .008) and median PFS (3.5 months vs. 2.8 months; <em>

11785P</em>

11786 &lt; .001) favored nivolumab. </li>

11787<li>

11788Rates of treatment-related toxicity were significantly lower with nivolumab than with docetaxel (all grades, 58% for nivolumab vs. 86% for docetaxel; grades 3&#8211;4, 7% for nivolumab vs. 55% for docetaxel).</li>

11789</ul>

11790</div>

11791</li>

11792<li>

11793A randomized, open-label, phase III trial included 582 patients with advanced nonsquamous NSCLC who had received one regimen of platinum-containing chemotherapy. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either nivolumab (3 mg/kg every 2 weeks) or docetaxel (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

117942</span>

11795 every 3 weeks), administered until disease progression.[<a href="#cit/section_12.57">

1179657</a>

11797] Previous maintenance chemotherapy after first-line platinum-doublet was allowed; patients with <em class="gene-name">

11798EGFR</em>

11799 mutations or <em class="gene-name">

11800ALK</em>

11801 translocations were allowed to have received an additional regimen of therapy with a TKI. The primary end point of this study was OS. <div class="pdq-content-list">

11802<ul id="_485836">

11803<li>

11804Patients who received nivolumab had a significant improvement in median OS compared with patients who received docetaxel (12.2 months vs. 9.4 months; HR, 0.73; 96% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.89; <em>

11805P</em>

11806 = .002). In this study, the response rate (19% vs. 12%; <em>

11807P</em>

11808 = .02) but not median PFS (2.3 months for nivolumab vs. 4.2 months for docetaxel) favored nivolumab. The median DOR in patients was 17.2 months for nivolumab and 5.6 months for docetaxel. </li>

11809<li>

11810Rates of treatment-related toxicity were significantly lower with nivolumab than with docetaxel (all grades, 69% for nivolumab vs. 88% for docetaxel; grades 3&#8211;4, 10% for nivolumab vs. 54% for docetaxel).</li>

11811</ul>

11812</div>

11813</li>

11814</ol>

11815</div>

11816<p id="_485837" tabindex="-1">

11817Both of these trials demonstrated long-term clinical benefit at the 2-year outcomes. The OS rates for nivolumab at 2 years compared with docetaxel in squamous NSCLC were 23% (95% CI, 16%&#8211;30%) versus 8% (95% CI, 4%&#8211;13%), and OS rates in nonsquamous NSCLC were 29% (95% CI, 24%&#8211;34%) versus 16% (95% CI, 12%&#8211;20%).[<a href="#cit/section_12.59">

1181859</a>

11819] Ongoing responses at 2 years were observed in 10 (37%) confirmed responders with squamous NSCLC and 19 (34%) of 56 responders with nonsquamous NSCLC. No patient treated with docetaxel in either study had an ongoing response.</p>

11820<p id="_485184" tabindex="-1">

11821Nivolumab is now considered a standard second-line therapy for patients with metastatic NSCLC with progression on or after first-line platinum-based chemotherapy and is associated with improved survival and lower rates of toxicity than docetaxel. However, clinical trials of nivolumab to date have not enrolled patients with a history of autoimmune disease, interstitial lung disease, or an ECOG performance status higher than 1. Patients with active autoimmune conditions cannot be treated with nivolumab. Closely monitoring all patients for autoimmune toxicities from treatment is required. Specific algorithms for the management of autoimmune toxicity are included in the FDA label for <a href="http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2014/125554lbl.pdf" title="http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2014/125554lbl.pdf">

11822nivolumab</a>

11823.</p>

11824</section>

11825<section id="_485185">

11826<h5 id="_485185_toc">

11827Pembrolizumab</h5>

11828<p id="_485187" tabindex="-1">

11829Evidence (pembrolizumab):</p>

11830<div class="pdq-content-list">

11831<ol id="_485210">

11832<li>

11833In a phase I study with multiple expansion cohorts, pembrolizumab demonstrated significant activity with respect to response rate and DOR.[<a href="#cit/section_12.58">

1183458</a>

11835][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11836Level of evidence C3</a>

11837]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11838<ul id="_485211">

11839<li>

11840In the study, 495 patients received either pembrolizumab 2 mg/kg every 3 weeks, 10 mg/kg every 3 weeks, or 10 mg/kg every 2 weeks. No significant differences were seen among the different treatment schedules. Key exclusion criteria were autoimmune disease, history of pneumonitis, requirement for systemic immunosuppressive therapy, and a performance status higher than 1. The objective response rate was 19.4% (95% CI, 16.0%&#8211;23.2%), which included a response rate of 18.0% (95% CI, 14.4%&#8211;22.2%) in 394 previously treated patients and 24.8% (95% CI, 16.7%&#8211;34.3%) in 101 previously untreated patients. Median PFS was 3.7 months (95% CI, 2.9&#8211;4.1) for all patients, 3.0 months (95% CI, 2.2&#8211;4.0) for previously treated patients, and 6.0 months (95% CI, 4.1&#8211;8.6) for previously untreated patients. The median DOR was 12.5 months (range, 1.0&#8211;23.3 months) in all patients.</li>

11841<li>

11842The study evaluated the efficacy of pembrolizumab in patients with high levels of PD-L1, as assessed by the anti-PD-L1 antibody clone 22C3. Using the cutoff of membranous staining in at least 50% of tumor cells in a validation group of 73 patients, the response rate was 45.2% (95% CI, 33.5%&#8211;57.3%), and the median PFS in this group was 6.3 months (95% CI, 2.9&#8211;12.5). Median OS was not reached at the time of publication. </li>

11843<li>

11844 The estimated prevalence of PD-L1 tumor staining from 1,143 screened patients, of whom 824 had evaluable samples, is as follows: 23.2% had 50% or more tumor cells with staining; 37.6% had between 1% and 49% tumor cells with staining; and 39.2% had less than 1% of tumor cells with staining.</li>

11845<li>

11846 The most common adverse events were fatigue, pruritus, and decreased appetite. Grade 3 or higher adverse events were reported in 9.5% of patients. Inflammatory and immune-mediated adverse events that occurred in more than 2% of patients were infusion-related reactions (3.0%), hypothyroidism (6.9%), and pneumonitis (3.6%).</li>

11847</ul>

11848</div>

11849</li>

11850<li>

11851In a phase II/III randomized clinical trial, patients with previously treated NSCLC with PD-L1 expression on at least 1% of tumor cells were randomly assigned (1:1:1) to receive pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg), pembrolizumab (10 mg/kg), or docetaxel (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

118522</span>

11853) every 3 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_12.60">

1185460</a>

11855][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11856Level of evidence A1</a>

11857] The primary end points were OS and PFS in the total population and in patients with PD-L1 expression on at least 50% of tumor cells. This study enrolled 1,034 patients; 345 of them were allocated to pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg); 346 were allocated to pembrolizumab (10 mg/kg); and 343 were allocated to docetaxel. <div class="pdq-content-list">

11858<ul id="_485212">

11859<li>

11860 In the total population, median OS was 10.4 months with pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg), 12.7 months with pembrolizumab (10 mg/kg), and 8.5 months with docetaxel. OS was significantly longer for pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg) versus docetaxel (HR 0.71; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;0.88; <em>

11861P</em>

11862 = .0008) and for pembrolizumab (10 mg/kg) versus docetaxel (HR, 0.61; CI, 0.49&#8211;0.75; <em>

11863P</em>

11864 &lt; .0001). </li>

11865<li>

11866In the total population, PFS was not prolonged in the pembrolizumab groups compared with the docetaxel group. </li>

11867<li>

11868Among patients with at least 50% of tumor cells expressing PD-L1, OS was significantly longer with pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg) than with docetaxel (median, 14.9 months vs. 8.2 months; HR, 0.54; 95% CI, 0.38&#8211;0.77; <em>

11869P</em>

11870 = .0002) and with pembrolizumab (10 mg/kg) than with docetaxel (median, 17.3 months vs. 8.2 months; HR, 0.50; CI, 0.36&#8211;0.70; <em>

11871P </em>

11872&lt; .0001). </li>

11873<li>

11874In the group of patients with at least 50% of tumor cells expressing PD-L1, PFS was significantly longer with pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg) than with docetaxel (median, 5.0 months vs. 4.1 months; HR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.44&#8211;0.78; <em>

11875P</em>

11876 = .0001) and with pembrolizumab (10 mg/kg) than with docetaxel (median, 5.2 months vs. 4.1 months; HR, 0.59; CI, 0.45&#8211;0.78; <em>

11877P</em>

11878 &lt; .0001).</li>

11879<li>

11880Grade 3 to 5 treatment-related adverse events were less common with pembrolizumab than with docetaxel (43 [13%] of 339 patients given pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg), 55 [16%] of 343 patients given pembrolizumab (10 mg/kg), and 109 [35%] of 309 patients given docetaxel).</li>

11881</ul>

11882</div>

11883</li>

11884</ol>

11885</div>

11886<p id="_485213" tabindex="-1">

11887The FDA granted accelerated approval to pembrolizumab as a second-line therapy for patients with NSCLC whose tumors express PD-L1 (&gt;50% staining as determined by an FDA-approved test) with progression on or after first-line chemotherapy. Patients with <em class="gene-name">

11888EGFR</em>

11889 or <em class="gene-name">

11890ALK</em>

11891 genomic tumor aberrations should have disease progression on FDA-approved therapies before receiving pembrolizumab (see the FDA label for <a href="http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2014/125514lbl.pdf" title="http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2014/125514lbl.pdf">

11892pembrolizumab</a>

11893).</p>

11894</section>

11895<section id="_485214">

11896<h5 id="_485214_toc">

11897Atezolizumab</h5>

11898<p id="_485216" tabindex="-1">

11899Evidence (atezolizumab):</p>

11900<div class="pdq-content-list">

11901<ol id="_485217">

11902<li>

11903Two international, randomized, open-label clinical trials (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02008227">

11904OAK</a>

11905 [NCT02008227] and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01903993">

11906POPLAR</a>

11907 [NCT01903993]) demonstrated efficacy and safety in a total of 1,137 patients with NSCLC who previously received platinum chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.61">

1190861</a>

11909,<a href="#cit/section_12.62">

1191062</a>

11911][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11912Level of evidence A1</a>

11913] Compared with docetaxel, treatment with atezolizumab in the intended patient population resulted in improved OS rates of 4.2 months in the OAK study and 2.9 months in the POPLAR study.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11914<ul id="_485218">

11915<li>

11916In the OAK trial, the median OS was 13.8 months in the atezolizumab arm (95% CI, 11.8&#8211;15.7) compared with 9.6 months in the docetaxel arm (95% CI, 8.6&#8211;11.2) (HR, 0.74; 95% CI, 0.63&#8211;0.87; <em>

11917P</em>

11918 = .0004). </li>

11919<li>

11920The median OS in the POPLAR trial was 12.6 months in the atezolizumab arm (95% CI, 9.7&#8211;16.0) and 9.7 months in the docetaxel arm (95% CI, 8.6&#8211;12.0) (HR, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.52&#8211;0.92). </li>

11921<li>

11922Although the magnitude of improvement correlated with PD-L1 immunohistochemistry expression on tumor cells and tumor-infiltrating immune cells, survival benefit with atezolizumab was seen in patients with tumors with and without PD-L1 expression.</li>

11923<li>

11924In the POPLAR trial, the most common (&#8805;20%) adverse reactions were in patients treated with atezolizumab and included fatigue, decreased appetite, dyspnea, cough, nausea, musculoskeletal pain, and constipation. </li>

11925<li>

11926The most common (&#8805;2%) grade 3 to 4 adverse events in patients treated with atezolizumab were dyspnea, pneumonia, hypoxia, hyponatremia, fatigue, anemia, musculoskeletal pain, AST increase, alanine aminotransferase increase, dysphagia, and arthralgia. </li>

11927<li>

11928Clinically significant immune-related adverse events for patients who received atezolizumab included pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis, and thyroid disease.</li>

11929</ul>

11930</div>

11931</li>

11932</ol>

11933</div>

11934</section>

11935</section>

11936<section id="_485692">

11937<h4 id="_485692_toc">

11938Everolimus</h4>

11939<p id="_485693" tabindex="-1">

11940Everolimus is used for patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional, neuroendocrine tumors.</p>

11941<p id="_485694" tabindex="-1">

11942Everolimus, an oral mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor, is clinically active against advanced pancreatic and nonpancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_12.63">

1194363</a>

11944] Based on the results of the RADIANT-4 clinical trial,[<a href="#cit/section_12.63">

1194563</a>

11946] the FDA approved everolimus for the treatment of adult patients with unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic, progressive, well-differentiated (low or intermediate grade), nonfunctional neuroendocrine tumors of lung or gastrointestinal origin.</p>

11947<p id="_485695" tabindex="-1">

11948Evidence (everolimus):</p>

11949<div class="pdq-content-list">

11950<ol id="_485696">

11951<li>

11952A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01524783">

11953RADIANT-4</a>

11954 [NCT01524783]) evaluated everolimus in patients older than 18 years with advanced, progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional neuroendocrine tumors of lung or gastrointestinal origin.[<a href="#cit/section_12.63">

1195563</a>

11956] Eligible patients were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive everolimus 10 mg daily orally or placebo, both with best supportive care. A total of 302 patients were enrolled (205 in the everolimus arm and 97 in the placebo arm), including 90 patients with neuroendocrine tumors of lung origin (63 in the everolimus arm and 27 in the placebo arm). The primary end point was PFS assessed by central radiology review in the intention-to-treat population. <div class="pdq-content-list">

11957<ul id="_485697">

11958<li>

11959Median PFS was 11.0 months in the everolimus arm and 3.9 months in the placebo group (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.35&#8722;0.67; <em>

11960P</em>

11961 &lt; .00001).[<a href="#cit/section_12.63">

1196263</a>

11963][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11964Level of evidence B1</a>

11965]</li>

11966<li>

11967 In a post hoc analysis of the lung subgroup, median PFS by central review was 9.2 months in the everolimus arm and 3.6 months in the placebo arm (HR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.28&#8722;0.88).[<a href="#cit/section_12.63">

1196863</a>

11969]</li>

11970<li>

11971The objective response rate was 2% in patients who received everolimus and 1% in patients who received placebo. Disease stabilization was observed in 81% of patients in the everolimus arm and 64% of patients in the placebo arm.</li>

11972<li>

11973The median duration of treatment was longer in the patients who received everolimus compared with those who received placebo (40.4 weeks vs. 19.6 weeks). </li>

11974<li>

11975 A planned interim analysis of OS showed a 36% reduction in the estimated risk of death with everolimus relative to placebo (HR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.40&#8722;1.05). These results were not statistically significant. </li>

11976<li>

11977The most common treatment-related adverse events were stomatitis, diarrhea, fatigue, infections, rash, and peripheral edema. The most common drug-related grade 3 or 4 adverse events were stomatitis, diarrhea, infections, anemia, and fatigue. Grade 3 or 4 adverse events resulted in treatment discontinuation in 12% of patients in the everolimus group and 3% of patients in the placebo group. </li>

11978</ul>

11979</div>

11980</li>

11981</ol>

11982</div>

11983</section>

11984</section>

11985<section id="_TrialSearch_48457_sid_12">

11986<h3 id="_TrialSearch_48457_sid_12_toc">

11987Current Clinical Trials</h3>

11988<p id="_TrialSearch_48457_22" tabindex="-1">

11989Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

11990advanced clinical trial search</a>

11991 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

11992General information</a>

11993 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

11994</section>

12049Thatcher N, Chang A, Parikh P, et al.: Gefitinib plus best supportive care in previously treated patients with refractory advanced non-small-cell lung cancer: results from a randomised, placebo-controlled, multicentre study (Iressa Survival Evaluation in Lung Cancer). Lancet 366 (9496): 1527-37, 2005 Oct 29-Nov 4.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16257339&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16257339&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12050[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12051</li>

12052<li id="section_12.15">

12053Kim ES, Hirsh V, Mok T, et al.: Gefitinib versus docetaxel in previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (INTEREST): a randomised phase III trial. Lancet 372 (9652): 1809-18, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19027483&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19027483&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12054[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12055</li>

12212<li id="section_12.55">

N Engl J Med 386 (3): 241-251, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34534430&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34534430&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12214[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12215</li>

12216<li id="section_12.56">

12217Brahmer J, Reckamp KL, Baas P, et al.: Nivolumab versus Docetaxel in Advanced Squamous-Cell Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer. N Engl J Med 373 (2): 123-35, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26028407&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26028407&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12218[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12219</li>

12220<li id="section_12.57">

12221Borghaei H, Paz-Ares L, Horn L, et al.: Nivolumab versus Docetaxel in Advanced Nonsquamous Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer. N Engl J Med 373 (17): 1627-39, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26412456&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26412456&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12222[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12223</li>

12224<li id="section_12.58">

12225Garon EB, Rizvi NA, Hui R, et al.: Pembrolizumab for the treatment of non-small-cell lung cancer. N Engl J Med 372 (21): 2018-28, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25891174&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25891174&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12226[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12227</li>

12228<li id="section_12.59">

12229Horn L, Spigel DR, Vokes EE, et al.: Nivolumab Versus Docetaxel in Previously Treated Patients With Advanced Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer: Two-Year Outcomes From Two Randomized, Open-Label, Phase III Trials (CheckMate 017 and CheckMate 057). J Clin Oncol 35 (35): 3924-3933, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29023213&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29023213&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12230[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12231</li>

12232<li id="section_12.60">

12233Herbst RS, Baas P, Kim DW, et al.: Pembrolizumab versus docetaxel for previously treated, PD-L1-positive, advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (KEYNOTE-010): a randomised controlled trial. Lancet 387 (10027): 1540-50, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26712084&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26712084&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12234[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12235</li>

12236<li id="section_12.61">

12237Rittmeyer A, Barlesi F, Waterkamp D, et al.: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel in patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (OAK): a phase 3, open-label, multicentre randomised controlled trial. Lancet 389 (10066): 255-265, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27979383&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27979383&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12238[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12239</li>

12240<li id="section_12.62">

12241Fehrenbacher L, Spira A, Ballinger M, et al.: Atezolizumab versus docetaxel for patients with previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer (POPLAR): a multicentre, open-label, phase 2 randomised controlled trial. Lancet 387 (10030): 1837-46, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26970723&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26970723&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12242[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12243</li>

12244<li id="section_12.63">

12245Yao JC, Fazio N, Singh S, et al.: Everolimus for the treatment of advanced, non-functional neuroendocrine tumours of the lung or gastrointestinal tract (RADIANT-4): a randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 3 study. Lancet 387 (10022): 968-977, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26703889&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26703889&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12246[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12247</li>

12248</ol>

12249</div>

12250

12251 </section>

12252

12253

12254

12255 <section id="_48494">

12256

12257 <h2>

12258Changes to This Summary (02/17/2023)</h2>

12259

12260 <div id="_section_48494" class="pdq-sections">

12261<p id="_48495" tabindex="-1">

12262The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as new information becomes available. This section describes the latest changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

12263<p id="_485978" tabindex="-1">

12264<strong>

12265<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_4">

12266General Information About Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)</a>

12267</strong>

12268</p>

12269<p id="_485979" tabindex="-1">

12270Updated <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_27">

12271statistics</a>

12272 with estimated new cases and deaths for 2023 (cited American Cancer Society as reference 1).</p>

12273<p id="_485980" tabindex="-1">

12274Updated <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_29">

12275statistics</a>

12276 with new 5-year relative survival rates for 2012 to 2018.</p>

12277<p id="_485986" tabindex="-1">

12278<strong>

12279<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_48552">

12280Treatment of Stages IIA and IIB NSCLC</a>

12281</strong>

12282</p>

12283<p id="_485987" tabindex="-1">

12284Added <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485939">

12285Neoadjuvant immunotherapy with chemotherapy</a>

12286 as a new subsection.</p>

12287<p id="_485988" tabindex="-1">

12288<strong>

12289<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_637">

12290Treatment of Stage IIIA NSCLC</a>

12291</strong>

12292</p>

12293<p id="_485989" tabindex="-1">

12294Added <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485945">

12295Neoadjuvant immunotherapy with chemotherapy</a>

12296 as a new subsection.</p>

12297<p id="_485981" tabindex="-1">

12298<strong>

12299<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_48406">

12300Treatment of Newly Diagnosed Stage IV, Relapsed, and Recurrent NSCLC</a>

12301</strong>

12302</p>

12303<p id="_485982" tabindex="-1">

12304Added <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485959">

12305Cemiplimab-rwlc plus chemotherapy</a>

12306 as a new subsection.</p>

12307<p id="_485983" tabindex="-1">

12308Added <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485964">

12309Cemiplimab-rwlc alone</a>

12310 as a new subsection.</p>

12311<p id="_485984" tabindex="-1">

12312Added <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485969">

12313Tremelimumab</a>

12314 as a new subsection.</p>

12315<p id="_485990" tabindex="-1">

12316<strong>

12317<a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_48457">

12318Treatment of Progressive Stage IV, Relapsed, and Recurrent NSCLC</a>

12319</strong>

12320</p>

12321<p id="_485991" tabindex="-1">

12322Added <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_485952">

12323HER2-targeted therapy (for patients with <em class="gene-name">

12324HER2</em>

12325-mutations)</a>

12326 as a new subsection.</p>

12327<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

12328This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment">

12329PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board</a>

12330, which is

12331editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

12332the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

12333information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

12334maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

12335About This PDQ Summary</a>

12336 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

12337PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

12338 pages.

12339</p>

12340</div>

12341

12342 </section>

12343

12344

12345

12346 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

12347

12348 <h2>

12349About This PDQ Summary</h2>

12350

12351 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

12352<section id="_AboutThis_2">

12353<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

12354Purpose of This Summary</h3>

12355<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

12356This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

12357</section>

12358<section id="_AboutThis_4">

12359<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

12360Reviewers and Updates</h3>

12361<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

12362This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment">

12363PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board</a>

12364, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

12365<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

12366 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

12367<div class="pdq-content-list">

12368<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

12369<li>

12370be discussed at a meeting,</li>

12371<li>

12372be cited with text, or</li>

12373<li>

12374replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

12375</ul>

12376</div>

12377<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

12378Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

12379<p id="" tabindex="-1">

12380The lead reviewers for Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment are:</p>

12381<div class="pdq-content-list">

12382<ul id="">

12383<li>

12384Janet Dancey, MD, FRCPC (Ontario Institute for Cancer Research &amp; NCIC Clinical Trials Group)</li>

12385<li>

12386Meredith McAdams, MD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

12387<li>

12388Monaliben Patel, MD (Advocate Christ Medical Center)</li>

12389<li>

12390Arun Rajan, MD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

12391<li>

12392Eva Szabo, MD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

12393</ul>

12394</div>

12395<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

12396Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

12397Email Us</a>

12398. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

12399</section>

12400<section id="_AboutThis_10">

12401<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

12402Levels of Evidence</h3>

12403<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

12404Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

12405formal evidence ranking system</a>

12406 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

12407</section>

12408<section id="_AboutThis_12">

12409<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

12410Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

12411<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

12412PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

12413<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

12414The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

12415<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

12416PDQ&#174; Adult Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq">

12417https://www.cancer.gov/types/lung/hp/non-small-cell-lung-treatment-pdq</a>

12418. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389304]</p>

12419<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

12420Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

12421Visuals Online</a>

12422, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

12423

12424</p>

12425</section>

12426<section id="_AboutThis_17">

12427<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

12428Disclaimer</h3>

12429<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

12430Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

12431Managing Cancer Care</a>

12432 page.</p>

12433</section>

12434<section id="_AboutThis_20">

12435<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

12436Contact Us</h3>

12437<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

12438More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

12439Contact Us for Help</a>

12440 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

12441Email Us</a>

12442.</p>

12443</section>

12444</div>

12704 <a href="/research/participate/clinical-trials-search"

12706Find a Clinical Trial</a

12707 >

12708

12709 </li>

12710

12711 </ul>

12712

12713 </section>

12714

12715 </div>
